If I miss anything you're wondering about post in the comments and I'll try to answer back quickly.This is my second Chromebook. The first is an aging, but still very speedy Acer C720, so don't worry Chromebooks hold up pretty well in the speed department.  My suggestion, it's worth it for the extra RAM to keep it useful longer.  Anyway, this one is cheaper and smaller than the C720.  The design is much less clunky and the sleek blue is smooth and attractive.  It's also got an astounding 1.5x the battery life!  Assuming you aren't doing a lot of video watching and are just using it for web surfing mostly, you should pass 10 hours on a charge.  I used it all week in the evenings on its first charge.  The keyboard is better in my opinion and feels less spongy and more like a regular PC/Mac/Laptop one.  It'll take some getting used to the keys if you haven't used a Chromebook before, like a search button in place of the caps lock key, but it works.  Touchpad is near perfect and you can easily scroll up and down using two fingers or move the mouse pointer using a single digit.The other nice thing with the Chromebook is the solid state hard drive.  Short version, no moving parts so it boots up in seconds and can't be hurt by jostling or bumping it.  The downside is it's tiny and you only have about 9.5 GB free after space taken by the OS.  I found it easy to set up with a google voice phone number and do video chat with my parents for free.  The camera isn't super powerful, but the picture was good enough for that and it has a little light built in that helps.  There's no need for an antivirus so you literally just turn it on and go.  The OS will update itself without telling you, which is not unique to this one, but may make your performance really bad when it does.  You can find out more details about your system by entering the following command in the web browser URL bar (or downloading an app from the Chromestore).  chrome://system/I do have a few concerns about the design choices.  It may have been done to keep size down, but I am not a fan of the micro HDMI connector.  It requires having either an adapter or a less common cable to show your video on the TV when visiting relatives.  It's purely personal preference, but I would also rather have seen a SD card slot than a micro SD, just so I could have the option of using a microSD with an adapter or use old SD cards I had around.  The device lacks USB 3.0 slots which is not critical since the hard drive is so small, but it definitely drags down file transfers when I copy files I downloaded while at the Starbucks.  Even having just one of them as a 3.0 would have been nice.  The real annoyance is that they are both next to each other and on the same side.  The C720 put them on opposite sides so if you have a fat USB drive it won't block the other one.  I had to buy a different USB drive to fit my mouse in at the same time.  Also, be aware because the thing is so slim, you also have a practical vertical limitation to how fat a connector is, so one of those novelty ones that looks like Bugs Bunny is not going to fit comfortably.  Can hardly blame it for that though.  No problems running video or music off USB flash drives.  I've included formats it can read at the bottom of my review.Last, to expand on what I said at the start, you can't run Windows programs, but you can go to the Chromestore and get many that are compatible for free to do document editing.  You can even use it to control your PC remotely, though after a recent update Chrome Remote Desktop seems to be slightly unreliable for connections at the moment.  To sum it all up, if you want one of these as your main PC, you'll have some limits.  I basically needed a really nice browser I could carry around without worrying about viruses, updates, or much of anything and I find it way more pleasant than trying to squint at a website on a phone.  Been using it about a week now. Will update if anything changes.--Supported Formats (From Google's Chromebook Help Page)--Microsoft Office files: .doc, .docx, .xls, .xlsx, .ppt (read-only), .pptx (read-only).Media: .3gp, .avi, .mov, .mp4, .m4v, .m4a, .mp3, .mkv, .ogv, .ogm, .ogg, .oga, .webm, .wavImages: .bmp, .gif, .jpg, .jpeg, .png, .webpCompressed files: .zip, .rarOther: .txt, .pdf (read-only)--Update--One last thing, if your a little technical and really desperately need Windows software, Google a Linux distribution called Crouton.  I've not tried it on this one, but the C720 could easily dual boot into Linux with it and I was able to use WINE to run a few Windows programs.  Gave up when it wouldn't work with a 3rd party downloader I needed that was Windows only, but possibly an option and Linux is fun to play around with.  As far as I'm aware, no Chromebook can use an external DVD drive for watching DVD movies, but Crouton might support your drive.  I don't have one to test the theory though.--Update 5/26/15--Sorry, I just realized the correct term for the connector is "micro HDMI" not "mini HDMI".  I've updated in the review above to reflect the correct term.

My wife's been complaining about my breath the past few months.  I brush regularly, tongue scrape, etc. and nothing seemed to help.  So got a chance to try these through Vine and see if they'd fix things.  After completing 7 of the 8 day supply, I see some improvement.  The taste isn't bad and they're chewable so no issues with swallowing a pill.I had noticed myself on a few occasions I've had truly foul/sulfur smelling morning breath. Since starting these, I haven't experienced that so they definitely do seem to be doing something.  This week she has complained about my breath exactly once.  In that case, I'd just had one of the tablets and she said my mouth smelled mediciny.  Otherwise, hasn't commented.  This was my primary reason for trying these so I like that.That said, I haven't noticed the other benefits.  My gums have been bothering me in one place and I got a throat ache after starting to take them, but I have no idea if that's from it or in spite of it.  They're also pretty pricy per pill. The package and Amazon listing aren't clear how long they're supposed to help after you've completed a box, but I can't imagine it'll be effective weeks or months later.  Suppose I'll find out soon since tomorrow is my last pill, but if I have to keep taking them daily for the effects then I'll have to find something else since my budget can't take what these are priced at.

Our dogs tend to get fleas from somewhere.  We think it's one of the neighbor dogs they walk near when we're out on nightly walks, but it could probably be from other sources too.  In any case, we got tired of watching them suffer so tried this.The best option we've found were some expensive pills from the vet that made the fleas very unhappy in a matter of minutes.  These tubes, well they don't work close to as fast and don't work quite as well, but we've never found the pills other than at the vet so this seems to be the best option.  The applicators are what you'd expect and easy enough to use.  It took a while, but after a week or so they'd stopped scratching so it seems to have worked pretty well.The smell on these isn't great, so be ready for some odor.  The other problem is that the dogs really, really didn't like the sensation of the stuff on their back.  We have two, so we used one dosage for each.  We'll have to buy a second package and do the same thing, for three total doses for each.  Make sure if you have a couple dogs, even if you're only dosing one at a time, that you separate them so they don't try to lick it off each other before it drys.

First off, we have liked (not loved) the regular Avery ones we've had in the past.  They're good for volunteer to semi-professional applications, though don't take the place of the expensive professionally made cards for looking businesslike.  Those have ridges around them.  These, well these have their own problems.The good, these are a very clever way to make magnetic cards.  If you're a plumber, electrician, or someone that may come up from time to time for when something breaks, magnetic cards are awesome since the customer can put them on their refrigerator and when they think of repairs, there you are.  I'd think that more frequent ones, they have you in their phone so it may not be as valuable, but the 1 offs are important.  Getting those made can be really pricy, so these make a reasonable alternative.  You get very few in the package, only 3 sheets, but they were fairly impressive as far as holding to metal.  They were thin, but we personally didn't see any pulling up at the edges.  Can't say if they might in time, but been a few days and fine so far.Word 2013 had the templates for these so that was convenient.  We had to go to Mailings tab, then Labels, then options, find it, and then go from there.  LibreOffice didn't have templates for it, but that's freeware and I can't count these off for that.  We ran them through one at a time and had no problems with paper jams.  The paper itself was pretty standard fare and showed off the ink jet printing well enough.  They don't look professionally done exactly, but serviceable for a small business.Onto the bad, well the cards just didn't print out that well.  We used the labels, but everything migrated up to the top of the sheet a little bit, so some text was 1 cm from the top, some was 0.5 cm, and some were even slightly sideways.  It also destroyed the first card on every sheet with some kind of ink smear.  So out of all the cards, maybe 60-70% of them were viable.  Those are NOT GOOD ratios considering cost per card.  It may be the magnets.  It may be the thickness.  It may be a combination, but it was very disappointing.So final verdict, would I get these again?  Sadly, the answer is no.  I'm giving it an average rating, because the ones that worked were really quite decent for what they are.  It's possible our printer is an anomaly and they'll work out better in another one.  However at the price per card, I just can't bring my self to to recommend these given the failure rates I saw.  So in short, good if they play nice in your printer and garbage if they don't.

If you've been sitting back from the whole SSD thing because it's the purview of the geek who wants to squeeze out every second of their computer down to the minimum and is willing to pay astronomical prices just to save 3 seconds, then be aware that things are changing.  SSDs are still massively more expensive than the old traditional hard drives, but the price per Gigabyte is dropping fast.  They are fast too.  Under the best circumstances real world you might get close to 500 MB in sequential reads and maybe 450-480 MB range for writes.  Random reads/writes up to 100k / 87k IOPS.  The drive isn't the very fastest out there, but overall it performs well without breaking the bank.---The Drive---This is a 2.5" drive.  Be sure you know that when buying.  It WILL NOT fit into most desktop systems, without an adapter.  For whatever reason, all theses SSDs I've seen seem to be coming out in the smaller size.  Right now I'm trying it in my laptop, which is what it's designed for, but I'm ordering a Silverstone Tek adapter in case I later want to try this in my Dell XPS 8700 later, because that cheap adapter is supposed to fit in that system.  The power/data connectors are identical for 2.5 or 3.5 SATA so no compatibility concerns there.Laptop installation was painless and took maybe 5 minutes.  The drive itself is tiny, EXTREMELY light weight, and feels like it's aluminum construction which should be good for heat dissipation.  It just feels extremely fragile, so it seems like it'd dent very easily, but then if you've you've dropped a hard drive you've got bigger problems.  The drive comes with a download key for Acronis True Image HD 2014 (more on that below) to copy your old drive to your new one.  This is the first time I've used a Crucial, so I can't say whether I have personal experience it will last a long time, but reviews I've seen generally rate them well.  Intel supposedly makes the best ones, but are also quite a bit more expensive.  I found the read/write speed to be very pleasant and had no concerns.  I think it also runs a bit cooler than my old laptop drive.  I'm also not as nervous if I have to pull out the laptop on the road because hitting a bump won't do the drive any harm.The only things I'm finding cumbersome about this drive is the lack of size.  I got the 250GB (about 231 GB formatted) model and it's pretty tight for my stuff.  The only reason I can fit most on is that I can't play a lot of games on it, so they aren't eating up tons of space.  It's why I'm considering it in my desktop.  What you can do, assuming you get an adapter so it'll fit and your system can accommodate two hard drives, is install one of these as your windows drive and use a traditional hard drive for your music, movies, etc.  Games you may still want on the SSD for performance, but for older/lower end ones you might compromise.  That'll get you the faster boot, avoid defragmenting, and let you get some of the benefits without spending an arm and a leg.I do need to warn you, if you use this to attempt to boost an old laptop running XP or Vista, you'll not be getting the best operation.  The versions Windows 7 and onward have started supporting the Trim functionality, which helps the SSD deal with files the operating system deletes.  I won't bore you with the long version, you can look it up if interested, but the short version takeaway is that you'll have a shorter lifespan under anything earlier than Windows 7.---What is a SSD---Just a quick explanation what a SSD is if you're not familiar.  The traditional hard drive you have is a mechanical device with multiple platters and little heads that read from them.  If you're over a certain age, then think of it as a stack of record players.  If you're a young pup, then look up how record players used to work with the spinning disc and the needle.  The SSD replace those moving parts with memory cells, so you can think of them more as a big USB flash drive in your machine, though they're designed not to wear out as quickly as USB drives do from read/write cycles.So why choose a SSD?  The primary reason is that they are faster, much faster.  I hadn't realized how much faster until I got a Chromebook with one.  My Windows 8 boot is quite a bit faster than the old drive was.  A secondary reason to pick these types are lack of moving parts.  You can still get one that arrives dead or dies quickly, same as with traditional ones, but bouncing/jarring them has no effect and they generate less heat.  In theory, they should last longer than a mechanical hard drive, though they're still too new to have a lot of real world data.  You also don't need to defragment them, the way they work is different so it won't slow them down, in fact doing so will shorten its life.  So minor time saved there as well.  One word of warning, at boot especially they may use a tad more energy than mechanical drives so if you're extremely tight on power it's an outside possibility that could be an issue.---Acronis True Image HD 2014---If you've never used Acronis, it's a disk imaging application at heart.  What this means is it'll take a picture of your drive, store it on another partition/hard drive/etc. and then let you restore that if something goes wrong later.  I've been using a version of Acronis for the better part of a decade and it has saved my rear many a time.  My system backs up an image of itself every week and so if something goes bad, at worst I lost the last weeks' worth of changes.There is no CD or other media in the container, just a piece of paper to download it.  The file size is around 300MB so if you're tight on bandwidth it won't break the bank.  The product key is an astounding 74 characters (give or take if you count hyphens), but they give you a shortened 16 digit one to put in, then you sign up for an account with Acronis, and they email you the long one to copy and paste.  This makes things a bit easier than the retail version.  Just look for an option of "I only have a short code" or similar when entering.  Setup of the software was simple and painless.I couldn't find this anywhere, so you should be aware, this is ONLY an OEM version of the software.  One thing I loved about Acronis is I can go to a program I got from them 5 years ago and download it again directly from my account there, so simple and easy.  This time, it provides no link (so back up the installer or don't lose the card!) and says it's a down rev version they don't support any longer and would I like to pay to upgrade.  Since I have the full version, no.  However, you may want to.The version you get includes a rescue media builder which will let you make your own recovery media.  I didn't try it in this version, but in the full version, I was able to create a USB drive with an image of my hard drive, so instead of answering all those setup questions, I just put in the drive, tell it go, and everything up to a few months ago is all set up as I'd left it.  Very handy.  It also includes a drive cleanser, which will try to destroy everything on a hard drive; anything you delete on your PC is not actually deleted, just forgotten until the OS overwrites it later and even then may be recoverable.  A cleanser makes it so if you gave your computer to Goodwill, the next user can't restore that folder of embarrassing selfies you thought were deleted when you formatted it.The disk cloning feature is its primary purpose.  This allows you to take your old hard drive and copy it to the new ones so you can most likely avoid having to reinstall Windows.  The one caveat, if your old hard drive is bigger than your new one, and filed up with more data than the new can handle, then you're out of luck.  It can also do some things like create a partition, though seems to only be able to destroy all of them and do it, not create new ones without hurting your data, can mount the image so you can pull files you need out of an image you made without having to revert your whole computer to that image, and can schedule backups.  However, it's limited in this version and doesn't have Secure Zone.What's it missing, well first off Secure Zone.  That's a great feature that Acronis has that makes a hidden partition on your drive, so nobody can muck with it, and simulates restoring to an external hard drive using your current one.  The only downside, if your whole hard drive dies your backups are gone too obviously, but if you regularly back up from time to time to an external drive you'll be mostly fine.  Hard drives don't die that often so I find that more convenient.  It also lacks a file shredder which does what a disk cleanser does just for specific files/folders without erasing the whole drive, Acronis' recovery manager, individual file backups, and the boot sequence manager.  If you need any of those, you'll have to pay.---Conclusion---Sorry to go on so long, but there was a lot to cover.  I am quite happy with the drive and found it to be fast, convenient, and relatively good for the price.  If you watch you can find some cheaper deals.  Crucial itself had some refurbished ones for sale, briefly before they sold out, for VERY cheap not too long ago.  However, even buying this smallish one here if you can get by with less space on your laptop by using an external hard drive like WD Passport on it, or get an adapter to use this as your Windows drive in your desktop with a 2nd hard drive for storage, then it's a pretty good way to go.  Alternatively, just wait another 5 years or so and probably all the new computers coming out will have SSDs in them.

First of all, the top priority for one of these is that it's safe.  Little kids can and will topple over things if they're able.  True, I do still have memories of the giant box fan with broken grill parts that we had most of my childhood and we never lost a finger, but why not remove the element of risk if you can?  This fan is a bit pricey, but given it has a 5 year warranty, you can look at it as price per year and it's not half bad.First off, the bits I liked.  The fan feels solid and is not especially easy to tip, a child could still manage it.  The floor is probably the best place for it.  They've protected the fan blades from probing fingers so it's next to impossible your toddler will be able to get a digit inside.  You can move the gray fan part to slightly different angles without any points that could pinch a little hand.  They've also put a nice little cord storage in place under the fan, so you can shorten it and reduce the risk of tripping.  The fan has reasonable power and is not terribly loud, though you'll hear it plenty well at the medium and high settings.  Overall design is solid and attractive.It's small so during the winter or unneeded you can store it away nicely.  The instructions included tell you how to remove the grill for cleaning and they make it pretty easy to remove the blade if you needed to untangle string or something that got inside and wrapped around.  The buttons are soft and won't pose a risk, but the power button is larger so you can find it by touch easily.  There is a nice feature to lock the controls so baby can play with it, but he/she can't actually change anything.  Generally a good idea, given how much they like to explore the controls they see adults using.Now onto the not so great.  The light is essentially a glorified night light with minor brightness controls.  It's not especially soothing by any means, though I suppose if that's the only light you have on in the room, maybe.  The sounds were also fairly unimpressive.  There are 4 tracks.  White noise is roughly equivalent to a fan being on and there isn't much to it.  The water one is pretty good, but if you're listening to it over a baby monitor be ready for frequent trips to the bathroom.  The froggy night one has poorly digitized frog ribbits that sounded cheap.  The womb one may reassure a baby, but both my wife and I found it to be extremely creepy and a slightly older child may be spooked.  We'll better know reaction to the sounds soon when my little niece visits.  The effects remind me of the perfunctory ones included on my alarm clock, where I just bought a dedicated device to have better white noise.As a fan, the thing is exemplary.  There's very little I can fault it for and the fact that it will remember the last settings (if you don't unplug it) until the next time you run it is a VERY nice feature indeed.  Auto shut-off would have been a nice feature though.  Where it falls a little short is in the add-on area.  The extra features on it are nice, but just don't come off as well as the base feature of the device.  However, especially with the warranty, definitely a good product for baby.

If you're running a business, you're better off having cards professionally made.  Plain and simple.  Easy as that.  I know it's expensive, but it's advertising and that's expensive.  Do not get these thinking you'll save a lot of money and still look professional.  You won't.  They're thinner and you can tell at a glance they were made by a home printer so you won't fool anybody.  However, if you're starting some small business or you need them for a church, club, etc. where people won't judge you on them, then these will work well and are a significant improvement over past ones I've tried.I don't remember the number, but we'd tried another Avery business card template years ago.  Those were thin and very bumpy around the edges.  This batch, well they're still a little thin, but not that bad.  They have dramatically improved how they feel around the edges.  You can still feel ridges and tell they're homemade easily enough, but it's not as blatant as the old ones.  Big points for that improvement.Templates weren't an issue with these.  Both Libre Office (nice little free office suite compatible with Microsoft Office) even had the Avery template for this model already present.  I did find Office 2013 to be far more cumbersome in setting up business cards than past versions of the software.  I had to go into create a blank one, go into Mailings, Labels button, then into Options to be able to pick the right one.  The whole ribbon thing just makes things harder, but that's not Avery's fault.  For the actual printing, this is sort of the Tale of Two Printers.  I tried these cards with both our Brother MFC-J430W and an Epson WF-2650 and had dramatically different results.These were tried first in the Brother printer first and the results were horrendous.  They went through the printer with some minor issues, like the sheet of paper below it being pulled in and printed to instead.  You're best bet is to feed one sheet in at a time and then they should go through the printer just fine.  The problem was, even after letting it dry for some time, the ink on the cards came right off when a finger was rubbed lightly over it.  I don't mean smeared a little if you pushed down, I mean a light touch was taking off entire words through light handling.  I couldn't believe it, so I tried another sheet, and the same thing happened.  If I print the cards on the back they look perfect and don't smear, but then it's not glossy.So I came here ready to write a one or two star review, but my wife suggested I try the Epson printer.  So I ran the same exact templates through the Epson and roughly 30 seconds out of the printer there was zero smear.  I think if you had a damp finger you could probably do it, but the difference was so stark it was like using an entirely different set of cards.  The only thing I can possibly think of is that the Brother is set to a lower quality ink output because it's very low ink and we're just using it until it runs out, since the Epson can handle 2-sided printing, so so I'd highly suggest trying it with the printer set to make the ink very dark.  You'll use more ink, but the cards won't be worthless.So the take away is that you have to have the right expectations going in.  These will not be professional grade, however they may very well be good enough if you're one of the more laid back uses above or if you're working with well known clients and it's just to give them contact information and not a first impression.  My sister uses these in her office and they like them, but then they mostly deal with predictable contracts from state agencies so they're not trying to impress anybody to get business.  They're good for what they are.

This game would be a 4 or even a 5 to me except for one thing, the AI in the game is TERRIBLE.  Your little helper monkeys essentially just have nearly unlimited health, though they can die.  I watched Megatron get hit by a train, die, and come speeding along 5 seconds later.  Otherwise, no matter how much they shot or were shot, my teammates didn't go down.  This took a lot of the realism out of it.  They also get in the way more than they help.  I lost track of the times I'd be shooting someone and they'd walk into the shot.  They also had an uncanny way of getting in the way of my dashes when I was trying to drive to avoid a boss.  The mini-bosses with any kind of trick to them were completely beyond their ability to damage even if they were behind them in perfect position.  To top it off, even if equipped with a healing ray, I only had one heal me once the whole time I was playing.  It was just infuriating at this point in gaming that kind of thing would still be done.Aside from that, this was an incredible game.  It's easily the best Transformers one I've ever played, though admittedly that's not many of the recent ones.  You can tell a lot of love went into the voices and the character models.  They look a bit closer to the old 80s show than the recent movies, but there's a little of both in it.  Everybody sounded just perfect.  One of my favorite parts of the whole game was fighting Soundwave and his little helper robots.  Fun!  You also get to see how Megatron ended up with Starcream and he's as delightfully annoying as in the cartoons.The production value for the rest of the game was stellar, though it is a bit short.  I finished the game in roughly 9 hours and a chunk of that was the final boss fight which is fairly difficult.  The story is solid and the plot plausible, so far as a cartoon story about a bunch of living robots on a metal planet can be.  There were few if any glitches I came across and the checkpoint save system was overall quite fair.  I did take issue with the amount of ammo it took to kill an enemy vs. the amount you could carry and some levels were just not fun because of lack of ammo for the guns I liked, but those were the exception more than the rule.  This is not a bad game in my opinion, but it could have been a beautiful work of art with just a bit more attention to the AI of both the good and bad characters.

I decided to try this for two reasons, one I'm getting a bit older and it can't hurt to do a bit to rejuvenate, and my wife who's still as pretty as the day I met her some 12 years ago is getting more and more worried about her face.  I keep telling her she's beautiful, but it's upsetting her so a convenient pocket "spa treatment" looked like a really cool idea.  After about a week it's given her a lot more confidence and I'm pretty happy too.  There are some bad experiences in other reviews you should probably check out too when deciding, but neither of us had major issues.The unit comes with a base cradle, cord, and a device that looks kind of like a funny little space alien.  You have to charge it for 12 hours minimum before first use.  Construction feels solid, so I can't tell if the internals will give out in time, but it doesn't feel like it's going to fall apart like the last similar device she had.  I really liked that it made sound when it started the charge routine so I could tell connection had been made.  My wife's last one would sometimes not connect quite right and she'd come back to a dead battery instead of a full charge in the morning.  The battery indicator also lights up on this, so you're not going to have that problem.  I'm always paranoid about how to keep it lasting its longest and according to the instructions it is designed to sit in the cradle when not in use.  Some batteries warn against that or it shortens the life.  Still, since they're NiMh batteries inside, it's not the worst idea in the world to use it down to leave it out once a month or two and let it drain down a bit to keep maximum capacity.Maybe women are made of sterner stuff, but the little zap it gave me was something I could feel on the low setting.  She turned it all the way up to maximum and was complaining she wasn't feeling enough of a zap.  Suffer for beauty I guess.  Anyway, she tried it with some water on her face and started feeling it more, so it made her happy.  I was quite content barely feeling it so the range of settings seems pretty solid for your level of tolerance.  Even at higher ones it didn't exactly hurt me, but was just unpleasant.  I can see a little bit of lift in my own face and she is happy with the way hers is looking.An interesting thing that she also liked and wanted me to mention, and this is just our experience NOT the product design, is that she found it gave her some relief for some mild carpal tunnel syndrome pain in one hand.  I absolutely do not want to tell someone it will cure that and have them buy this device for that and be disappointed, but for her limited symptoms, she said she found some relief by turning it to full and doing it on her wrist.  Basically, if you're buying it anyway and you have some symptoms it probably can't hurt to see if it has any effect for you.There's been only a little love loss with the device.  After using it for maybe 3 times, she suddenly started breaking out with bumps across her face.  She never has breakouts, so it was definitely the device.  However, after a few days they had disappeared and haven't come back since.  I used it for the same number of times with no effect at all and I'm more prone to breakouts, so it's entirely dependent on the person using it, but the important thing is it doesn't seem to be a permanent situation.  If it does happen again or if the device dies prematurely, I'll update my review.One last thing, if you see any other Vine reviews for it, just be aware there is absolutely no pressure to write either a good or bad review.  Zero.  If a reviewer thinks something is a steaming pile of poo, the reviewer can come out and say that with no consequences of any kind.  As with all reviews though, you're MUCH better off reading the whole review to see if the person likes it or hates it for the same reasons you might than by just looking at stars.  I hope you enjoy this like we did, but keep the box since Amazon has a pretty good return policy if you don't.

These replace some Sunbeam ones that were so old they'd lost any effectiveness.  I like these a lot better in all except one way, they do not have any kind of outlet on the side as a pass through so they will eat up an entire power outlet slot.  Not a big deal, but just something to be aware of.  It's not a bad idea to write down the date you bought them either, possibly in permanent marker on them, since the instructions say they'll generally last 3-5 years.We've had occasional mouse problems the past year or so.  We had a mount of "gifts" left all over the place, convincing us we had a small family roaming our halls at night.  However, a series of traps captured one small mouse which apparently had one heck of a metabolism because there was nothing after that.  I'm the type that normally tries not to kill things, for example we rarely kill spiders unless they're poisonous types, but when it comes to mice they can cause expensive harm and spread disease so we can't put up with them.  So we're VERY interested in anything that will keep them from moving into the house in the first place and avoid having to harm anything in the future again.Installation is simple as can be.  You just plug them into an outlet and you're done.  Just be aware, you need to place them somewhere in an open area so they aren't blocked by anything or the mice will not be bothered enough to leave.  You also should be aware the night light on these is very bright and on 24/7, so plan accordingly.  The instructions say to leave it in the bottom outlet, but we found they'll work well flipped upside down and put into the top.  The lights shouldn't generate much heat, but there's one outlet we decided not to use because it has sort of a hood that the light almost touches and we didn't want to find out heat builds up the hard way with a house fire.A pack of four is a really good size to cover most of the major rooms.  We're thinking we may figure out some way to put an extension cord up into the attic (no outlets sadly) so we can try up there, since that's one place they got in before.  Very small, very handy, like them a lot.  The only annoyance is that we'd kind of like an off switch for the light and even the bigger old ones we had freed up the outlet with a plug on the side.  I'd take slightly bigger to have an outlet, but still a nice product.  I'll update my review if we do get another infestation after putting them in place

We have two dogs and they can smell a bit.  So this looked interesting.  I can't say it was awful, but it was definitely not what we expected.The first problem is the size.  This thing is seriously huge compared to the outlet.  It takes up way too much space and drastically limited where we could put it.  It really needs some sort of cord out of it and to sit on a counter or something.  So in any event, we ended up finding a home for it in my wife's bathroom since she had nothing plugged into one of the outlets.  Today I came home and found it unplugged.  To quote her "You shouldn't have shut the door.  I almost died when I opened it."  Set to the lowest, just overnight, door open a crack, and she felt the smell was overpowering.It's not a bad smell, but nothing special really.  Sort of your usual, or slightly above usual, chemical smelling "freshness".  It does mask other odors very readily, so it definitely lives up to that promise.  It's just so strong after you leave it on for a bit that you'll only want to use it in a really large room.  Even then, I'm kind of leery of turning it up to full.  So yeah, if you have a big room and need heavy coverage this is great.  If you're very sensitive to smell or have a slightly smaller room, then it's too overpowered in our opinion.  Cut it in about half and we'd probably buy replacements cartridges later, but I doubt we'll even use this one until it's out.  Maybe put it in the garage or something.

These are just great.  I can say with no qualifications, they're the best disposable cup I've used.  The sliding cap part at the top is neat and makes it very easy to open and close while preventing minor sloshing out when you drive.  There isn't any need for an outside cup holder or double-cupping, because the cup has that sort of fuzzy feeling insulation around the outside.  I suppose if you were very sensitive to heat, it might still be a good idea to save a few of those paper outer things off the coffee you pick up at work or something, but I had no problems with even very hot stuff.  My wife really loves these as a quick "to go" cup.The only thing I can say bad about these is the price per cup is steeper than you may be used to, but they're not VERY expensive.  These are probably not a good replacement for the travel mug you take to work each day or a good one for a business, but as a little bit of luxury for when you forgot to wash the other one and need something quickly or you have a guest to give coffee to and would like to be a little impressive, then they are definitely perfect for that.--Update 02/04/15--My wife was testing it and found that the lids worked on some cheaper cups we'd picked up, so she's saving the lids now and reusing them a bit which adds some more value and is a tiny bit better for the environment not tossing them so something that might work out for you.

I bought one of these 8 years ago for work to use as my desk water bottle that I fill from the cooler. I didn't need a 2 liter bottle but the one I got back then was bright blue and I knew I'd never misplace it as it was so large, and sure enough I haven't.I got this one for home because I really needed the size and since the one I use at work has held up for 8 years I figure that this will too.

I have always worn Jockey but they haven't seemed as nice to me as they used to be and these were on sale and I gave them a shot. I haven't had them long enough to know how they wear, but they are significantly thinner than Jockey t-shirts. That may or may not be a positive for you but they seem cheap to me. Perhaps I'm being unfair, as they are indeed less expensive.

I have liked every Calexico album prior to this one, but this feels like 'easy listening' to me, as though they've lost all of their edge. It's not a bad sound, but it's... bland, which isn't a word I ever thought I'd use for them

I wasn't expecting a whole lot from a $12 belt, and when I saw it I was pleasantly surprised, as I really liked the shade of green when I ordered it and it's the same color in 'real life'. (Note that they call this color "olive" but it's really a much brighter more intense green than that.)The buckle looks like the cheap gold-tone it is, but for $12 what do you expect.However, I'm probably going to return it because it's *too* stretchy. I ordered the medium because while I wear a 36" slack, I would normally have ordered the 38-40" belt. However, I thought that if I got the 34-36" belt (which the medium is supposed to be) that it might be snugger, as I didn't want a loose belt and many braided stretch belts are. But this one just has too much give.If you need a belt just for the look then this will work fine. For me this feels to loose.

I bought this to use on an elliptical machine at the gym, and it works. There's no place to clip it on my machine (even though it has a TV monitor) because the places are too thick and because with the D cells this thing is too heavy for that. However, I have managed to find a way to balance it between the control panel and the monitor support so that it works.Does this make a great deal of air? No, but it's better than nothing and better than those delicate little fans. This sits about 24 inches from my face (toward which it's aimed) and I can feel the breeze. That's far better than any other battery unit I've found will do. If someone knows of a more powerful battery one that isn't too much larger, I'd like to know.

I'm a Vine reviewer and when offered this I figured 'what the heck' as there was something in the description or some review that made me want to try it. I'm a guy with baby-fine straight hair who also has a very oily scalp. This is a bad combination because I need a shampoo that gets the oil off but not that has any conditioner as almost anything weighs the hair down too much.I used this and from the first time noticed that it does indeed get rid of all of the oil, and I can see why some folks think it leaves their hair too dry, especially if they have longer hair. (Mine is sort of typical guy's length short, with some length on top.)What surprised me is that after I blew dry the hair I noticed that it felt fuller and looked thicker. I have no wave and this didn't add any wave, but I like the look and feel and the thickness without any feeling of greasiness or oiliness or waxiness.I don't like the smell, especially, but since it goes away when you rinse it off, it doesn't matter. It's not horrible, but not what a guy would tend to like.

I'm giving this 4 stars because while it's not the product for me, the fact that it has a very mild scent that almost immediately dissipates makes it a great product in my eyes. It's not for me because I have baby fine silky hair and this product just has too much 'weight' for my hair, relative to its hold, and using more of it, given that I want lift, is going to make my hair feel greasy. I use American Crew Modeling Clay and for me that's a better choice.Someone mentioned that this is identical to a Suave product but that the Suave is much less expensive. It may be the same product, but I looked for the Suave that was mentioned, out of curiosity, and when I found it it was very expensive and I suspect discontinued.Having said that, this seems not competitively priced at the time I'm writing this review. I was given this for free as a Vine reviewer

I was trying to decide if I wanted to order this as I like the idea of a portable small grinder, and this may be a terrific product. But I am giving it this review because the make has effectively given it to the current 3 reviewers, and not one of them knows anything about grinding coffee. Notice that one says that it can be used for anything from a "coarse to French press grind". No one who knew anything about grinding coffee would make this comment.I am concluding that the maker feels that the product can't stand and sell without clearly fake reviews.

I have been using electric shavers for about 20 years. I used to use Braun, and then fell in love with the various incarnations of the "3 head" Panasonics (I put that in quotes because they have two cutting foils) like the ES8109/8103 and the Arc3. They work well, and I find great prices on them and they charge quickly so I figured I'd stick with them and maybe later move to one of the more expensive models if I wanted more cutting foils to speed things up.THEN, you ask, why did I request (as a Vine reviewer) this Norelco to review? Well... because I lost a great deal of weight and I now find that my round, plump, easy to shave face doesn't work as well with the Panasonics because I now have a gaunt face and lots of bone structure and sharp edges, and it's just harder to shave, either with an electric or a blade.I looked at this Norelco and it looks to me as though it might work better at 'getting around corners' and indeed it does. As for the rest of it:1) Build quality: It seems fine and on par with the Panasonics and Brauns I've used.2) Charging: It charges quickly, about at the rate my latest P. does, which is under an hour and quickly enough for one shave in under 10 minutes.3) Comfort: Seems fine, which means it's like the P's, since I don't notice anything.4) Closeness: This is a difficult one because on the smooth places, I think the Panasonics provide a closer shave, but I have to struggle with them to get around the corners and this does a better job around the corners.When all is said and done, for me it would be about price: As I review this, the price is $140, which seems mid-market for high end shavers. But... I often find the Panasonics I like on sale for $80/90, perhaps because they are older models, and I don't think this is worth the difference. If it's on sale, then they're well-matched.

I bought these boat shoes when they were on sale for half the usual Amazon price, and I think that they are a great deal at half price. At the usual price ($110) at Amazon I think they're still a good deal and since the half price isn't common I'm reviewing them on the full price basis.One of the things that I like about companies like Rockport and Allen Edmonds is that the size I take doesn't change from shoe to shoe. Even with Amazon's generous free return policy for much of their clothing stock, I dislike the guessing game about sizes. That continues to be true of this shoe, as I don't think I should have gotten a different size. They are perhaps a bit wider and have a wider toe box than I'm used to in Rockports, but it's a subtle thing.They have decent arch support and a more padded feel than most boat shoes do. Rockport used to be known for that and in recent years they've moved away from the "running shoe feel that looks like a dress (or whatever) shoe".  This shoe hits a middle ground: not nearly as padded as they were years ago, but far more so than most boat shoes.The images on the web are just slightly off, as they are more brown (vs tan) when you get them than to me they appear on the web which I think was a matter of lighting when they were photographed. Other than that, what you see is what you get.NOTE: When I glanced at the page it had the size I wear all messed up. I wear a size 13 in Rockports and if they had a just slightly narrower shoe than the D, I might have gotten it.

I'm at a loss as to how to review these because I can't figure out the difference between this set (which is currently selling for $15) and a set I was given to review a couple of months ago that is currently selling for $9-something. Both are from Clipperton and both are high-glass chrome finishes. The packaging is slightly different, but holding one from each set together I can't see or feel any difference.These say that they are brass with a chrome finish, which is exactly what the others say. They both look like very standard, pleasant chrome shower rings, and they move identically. Also, I should note that while I was given both of these sets as a Vine reviewer and have had this set only briefly and the other free set for a couple of months, I selected these because I bought a set of these rings (from Clipperton) two years ago and they look and work now just as they did then.So while these are fine, look nice, and move as one would expect, I'd search for Clipperton on amazon and buy the less expensive set (which oddly, comes in what looks like slightly higher-end packaging) rather than paying half again as much for these.

This is my favorite new non-gaming mouse. For many years I've been using nothing but Logitech mice, both for myself and for the people at work (for whom I often order computers and peripherals). For years I had no problems finding mice I liked, but recently I haven't like the wireless options. It seemed that the ones I liked were either small laptop-oriented mice or were the large clunky ones. I'm a big guy with good-size hands but I don't like huge mice.What I wanted was a standard-sized desktop mouse with 1) buttons on the left where my thumb is that for back and forward (or could be configured to work that way), and 2) a button I could assign to do whatever I wanted. And I wanted that button in a convenient location.That seemed oddly difficult to find but my M520 died and I gave this a shot and it's terrific, so long as you want a right-handed mouse. Some details:1) the button just behind/below the wheel isn't configurable (using the SetPoint software Logitech provides) as it serves to switch the wheel from smooth to "notch" behavior.2) It has two buttons on the left that by default act as forward and back (for web and other uses) that happen to fall where my thumb falls.3) There is a subtle bulge on the lower left (that isn't like the huge bulges some of their big mice used to have) that if you press with your thumb (or just roll the thumb down a bit) with a huge variety of customizable options. It took me about an hour to get used to it and now I prefer it to a button on the top of the mouse because I don't have to move my hand to press it.4) Like all new Logitech products, it uses a "Unifying" receiver, which allows you to use one (tiny) dongle to work with any number of Logitech products. Incidentally, note that while your mouse or keyboard comes pre-configured to work with the its own dongle, there is a Logitech utility that lets you configure the dongle to work with other devices.  Note that this is *NOT* Bluetooth pairing - these are not BT devices which is great as Logitech advertises 3-year battery life for the 2 AA batteries you'll need.What's nice too is that this mouse is selling for about $30 on amazon as I write this.

I was given this to review through the Vine program and was interested to do so, and have tried it both with alcoholic and non-alcoholic beverages. I used to wonder why the Margaritaville series was so expensive, but now that I've used this one I understand, as this is far more than a blender. That may seem obvious but if you only look at the front view it looks like a blender with an ice hopper on top. You have to look at the side view to realize it's more involved than that.The basic functionality is that you add the drink mix (minus the ice cubes) to the blender and ice top the hopper on top. If you use the automatic cycle, the machine will shave the ice, drop it into the blender (which has a blade like a regular blender would) in the right proportions, and will then turn itself off. I was skeptical at first that it would get this right, but it certainly seems to, regardless of whether you are using alcohol.If you don't want to use the automatic cycle, there is a manual cycle, which basically is a switch that allows you to run the shaver or the blender blades independently as long as you like. You push (and hold) a toggle switch on the control panel in the up position to shave the ice and the down position to use the blender blades.There is also a reservoir to allow you to drain unneeded ice for disposal. This doesn't seem all that essential to me as you can just dump it out, but maybe I'm just missing that. It certainly doesn't hurt to have it.Oh... I almost forgot to mention that the consistency of the drinks is very nice and what you'd expect from a good frozen margarita or daiquiri.I'm not sure I'd buy this for myself but I think it would make a terrific wedding present for people whom you knew really enjoyed frozen drinks.

While these won't replace a real whiteboard, they are a terrific idea for those times when you need a whiteboard and can't get one. I teach 'computer stuff' in technology topics for different firms, and sometimes I have to teach in rooms with flipcharts or easels, but no whiteboards. This seems odd but the class sizes can sometimes be small and we're using a room that isn't designed for presentations.In these classes, I have small groups of 3 students doing design work that can only really be done where they have a surface on which they can constantly change their ideas, like a whiteboard or blackboard. Without something like that, the exercises just don't work. While these can only be erased 20 times (and they don't wipe quite as cleanly as a well-maintained real whiteboard) they are a life saver for times like this and I can take multiple packages with me if needed.

I can't believe this mat was only $11. It looks very nice and is clearly very tough, though I've only had it a few months. I like the fact that it's dark and while you can see the pattern in it, it doesn't leap out at you.  There are certainly 'prettier' designs out there (this one is monochromatic and plain) but I needed one this size, and because it was going to be used in a vestibule that is tile mosaic, I didn't want something that would clash with that.If you want something more attractive in itself, and are OK with something a little larger, then look at others. But I was way more impressed with this than I expected to be for the price, and I like the fact that it doesn't look like the cheapest mat I could find at the discount store.

This is the strongest clear packing tape that I have used and it works really well. The width and strength means that often one piece will do, and that's good as it doesn't seem to stick to itself as well as some other tapes I like, such as the Duck HP260.However, this stuff is pretty expensive and while I'm enjoying my free roll (as a Vine reviewer), I'm not sure I'll buy it. I think I'd rather get HP260 and have to use more and save the money.One other thing: I often ship boxes and I print the shipping label and then tape it to the box, and I like to completely cover the label with tape. In that case, clearly any cheapo clear shipping tape will do, and that's fine. I don't know that I'd want to bother with having 2 kinds around.Still, this is nice stuff and perhaps the price will drop when it's not so new
You know, for $15 I probably shouldn't complain, but do understand that this is a case where you get what you pay for. Perhaps the only useful thing I can say is that they tend to run large.

This is a lovely grill. It looks and feels like Le Creuset. I've only had it a little while so I have no idea if it will hold up well since the big difference between Le Creuset and imitators seems to be that some of the latter become chipped over time. But at least when I first got it, and after a number of uses, I can't tell the difference.One issue I have that was partly the maker's fault and partly amazon's, is that the packaging was a mess when I got it because of insufficient padding. The retail packaging offers no padding or protection and amazon shipped it in a much larger box with some crinkled paper, but not enough that the retail box wasn't beaten up quite a bit. I'm a Vine reviewer and was given this for free, so it didn't matter, but were I going to give this as a gift, I'd have asked amazon to replace it as the presentation is awful. I'd never buy something with a retail box in this condition in a store.If I had the choice between this and Le Creuset, for the same price point, I'd go for the Le C, if just because it's a known quantity with a reputation for durability. But for a significant difference in price, I'd sure give this a shot.

First, I was given these for free to review (as a Vine reviewer), but this is one of those cases where had I think I'd buy this set anyway (though in a different color than the white that was sent) because I really like these sheets. There's nothing "special" about them but they're the way I think nice sheets should be: They're all cotton and they feel like cotton that will wear well. I have little patience for inexpensive-but-really-high-thread-count all cotton sheets because that inevitably means that really short fibers were used and they don't have a nice 'hand'.I washed these right away and of course they aren't all smooth (I won't iron sheets) but they're almost exactly what I'd expect from a traditional, well-made all-cotton percale sheets. They have a nice weight to them.As I write this amazon is charging a little over $50 for them and that seems fair for a nice quality set of this nature. If the price drops (and it often does after products have been available for a little while) then I think it will be an even more solid deal.

I bought two Dockers belts at the same time (amazon sale), both of the same size, and this one is too large by almost one size. That's too bad because it's a very attractive belt, much more so than the photos of it suggest. The leather, both on the solid part and the braided part, is a nicely burnished dark brown and there are these two black "pipes" (no idea what to call them) on either edge of the belt around which the braiding goes.Dockers calls this a stretch belt, but it really doesn't have much stretch, and it's a great belt, but not sized quite right.

This is a great case, consistent with OtterBox standards and will provide adequate protection for most people.  Even though the case itself is lighter and thinner than the case I am currently using it appears as though it would cushion my phone under typical use.  The cutouts etc all line up just fine on the case I tested allowing me to operate all buttons, plug in adapters, jacks etc with no difficulty.  This case does not come with a clear shield for the front but it would be really simple to put on a protective cover.  Also the side of the case does extend slightly above the front screen which should provide some protection for the screen.As I have said this is a great case for typical use.  The phone have have put this case on is one that is subjected to much rougher handling.  This phone is routinely taken in construction areas, falls out of a pocket onto a hard surface, knocked off tables, dropped and other abuses on a regular basis.  As a result I will be sticking with the bulkier OtterBox case, with a protective screen that I had been using even though this sleeker case does seem to be a very well made product.

This one of the earlier Saint adventures, one that had originally appeared as two separate magazine stories were then combined by Charteris into this adventure. Years later this adventure was further adapted into a movie version as well.Simon and Patricia have left England to tour the continent, more to allow the British police to calm down from Simon's recent activities than to pursue any further adventures.  Still Simon, being Simon, could not possibly let an opportunity pass by so when a former adversary appeared in the neighborhood, as well as crown jewels worth a fortune Simon was determined to separate the two.  Aiding Simon and Patricia in this adventure was an old friend, Monty who was quite new to this adventuring life.  The question was though would Monty really live to tell the tale?As is the norm with these stories there is never really any question as to whether or not Simon will be successful and of course he will survive without suffering any permanent harm.  There will be one improbable coincidence after another, coupled with amazing strokes of luck which will allow our hero to always escape with mere seconds to spare.  It is up to the reader to suspend all doubts and simply enjoy the story.  Additionally the reader must keep in mind that these early stories were written more than 80 years ago, the high speed car chases involved speeds we all travel every day, the police could be easily eluded and rarely communicated with their counterparts even a few miles away.So pull up an easy chair, open this novel and join Simon and Patricia as they tear through Europe on this madcap adventure.

This comes in a very attractive box, and in a nice little bag (perfect for packing this necklace and perhaps some matching earrings when traveling) which would be a consideration when presenting this as a gift.  The necklace itself is very pretty.  The silver chain is delicate but feels substantial enough to wear well.  The clasp is large enough to operate easily but not so big that it would be a detraction if it happens to work its way to the front.  There is a little extra silver heart shaped tag, stamped with 'Hallmark' that I could do without but it is by no means a deal breaker, just not necessary in my opinion.  The length of the chain (plus included extensions) allows the stone to sit in a good position, just far enough down that it will be visible in an open shirt, or sit comfortably around a lightweight turtleneck etc.  The stone itself is a deep vibrant blue and of a good size - large enough to be seen but not so big as to be gaudy or obtrusive.  The setting is delicate, in good scale with the size of the stone and the chain, but it also appears to be substantial enough to hold the stone securely.The only negative comments I have to make about this about the price and the labelling - it is a bit more than I would be willing to pay for this.  I can easily find similar necklaces without all the 'Hallmark' labelling for less.  I do not feel that being labelled 'Hallmark' is worth paying extra for, although others may disagree, and would like this better without all the advertising.

I have given this a five star rating because I, personally have enjoyed it immensely.  For someone who is not a fan of period mystery novels, who does not understand life in the early twentieth century the rating would be less.  Unless the reader also enjoys the early Poirot (Christie), or Wimsey (Sayers), or Saint (Charteris) novels this one will probably not be nearly a five star experience.  And unless someone is already a fan of Ellery Queen in some form this is probably not a good starting point.Each lunchtime a crowd has been gathering to watch a model conduct a live demonstration of some advante garde home furnishings in the window of a large department store.  Today though the demonstration was not quite as 'live' as planned, the corpse of the wife of the owner became a part of the show.  Inspector Queen was called in to investigate the case, and soon his son Ellery found himself involved when one of the suspects was revealed to be an old friend.  Together father and son, assisted by the NYPD manage to solve the case despite a number of false clues.  As always with this series all the clues are fairly presented for the reader to follow, and a challenge is issued for the reader to do so just before the reveal.This series is contemporary to the period in which the story is written.  This is different from a period novel in which the author is writing about a time in the past primarily because the author of a contemporary novel will assume the reader will understand the setting while the period novelist will explain many details.  In this series the 21st century reader must keep in mind that besides the lack of modern day procedures and professionalism in the police force there were great differences in society in general.  Household servants were the norm, jobs for middle class women were not.  And rank had much more privilege then than it does now, allowing Inspector Queen to bring Ellery in on cases on a regular basis, even allowing Ellery to behave in an extremely arrogant manner to other members of the NYPD.Despite these quirks these early novels are not without their charm.  They offer a glimpse into life of nearly a hundred years ago while telling a challenging mystery story.

Often when writers take over well loved characters the result is less than stellar, the familiar characters are forced to say things they never would say, behave in ways they never would behave and are placed in situations where they are most uncomfortable.  Often odd new characters are introduced or key elements of the series are altered.  Every now and then though an author steps in and continues the story, honoring the established traditions without merely rehashing old material and managing to tell an excellent story as well.  Happily Goldsborough has managed to carry on the series almost seamlessly from Stout.As this story opens in the late 1970's long time associate Lon Cohen asks Wolfe for a favor.  Cameron Clay, a newspaper colleague, who is an abrasive, muckracking columnist, has been receiving threats, ones that Cohen feels should be taken seriously.  Out of respect for Lon Wolfe agrees to speak to the Clay even though Wolfe holds the journalist's work distasteful.  After meeting him both Wolfe and Archie have come to the conclusion that Clay is as unpleasant in person as he is in print.  When Clay is found dead, an apparent suicide, not everyone is convinced that Clay had not been murdered - a suspicion that Wolfe shares.  Soon Wolfe has sent Archie on the trail, bringing together the most likely suspects of the very large group that disliked Clay, personally as well as professionally.  In order to sort out the truth Archie finds that he needs the help of not Saul or Orrie this time but that of his long time lady, Lily Rowan.  Of course in the end the matter is brought to a close in a most satisfactory manner.

Imagine a world where Rome did not fall, where it managed to continue to expand it's Empire pushing eastward to be stalled by the Mongol and west, across the Atlantic to the lands the Vikings had discovered a few years before.  Little was known about this land other than it was peopled by barbarians who would be no more difficult for Roman legions to bring into submission than the numerous other tribes that had conquered in the past.  There was a special incentive for Rome to add these lands to the Empire, there were reports of gold in these new lands, gold that the Empire had great need for in order to maintain their ever expanding frontiers.The young Roman in charge of the invasion force had managed to bring his troops across the Atlantic, to land in the Chesapeake Bay.  The Romans had quickly dispatched the coastal tribes and then set forth traveling due west in search of the great cities that were said to lie there.  As the Romans penetrated further into the new lands the resistance they encountered increased until they finally came face to face with the Chahokia a military force that just might be able to bring Rome to it's knees.As is the norm with alternate history stories the differences start out fairly simply, one or two major events diverge from history as we know it.  In this case Rome did not fall, an Emperor was not killed and the Empire continued to expand.  After the initial event(s) though the differences continue and spread.  Here the native Americans are not only well organized themselves but they have developed some fairly sophisticated weaponry themselves that put them on a more equal footing with the Roman Legion.  Some of this technology would be plausible for a prospering Neolithic culture others require a big leap for the reader.  This sort leap is not unusual in any sort of speculative fiction and so is not a fatal flaw in this novel.  A bigger problem is the rather sketchily drawn characters.  Other than the main character there is little to distinguish the remaining characters from each other.  Basically they enter, perform their tasks and exit telling the reader nothing of substance about themselves.  It's too bad because there are some really interesting stories to be told here.  I hope that the author will get to them in the next novel.

I enjoy time travel themed stories so I began this one with some high hopes.  The heroine, Lara, is appealing, her problem - preventing her mother's death - compelling.  The author has done an excellent job of establishing a believable universe, unfortunately her characters are not as well drawn.  The parents in particular are one dimensional, cardboard figures who behave in unrealistic ways.  After a strong start the story goes down hill with only a few interesting developments along the way.  The ending is open ended and not very satisfying at all.Overall this is a passable novel, perhaps a YA reader who is unfamiliar with better examples of the genre would enjoy it but there are better stories available.

These towels have a satisfactory heft to them, are well made (none of the hem or lack thereof issues mentioned in earlier reviews), and washed well (no bleeding of color).  The towels are large enough to effectively dry dishes, do a great job on mopping up kitchen spills, wiping counters etc but the microfiber fabric dries quickly.

The problem with having a favorite author is that at some point, no matter how prolific that author is, you will realize that you have read everything available and, if the author has died, you know there will be no more.  Occasionally an undiscovered work might emerge, although often it is apparent why the project had been tucked away out of sight but for the most part all the reader can do is re-read old favorites or look around for another writer to fill the void.  Sometimes though another avenue is available, a new author will pick up their pen and carry on the adventures of a favorite character.  Once in a while the results are satisfactory, even excellent and so a beloved series continues for a bit longer, other times the results are painfully bad and the reader is left feeling upset.  This effort falls somewhere in-between.  The author hasn't quite revived the true Poirot but she hasn't insulted him either, the problem Poirot is presented with is a challenge worthy of his talents and one that he meets fairly, presenting all the clues for his companion (and the reader) to pick up on or not.Poirot has taken up temporary residence in a London boarding house in order to take a break from his rising fame.  One evening, while dining in a neighborhood cafe Poirot meets a young  woman who makes some astonishing statements before dashing off into the night.  Upon returning to his temporary residence Poirot's fellow boarders, a rising young police officer with whom he has struck up an acquaintance is visibly shaken by a case he was working on.  Three people were found murdered in a nearby hotel, which was disturbing enough, but the three crimes, although identical in nature appear to have nothing in common other than being murdered on that day and in that hotel.  Intrigued by the crimes Hercule soon joins the investigation which leads to events that took place in a country village long ago.This is a story worthy of Poirot, and one that incorporates many of Christie's favorite elements - village scandals, tragedies caused by gossip, red herrings and false alibis - to challenge the Belgian's famous little grey cells.  Unfortunately one of Christie's traits that this author did not copy was Christie's spare style.  Christie's stories always get right to the point and move along at a brisk pace.  This novel would benefit greatly from being trimmed quite a bit.  Some scenes drag on for too long, some descriptions are overly detailed leaving this reader at least wanting to skim through long sections to get to the good parts.  The good parts are there, it's just too bad there is so much unnecessary other bits cluttering up an otherwise good story.

These are sturdy, well made tea towels.  The pattern is attractive, the material is heavy enough that the towels feel substantial.  The towels held up well to being washed and do a good job of drying glass wear without leaving lint behind.  The only limitation with these would be that they are lightweight tea towels rather than heavier more absorbent dish towels.  Anyone expecting to dry a couple sinks full of dishes and pans will be disappointed.  These towels are for jobs like drying and polishing glasses and crystal, then hanging in a visible location - these are attractive enough to be on display rather than being stored out of sight.

This is the 4th in the CeCe Caruso series of chick lit mysteries.CeCe has been hired to organize the gala opening of a housing development based on Agatha Christie's mysteries.  Even though CeCe considers this a dubious venture in southern California even in the best of economic times (these were far from the best of times) who was she to turn a paying job?  After all as her accountant, who had arranged the job, so frequently pointed out, writing biographies of dead mystery writers was not exactly steady work.  CeCe was in need of a little stability in her life just now, her daughter and son-in-law had just gotten custody of his son from a former relationship, and were expecting a baby themselves and CeCe was in the midst of planning her own long awaited wedding to Gambino.  CeCe had arranged a location for the reception, found a dress, had everything but a date - much to the annoyance of her fiance.Life got a bit more complicated though when a dead body turned up at the gala opening, once again drawing CeCe into an investigation - further annoying her long suffering boyfriend.This is the fourth book in this series that I have read and the first one I have really gotten into.  The premise of focusing on a different mystery author in each book is interesting, the characters, particularly CeCe have grown on me over time but this is the first of the series I have given more than 3 stars.  Readers who are interested in both chick lit and classic mystery authors might enjoy the series but others should probably give it a pass.

CeCe Caruso began her career as a biographer of mystery writers by writing a book about Dashiell Hammett.  The most successful aspects of the book, at least from CeCe's point of view, was that it had gotten her out of her disastrous marriage and launched her career which allowed to support herself and her daughter.  Now that the book was finally going to be made into a movie CeCe was once again reaping the rewards.  She was hired to  coach the actor hired to play the lead about the life of Dashiell Hammett.  CeCe was delighted until she realized that the actor, Rafe, was certainly good looking, and definitely charming but he was not the sharpest tool in the shed nor particularly interested in learning about the subject.  Still it was some easy money which CeCe had a need for so what could go wrong?  Well all too soon CeCe found out, when she became involved in yet another real life mystery, one that lead to bullets crashing into her own home.This is the third in the series of chick lit mysteries.  In order to follow this series begin at the beginning and proceed in order but unless you are a fan of both chick lit and classic mystery series don't bother with this series.

This is the first book in the CeCe Caruso series of chick lit mysteries.CeCe Caruso is a writer specializing in biographies of mystery writers.  Her current subject is Earl Stanley Gardener, best known for his Perry Mason series.  CeCe has hit a writer's block on this project and is looking for a distraction, any distraction from the now frustrating project. The longer for distraction arises in form of a mystery of her own to solve.I mistakenly began this series with the second book, and was quite lost.  This book did supply the needed background information which did make for a more enjoyable experience but still was slow going.  If the reader is a chick lit fan as well as a mystery lover this series would probably be appealing, otherwise there are many better series available.

This is the second book in the series and the first one I have read which could account for the difficulties I had with the story.  I found it difficult to get into this story, or develop much of a rapport with any of the characters.CeCe Caruso is a biographer and amateur detective, based on these qualifications she has been asked to speak at a Nancy Drew Collectors Convention.  Along the way she and her friends become involved in a mystery or two.The author seems to be channeling the style of the original Nancy Drew stories - plucky girl detective who, accompanied by some eccentric gal pals, stumbles onto some mysteries which she manages to solve by a combination of daring and luck while obsessing over her wardrobe.  Cece even has a faithful boyfriend waiting in the wings for her post adventure entertainment.I found this book quite easy to put down.

I have rather thick shoulder length hair that takes a while to dry and style, a process that I find rather tedious.  This unit managed to get the job done a bit quicker than the dryer I have been using.  The unit was also comfortable to handle and easy to operate.  I particularly liked the design of the controls that allowed me to adjust the temperature and speed without stopping my styling.  The styling brush that is included is a nice size and also easy to manage.  The clips are also a useful addition, particularly on those occasions when I want my hair a bit bouncier than usual.

These are lightweight but definitely not flimsy.  I am rather light sensitive and was quite pleased with the level of protection these glasses provided, the lens are dark enough and eliminated the glare even on a sunny day.  Also the lenses wrap around enough to keep light out from the side while still allowing me to see more peripherally than I can with other wraparound sunglasses.As for the comfort issues others have mentioned - I found these glasses quite comfortable with no adjustments at all.

The cord is well constructed, flexible, and a good length.  It feels sturdy, the end pieces firmly attached.  The four foot length is long enough to connect devices but not so long as to be cumbersome.  In other words, this cable does what it is supposed to do without causing any problems.

The story begins in the immediate aftermath of WWII.  A young woman had written a series of humorous articles during the war that had been quite popular but now was looking for a new subject to tackle.  When she learned about an unusual group that had formed on one of the Channel Islands during the German Occupation she was intrigued and soon found herself drawn to learn more about the circumstances and the people involved, even though doing so was causing her difficulties in her own life.The novel is written solely in the form of letters between the various characters which gives the reader a surprising amount of information about the characters and the events, both past and present.  It is also very effective at drawing the reader into the story, enticing the reader to read 'just one more' letter to find out what happens next.

The workmanship is great, the stitching even, the zippers appear sturdy.  The design is well thought out - a hood to keep the sleeper's head warm, a collar to prevent drafts from getting in, the zipper opens from both the top and bottom to facilitate dressing/undressing inside the bag.  The bag is definitely cozy and comfortable to lie in.This is the first mummy style bag that I have used, and I was concerned that I would feel too confined but my 5'6" frame fit in there quite comfortably.  I have not had the opportunity to test it out in truly frosty temperatures yet but I was quite comfortable in 50 degree weather with no hood and with the bag partially unzipped.Getting it stuffed back into the sack was no different than any other stuff sack situation.  As to the size/weight issue - this is probably not the bag for somebody doing really serious backpacking due to both the size and weight but considering the price and performance this bag is just fine for short back packing trips (a week or less), canoe camping and of course for car camping etc.
