This is the 19th in the SPENSER series, originally published in 1993.A 15 year old girl and her baby were gunned down in the street, victims of the never ending gang wars that were raging in the neighborhood.  Knowing that the police department would probably not spend much time or effort on the crime, a local tenant's association hired Hawk to look into the matter, placing Spenser in the unusual position of following Hawk's lead.  Together the two sort through the complicated gang structures in order to determine why the girl had been murdered, and who had committed the crime.On the homefront Spenser was also treading into danger.  His long term girl friend, Susan, had suggested (decreed) that Spenser move in with her and their shared custody dog, Pearl.  The question for Spenser was whether it was more risky to be out on the streets or in his own living room?This is a very long running series, and as is common with long running series, the real draw is the on going interactions between the recurring characters rather than the crime being investigated.  There is little question that Spenser and/or Hawk will be successful, it is of more interest how they achieve that success and how their own lives will be impacted by their actions.This is a well written story, full of action, filled with interesting characters.  The stories are very quick reads - an ideal way to spent a lazy afternoon or a quiet evening.

This is the 15th in the Spenser series.  It is also happens to be the first one I have read, and other than a vaguely remembered episode or two of the TV series it is my introduction to the series.  This is probably not the best place to start the series.A serial killer has been stalking black women, murdering them in a particularly sadistic manner and then leaving a red rose on their body.  Parker has been called in to aid in the investigation and before long the killer begins to taunt him and even worse begins to target Susan, Spenser's long term girl friend.  As Spenser, aided by Hawk, continue to investigate while now protecting Susan we readers are given brief glimpses into the killer's thoughts.  As with all long running series there is never any doubt that our hero(s) will triumph in the end, the point of the story here is how Spenser and company manage to solve the crimes.This is a well written story, filled with interesting, believable characters and written in a witty style.  I will be backtracking in this series, reading the earlier novels to fill in the blanks in the back stories of the main characters since Parker, unlike most series authors, seems to assume that the reader is already familiar with the series.

This is the 4th in the MAX TUDOR series of cozy mysteries.Summer has arrived in the little corner of the world that former MI5 agent turned Vicar Max Tudor has come to call home.  Max and the love of life, Awena have spent the weeks since the events of A PAGAN SPRING working out a mutually acceptable way to marry, a thorny problem when the village Vicar's bride to be is a neo-pagan!  The villagers are not nearly as concerned about the details of the upcoming ceremony as much as the timing - would the pair marry before or after the baby arrived?  When Max was summoned to a meeting with his Bishop he assumed that word of his unconventional circumstances had reached the Bishop, and Max was going to be fired.  It was a huge surprise when instead the Bishop wanted Max to once again use the skills he had learned at MI5 to solve another crime.  And what a crime!  A local aristocrat had been poisoned...by a fruitcake...that had come from a local nunnery.  A rather bewildered Max set off to the nunnery, to try to sort which, if any, of the 31 nuns in residence had tried to poison one of their most generous benefactors.  Of course Max will sort out everything in the end but the biggest question is if he can do it and get to his wedding on time?This is a charming series of cozies, with all the usual cozy elements:  picturesque setting (a charming little village); main character sleuth with an unusual trait (MI5 agent turned Vicar) on going romantic interest (lovely neo-pagan Awena) etc,  The series also goes in for all the usual cliched plot devices - long lost heirs, hidden identities, long concealed secrets, hidden staircases, clues that just happen to arrive at just the right time etc.  The author spins these tales with her tongue firmly in her cheek, gently poking fun at the genre while providing a fun read.There are a few problems with the series, and this book in particular though.  First this book, like the other novels in this series are crammed full of characters that are a challenge for the read to keep straight.  A list of characters is thoughtfully provided at the beginning of the book, but it is a bit annoying that it needs to be consulted so frequently.  This novel also stars out rather slowly but the action does finally build quite nicely as the story continues....at least until the reveal.  As Max is explaining what happened it is as if the author had written several versions of the scene, and couldn't decide which one to use so just sent along all of them.  The same information is given about 5 times, making this scene much too long and redundant.  Other than those issues this is a fun read, one that maintains the best of the cozy genre.

This is the third book in the MAC TUDOR series of cozy mysteries featuring an MI5 agent turned village Vicar.Max Tudor's new life as a vicar in a small village has taken some unexpected turns in the last few months.  The murder rate in the little town has climbed alarmingly - a town bully, reclusive writers, members of the local gentry...all have bit dust and even though Max has managed to bring the killers to justice still the bodies keep piling up!  And it isn't as though Max doesn't have enough other things to do - there is his parish to run, an ancient church that requires almost full time attention to keep up and his budding romance with Awena, a beautiful woman with decidedly unorthodox religious views.Once again Max is back home, looking forward to spending the weeks leading up to Easter as a time for quiet enjoyment of the English countryside.  Little did he realize that once again the village population was due for some reductions.  As Max looks into the crime he is drawn into stories of long ago crimes that had gone unpunished.As with most cozies the details of the story require the reader to not look too closely. - coincidences abound, chance meetings, clues that conveniently appear at just the right time - all the cliches turn up.  The true appeal to this series, as with most cozies, is not the mystery as much as the characters, particularly the recurring ones and their on going stories.  In order to really appreciate this one reading at least one, and better still both, of the earlier books is needed.

Max Tudor, former MI5 agent turned Vicar, is traveling back from a rather boring conference when he shares a train compartment with a woman from a nearby village.  A short time later he learns that the woman has died under rather unusual circumstances and once again Max is called upon to use all of skills to ferret out the truth in this delightfully complicated tale.This is the usual cozy fare, a charming out of the way location, filled with quirky characters, an impossibly high crime rate and an investigator with some unique qualifications.  Former MI5 agent turned Vicar is pretty darned unique!  The location is interesting, many of the village characters are well written enough to lure the reader back for more.  As is often the case with cozies, the details of the crime, the method, motive etc are a stretch, and the circumstances involving the sleuth really don't bear close examination.  Realism isn't really the attraction in this genre, and this series is no exception.  The point to cozies in general, including this one, is gentle escapism to an imaginary location, filled with interesting characters for some adventure that everyone knows will turn out happily in the end.
This is a lightweight unit, easy to use and delivers good sound quality - all for a very affordable price.

This is the first in the MAX TUDOR series.Max Tudor had lived an interesting life working for MI5 but after a disastrous mission he needed a career change.  The career he chose though was an unusual one - village priest.  Little did he realize that his old job skills would be called up so often in this new life of his.  Instead of dealing with foreign agents or terrorists Max found himself contending with the village bully.  As he contemplated a way to curb the bully's overbearing ways someone else took matters into their own hands and killed the woman.  Now Max drew upon his old skills to discover who would take such a drastic step and why but along the way Max discovered that there more than a few long kept secrets in this sleepy little village.This is a strong beginning to this new series.  Malliet has made these characters much more fully realized that those of her previous ST JUST series.  As in most introduction to a new series novels this one spends quite a bit of time setting the scene and providing backstories but still the author has presented the reader with an engaging, and moderately challenging mystery.

This is the third (and final?) ST JUST mystery.St Michael's is certainly not the first college anyone thinks of when Cambridge University is mentioned.  In fact most would not even think of it at all which meant that funding for the college was always a difficulty.  In order to address the issue the administration had devised the strategy of inviting groups of successful graduates to college reunion visits, in the hope the former students might be inclined to made some donations.  The current group seemed particularly promising, a group who had attended the college in the late 1980's and who had all done quite well for themselves.  Unfortunately after al the arrangements had been made it was pointed out that not all the experiences this group had while in residence had been happy ones.  The Bursar only hoped that enough time had passed for the attendees to have forgotten any unpleasant memories, at least enough to write out some generous checks before they departed.  His hopes were dashed though when one of the most successful former students just departed, permanently and on the school grounds.  There's nothing like a murder to put a damper on the festivities!As usual the author pokes gentle fun at mystery cliches as the story unfolds.  Long hidden secrets are revealed, old scandals are revisited in the stately setting of the ancient university in the style made famous by so many writers before.  The mystery is moderately challenging but the real attraction to this series is the author's sly sense of humor.There is a slight story arc to this series, so reading the books in order is a good idea although not completely necessary.

This is the second in the ST JUST series of novels.  There is a slight overall story arc to this series, reading in order has some advantage but is not strictly necessary.A writers' conference is being held in most romantic setting - a Scottish castle turned into an elegant resort hotel.  Writers from both sides of the pond have turned up to promote their books - a cross section of romances, cozies, police procedurals and thrillers.  Added to this mix to provide the expert's point of view is DCI St Just.  His nice little holiday though turns into business as usual when the castle becomes sealed off from the outside world and a body turns up.Once again the author combines a neat little send up of literary genres, this time chick lit, historical romances, thrillers etc are gently skewered as a mystery story is skillfully told.  This is meant as a fun read, which it certainly is and although the mystery is moderately challenging the characters rarely rise above the cliched level.There is a slight story arc to this series  so it would be good to read it in order although not strictly necessary.

This is the first of the ST JUST series, and, I believe, the first published work for the author as well.Sir Adrian Beauclerk-Fisk is a very successful writer, famous for his popular series of cozy mysteries.  Unfortunately he was much less successful as a human being, and an abject failure as a parent.  His first wife had long since left, leaving behind their four children to be raised by a succession of nannies and boarding schools until each also fled to live their own dysfunctional lives.  All were surprised when they were summoned back to the family estate to attend Sir Adrian's upcoming wedding.  Spurred more by self interest than affection the group came together only to find themselves in a classic cozy mystery plot - there are long hidden family secrets, false identities, a mass of motives and a truly astonishing body count.The author has managed to roll just about every cozy mystery cliche into this novel and still written an engaging story.  The book does get off to a slow start, most of the first half of the book is devoted to stage setting but once the bodies start dropping the pace picks up.  After all is finally revealed it becomes apparent that all the little bits of information given out in the beginning do have relevance and rather cleverly contribute to the solutions to the various mysteries.  Once such little detail - all of Sir Adrian's mysteries had exactly 26 chapters and does this novel.St. Just's adventures continue in DEATH AND THE LIT CHICK.

These are two adventures that are story versions of episodes from 1960's The Saint television series so it is quite possible they may seem familiar. The first adventure involves Simon uncovering an art hoax in Europe and the second involves a coup in an emerging African nation.  Whether the reader has seen the tv episodes or is discovering these stories for the first time these are fun Saint adventures.  Simon is, of course, dashing and always one step ahead of everyone else so the fun here is seeing how manages to bring about his own brand of justice because it is a foregone conclusion that he will.

This rating and review will be revised after the hot weather sets in here 8 -12 weeks from now.  At this point I can only really comment on the unit's construction and ease of installation.When I unpacked this unit I was pleased with the quality of its construction - the unit is sturdy, solidly made with heavy materials.  This was reasonably easy to install, the directions were clear although much of the process was pretty intuitive.  My unit was installed in a location that already had a louver installed so all I needed to do was mount the fan and connect it to the power.  This did not take very long although giving an exact time estimate is not possible due to other issues unique to my installation coming up (shifting stored items out of the way to bring unit into attic, moving a light fixture out of installation area, and correcting poorly installed 40 year old wiring).Although the truly hot weather has not arrived yet I can detect a difference just during the moderately warm spring days.UPDATE The horribly hot, humid midwest summer weather has arrived and the second floor of my house is now habitable.  In the past there was a huge difference between the first and second floors of my house, now while there is still a difference it is not nearly as extreme.  So far the portable air conditioner that I had used in previous years to make the upstairs habitable is still in the garage.

This long running series is focused on China Bayles, an attorney who has left the high pressure world of big city criminal law to open a herb shop in the little town of Pecan Springs, Texas.  Over the course of the series China has accumulated a group of friends, found romance, reconnected with long lost relatives, become a step mother and solved a whole lot of murders.  And herein lies the problem, one common with many long running series, particularly those in the cozy genre - when the main characters live in charming little communities just how many murders take place nearby?  The author has sent China off to nearby communities and further afield on road trips to solve this problem.  This time China has traveled a few hours away to visit her mother and step father over the Thanksgiving holiday.  Naturally some problems develop, some nefarious activities come to light and a couple of murders take place.  It is never in any doubt that China, aided by a friend Mack, rather than her husband McQuaid, will clear everything up on the end.As is typical with this genre the real attraction to this series is the on going story arcs of China, her family and friends.  This is particularly brought home in this case by the liner notes on the jacket cover that identify just who is slated for death and what crimes are being committed.  The suspense all lies in the subplots involving the characters' personal lives.  The real mysteries here are whether or not China's step father will recover enough to return to work and how will Mack's new romance work out.This series has always focused more on the subplots than the murder aspect but the author has usually woven a bit tighter story.  While it is necessary for any book from a series to rehash some of the background material in order to get a new reader up to speed or refresh the memory of a fan.  Unfortunately in this one the same material is supplied multiple times - we are told more than once that China and her mother have had a difficult relationship, or that China is now raising her dead half brother's daughter.Another issue with this novel is how the novel ends.  The crimes are solved but the various subplots are very blatantly left has cliffhangers - will Sam recover? will Leatha fall off the wagon? will Mack and Ethan find romance? will China need to move to Utopia to save Bittersweet Ranch?  And the biggest cliffhanger of all - will Albert abandon China and Pecan Grove for Mack and Utopia?

This unit does do what it claims to do - charge devices quickly.  Normally delivering what is promised would rate at least a 4 star review but there are a couple of problems with this product.  In my opinion I should be able to use a product pretty much immediately upon wresting it out of the packaging.  No such luck with this, I needed to locate a cable to connect this device to each item I wanted to recharge.  This entailed going to a store and purchasing a cable that was about half as much as the charger itself cost.  The next issue was when I realized that the each outlet delivers a different amount of current, so even if I have two cables I cannot charge two phones at once.  To make this even more troublesome the markings to differentiate the two ports, and the ports themselves are located on the sides of the charger.  Don't plan on connecting something while zipping down the highway, this is not a simple process that can be easily accomplished without looking.On the plus side, it does do what it promises - charge my phone quickly.

As this tenth in the SEBASTIAN ST. CYR series begins it is late March 1813.  Sebastian and Hero are settling into life as parents when Sebastian is called upon to investigate the death of a member of the aristocracy.  The night time streets are dangerous places as every Londoner knows so why then had a wealthy landowner ventured out alone late at night, and what could he have possibly been doing at a popular trysting place in one of the seedier parts of town?  And why had whoever killed him bothered to cut off his head?Sebastian soon discovered that his inquiries into the matter brought some unwanted attention to his family, including that of an old enemy.  Despite the distractions of the case, or maybe because of them, Sebastian and Hero found themselves growing closer.  Would they be able to protect their little family from the dangers that threatened it?This is an interesting series, one that combines mildly challenging mysteries with well written characters to provide a glimpse into the turbulent early 1800's.  The overall story arc of this series is quite pronounced so if at all possible the novels should be read in order.
This has an exotic, spicy scent but is not overwhelming.  It is a subtle, clean masculine fragrance that suggests rather than announce its presence.

This is a very well made kitchen towel. It is cut straight on the grain so it hangs properly, the stitching is even.  The color is even and remained so after washing. It is definitely larger than average although it shrank after washing it is still larger than average.  It is thick enough to handle a full batch of dishes but is not so thick as to be unwieldy while wiping off counters etc.  The fabric is 100 percent cotton and is pleasantly soft to the touch.

This is the 6th in the LADY EMILY series of period romantic mystery novels.As this story begins it is early summer 1893, the London season is in full swing, parties are taking place every night and everyone who is anyone in London Society is obsessing over who is in and who is out, a status that can change overnight because of a whisper of scandal.Lady Emily and friends are enjoying themselves at a ball when her husband Colin Hargraves is called upon to run another errand for the Crown.  A fire has tragically taken the life of a young man, a member of Society who was due to be married in a few days time.  As Colin, and soon Emily aided by Ivy and Jeremy, begin to make inquires it becomes apparent that this tragedy is related to the mysterious  scarlet paint that has been splashed upon some very fashionable doorsteps over the past through weeks.  It has not taken long for the word to leak out that the red paint is being left as an indication of a shameful secret, and soon becomes the quickest way for a London socialite to become ostracized by 'polite' Society.This series is a fun read with the major attraction being the ongoing story line rather than the mystery aspect.  Because the series long story arc is so pronounced it is highly recommended to read this series in order, beginning with AND ONLY TO DECEIVE.  Fans of the AMELIA PEABODY or LADY JULIA series will probably enjoy this one as well.  As to which series is superior, each reader needs to decide for themselves, or simply enjoy them all.

This is the 5th book in the Lady Emily series of period romantic mysteries.The novel is set in July 1892, a few weeks after the events of TEARS OF PEARL, the previous story.  Colin has brought Emily to his mother's home in Normandy to recover from the tragic end of their honeymoon.  Emily was still distraught, far from her usual feisty self but her talent for stumbling upon mystery and intrigue had returned.  While out for a quiet ride in the country she found not the peace and solitude she was seeking but instead the mutilated body of a young woman.  For once Emily would have preferred not to have been included in an investigation but soon she, Colin and Cecile were once again together trying to uncover the truth behind a violent death.  This time though they had a most unusual ally, the elusive gentleman thief, Sebastian.  Could it be that a bit of investigation would help Emily recover?This is a charming series of romantic mysteries that has a very strong overall story arc.  Those new to the series should begin with the first book in the series, AND ONLY TO DECEIVE then proceed in order.  The mystery element is really secondary to this on going story line.  Fans of Peters' Amelia Peabody would probably also enjoy these.

This is the fourth in the LADY EMILY series of romantic period mysteries.It is April of 1892, Colin and Emily have finally wed, much to the delight of their friends.  The pair decided that perhaps it would be prudent to allow those who were not so pleased with their impulsive elopement (their families and the Queen) a chance to calm down and decided to honeymoon off the beaten path in Turkey.  While their choice is delightfully romantic the newlyweds soon discover that in the waning days of the Ottoman Empire Constantinople is filled with intrigue and danger, a combination with which they are all too familiar.  Once again Emily and Colin are drawn into political schemes and charged with solving crimes.  Would this marriage last any longer than Emily's ill fated first one?There is a very strong overall story arc to this series so those new to Emily's adventures would do well to begin with AND ONLY TO DECEIVE, and then proceed in order.  This series will appeal to fans of Peters AMELIA PETERS series.

This is the 3rd in the Lady Emily series of romantic period mysteries.  Those who are new to this series really should begin with the first book AND ONLY TO DECEIVE and proceed in order since there is a very strong story arc to the series.Emily, and her fiance Colin have discovered that the path to romance is still not running smoothly for them. Emily's mother and Queen Victoria have decided that Emily and Colin will have an elaborate high society wedding in several months, Lord Fortescue is determined that Emily and Colin will not ever wed, and all too often Colin's duties to the Crown take him off on mysterious missions.  At least the couple will be able to spend some time together at a shooting party even if their host is the odious Lord Fortescue.  When a murder takes place it seems as though not only Emily and Colin's lives but also the lives of Emily's dearest friends is also threatened.  Will Emily manage to solve everyone's problems in the end?

These work great for me. One end of the ear plug is round, and the other is not. It is easy to roll between my fingers. It does not expand too fast, so there is enough time to get it into my ear. It fits into my ear canal well, and tucks behind my tragus (which holds it in place). They do not hurt my ear.Be sure to follow the instructions and lift your ear with one hand, while inserting the plug with the other hand. You know if you got it completely in your ear, if you can feel it touching your ear drum (usually you'll get a slight sensation in your throat when it touches your ear drum).If I wake up in the middle of the night, I sometimes remove them. I place them in a small container when not in use. They last a long time (a month or longer for one pair). I use them as needed...not every night.If it is a warm summer night, and If the neighbors are talking outside or people are playing (basketball) outside, then these ear plugs stop the sounds completely. Wonderful.It would be even better if people were considerate to those around them, but that's just not the world we live in.  So, these ear plugs are the answer. I paid 6 bucks. Highly recommend.

I paid 8 bucks.  The fan I received was 0.28A / NIDEC with copper bottom including thermal paste on the bottom disk.My original fan was an Intel E97378-001. It was 0.60A / Delta. Every couple of months, it would intermittently stop or run slowly at PC startup, and this prevented my PC from booting; when turned-on, my PC would stop at the initial boot screen, and it would display "CPU fan error".  My original fan only lasted 3 years before it started giving me problems.It seems there are several varieties of this fan all using the same part # of E97378-001.  Here are the ones that I noticed: 0.17A / Foxconn, 0.60A / Delta, and 0.28A / NIDEC.The heat sink is aluminum (the large circle of silver fins under the fan itself), but the bottom small disk/circle of the heat sink may be either aluminum or copper (depends on who you buy it from); this is the part that rests on top of the CPU; it touches the CPU.  Copper does a better job of conducting heat from the CPU.  It's best to look at the photos; if there are no photos of the bottom, ask the seller to check before buying.Also, some fans come with thermal paste already placed on the bottom of the heat sink (it looks like 3 gray bars on the bottom).  If you fan doesn't come with thermal paste on it, then you need to buy it separately.The photos on Amazon may not reflect what you actually get from a seller.  If you really want to know what you are buying before you buy it, then pick a seller and email the seller before buying; ask them 3 things:1) What is the amp rating?2) Is the bottom disk copper or aluminum?3) Is thermal paste included on the bottom disk?I replaced my 0.60A fan with a 0.28A fan, and my PC boots fine now.  Looking at the BIOS settings/status, the CPU fan runs at 980-1020 RPM when the PC is first turned-on.  I'm not sure that the amp rating has much meaning for these fans; if it did, then I would think that Intel would have created different part numbers for each one.Since my original 0.60A / Delta fan only lasted 3 years, I wanted to try a different one this time.

It's best to look at the photos; if there are no photos of the bottom, ask the seller to check before buying.Also, some fans come with thermal paste already placed on the bottom of the heat sink (it looks like 3 gray bars on the bottom).  If you fan doesn't come with thermal paste on it, then you need to buy it separately.The photos on Amazon may not reflect what you actually get from a seller.  If you really want to know what you are buying before you buy it, then pick a seller and email the seller before buying; ask them 3 things:1) What is the amp rating?2) Is the bottom disk copper or aluminum?3) Is thermal paste included on the bottom disk?I replaced my 0.60A fan with a 0.28A fan, and my PC boots fine now.  Looking at the BIOS settings/status, the CPU fan runs at 980-1020 RPM when the PC is first turned-on.  I'm not sure that the amp rating has much meaning for these fans; if it did, then I would think that Intel would have created different part numbers for each one.Since my original 0.60A / Delta fan only lasted 3 years, I wanted to try a different one this time.INSTALLATION:HOW TO REMOVE OLD FAN:Unplug the fan cable from the motherboard.You may need a small flathead screw driver to unhook the tab that holds the fan cable to the motherboard fan connector.Turn each of the 4 fasteners counterclockwise.Gently lift up each of the fasteners to release them from the motherboard.When all 4 fasteners are loosened, lift the fan from the motherboard.TO INSTALL NEW FAN:Ensure there is thermal paste on the bottom disk.Make sure the fan cable does not touch the heat sink fins.Make sure the fan cable does not touch the fan blades.Make sure the fan is positioned so the fan cable reaches the motherboard connector.Turn the 4 fasteners counterclockwise.Position the fan assembly over the CPU over the 4 connector holes.Gently press the 4 fasteners down.Gently turn each of the 4 fasteners clockwise to lock them in place.Connect the fan cable to the motherboard.

I paid 8 bucks.  The fan I received was 0.28A / NIDEC with copper bottom including thermal paste on the bottom disk.My original fan was an Intel E97378-001. It was 0.60A / Delta. Every couple of months, it would intermittently stop or run slowly at PC startup, and this prevented my PC from booting; when turned-on, my PC would stop at the initial boot screen, and it would display "CPU fan error".  My original fan only lasted 3 years before it started giving me problems.It seems there are several varieties of this fan all using the same part # of E97378-001.  Here are the ones that I noticed: 0.17A / Foxconn, 0.60A / Delta, and 0.28A / NIDEC.The heat sink is aluminum (the large circle of silver fins under the fan itself), but the bottom small disk/circle of the heat sink may be either aluminum or copper (depends on who you buy it from); this is the part that rests on top of the CPU; it touches the CPU.  Copper does a better job of conducting heat from the CPU.  It's best to look at the photos; if there are no photos of the bottom, ask the seller to check before buying.Also, some fans come with thermal paste already placed on the bottom of the heat sink (it looks like 3 gray bars on the bottom).  If you fan doesn't come with thermal paste on it, then you need to buy it separately.The photos on Amazon may not reflect what you actually get from a seller.  If you really want to know what you are buying before you buy it, then pick a seller and email the seller before buying; ask them 3 things:1) What is the amp rating?2) Is the bottom disk copper or aluminum?3) Is thermal paste included on the bottom disk?I replaced my 0.60A fan with a 0.28A fan, and my PC boots fine now.  Looking at the BIOS settings/status, the CPU fan runs at 980-1020 RPM when the PC is first turned-on.  I'm not sure that the amp rating has much meaning for these fans; if it did, then I would think that Intel would have created different part numbers for each one.Since my original 0.60A / Delta fan only lasted 3 years, I wanted to try a different one this time.INSTALLATION:HOW TO REMOVE OLD FAN:Unplug the fan cable from the motherboard.You may need a small flathead screw driver to unhook the tab that holds the fan cable to the motherboard fan connector.Turn each of the 4 fasteners counterclockwise.Gently lift up each of the fasteners to release them from the motherboard.When all 4 fasteners are loosened, lift the fan from the motherboard.TO INSTALL NEW FAN:Ensure there is thermal paste on the bottom disk.Make sure the fan cable does not touch the heat sink fins.Make sure the fan cable does not touch the fan blades.Make sure the fan is positioned so the fan cable reaches the motherboard connector.Turn the 4 fasteners counterclockwise.Position the fan assembly over the CPU over the 4 connector holes.Gently press the 4 fasteners down.Gently turn each of the 4 fasteners clockwise to lock them in place.Connect the fan cable to the motherboard.

The seller was JCandy. I paid 9 bucks including shipping.When it comes to lip balm, I buy the least expensive kind.  In my local store, that means between 75-cents and 1 buck per stick.  So, buying a 24-pack of CHAP-ICE from JCandy for 9 bucks means they cost 37.5-cents per stick.  Great deal.I don't buy candy-flavored lip balm, but at this price, I can tolerate it. My pack came with 12 cherry, 4 watermelon, and 8 original.I can compare CHAP-ICE to the following brands:* ChapStick* Western Family (store brand, like Chapstick)* Natural Ice (original)CHAP-ICE reminds me of ChapStick and the store brand.  CHAP-ICE glides on my lips easily (more like oil); so, I can apply it on my lower lip and then rub my lips together to apply it to my upper lip.  In contrast, Natural Ice goes on dry; and that means I have to apply it to my upper and lower lips separately.Underneath the base of the stick (the part you twist), there are some numbers.  The top number is a lot number.  The bottom number is an expiration date.  My sticks say EX1117, which means they expire November 2017.According to the ChapStick website...Expiration dating is related to certain ingredients, like sunscreens and skin protectants. ChapStick products that are not labeled with these ingredients do not require expiration dates. Products without an expiration date do not expire. For best freshness, we recommend that you use your ChapStick within one year after opening and store it at 20-25C (68-77°F).So, given the above info about ChapStick, only the sunscreen and skin protectant ingredients in CHAP-ICE will expire...expire as in no longer effective, not expire as in rancid.  Other than those 2 ingredients, CHAP-ICE (like ChapStick) does not expire.I am happy with CHAP-ICE.Here is more information from the labels...Made in the USA.OraLabs, IncParker, CO 80134Net Weight 0.15 ounces or 4.25 gramsOnly CHERRY and ORIGINAL have sunscreen SPF 4 on the label.  WATERMELON does not.CHERRY and ORIGINAL active ingredients:padimate-0 1.5% (sunscreen)petrolatum 44% (skin protectant)CHERRY inactive ingredients:mineral oil, ozokerite, flavor, microcrystalline wax, isopropyl myristate, phenyl trimethicone, copernicia cerifera (carnuba) wax, lanolin, euphorbia cerifera (candelilla) wax, cetyl alcohol, camphor, Red 6 Lake (CI 15850), methylparaben.ORIGINAL inactive ingredients:mineral oil, ozokerite, flavor, microcrystalline wax, phenyl trimethicone, lanolin, copernicia cerifera (carnuba) wax, isopropyl myristate, cetyl alcohol, euphorbia cerifera (candelilla) wax, flavor, camphor, methylparaben, titanium dioxide (CI 77891, Yellow 5 Lake (CI 19140), Red 6 Lake (CI 15850).WATERMELON ingredients:mineral oil, ozokerite, petrolatum, microcrystalline wax, ceresin, copernicia cerifera (carnuba) wax, flavor, sodium saccharin, Red 27 Lake (CI 45410), Red 40 Lake (CI 16035), Aloe Barbadensis leaf extract, tocopheryl acetate.

The seller was shortpancho. I paid 5 bucks including shipping.The lock is easy to set/reset and easy to use. The instructions are easy to understand.  It seems well built and durable.  It is made in China.I am using it to lock an outside/outdoor gate.  The lock is secure enough for my needs.  The dials are easy to turn.  I am happy with my purchase.All measurements are in inches.The shank/shackle measures 13/16 when closed (from lock body to outside top of shank).The shank/shackle measures 11/16 when closed (from lock body to inside top of shank).The lock body (the black part) measures 1-5/16 tall by 27/32 wide by 5/16 thick/deep.The total height of the lock when closed from bottom to outside top of shank is 2-1/8.

Cheap plastic.  It lasted one season only.  The part that connects to the garden hose is fixed to the base (it swivels, but cannot be removed); there is a thin plastic ring that holds the connector to the base...and that's what failed...it broke-off.  See photos.  If you place any pressure on the connector when you connect/screw the hose into the base (or if you lift the sprinkler by the hose), then it will stress this area, and it will break.  Made in China.

I purchased it new for about 5 bucks including shipping.  The narration is informative and well done.  It spans the full length of the Bataan incident (fighting, surrender, death march, captivity experiences, rescue, homecoming).  They did a good job of compiling footage about the Bataan Rescue, including veteran interviews.  They also interviewed Filipino guerrilla fighters.Being only an hour long, there are no "slow parts"...and there is no "filler" footage here, which is good. I had seen the movie The Great Raid in the past.  The movie appears fairly accurate in comparison to the PBS documentary.

The seller was Amazon. I paid 130 bucks.Before purchasing, I visited Corsair's website and used their "memory finder" to confirm the correct memory module for my motherboard.I installed these 2 sticks of RAM in my Intel DX79TO motherboard in DIMM slots 1 and 2.  After installation, my PC booted normally, and the memory was recognized.  I also ran memtest86 and there were no memory errors.I previously purchased Kingston HyperX FURY 8GB 1866MHz DDR3 CL10 DIMM - Black (HX318C10FB/8), which the Kingston website said was compatible with my motherboard. However, my PC would not even start; it just gave 3 beeps, and turned off immediately, which means "memory error" according to my motherboard documentation.I have had Corsair RAM in the past, and it has worked well.  I am hoping that the CMZ16GX3M2A1600C10 will be as trouble-free as my prior RAM.  If not, then I will update this review.

The seller was Amazon. I bought 3 of these and paid 64 bucks for each one.I visited the Kingston website and used their "Memory Search" tool.  They confirmed that this is the right RAM for my motherboard.I removed my old RAM.  I installed one new RAM stick in my Intel DX79TO motherboard in DIMM slot 1.When I powered on my PC, the motherboard beeps 3 times, turns-off, turns-on, beeps 3 times again, etc. until I power down my PC.My motherboard documentation says this means "memory error".I installed all 3 sticks of RAM separately, and got the same error with each one.My BIOS is current (version 0650). In BIOS, I set the memory override setting to automatic...didn't work.  I also set the memory override setting to manual at 1866...didn't work.So, I installed my old RAM, and my PC started just fine.  My old RAM is Corsair DDR3 4GB 1600Mhz CMZ4GX3M1A1600C9.I returned the Kingston RAM to Amazon. Disappointing.Instead, I purchased Corsair Vengeance  16GB (2x8GB)  DDR3 1600 MHz (PC3 12800) Desktop Memory (CMZ16GX3M2A1600C10), and it worked great!  My motherboard recognized the memory without making any BIOS changes, and when I ran memtest86, there were no errors.

Excellent acting. Believable story-line. Decent special effects. No gore. Violence is limited to a few dogfights.There is some in-air action with German planes and British planes fighting each other. However, a good deal of the movie takes place back at the base...when the pilots return from a mission.There is definitely a psychological part to war, and this movie presents that very well. If you are able to relate to the characters and what they are going through, then the story will likely cause you to shed a few tears.Did you like this movie? Are you interested in a similar story but set to WWII? Then checkout Twelve O'Clock High.Visit my Amazon wish lists to see my 4-star and 5-star military/war DVDs:http://smile.amazon.com/gp/registry/wishlist/3DU5CH5ZFWRNI/http://smile.amazon.com/gp/registry/wishlist/24H8TDYHFDOET/

The seller was GAMESPlus-Woodlands. I paid 18 bucks including shipping in Fall 2012.I rented war movies from Netflix for a couple of years, and finally ran across Band of Brothers.  It is one of the best WWII movies.  The down-to-earth nature and realism of the production is excellent.  Sounds, sights, dialogue, actors, location, props, etc. are all right on the mark.  Amazing.  It is an excellent way to learn and understand some of what these men experienced.Nearly every episode brought me to tears at one point or another.  Other times, some stuff made me angry; some made me laugh.  Those are signs of a very good movie...a movie that is engaging...one that pulls you in, puts you there, and allows you to experience a little of what the men experienced.  It can be difficult to watch at times.Other descriptions for this series: realistic battle scenes, camaraderie among the men, attention to detail, great acting, bonus disk with veteran interviews.I could recount many scenes that had a lot of impact on me, but that would make this review very long...so I won't do that.Some things I didn't like:Foul language--the degree of profanity was typical of Vietnam and today, not WWII; while not excessive, the language was not representative of the time.  Extensive hand signals were not used by WWII paratroopers.  A few other historical inaccuracies...search the internet, if you're curious. The primary military adviser (Captain Dale Dye, USMC, Retired) served in the Vietnam War; this helps explain the overuse of foul language and hand signals.This boxed set includes 6 DVDs: 10 episodes on 5 DVDs plus an extra DVD with special/bonus features.  Each episode is about an hour long.I highly recommend this series.  I have watched it twice, and I am looking forward to watching it again and again.Visit my Amazon wish lists to see my 4-star and 5-star military/war DVDs:http://smile.amazon.com/gp/registry/wishlist/3DU5CH5ZFWRNI/http://smile.amazon.com/gp/registry/wishlist/24H8TDYHFDOET/

The seller was Startup Media UK. I paid 10 bucks including shipping. The game installed and played fine on my PC running Windows XP Home SP3.Lost Planet 3 is a prequel to Lost Planet 1.Good stuff* Graphics* Sound effects* Dialogue* Voice acting* cover system* decent, and sometimes unusual music* redneck, normal fella for main character* audio logs (help to tell the story, not enough of them)Bad stuff* Boss fights (Really? Very old school, annoying, noisy, boring, repetitive. Not fun.)* Boss fights (Very unrealistic. Huge Akrid slam their claws on you, but you don't die until you are hit multiple times.)* When you are in your rig during a boss fight, they display on-screen the exact keystrokes needed to defeat a boss while fighting. Unless you hit those keys when you are told to do so and at precisely the right angle, you cannot win the fight. This is also known as a QTE (quick time event).* During each boss fight, doors close around you; once you defeat the boss, doors open again.* Every boss battle is the same: Roll around and shoot the orange spots...over and over again until the boss is dead.* Checkpoint saves* Keyboard configuration (until you change it)This game is best played on Easy difficult in order to make the annoying boss fights easier and quicker to get through.The game has a decent story, even though the story moves a bit slowly at times.  At least there is a story (unlike Lost Planet 2).Lost Planet 3 is better than 2.Lost Planet 1 is better than 3.This would be a 4-star game, if it wasn't for the boss battles.  The boss battles ruin it.Frustrated by the boss fights?  Not sure how to beat a boss?See the first comment to my review for tips on what I did for boss battles that I had trouble with.=============================How to change keyboard configuration=============================Go to<drive>:\Steam\steamapps\common\Lost Planet 3\Binaries\Win32\Make a copy of this fileKeyMappings.INIand rename/backup the copied file asKeyMappings.INI.originalThen edit the KeyMappings.INI as you like.In order to see the changes in-game, restart the game.=============================How I combined my keyboard settings=============================I set the following actions to E:...for "on foot"...RepairUseOperatePickup ItemPickup WeaponPickup Item (yup, they listed it twice!)Planet BombOperate T-PostPrep T-PostTransfer T-PostSet DeployableCancel ConversationRevive...for "utility rig"...Shock-Jumper...for "vital suit"...Exit Vital SuitI set the following actions to F:...for "on foot"...StruggleMeleeCancel Repair...for "utility rig"...Swing ArmThe Grapple Hook was H, and I also set the utility rig winch to H, since they serve the same function.In order to set E and F to several different actions, you have to edit the INI file as described above under "How to change keyboard configuration".

The seller was Amazon. I paid 70 bucks.The drive installed just fine for me.  After installation and formatting, the drive shows 931 GB free space. My PC is running Windows XP Home SP3.  I am using this drive as an extra data drive; I did not install the operating system on it.This is an advanced format drive.  To learn what this means, use google and search for "western digital advanced format".I needed a data cable, so I purchased Aleratec Left Angle to Straight SATA 2.0 Serial ATA Data Cable with Clip, 12 Inch - 2 Pack.Since I only had one SATA power cable remaining, I also purchased a 2-Port SATA Splitter Power Cable (2 x 15-Pin).I purchased this drive based on my past experience with Western Digital, and based on the good reviews that this particular drive has. The 5 year warranty was also important to me.The drive is quiet. I have no problems with it, but it is still new.  I'll update this review as needed, if I experience problems.===========================================Here is what I did to install the drive on my PC using Windows XP:===========================================Plug in SATA data and power cables.Start PC as System Admin.Go to Admin Tools.Run Computer Management.Click on Disk Management.It may show as:Disk 0UnknownNot InitializedRight click where it says "not initialized".Select Initialize Disk.Disk shows "unallocated".Right click on "unallocated".Select New Partition.Select Primary partition."Partition size in MB" should be the same as "maximum disk space in megabytes".Select a drive letter to assign to the drive.This can be changed later.Format this partition with the following settings:File system: NTFSAllocation unit size: DefaultVolume label: Western HDD (can change it later by right clicking drive in Windows Explorer)Do NOT select quick format or compression.Wait for the drive to finish formatting.See the status indicator.After a few minutes, it will show % complete.

The Moen 7560BL Extensa One-Handle Low Arc Pullout Matte Black Kitchen Faucet was installed while my home was being built. I've been using it since January 2006 with no problems.In 2014, the spout began to leak at the top and down the flexible tubing on the inside when I pressed the spray button on top.  I don't use the spray feature much, and when I do use it, I usually pull the spout from the base to wash-off items in the sink.  The leak was noticeable when I pressed the spray button, but the leak wasn't excessive.The fact that some water was leaking down the flexible pipe to the base of the cabinet below was not good, so I began looking into a new faucet.  New faucets (from almost any reputable manufacturer) are not cheap.  Thankfully, I ran across some reviews about warranties, and then remembered that the Moen came with a lifetime warranty.  In Fall 2014, I called Moen and within 3 days I received a new spout via FedEx at no charge.  It was easy to install, and it works great.I did not have a receipt for the original faucet, because it was part of new construction. I did register my faucet on the Moen website before I called them.  They did not give me any problems. I was surprised that they were so quick to honor their warranty.  My past experience with other companies and their warranties has been poor; there always seems to be a reason to say "no".  Moen was not like that.The new spout is made of plastic, is much lighter than the old spout, and the internal design is a bit different.  After reading reviews, I understand why: The hysteria over tiny amounts of lead in faucets, and laws passed by California and other States prohibiting lead. I think there needs to be a sensible approach to safety versus practicality, but that no longer exists in our society.  The extremists have won, and safety at any cost is now the norm.Another difference with the new spout is the color or sheen. It doesn't exactly match the faucet base or handle, but it is close enough. From a distance, you can't tell.  Up close, you can tell it is different.  Good enough for me.  The spray button works well. It seems that the faucet needs less water pressure to activate the sprayer, which is good.I am still pleased with my faucet. And I am very pleased with the warranty support that I received from Moen.

It is a large faucet, which is what I wanted for the single bowl kitchen sink. I was familiar with the Moen name, it looked good, had the features I wanted, and it came with a lifetime warranty.I was interested in a sleek, single handle faucet for ease of use when adjusting water temperature.  It's also easy to turn-on when your hands are dirty or full. I can use my fingers, wrist, or arm to lift the lever.The pull-out faucet works well.  It pulls-out far enough, and it returns to its base.  It is not like a tape measure, which retracts by itself.  You have to guide the flexible pipe and spout back into the faucet base. The seller was goHastings. I purchased 2 sets for a total of 20 bucks including shipping. That's 12 cones.The cones measure about 6.5 inches tall, 5 inches in diameter at the base, and about 1 inch in diameter at the top. They are stiff plastic, and good quality (about 1/16 inch thick).I purchased the cones as a gift to be used with a Redcat Racing Volcano EPX Electric Truck, Blue/Silver, 1/10 Scale.

The seller was Texas Corner Store. I paid 6 bucks including shipping.I am using this connector adapter with a Tenergy Universal Smart Charger, model 1025. The charger did not come a banana adapter, and I needed a banana adapter for my batteries.The female Tamiya connector on the cable fit the male Tamiya charger connector on the Tenergy charger perfectly. I've been feeding these dental treats to my dog for several years. The dog likes them. The treats appear to be healthy. The treats are green with white markings (the white markings make them look old, but each time I order, the expiration date is always a year or two in the future). He gets this treat 5 days a week.Good prices on Amazon, but... There are several package/quantity varieties of this item on Amazon, so look around on Amazon to find the best deal. The seller was Amazon Warehouse Deals. I paid 120 bucks including shipping. The item was marked "used--very good".There were some signs of prior use (scuffs on/under the front bumper, and some dust), but I would agree that the truck was in "very good" condition.  It looks like someone may have purchased it, tried it out,  didn't like it, and returned it to Amazon. All of the original items were there.I tried a few test runs.  The truck works well.  Forward, reverse, turning all work well.  The truck appears well made. The handheld remote control radio is well designed and responsive. I like that the radio and the truck receiver are already bound to each other. This truck is ready to run...just like it says; insert/charge batteries and go!As other folks  have noted, the receiver on the truck does not appear to be waterproof. On the Redcat Racing website, it says the receiver is "splashproof".Under the hood, there seems to be a good balance of metal versus plastic parts. Unless you plan to use this truck on very tough terrain or do stunts with it, it looks like it should hold-up well.I also like that you can purchase upgrades and replacement parts online...either at the Redcat Racing website, or at a dealer website, or on Amazon or eBay. To find a dealer in your area, visit the Redcat Racing website and click on "Find a Dealer".Based on another Amazon reviewer's suggestion, I replaced the stock plastic spur gear with a metal one: Redcat Racing 64T Steel Spur Gear 11184. It took a little doing, but it wasn't too tough. You'll need a Phillips screwdriver, a Flathead screwdriver (for the E clip), and a 2mm hex wrench (for the drive cup).While removing screws to install the metal spur gear, I noticed that there are at least 3 types of screw lengths and threads (even for screws on the under carriage).  So, if you do maintenance on it, I recommend grouping the screws together, so you know where they came from (when it comes time to reinstall them).I also adjusted the suspension on the front and rear, so that the truck will bottom-out if it hits the ground real hard. To hear why this is important, visit youtube and search for qIO6KwVOM4Y. Youtube user ramrod340x does a good job of explaining and showing how to adjust the suspension.  It's also easy to do.It came with a 7.2v 2000mAh battery.  I upgraded the battery to a Redcat Racing HX-3800MH-B 3800 Ni-MH Battery-7.2V with Banana Connector.I purchased some Duratrax Kwik Trak Racing Cones (6-Piece).I purchased a better charger, since the "travel charger" that was included with the truck seemed cheap and other reviewers complained that it didn't last long.  Here is the better charger: Tenergy Universal Smart Charger for NiMH/NiCd Battery Packs (6V - 12V). The Tenergy charger does NOT come with banana connectors, so I also had to buy this: Redcat Racing ST-TAMFTO4B Version 4.0 Female Tamiya to Banana Adapter.I also purchased a Tactic 4-Cell AA Battery Holder with Futaba J Connector. The receiver and controller that come with a new truck are already bound together. The only reason to use this item is to bind a different/replacement receiver or hand-held controller. During the bind process, this battery pack should be plugged into the VCC slot on the receiver. For additional instructions on how to bind a receiver and controller, see the quick start guide in the first comment to this review.Minus 1 star because the owners manual and instructions are poor. There is nothing to tell me what the controls on the handheld remote do (or what the abbreviations mean). Although I don't need to bind the radio to the receiver, there are no instructions on how to do that. What are the extra items for? (5-inch tube--for antenna, shock spring spacers, bind plug/control) And there is no explanation of how to charge the battery (e.g., how long? what does the LED indicator on the charger mean? etc.). How do you turn-on the truck? The on/off switch is somewhat hidden and black in color. Simple stuff, unless you are new to RC. I can usually figure out stuff on my own, or I check online; but when I give this as a gift to someone who is new to RC, then I have to provide additional help (or write-up my own documentation).For people who are new to RC, or who are giving this truck to someone else as a gift...I created my own quick start guide using OpenOffice Writer. The guide includes instructions that are specific to my gift, so not everything is applicable to a brand new truck. For example, I purchased extra batteries, a quality charger, extra body clips, and 4-cell AA battery pack in case the owner wants to bind a different receiver/controller to the truck.  To download my quick start guide, see the first comment to this review.  After downloading it, you can use OpenOffice to change it to meet your needs.Overall, I am pleased with my purchase.  This is a Christmas gift for a boy age 11.The truck also comes in red:Redcat Racing Electric Volcano EPX Truck, Red

The seller was Bike Towne. I paid about 10 bucks including shipping.My old chain was still okay, but after almost 20 years of casual biking, I decided it was time to change it.  I measured the old chain to determine how much it may have stretched; thankfully, it hadn't stretched (or at least it didn't stretch enough to be noticeable to me). To remove the old chain, I just broke it with pliers.The new KMC chain was lightly oiled.  It was longer than my original chain; a coworker who has bike tools was kind enough to shorten it for me; it was easy for him to remove the excess chain with the tool he had.The new chain was very easy to install. I threaded it onto the cassette and the rear derailleurs, and then attached the master link. The master link fit so easily that I did not have to step on the pedal to lock it into place. My mountain bike is a 21 speed (7 gears in the back, 3 in the front).Time will tell if the chain will hold-up as well as my prior chain. I'll update this review again as needed.

The seller was GRPerks. I paid about 16 bucks including shipping.I had 2 old folding hex sets, but they were only SAE/inches and they only had 8-9 wrenches per set (and most of the sizes were the same between the two of them).I wanted a set that had both SAE and metric, and a set that had most sizes...at a reasonable price.  This set fits the bill.  The quality is good too.So far, I have used the 2mm wrench to successfully remove a nut that was way too tight.  I had to put quite a bit of pressure on the 2mm wrench, but thankfully it did not bend.  It also fit the nut perfectly.The other wrenches appear to be shaped/cut well too.  The case is heavy duty and very handy; the wrenches stay in their slots.I am pleased with my purchase.  And because there is a good selection of sizes for both SAE and metric, I don't think I'll need to buy another hex set!  I'll give my old hex sets to my local charity.

I purchased a Quik Stik in 1995 from a local bike shop, and it still works great. When installing a tire, the Quik Stik makes it easy to pop the last bit of tire over the rim.  When removing a tire, I use tire levers.The Quik Stik has saved me a lot of frustration!

The seller was Amazon. I paid 48 bucks for each tire including shipping.  I purchased 2 tires.I purchased this tire along with two other items...to upgrade my old bike.  My goal was to make my tires as flat-free as possible. This tire has "smartguard", which is about 5mm thick; add that to the  rubber that is above and below the smartguard, and that means there is about 8-9mm between the road and the tube.There are goathead weeds in my area, and they flatten tires real fast.  I don't rely on this tire as my only defense.  I also purchased a quality tire liner: Mr. Tuffy Bicycle Tire Liner.  And I purchased quality tubes: 2 x Schwalbe Inner Tubes - 26" x 1.50 to 2.50 - Schrader/Auto Valve - PAIR - FREE VALVE CAP UPGRADE [No. AV13].Between the tire and the tire liner, there is about 10-11mm of barrier between my tube and the road.  That's enough to keep the goat heads out.Slime doesn't work for me--it just clogs the tube value; and after a while, Slime dries and clumps inside the tube, making it useless.The tire was easy to install. I have tire levers and a Quik Stik Tire Changer.  The Quik Stik makes it easy to pop the last bit of tire over the rim.I'm happy with my purchase, and I'm looking forward to a future with no flats!

The seller was Amazon. I paid 17 bucks including shipping.I purchased Tuffy Tire Liner along with two other items...to upgrade my old bike.  The liner is about 2mm thick.There are goathead weeds in my area, and they flatten tires real fast.  I don't rely on this liner as my only defense.  I also purchased a quality tire that has a 7-8mm barrier: Schwalbe 26X1.75 Marathon Plus Rlx Wire Tire.  And I purchased quality tubes: 2 x Schwalbe Inner Tubes - 26" x 1.50 to 2.50 - Schrader/Auto Valve - PAIR - FREE VALVE CAP UPGRADE [No. AV13].Between the tire and the tire liner, there is about 9-10mm of barrier between my tube and the road.  That's enough to keep the goat heads out.Slime doesn't work for me--it just clogs the tube value; and after a while, Slime dries and clumps inside the tube, making it useless.The liner was easy to install: Since I bought new tires and tubes, I waited until everything arrived and install everything at once. I unrolled the liner along the inside of the tire, and overlapped the ends.  Then I inserted a partially inflated tube to hold the liner in place.  Lastly, I carefully placed the tire on the wheel rim.I'm happy with my purchase, and I'm looking forward to a future with no flats!

The seller was Skyscape Cycle Co. I paid 20 bucks including shipping.Things I like about these tubes:* thick rubber* tall valve (about 1.5 inches tall)* valve nut* hold air well* good connection between value and tubeThe valve nut is good, because it keeps the value secure on the rim; the nut prevents the valve from pushing back into the rim/tube when I place the pump on the value.The tubes came with clear plastic valve caps.  However, the seller included 2 metal value caps for free, and they fit just fine...very nice.When installing a tube, I inflated the tube to a low PSI (enough so it would hold its shape), and then placed it between the rim and tire.  If you try to install the tube deflated, then it could get caught between the rim and tire (and then it might pop when you inflate it).My bike was old, so I also upgraded my tire and added tire liner when I installed the new tubes.  Here is what I used for tire and tire liner:Schwalbe 26X1.75 Marathon Plus Rlx Wire TireMr. Tuffy Bicycle Tire LinerI'm happy with my purchase.

The seller was Amazon. I paid 229 bucks. I purchased the set 9 months ago.The set arrived well packaged; nothing was damaged; everything looked good.My prior cookware set was a cheap $40 non-stick set. It worked fine for many years. However, as with all non-stick surfaces, the non-stick part wears-off over time (no matter how careful I am). So, this time, I wanted a cookware set that would NOT wear-out over time.  After researching my options (ceramic, anodized, cast iron, cooper, etc.), I decided on stainless steel.After researching several stainless steels brands, I settled on this Cuisinart set.  There is a cheaper version of this Cuisinart set, but it got bad reviews, because it was too thin.I am very pleased with the weight of this set. It has worked very well for me.I did have to change my cooking habits, but that's fine.  Here is what I changed:1) Use lower heat2) Preheat the cookware3) Use oil when cookingAs long as I follow the above 3 habits, I don't have a problem with sticking.There is a way to season stainless steel cookware; do an internet search to find it.  I tried it once for one of the pans, and it worked. But I don't use my pans regularly enough to season them. I usually cook enough of a dish to last me 2 weeks.Depending on how careful you are (and how thorough you are with cleaning), the cookware may discolor over time.  The instructions provide a way to clean the pans when they become soiled (boiling water for several minutes with a certain amount of dishwasher detergent). There is also a cleaner that you can buy (like bar keepers friend). Discoloring of the bottom (inside or outside) does not impair cooking ability.I also like the fact that scratches don't impair cooking ability. And no more non-stick surface to erode over time.  Very nice.  The set is dishwasher and oven safe.I am pleased with my purchase. As long as I don't accidentally leave a piece on a hot stove, it should last me for the rest of my life.
