I purchased this from Walmart (ordered online and shipped to my local store for free).  I paid 19 bucks.The plastic is tough and thick.My washer is 25.5" deep by 27" wide.  I installed it so the 32" side was front-to-back, so there were several extra inches of drip pan in the back (to catch any potential drips from the hoses where they connect to the washer).Regarding width, after installing, there is still about 1" of extra room on one side and 1.25" on the other side.I was able to install it by myself.  I pulled the washer forward, then tilted it forward and placed some bricks in the back left corner under the washer.  Then I tilted the washer back toward the wall, and slid the drain pan underneath.  Then I tilted the washer forward and worked it toward me (back/forth slowly).  Then I removed the bricks.  Finally, I slid the washer (now fully on the pan) into place and made some minor adjustments to center it.I did not install the PVC pipe fitting.  My purpose for the drip pan is to catch a slow drip, if one develops in the future.  I turn-off the water spigots in the wall after I use the washer, so that keeps pressure off the hoses unless I'm actively using the machine.The walls of the drip pan are not straight up/down; the sides/corners are rounded and they do flare a little.  So, inside measurements are about 29" wide by 31" deepI'm very pleased with my purchase.

The seller was Amazon.  I paid 109 bucks.This replaces a Sears Craftsman gas mower 6.5 horsepower (mulching or bag); I mulch my lawn.I narrowed my search to the following push reel mowers:American Lawn Mower 1815-18 18-InchGreat States 815-18 18-Inch DeluxeThese 2 mowers are identical, except for their name, model #, color, etc.They are made by the same company (American Lawn Mower).Maximum cutting height is 2.75 inches.Made in China.Fiskars 17-Inch StaySharp (6208)Fiskars 17-Inch StaySharp Plus (6207)Fiskars 18-Inch StaySharp Max (6201)Fiskars was too expensive.Maximum cutting height is 3.5 inches for the 6208, and 4 inches for the others.Parts are not available online, but available under warranty if you call Fiskars.The "max" model has an internal chain, which can wear over time.Made in China.McLane 17-PH-7 17-Inch 7-Blade Front-ThrowMcLane was too expensive.Maximum cutting height is 2.5 inches.Made in the USA.Some key features of the Scotts 2000-20:* Maximum cutting height is 3 inches.* 20-inch blade.* Width measured from wheel-to-wheel (outer edge) is 26.5 inches.* Parts are available online from American Lawn Mower at reasonable price.* Shipping for parts is also reasonable.* For online manual and parts, visit www reelin dot com* Made for Scotts by the American Lawn Mower Company.* Made in China.Other notes about my yard and the Scotts 2000-20:All parts are metal except for the wheels, wing nuts knobs, and wheel gears.  The wheel tires are rubber, and the wheel rims are plastic.  The wing nuts knobs are plastic, but there is a metal nut inside; this was no different than my Craftsman.  The wheel gears (inside each large wheel) are plastic, but it is a thick/sturdy plastic.I like the 2 small wheels on the back (instead of rollers, which some reel mowers use).  The handle is sturdy (it does not flex when I push the mower).My grass type is a blend of Kentucky Bluegrass and Perennial Rye; I live in the northwest USA.  I keep my grass "high" all season.  So, with the Scotts, I have the mower set to 3 inches (the maximum cutting height).  I keep my lawn weeded, so I am mowing grass...not weeds.  I mow once a week.  I try not to overwater, and I use a fall fertilizer the entire season (19-4-4); this helps keep the lawn healthy, but prevents it from growing too quickly).My front lawn is about 600 square feet, and my back lawn is about 800 square feet.  It takes me less than 30 minutes to do my entire lawn, which is about the same as my gas mower.  In most cases, I can mow my lawn in one pass.Most of my lawn is bordered by pavement or by cobble stones, so that makes it easy to edge (I straddle the mower over the lawn/pavement and over the lawn/cobble stones).I do have trees and shrubs in the front yard and several trees in the back yard...all bordered by cobble stone.  The border around the trees and shrubs is circular.  It's easy to mow around the circle.  The Honey Locust trees sometimes drop small, thin twigs; the mower grids them just fine.My yard has corners, nooks, smaller strips, circular areas, etc.  I have no problem maneuvering the Scotts around my yard.When I first received the Scotts, I thought the blades were too tight, so I loosened them (and tested them by slicing pieces of paper with the blades).  The adjustment was easy to do; a small wrench is included with the mower (or you can use your own wrench or a large flathead screw driver).Sharpening the cutting bar (blade) is easy to do (i.e., backlapping).  Remove both wheels, reverse both gears, replace the wheels, place grinding compound on the reel blades, run the mower up/down your driveway several times, wipe off the excess compound, remove both wheels, reverse both gears, replace the wheels, done.  Here is some valve grinding compound available on Amazon: Permatex 80037 Valve Grinding Compound, 3 oz...about 5 bucks.Alternately, you could buy the American Lawn Mower SK-1 Reel Mower Sharpening Kit, but why pay extra for it?A Scotts owner posted a video showing how to maintain the mower, including how to disassemble and reassemble the Scotts; go to YouTube and search for: oEePHETPZhEI'm very pleased with my purchase.I'm happy to sell my gas mower; things I won't miss about my gas mower: gas, oil, air filter, spark plug, noise, fumes, changing the oil, winterizing it, sharpening the mulching blade (couldn't do that myself), the smoke when I first ran it at the beginning of each season.keyword: maintenance, measurement, square footage, size

This DVD started with war footage.  There was no attempt at the history of Korea (you hear about the 38th parallel, but no history behind it).  What was Korea like before the war?  I don't know.  I just know that the Commies came from the north, and the United Nations came from the South, and there was a war in Korea.  Disappointing.The footage is mostly black-and-white.  The sound/narration is fine, but the veteran interviews are muffled.  There are rudimentary maps/diagrams...nothing helpful.The narrator exaggerated several times, which led me to doubt other things he said.  For example, "the soldiers fought for every step of ground".  And while saying that, they showed a bunch of soldiers walking down a road.  They certainly weren't fighting for every step.The narrator was professional, but the narration was not very informative.  Sometimes the narration did not match the footage.  Most of the time, the footage was random, short war clips strung together.  What was actually happening in the footage?  I don't know.  The narrator just kept telling the Korean War story...sometimes without regard to the footage itself.I am still looking for a well-round documentary about the Korean War.  I had the same problem while looking for a decent documentary about the Vietnam War, but I eventually found this excellent documentary: Vietnam - A Television History.  Maybe there is something like it for the Korean War, but I haven't found it yet.Visit my Amazon wish lists to see my 4-star and 5-star military/war DVDs:http://www.amazon.com/gp/registry/wishlist/3DU5CH5ZFWRNI/http://www.amazon.com/gp/registry/wishlist/24H8TDYHFDOET/

The seller was Amazon. I paid 50 bucks.I'm using the G600 on a PC with Windows XP Home SP3; the Logitech Gaming Software (LGS) version is 8.45.88.  The firmware version is 77.02.17.  I'm also using the G600 on a PC with Windows 10 Technical Preview with LGS version 8.57.145.Several years ago, I switched from a regular 3-button mouse to a Logitech G700. It took some time to get used to the G700, but I liked the G700 very much. The same is true for the switch from G700 to G600. It takes a little time to get used to it, but it is worth it.I do like lots of buttons on my mouse for flexibility in Windows applications, browser, and games.  I don't always use every button, but I have the flexibility to do so.WEIGHTThe G700 with battery (can't run it without the battery installed) weighs 6 ounces.  The G600 weighs 5 ounces.  I've heard some people complain about how heavy the G600 is, but I don't have any problem with the weight, because my prior mouse was a G700 (which is 1 ounce heavier).SIZEI measured both mice across the top over the scroll wheel area. The G700 measures 6 centimeters; and the G600 measures 7 cm.  Not much difference, considering the G600 adds a third button along the right side.SCROLL WHEELBoth mice have a tilt scroll wheel with 3 buttons built in (middle click, left tilt, right tilt). I like the wheel tilt feature very much. The G700 wheel is metallic on its sides and rubber down its middle; you can set it to have smooth rolling or notched. The G600 is all rubber; you can not set it to smooth rolling...it's notched and that's it. I like notched, so it is not a problem for me.BUTTON CLICKSWhen clicked/pressed, the tactical feel of the G9-G20 buttons (the 12 buttons on the left side) on the G600 is like the G11 button on the G700.  The G600 G7-G8 buttons sound/feel like the G700 G9 button.  The left, middle, right, scroll tilt buttons on the G600 feel the same as their counterparts on the G700. I don't have to press G600 thumb buttons as hard (compared to G700), and the thumb buttons on the G600 take less pressure to actuate.G-SHIFT BUTTONI like this button a lot. It doubles the function of all mouse buttons except left click, right click, G8, and the G-Shift button itself.  So, the mouse has 20 buttons, and with the G-Shift, the mouse now has 36 button options.  Lots of flexibility.  Very nice.  If you reassign left click to another button, then you can use the left click button with G-Shift (same for right click).  For G8, if you use it with the G-Shift, then you can assign 2 functions to it, but you lose the mode switching ability for that profile.If you don't like the G-Shift button, then you can unassign it, and assign another function to that button.  You can always get it back by dragging/dropping the G-Shift function from the commands list/menu to the button.GRIPWith my fingers together, my hand measures about 8.25 inches around...just below the knuckles, which makes my glove size a medium. The G600 feels very nice to me. Because it glides so easily, and because of its shape, I find that I don't have to grip it as hard as the G700...and that's easier on my hand.On the thumb side of the mouse...The mouse glides very well. I can rest my thumb on the side buttons and move the mouse around easily without actually pressing the side buttons. Sometimes I rest my thumb just beyond or below the G9 button. Either works well for me...depends on what I am using the mouse for.On the ring/pinky finger side of the mouse...This took a little getting used to, but it works well. Again, two choices: If I am not using the G-shift button, then I can rest my ring finger along the side of the button. However, I do like the G-shift button, so I rest my ring finger on top of it. My pinky finger grips the mouse on the right side. Since the mouse is lighter (compared to the G700), using my pinky finger to grip and help with movement is not a problem for me. The bottom edge of this side of the mouse is rubber, which helps to grip it. Does your pinky hurt? Give it a chance. Your muscles will adjust.Depends on how you use your mouse...In games, instead of using the traditional W-S-A-D keys for movement, I use mouse buttons. I started doing this with the G700, using the wheel tilt for left/right, G7 forward, G6 back, G7 plus G5 forward sprint/run. This makes movement much more natural in my opinion.  For the G600, it's similar: wheel tilt for left/right, G11 forward, G20 back, G11 plus G10 forward sprint/run. Since I am usually walking or running forward, I am gripping the mouse with my thumb most of the time. When not gripping the mouse in this way, I grip it with the area of my palm below my thumb (or just beyond the G9 button). This works well for me.TRACKING, POLLING/REPORT RATE, DPIFor the G700, I used 1000 DPI and 250 for report rate.  For the G600, I am using the same settings. The mouse tracks very well for me; this is probably a combination of mouse quality and PC configuration.LOGITECH GAMING SOFTWARE (LGS)I used this same software for my G700, so it is nothing new to me. Same software, except the screens are different in order to support the additional/different features of the G600. I recommend using "automatic game detection", not on-board memory (this setting is on the home page of the LGS; it's a toggle switch). While using the G700, I switched from Setpoint software to LGS, and I noticed that onboard memory did not work well (it was fine with Setpoint, just not LGS). For the G600, I didn't even try on-board memory, since "automatic game detection" works so well for me.MODES VS. PROFILESI use automatic game detection for both G700 and G600, which means unlimited profiles and no hassles with profile switching...works well for me.  For the G600, there are also modes.  So, for each profile, you can have up to 3 modes...each mode has its own button configuration. Here is how this is helpful to me... Game #1: The main character has two movement options: human, which is used most of the time; mechanized armor/tank, which is used occasionally. The controls are different for each. So, I have 1 profile for the game with 2 modes (one for the human, one for the armor/tank). Press the mode switch button (G8 or whatever you want to set it to) and I can easily switch between human and armor/tank settings.  Very nice.CORDThe G700 cord is rubber coated. The G600 cord is less thick and braided nylon. Both work fine. The G700 cord showed no signs of wear after 3+ years of use.  Wait and see with the G600 cord.LIGHTSThe G700 has 3 lights on the side to indicate what profile you are using (if you use onboard profiles, which I don't). The G600 is a regular Christmas tree...each of the G9-G20 buttons are backlit, and there are lots of color and lighting options. Very nice, if you're into that sort of thing. I'm not, so I disabled the lighting effect.SOME GOTCHASGOTCHA #1Converting profiles from the G700 to the G600.  These 2 mice have different buttons, so don't expect to plug-and-play. Although you can see the G700 profiles in the LGS when the G600 is plugged in, you cannot use the G700 profile successfully unless you remap all keys to the G600. It's easy to do. All of the commands associated with a profile are listed in the commands menu area in LGS (on the left side of the screen). Drag and drop the commands from the commands menu to the G600 buttons and you're ready to go.  If you are permanently switching from G700 to G600, remapping existing profiles is fine. If you plan to use both mice interchangeably, then rename the G700 profiles to have G700 in the name, and copy/save-as the G700 profiles to G600 profiles and do the remapping; so, you'll have 2 sets of profiles...one for G700 and one for G600.GOTCHA #2Setting or assigning commands to the normal and G-shift buttons. "Normal" means the normal use of a button without using the G-shift button. ALWAYS drag and drop commands from the command menu on the left side of the "customize buttons" screen to the mouse button on the right side of the screen. NEVER use the little drop down menu for each button to edit commands; it's okay to use the drop down menu to unassign, use generic, use default. If you don't follow this advice, then when you attempt to edit commands for G-shift buttons, you will overwrite the normal button assignment with the G-shift assignment. It's just a quirky software thing. To create new commands, use the plus sign next to the word "Commands".GOTCHA #3By default, the mouse wheel tilt buttons are assigned to back and forward; and this works great when working with Windows applications and browsers.  However, some people like me had the problem of the G600 going back twice or going forward two times when only clicking the tilt button once (i.e., double click problem). In Windows XP, the solution is to go to Control Panel, System, Hardware tab, Device Manager button, expand Mouse, double-click each "HID-compatible mouse" device to find the one that says "on Logitech gaming Virtual Mouse", and then right click that device and disable it. This solved the problem.keywords: gotchyas, bugs, buggy, problems, answers, fixes, solutions, G700s, hurts, painfulSUMMARYI am very happy with the G600, but I haven't used it for very long.  I hope to get many years of use out of it.  I plan to update this review as needed, if I experience problems.

This documentary describes lots of history about how the national park system came into being (and some history of certain individual parks), but it does NOT provide much detail about any particular park (and that was disappointing). The producer attempts to divide the DVD series by time periods that are relevant to the national park system.======================Stuff I liked...======================* beautiful photography* lots of historical information about how the parks came into being* professional narration* music, sound effects======================Stuff I did NOT like...======================* not enough photography of the parks* repetitive photography* too many talking heads (just show me the parks while they talk, I don't need to see them)* photos with no identifiers (give me captions, what am I looking at?)* some scenes and narration were repeated (like the "Just Americans" part)* the "special features" were mostly repeats of episode photography with no narration* it jumps around way too much* too much history, not enough about the parks themselvesThe DVD series jumps back-and-forth from park-to-park in many different episodes, and shows similar photography of each park in the various episodes. The lack of focus on various topics and parks is annoying. For example, Hetch Hetchy is discussed several times on different DVDs, instead of discussing the entire story in one episode. Another example is the description of Rockefeller buying-up land in Jackson. Just when you think they are done describing something, then one or two DVDs later they talk about it again (repeating some of what was said previously, and adding a bit more info).4-stars, if you are expecting a documentary about national park system history.2-stars, if you are expecting a documentary about the parks themselves.

The seller was GW Security Inc. I paid 2 bucks. They shipped fast, and they included a tracking #.The BNC female end fit perfectly with my existing BNC cable.The RCA male end fit perfectly with my existing RCA cable.It seems well made, and it works.

I have used the following brands (or their generics): Gum, and Johnson & Johnson Reach.  Oral-B Glide floss (or a similar store brand/generic version) is the best.  It is a ribbon that slides/glides easily between my teeth.  Some of my lower teeth are very close together, but Glide does the job on those teeth perfectly.  So, my gums don't bleed, the floss does not get stuck/break in my teeth, it does not fray, and I can spend time actually FLOSSING (i.e., gently working the floss back/forth between my teeth to remove debris).  Since it does not fray or break, I end up using less floss.  Now I enjoy flossing!THE COMPETITIONGum floss was thin.  It not only frayed quickly, but broken in my teeth right away.  I tried regular Gum floss, not the butter-weave version.  The labeling on both versions of Gum floss make the same claims: strong, slides easily between tightly spaced teeth.  Not true...not for me.Johnson & Johnson Reach is a thicker floss, it was difficult to get between some of my teeth, it also frayed after flossing a few teeth; and when it broke, it was uncomfortable and difficult to remove from between my teeth.  I have used Johnson & Johnson Reach in the past, because it was cheap.  However, I do NOT like it.  It did not encourage me to floss.  For some of my tightly spaced teeth, I hate having to put so much pressure on the floss to get it between my teeth...then as it gets forced between my teeth, it slices into my gums, and that hurts and causes bleeding.  And when I pull the floss back out, it feels like my tooth might come out with the floss (only applies to my tightly spaced teeth).PRICEFor Glide floss, I am able to purchase the Equate store brand (generic) at Wal-Mart; it sells for about 4 bucks for a two-pack; each item in the pack is 40m (43.7 yards) for a total of 80m (87.5 yards) for the whole pack.  In comparison, Gum was 3.50 for 200 yards, Johnson & Johnson Reach was 1 buck for 50 yards, and the generic version of Johnson & Johnson Reach was 1 buck for 100 yards.  In comparison to the other brands of floss, Glide is expensive.However, I don't need to use as much Glide, because it doesn't break or fray (and because it slides easier between my teeth, which means I don't need to have a death grip on the floss itself).  Instead of needing about 18 inches of floss tightly wrapped around the fingers of both hands, about 12 inches of Glide works just fine for me.  So, using 1 foot per day at 87.5 yards means that one two-pack should last me almost 9 months. And that's pretty good for 4 bucks!

First, the good stuff...The bonus feature!  If you don't like the movie, don't just turn it off.  Watch the bonus feature.  It is about the battles of Verdun and Somme.  The footage is black-and-white.  The narrator does a good job.  The music is lousy at times, but most of it is okay for an old documentary. It is produced by CBS News, and it is 47 minutes long.  It is informative and has lots of WWI footage.Second, the bad stuff...The movie itself!  The movie is slow moving. I kept waiting for something to happen. There was only 3 minutes of fighting, which showed the soldier's running across a field and being gunned down; then the movie ends.  Not much fighting.  This movie is 1 hour 36 minutes long, but only the last 3 minutes involved fighting; the rest of the time was trench drama (i.e., conversations among the soldiers).American audiences may find the thick British accents and British colloquialisms hard to follow.This movie is NOT for kids. This film is not rated, but it would carry an "R" rating. There is liberal use of the f-bomb through the entire movie, adult humor, two disturbing war scenes/images (gore) plus the last 3 minutes, and one scene where soldiers are viewing a topless photo. The excessive foul language seemed out of place for the era; the director used late 20th century swearing in an early 20th century setting; it's not historically accurate.The movie lacks reality.  Pretty boys in a trench discussing inane crap.  All cleaner than a whistle. The trench was immaculate. Did you get a load of the battlefield above the trench? It looked like a farm yard in Yorkshire or something. Very little reality in this movie, and that was disappointing.Remember to watch the bonus feature!Visit my Amazon wish lists to see my 4-star and 5-star military/war DVDs:http://www.amazon.com/gp/registry/wishlist/3DU5CH5ZFWRNI/http://www.amazon.com/gp/registry/wishlist/24H8TDYHFDOET/

I wasn't sure what to expect. I was pleasantly surprised by this documentary. The modern day interviews/recollections of WWII German military men were very interesting and informative. The war footage was also exceptional (mostly black and white).The narrator was professional; and when there was music, it was appropriate.DVD episodes include:* Blitzkrieg* Luftwaffe* Waffen SS* U Boats* Russia - The Unholy War* Defending BerlinEach episode is about 50 minutes long (maybe 45 minutes, if you exclude the beginning/ending credits).This documentary reminded me of The Nazis: A Warning From History, which also included many interviews of WWII German military men.Visit my Amazon wish lists to see my 4-star and 5-star military/war DVDs:http://www.amazon.com/gp/registry/wishlist/3DU5CH5ZFWRNI/http://www.amazon.com/gp/registry/wishlist/24H8TDYHFDOET/

0:11 MinsAmazon was the seller. I purchased it "used - very good" for 55 bucks.I made 2 attempts to buy this item "used" from Amazon. During the first attempt, the item was previously damaged by the person who had returned it (and Amazon didn't notice the damage); but the Amazon return process was quick, easy, and free. The second attempt was a success.===========================INSTALLATION and MEASUREMENTS===========================It's pretty easy to put it together. The pieces are plastic, so they are light weight. The plastic seems sturdy enough. The instructions were good enough. One thing to be careful of is the pegs on the steps. When installing the steps and front panels. Do not twist the steps/panels from side-to-side. Press the pegs of the steps/panels straight into the large sides of the stairs. If you wiggle or bend the steps/panels from side-to-side, then the pegs may break-off (and that's what I had to return the first "used" item that I bought--the person before me broke the pegs on some of the front panels).If you have difficult pressing the pegs into the large sides of the stairs, then apply some oil or soap, and they will slide right in.You can google the instructions, or just visit the first comment to my review, where I posted a link to the instructions on the manufacturer's website.The carpet that covers the steps is thin, but it's adequate to keep the dog from slipping.Step Measurements:The top of each step: (not including the lip of the large side panels on either side of the step)* all steps:13.5 inches wide* top step: 9.5 inches deep* bottom 3 steps: about 8.75 inches deep* front part of each step: about 6 inches tallThe lip of the two large side panels adds about 2 inches total to the width of the steps (i.e., one inch on each side of the step).The steps are not level/flat (by design); the steps are angled up (if viewed when walking up the steps).Overall Staircase Measurements:The back/tallest part is about 30.5 inches tall.It is about 33.5 inches deep.It is about 15.5 inches wide.================PERFORMANCE================I got these stairs for my Chihuahua as a toy. I live next to a park and my fence is only 4 feet tall. When he hears people in the park, he runs outside along the fence and barks for a bit, but he can't see what he is barking at. So, I thought it would be fun for him to see what is in the park. This way he can associate sounds to sights.Dog weight wasn't an issue for me. And my dog doesn't have arthritis or something. I got the 4-step version of this product for height (so my dog could see out the window and over the fence). I added a small barrier around the top step (so my dog didn't get the feeling that he would fall off the other side); I just took some cardboard and wedged it between the top step and the large side panels. Usually the dining table isn't next to the window (just for starting seeds/plants for a vegetable garden).He was nervous about using it for 4 days or so. I placed treats on each stair step, and eventually he made it all the way to the top.I used to say "wanna see?" and then offer to lift him up, so that he could see what was happening in the park. As part of his training to use the steps, when there was someone in the park, I would tell him "wanna see?" and then point to the steps. That was his cue to use the steps.At about 10 days or so, he learned to use the steps himself when he heard a noise in the park.  After a couple of months, it became one of his favorite places (to sit in the sun light, and to watch what happens in the park).

This series had promise, and I was looking forward to it. But for me, it fell short. Here are some of my observations after watching the first 2 DVDs in the series:Complaining. And more complaining. Whining. And more whining. Drama. Sometimes lots of drama. That's not my idea of the regular military or National Guard, but that's what this series portrays. Why not just do your duty without the groaning, moaning, and griping?What is the main reason why people join the National Guard? Is it just to make an extra buck? Sounds like it to me.One guardsman held up a handmade sign that said "what happened to 1 weekend a month and 2 weeks a year?" When you join the National Guard, don't you know that you could be called to active duty? Didn't these guys know that?"Ask not what you can do for your country. Ask what your country can do for you!" That's the impression I got from most of the guardsmen in the series.Why are people allowed to be in the National Guard if they are not deploy-able? It doesn't make sense.If your marriage is rocky, then a deployment won't help it. More drama.Some of the guardsmen didn't have their facts straight:Iraq didn't attack or invade the USA.Iraq didn't cause 9/11.Some of the guardsmen likened their Iraq situation to the Vietnam War. None of those guardsmen were in Vietnam. Those 2 wars were very different.The religious people and their church drama were awful. It reminded me of the religious people and synagogues that Christ encountered when He walked the planet. They were showy, glitzy, trivial, carnal, fake, ungodly; they did things to impress the people around them.For any given episode (there are 3 episodes per DVD), roughly half of an episode is about the guardsmen in Iraq, and the other half of the episode is about the life of their loved ones back home.After watching the first 2 DVDs, I didn't care enough about the series to watch the last 2 DVDs.This program shows a small cross-section of society. Folks in the National Guard come from all walks of life, but you wouldn't know that from this program. I think this program does the National Guard a disservice, which is a shame.Visit my Amazon wish lists to see my 4-star and 5-star military/war DVDs:http://www.amazon.com/gp/registry/wishlist/3DU5CH5ZFWRNI/http://www.amazon.com/gp/registry/wishlist/24H8TDYHFDOET/

I really enjoyed WWII in HD, so I was looking forward to "Vietnam in HD"."Vietnam in HD" starts with 1964. The USA went to war to kill commies. That's just about as much history as you get. The rest is war footage. The lack of history prior to 1964 was disappointing to me.Unlike "WWII in HD", the footage in "Vietnam in HD" was produced more like a movie than a documentary. It seemed like its purpose was more to entertain than to educate. This was also disappointing to me.At the end of the Battle of Inchon episode, they described that battle as a triumph and huge success for USA forces. Really? That screamed propaganda to me. That was about 50 minutes into DVD #1. Based on the footage and narration, it was not a huge success.Things I liked about this DVD:* veteran interviews* lots of war footage (mostly in color)* narrator* well organized (by year)Things I did NOT like about this DVD:* Lack of history* The music was too much like a military recruiting video.* Produced like a movie, not a documentary* For the most part, they used young voice actors for recounting war events (they should have used the veterans).The point of this DVD is to show color footage of the war. Don't expect a thorough historical documentary.The one telltale phrase that stuck with me went something like this: The Vietnamese have been battling foreign invaders for over 1000 years.If you want to learn about Vietnam before/during/after (i.e., some real history about the country and the war), then I highly recommend Vietnam - A Television History.Visit my Amazon wish lists to see my 4-star and 5-star military/war DVDs:http://smile.amazon.com/gp/registry/wishlist/3DU5CH5ZFWRNI/http://smile.amazon.com/gp/registry/wishlist/24H8TDYHFDOET/

This DVD started with war footage.  Then there was a very brief attempt at the history of Korea.  Then the war footage continued.  What was Korea like before the war?  I don't know.  I just know that the Commies came from the north, and the USA came from the South, and there was a war in Korea.  Disappointing.The footage is black-and-white, but mostly washed-out white, which makes it difficult to watch.The sound/narration starts-out muffled, but it got better quickly.The narrator was professional, and the narration was somewhat informative.  However, for the most part, the narration did not match the footage.  Most of the time, the footage was random, short war clips strung together.  What was actually happening in the footage?  I don't know.  The narrator just kept telling the Korean War story without regard to the footage itself.  The footage of Inchon seemed to match the narration, but that was not the norm for this documentary.I am still looking for a well-round documentary about the Korean War.  I had the same problem while looking for a decent documentary about the Vietnam War, but I eventually found this excellent documentary: Vietnam - A Television History.  Maybe there is something like it for the Korean War, but I haven't found it yet.UPDATE 6/29/15I found a well-round Korean War documentary; here it is: Korea The Forgotten War - 4 DVD Set.Visit my Amazon wish lists to see my 4-star and 5-star military/war DVDs:http://www.amazon.com/gp/registry/wishlist/3DU5CH5ZFWRNI/http://www.amazon.com/gp/registry/wishlist/24H8TDYHFDOET/

I watched Dunkirk and part of Norway on the first DVD. Then I turned it off. The narrator was a bit sensational at times, and boring at other times. The music didn't fit. The footage is not in color; instead, it is black-and-white footage that has been colorized. They jumped from one battle to another without telling the full story of the war.What led up to WWII?  How did WWII start?  What role did Russia play? None of these questions are answered. And why would they start a 5-DVD set with Dunkirk? Is that where the war started? Then they skip to Norway. Why? What about Austria, Czechoslovakia, and Poland? Those countries are only mentioned briefly. It makes no sense. And it gives people a very convoluted impression of the war.This reminds me of the kind of WWII documentaries that some of teachers used to show kids in elementary school or high school...the kind of documentaries where I do not learn about the war at all...instead, I just get glimpses of certain war events with limited explanation. It's the kind of documentary that leaves kids confused about WWII, not wanting to learn more.If you are a glutton for punishment and still want to buy this DVD set, then you may also be interested in another version of this DVD set on Amazon: WWII Battlefront (Tin Can Collection). However, I recommend that you rent it before buying it.There are several WWII documentaries that are much better than this one. Want to know what they are?Visit my Amazon wish lists to see my 4-star and 5-star military/war DVDs:http://www.amazon.com/gp/registry/wishlist/3DU5CH5ZFWRNI/http://www.amazon.com/gp/registry/wishlist/24H8TDYHFDOET/

The seller was ValuePetSupplies. I paid 75 bucks.My 8-pound Chihuahua dog usually eats one in about 20 minutes.  It is something natural for him to chew-on, and it  helps to keep tartar and plaque down.  I give one to him a couple times a week.  He liked most of these (got through 50 of them over time), but he got sick on some of them.  I thought maybe it was because they were too rich/fatty; but the last time he got sick, it was like food poisoning.  So, I stopped giving them to him.These sticks don't smell much when they are dry (in the bag); but when my dog starts chewing on one, then it really stinks. My dog was eating one in my bedroom one evening, and I had to escort him into the living room. After he finished, he joined me in the bedroom again. His breath was bad due to the stick. So, my lesson learned was: Don't give these bully sticks to my dog shortly before bed (since he sleeps with me, and I don't want bully stick breath in my bed!).They don't leave residue on the carpet or furniture, but if your dog eats them on carpet/furniture, then the bad smell will remain in it (dog's saliva + bully stick = stink).The package says they come from Brazil. You can also buy these directly from Value Pet Supplies; just Google their name, and visit their website; they have free shipping too.I used to get 6" BULLY STICKS - Free Range Standard Regular Thick Select 6 inch (10 Pack), by Downtown Pet Supply before they raised their prices. These are not as smelly as the ValueBull sticks, but they do cost more.For further dental care, I also use the following item in my dog's water: Pet Dental Liquid Tartar Remover Liquid 16 Fl OZ or V-Oratene Drinking Water Additive 4 oz. For variety, I also feed him Nylabone Nutri Dent Edible Dental Chew, 36 Count Extra Value Pack, and he likes those a lot too.Another healthy treat that my dog likes is Himalayan Chews, Dog Chew Treat Made of Yak Milk (Large). The best price I could find for those chews is at a place called New Puppy Pads. Pet Expertise also had good prices. Both retailers sell them on Amazon, eBay, or their own websites.

The seller was Amazon. I paid about 2 bucks. My sole use for this item is to clean tough stains in my toilet. I don't use it often, but when I do, it comes in very handy. I highly recommend it for this purpose.

The focus of this documentary is Germany (before, during, and after WWII). It contains color and black/white footage, much of which I had not seen before. It also reveals history about Germany, Hitler, and the Nazis that I was not aware of.The narration is very well done. The music is fine.One of the highlights of this documentary is the many interviews with German people as well as interviews Jewish people and other European people who were impacted by Hitler.My only complaint is that it seemed to end abruptly; I think they could have spent a little more time on the suicide of Hitler and those with him.Although there are only 2 DVDs to this set, it contains a wealth of information.  Very well done.Visit my Amazon wish lists to see my 4-star and 5-star military/war DVDs:http://www.amazon.com/gp/registry/wishlist/3DU5CH5ZFWRNI/http://www.amazon.com/gp/registry/wishlist/24H8TDYHFDOET/

The seller was JetAudio. I paid 249 bucks for this item in October 2004. I posted this review to epinions long ago, but they are shutting down, so I thought I'd share it on Amazon too.I debated between the 512MB and the 1GB units, but finally decided on the 1GB unit because I felt the extra 512MB was worth another $50; so, instead of being able to store about 8 hours of mp3 music, I can store 16 hours of mp3 music with the 1GB model (which is much more than I'll need, but it will keep me from deleting songs so that I can add new songs; this way, I can keep all the songs I like without having to add/delete).The quality is very good. Here are some points:1) Be careful opening the battery compartment; be sure to just slide the compartment open a little bit and then lift it out (as opposed to sliding it completely back to expose the USB connection). If you slide the compartment all the way back and then lift up, then you will break-off the little tab which keeps the compartment housing attached to the unit for USB use. You'll see what I mean when you handle the unit (just be gentle).2) The buttons are well positioned and they all worked just fine. The menu structure is simple to learn and easy to use.3) The unit was smaller than I had expected, which is great.4) The screen is big and clear. The colors are cool.5) The battery indicator works well, and if you click on the Information menu, you can see the actual battery voltage (a really neat feature, I thought).6) The sound is excellent. There are several ways to adjust sounds (as indicated in the product details at the beginning of the Amazon webpage).7) The radio worked great.8) The voice recording also worked great.9) The product does NOT include an armband as indicated in the product details section. It does include a neck strap. I have reported this inaccuracy to Amazon. You can purchase an armband from JetAudio for a reasonable amount...see their website.10) I connected to Windows XP without any problems (after turning-off my virus scanner and the Windows firewall).11) I was able to download mp3 songs to the unit just fine; the download speed is fast.12) I did not install the software CD. You don't need it to copy files to the unit (just use Windows Explorer).13) I did upgrade the firmware to version 1.60a (which you can download from the iAudio or JetAudio websites).14) The unit is very attractive; I purchased the metal silver (they also have a model with a black face plate).15) Check-out iAudio's website for a lot of helpful info like user forums, where folks post helpful stuff about iAudio units.16) The unit comes with 1GB of memory, but due to the firmware and special effects, 983MB is available for music/file storage (which is still plenty for me).I'm very pleased with my iAudio4 1GB unit.My only complaint: This unit was pricey when compared to other units. I seriously considered the Creative Labs Muvo TX FM 512MB, but the 512MB version was not available at the time...only the 256MB version was available. Creative Labs prices were much more reasonable; and after doing much research, I learned that this particular Creative Labs product also received top marks from consumers.

The seller was Amazon. I paid 5 bucks. This is a "click & clean" device: It is compatible with Ettore's high reach extension pole.The handle is plastic. The part that holds the rubber is metal. It is made in China. It appears to be well made. The blade is level (not warped). It does not streak. I use it at home. I suspect it will last a long time (at least until the rubber dries-out or wears-out). I am happy with my purchase.

For the most part, this documentary is from Japan's perspective.Things I liked:* footage I haven't seen before* narration* some interesting facts* some prelude to WWII like Manchuria* Japanese dairy readingsThings I did NOT like:* too short, only 1 hour 34 minutes long* not in-depth* footage that is repeated from other documentaries* some footage was random shots of Japan with no war significance* at start, they bounced back/forth between 1931 and 1937* limited to color footage, so the story is incompleteDespite the negatives, it was worth watching...especially for the footage that was new (i.e., the footage that has not already been shown by other "in color" documentaries).Visit my Amazon wish lists to see my 4-star and 5-star military/war DVDs:http://www.amazon.com/gp/registry/wishlist/3DU5CH5ZFWRNI/http://www.amazon.com/gp/registry/wishlist/24H8TDYHFDOET/

Usable for both inkjet and laser printers, Avery's White Shipping Labels (8.5" x 11") help deliver a quick and efficient way to get packages out the door, while also looking professional.  Depending on the size of packages you typically ship, the full sheet version might be a bit much, but in some cases it's the perfect size.The labels have been completely error free.  No jamming in both a Brother and HP printer that I tested.  They were also smudge-free.  Creating the labels is simple use Avery's templates.  You may also have other software or shipping possibilities (eBay).  These labels are also useful for other activities around the house, but they are primarily used for shipping for me.

Black + Decker's PureOptics Summit Flex Desk Lamp stands out with it's thin profile and quality build. Add in the ability to adjust multiple light levels and it's professional look, and I call it a winner.The most surprising thing about the lamp is the weight.  Even before I took it out of the box I was surprised by the heftiness.  That's not a bad thing, as the base is very sturdy and again, the lamp is nice and has a really nice build quality.  There are multiple adjustments (hinges) that allow you to direct the light in nearly any direction.  The hinges are fairly sturdy without give unless you bump or hit it hard.I was also pleased with the amount of light output that the lamp had.  The light was diffused well and while there was plenty of output it was not glaring.  A USB power port is included, I just wish it had at least two ports.  That is a minor gripe though.Overall, a solid and professional desk lamp.  It looks good on your desk and provides excellent lighting.

I've used many TP-LINK products (switches, extenders, etc) and I was excited to try this Tri-Band wireless router.  The TP-Link AC3200 (Archer C3200) is a beast in terms of speed and connectivity.  Like many other companies right now, the outside design is a bit much, but there is no questioning the advantages of a router like this.Setup is extremely easy.  You can go the more typical route of plugging it into a laptop or use their iOS or Android app.  You can easily have it going in under 15 minutes, or a little longer if you choose to do additional configuration.  Then you can begin adding your devices.  For me, that is over ten devices, so that part of the process may take longer.  I didn't have any issues  getting my phones, tablets, computers, media devices, or printer hooked up and going.The wifi coverage is excellent.  I was using an extender previously for one portion of my house, but with the Archer C3200, I'm covering the entire area needed.  Best of all, I've had absolutely zero issues staying connected and the speed has been exceptional.  The Smart Connect helps your network by assigning devices to the best channel.  While I did not test the parental controls, they looked easy to configure and would be helpful for some users.Overall, I'm impressed.  The ease of use, configuration options, plus excellent speed and connectivity earn the TP-Link Archer C3200 five stars.

The next installment of Adobe Acrobat tries to continue improving upon tools and functions that have long been more than acceptable to 75% of us.  The majority of home and business users likely only use half of the features that are in Acrobat.  Creating PDFs, editing them (removing pages, adding pages), making comments, and exporting PDFs likely cover most users.The problem is that rather truly improve upon those features, each release of Acrobat brings about mostly UI changes.  With DC, you also get (dragged) into the Adobe cloud more than before.  While there are certainly some useful things that DC brings, like signing abilities, it's very possible that you use another service for those needs.  For home users, it's possible that they don't even need what DC brings.  For small businesses and even larger organizations, it brings more requirements to your end users for activation and cloud services.Sadly, there just isn't enough improvement in the basic features of Acrobat in this version to warrant and upgrade.  In fact, that has really been the case the last couple of versions.  If you need Acrobat and don't mind the cloud bit, then there certainly isn't anything wrong in DC.  But if you have a prior version, there isn't as much reason to go for an upgrade.  Acrobat is the standard for PDFs, so it's hard not use it, but I'm finding prior versions to be fairly useful at the moment.  If you need simple PDF creation you may look elsewhere.  If you need more complicated editing, conversions, or signature abilities, then DC will fulfill your needs.

These Sterling Silver Elongated Cultured Pearl earrings offer an elegant looking piece of jewelry without being overdone.  They are fairly lightweight and are good for most evenings.The pearls standout very well, being roped with the sterling silver and stones.  They are noticeable, however, the stones aren't hardly as evident.  I didn't think they had as much sparkle or shine.  Near the top where the larger stones are there is a bit more sparkle.  I would say that they are elegant overall, but not modern.  The earrings offer a nice touch of class without going overboard.  The metal is a bit dulled.  The weight if fairly light.  You won't really notice them on your ears except by the swing of the jewelry itself, which isn't a whole lot.

NOCO's XGrid XGB3L Rugged USB Battery Pack and LED Flashlight is tough, bright, and incredibly useful.  With its multiple uses, small footprint, and tough exterior it's great to throw in glove compartment, safety/emergency box, or keep with you.The rubberized exterior makes it great for outdoor use (another great use is for hunting or camping).  But the toughness also speaks to being able to throw it in an emergency box for disasters and accidents.  Not only can it serve as an extra light source, but it can charge your phone.  The light has different modes, but it is bright, especially for up close viewing.  A strobe mode is included as well.The device itself gets a charge fairly quick and after charging a few different phones from it, I can say that it provides consistent and constant power.  Overall, you cannot beat having this device around when you need it.  Whether you use it often or just for an occasional emergency, it's a trooper than can fulfill your needs

AmazonBasics' Digital Kitchen Scale is a great tool to have in your kitchen.  While scales are great for baking, they are also good for other cooking or postage (as long as it will not be over 11 pounds).The styling of the scale is very simple and nothing fussy.  It's small and can easily slide into a drawer.  It's size is perfect for a kitchen.  The LCD screen is easily readable and can display results in ounces, grams, pounds, or kilograms.  There are two buttons (Unit and Tare to adjust for container weight).Overall, the weights were spot on.  Design is very good.  If there were a complaint, it would have been to put the AmazonBasics logo somewhere besides the front; maybe on the bottom.  But that is a very small comment.

The Bose SoundTrue Ultra in-ear headphones (for Apple devices) deliver a clear, crisp sound in a very small package.  The headphones just work and best of all, they stay in place.  Very little hassle and great sound.While I don't really consider myself to be an expert at sound quality (I'm the type that uses reasonably priced headphones), I'm very surprised at the output these headphones produce.  I've experienced a few high quality headphones before and usually found them to be better but overpriced.  The Bose SoundTrue, however, deliver not only great sound at a reasonable price but do so using the in-ear style of headphones.The sound is crisp and the bass is deep but not overpowering.  Environment noise is pretty well hidden as well.  The headphones fit snugly in the ear without being uncomfortable.  I tried all three sets of StayHear tips (small, medium, large) and settled on the medium.  The fit was excellent and tips stayed in place while at my desk and also while moving around.  The cord was a little stiff, but is not easily tangled.Overall, you cannot beat the sound in this price range, nor the excellent fit.

The Timex RediSet Dual Alarm Clock has plenty of features that you don't always see in other alarm clocks and offers a twist in the typical design.  There are a couple of annoyances, but overall it's a quality clock that deserves a spot on your nightstand.  Easily five stars.This Timex alarm clock has a dual alarm, which is not something I use often.  It's nice to have though.  It also has a gradual alarm.  A nifty feature I found was the nap timer.  You can set a nap alarm without changing your typical alarm settings.Having USB charging is another plus as it's something we all need or use and it's built into the clock.  That, together with the nightlight make this clock better than your standard clock.  The numbers are also large and easy to read.  I realize these sound like small things, but they are nice features to see on an alarm clock.The design and visual appeal is also a bit different.  The clock is a bit thin, but tall.  Most clocks tend to be flat.  It's a difference that makes the clock feel more modern.  However, it feels a little top heavy.  The buttons are a bit hard to distinguish (rounded and designed to be more modern, but can be hard to find in the dark).Overall, this alarm clock is a winner.  Nice design and plenty of little extras and features.

Belkin's USB 2.0 Ethernet Adapter (F4U047bt) is a quick and easy way to add an Ethernet connection to an ultrabook or other computer that does not have room for an Ethernet connection.  Many laptops/ultrabooks today forgo the Ethernet connection in order to make their devices smaller.Belkin's device is simple to use and installation was a snap.  Most likely you will not need the included software CD as your device will likely have the drivers and you'll be ready to go, as was the case in my situation.  Plug it in and within a few moments you are ready to go.  It's small enough to throw in a briefcase and take with you when you travel.  These are usually a necessity for IT folks as you never know when you need a hardwired connection.For gigabit capabilities, get the Belkin USB 3 version.  Otherwise, the USB 2 works fine as well.

The George Foreman GFG240X Dual Surface Griddle + Grill is a versatile small kitchen appliance that offers plenty of space and tends to beat out griddles I have used in the past.First, the cooking space is pretty large.  I was surprised when the box showed up because it was fairly huge.  There is definitely plenty of cooking space.  On the flip side, however, you have to store this thing somewhere.  I'm not going to lie, you will either need a large drawer/cabinet or leave it on your countertop.  The plus is that you can easily cook breakfast or any other meal for multiple people.Second, I love the versatility of the grill and griddle.  I know it seems like a small feature, but it could be great to grill some meat or vegetables, then use the griddle for heating sides up.  Grease does flow away from the food.  Cleanup is very easy as well.The one downside, besides size (which is also a positive) is the evenness of cooking.  There were some spots that seemed cooler than others, but I've always found that on almost every griddle I've used.  Overall, I'm fairly pleased with the GFG240X.

Belkin's Conserve Insight Energy Use Monitor offers an easy to use, quick, and full featured way to track energy use.  There are many of these units on the market, but this is one of the easiest I've had the pleasure of using.There is a nice, long power cord making it easy to monitor on almost any device.  The numbers/screen are large and easy to read.  Plus, the buttons are large.  Compared to other devices, the readings were almost spot on, but honestly the long cord is something many other manufacturers leave out.  Combine that with the Belkin name and quality, and I'd consider it a five star product.  The build quality is good and tight.Definitely worth the investment to determine potential energy savings throughout your home.

Leggett & Platt’s Signature Adjustable Platform Base has been a delight.  While never personally owning an adjustable bed, I’ve always considered purchasing one.  I have, however, tested many out and been around others that own them.  Thankfully I recently purchased a mattress a few months ago and it was definitely compatible with adjustable bases.It’s important to note that installing this platform is not a one man job.  It’s heavy and as expected it comes in a large box.  You should definitely plan to have some help getting this moved in and properly setup.  For me, that moving it up a flight of stairs.  Not easy, but again, have yourself some assistance.It was worth the effort, though, as I’ve been extremely pleased and impressed.  The motor has a good amount of lifting capacity and it handles weight with ease.  It is smooth moves up and down fairly quick.  Best of all, it’s quiet.  Among the quietest I have heard.If there is one thing that is unmistakable, it’s that this product is made of quality materials and produced with care.  The upholstery, metals, everything is made well.  After almost a month of use and you don’t hear any squeaks or noises.  Even the remote feels nice.  The remote control is simple to use (easy to remember which button is which without looking at the remote).  Large buttons, so even in the dark you can use.  But, it’s also backlit, so that’s a plus.As someone that has issues with heartburn/indigestion and other stomach issues, I look forward to many more years of use out of this bed platform.  Being able to raise the head  is extremely important and has been a relief.

Monoprice's 16,000 mAh Portable Charger gives you enough charging power not only in a pinch, but enough to recharge devices over and over for an extended period of time.The Charger comes in a non-retail packaging, so it is a simple cardboard box with the charger and USB cable inside.  No need to worry about having to cut through typical plastic packaging, but keep that in mind if ordering as a gift.  Like many other portable chargers, a wall charger is not included (but you can use other USB wall chargers or a powered USB hub or computer, keeping in mind that the type of charger will effect the recharge time).At 16,000 mAh, the unit can be considered somewhat heavy, but keep in mind the amount of charging you are getting out of this unit.  Consider a smaller one, if that is a concern.  However, the unit is sturdy and appears to be built to last.  I have been able to charge multiple devices and still have plenty of power left in the portable charger.  There are two charging ports, which is sufficient for most cases.Overall, this a great unit.  Plenty of charging capacity and a quality build.  It should definitely be a consideration for you, especially if you are looking for a unit that can provide plenty of charging.  At 16,000 mAh, you'll have plenty of power for multiple phones or tablets, or use it to charge devices many times over an extended trip.

The Crescent DB18X Flat Pry Bar is not your typical pry bar.  With an indexing and lockable head, striking surface, and tough grip, it gets the job done.  There are many reasons to like this tool.While the positional head seems like a gimmick at first, you soon find out that it comes in handy.  Not all of the 180 degrees will be for everybody, but the various angles give you some great control over prying items apart, pulling nails out, or countless other activities.  Best of all, the locking positions are very sturdy.The tool is tough.  Yet, the grip is comfortable and gives you plenty of control.  There is also a great striking surface when more power to loosen something is needed.  My only complaint is that after many strikes the locking mechanism seems a bit more loose than what it was.  So I have some concerns about long term use when a lot of striking is required.Overall, this is a handy tool to have around.  Good quality and very versatile.

Preen's Weed Preventer is an excellent product.  They have a couple of variations, but I've used their products for a long time and always been happy with the results.  Depending on the size of the area you plan to treat, there are multiple sizes.  The smaller 5.6lb version comes in an easy to use bottle with a spout on the end for spreading.While Preen's Weed Preventer will not kill existing weeds, it's great at preventing new ones.  Early in the Spring, after weeding and cleaning, it's a good idea to put Preen's down.  Then follow up with another application about three months later.  It's easy to apply.  Like I said, the 5.6lb version has a spout to spread it easily.  Otherwise, you can get larger containers and use a spreader or small gardening tool to apply it (or the larger ones often come with a scoop).I use Preen every year and stand behind it.  It's well worth the money and the time (even though it takes very little time to apply).

The Silk'n Blue Acne Solution Device is one of many products in a crowded market of skin and acne products.  After a short time with item, it does seem safe and easy to use.  It can be time consuming and results appear to be positive.  Of course, only long term usage can really determine the overall effectiveness.The instructions are easy to follow and using the device is simple to operate.  I will say that it takes time to cover the entire face (if needed), so that is something to keep in mind.  Covering limited affected areas is a little easier, but still time consuming.  It also seems a bit flimsy, so I would be concerned about its lifespan.I personally have notice some improvement over the short term.  I'd be interested to see how it goes over the recommended 6-8 weeks.  I found it best to use in evening when more time was available, but it is supposed to be used twice daily.  It gets warm, but nothing too terribly uncomfortable.  I think it's worth adding this to your skincare treatment.  I still think other products might be necessary, but there has been some effectiveness after using the Silk'n Blue.

A new twist on an old favorite is offered in Nature Valley's Soft Baked Granola Bites.  At first, I was really eager to give these a try as I love Nature Valley's soft granola bars.  They are often full of flavor and have a variety of ingredients.  These granola bites are basically in the shape of a ball, but I think they are a bit larger than bite sized.  They could be a little smaller.As for taste, the blueberry was hardly noticeable.  There were almonds, mostly noticeable by their texture.  Unfortunately, the flavor profile was fairly flat and one note.  The bites were soft, but I quickly grew tired of them.  I would have loved to have more flavor in them and a smaller size.As a side note, the bites arrived mostly smashed from shipping (that was a shipping issue though and was not reflected in my rating and review).

The Kitchen Aid KCPI40CRAC Professional Cast Iron Casserole Pot is a beautiful piece of cookware.  It performs very well and has excellent build quality.While this pot is great for stews and similar items on top of the stove, you can also put it in the oven.  Even better?  The lid also serves as a cast iron grill pan!  All you have to do is flip it over.  I love the versatility of that.As soon as you receive this item and take it out of the package (although you will want to clean it a bit just like any new item), it will be ready to go.  It's preseasoned and done very well.  The exterior is a beautiful and smooth.  I have the Almond Cream, which is a nice, versatile color.  But the quality of this item is great from the interior to the exterior.Cooking with it is great.  I don't use it for everything, but love doing stews or braised type of dishes in them.  Best of all, if you keep care of this cookware it will literally last forever.  Kitchen Aid has a winner with this one, they did not cut corners.

The Philips SHQ2300LF/27 Action Fit Sports earbuds have some promising qualities, but lack in a few key areas.  Having a pair of earbuds/headphones that can withstand workouts, action, and moving around are great, but the Action Fit Sports took some getting used to.  There are also headphones in this series, as well as earbuds.The earbuds are very lightweight, which were impressive.  They were almost unnoticeable from that perspective.  At times, I almost had to make sure they were still in my ear and that's the problem.  They are lightweight and can be hard to notice, but the sound was not very noticeable either.  The fit in the ears was not as idea as I had hoped.  Worse yet, outside noise was distracting and not well displaced by the earbuds.  Also, they were also a bit awkward.  The earbud itself is small, but the outer part is larger and that part was noticeable in the ear.There are some positives here, though.  The cable clip is a nice addition and the cable does a good job of staying tangle free.  In contrast, the cable is also a bit stiff, but that's likely what lends itself to being tangle-free.  I just wish there was more performance, sound output, and noise reduction.  But from an athletic perspective, I can see how these would be a positive to have.

The Philips SHQ3300LF/27 Action Fit Sports Headphones have some promising qualities, but lack in a few key areas.  Having a pair of headphones that can withstand workouts, action, and moving around are great, but the Action Fit Sports took some getting used to.The headphones are fairly lightweight, which were impressive.  At times, I almost had to make sure they were still in my ear and that's the problem.  They are lightweight and can be hard to notice, but the sound was not very noticeable either.  The fit in the ears was not as idea as I had hoped.  Worse yet, outside noise was distracting and not well displaced by the headphones.There are some positives here, though.  The cable clip is a nice addition and the cable does a good job of staying tangle free.  In contrast, the cable is also a bit stiff, but that's likely what lends itself to being tangle-free.  I just wish there was more performance, sound output, and noise reduction.

The Haier ESAQ406P Ultra Quiet Window Air Conditioner sells itself on being quiet and powerful.  In many instances, this is the case and the unit does an excellent job of cooling.Upon receiving the unit, I can say it is certainly heavy.  The weight might be on par with other units that cool this amount of space, but I'm used to using smaller window air conditioners.  Installation was as expected, but make sure you have some assistance.I picked a perfect time to get this air conditioner as we had a hot streak of weather.  It has since cooled down a bit, but I was able to put the unit through its paces.  It did an excellent job of cooling about a 300 sq ft space.  It was never uncomfortable.  The weather has ranged from high 90s down to high 60s.  During the nights we were able to use the quiet mode and it was extremely pleasant.  During the day other fan speeds were used and it was a little more quiet than other units.  But most of the selling point here likely comes in the quiet mode.Overall, I have been very pleased.  It has kept up with the weather and offers many options with the fan and controls, as well as the adjustable vents in the front.  This is my first experience with Haier, but so far it has been pleasant

The Belkin Pocket Sleeve for the Microsoft Surface Pro 3 is a nice case, with moderate protection and a few extras that other cases do not provide.  I've used a good number of SP3 cases and I'm always on the lookout for something that improves upon the others.  Personally, I'm not a fan of this material, although it is soft and very durable.  Overall, the Belkin Pocket Sleeve is a good four stars.First, I got the blue one, which is a nice color.  It's a bit bright, but is a pleasant color.  The padding is adequate and just enough for most protection without being too thick.  It fits the SP3 fairly well, although with the keyboard on it's a little tight.  That's the case with move sleeves and cases I have used.Second, the sleeve provides a zippered pocket and stylus loop.  It's nice to see that they actually did think about the stylus, that's something a lot of competitors have left out.  The pocket is enough store either the stylus as well, or a slim mouse, pen, and other accessories.Overall, the Belkin Pocket Sleeve is a solid sleeve.  It provides protection and storage without being bulky.  While my personal preference is leather or something besides neoprene, this sleeve is still a solid buy.

The Zenna Home Luxury Hotel Waffle Weave Shower Curtain is a nice for just about any bathroom.  It's very similar to what you would find in many hotels, spas, etc.  The material is really nice, it's soft and durable.Personally, I've never liked combined curtains and liners, so I am using this with an additional liner.  The fabric of this item is really nice and I'd consider it be more of a curtain.  Like others, it might be questionable if it's truly a waffle weave and instead just a pattern.  But I think it's nice, durable, and has an elegant touch.The length and width are standard, and it hangs nicely.  It wasn't too wrinkled out of the package.  If you have seen these in a hotel, you'll likely know that they do soak up water (again, I'm using it more as a curtain with another liner behind it).  Overall, though, it's easily a four star item.  Possibly five stars.  You will thoroughly enjoy the fabric, design, and overall addition to your décor.

Upon opening the packaging my first response was wow, these look really great.  The design looks great (refined, subtle, and can likely match most decors) and they appear to be very well made.  There are three different colors/shades and each has a decorative strip along the bottom.These look great laying around, hanging on an oven handle, or hanging up on a wall/elsewhere (there is a nifty strap on each towel on one corner that allows you to easily hang them on a hook).  Design, is easily five stars.  I gave it four stars, because they are not very absorbent.  While they are great for general use, if you are drying more than a few dishes they won't soak up as much water as a really thick towel.  With that said, I'd definitely recommend these and will likely get more.

Urban Armor Gear's Microsoft Surface 3 Composite Case is a good option for those looking for extended, tough protection for their Surface 3.  If you need general protection, I would not necessarily recommend it.  This is certainly meant for those that are drop prone or need the Surface in the field or other special needs.  However, it's a good fit and they took great care in making sure it accommodated the Surface 3.As stated, for those that need it, this is a great option.  It's a bit bulky, but that is where the protection is coming from.  The corner protection is very good and thick.  There is an integrated spot for the stylus, which is awesome.  There's also a kickstand to take the place of the original Surface 3 kickstand (some cases work around the original kickstand).  The kickstand is stiff, so hopefully it will stand the test of time, but it seems to work very well.  Use of the screen isn't really interrupted and you can still use the side swipes of Windows 8.Overall, I'm fairly pleased.  Good for field use and other potential use cases.

The Netgear AC1200 Wi-Fi Range Extender works very well, helping to eliminate dead spots in the home and extend coverage.  Not only was coverage very good, but speed was great as well.  Installation/configuration was fairly simple and the overall design is on par with other similar units.Upon opening the box, you can have this configured fairly quick.  If you have WPS (Wi-Fi Protected Setup) that will be the quickest and easiest option for you.  However, you can setup with the additional Netgear instructions fairly easily if you need to.  Within 5-10 minutes max, you should be good to go.  The device does not cover up the second plug on your outlet, so you can still use it for whatever you need.  The antennas are not really in the way either.  The device is somewhat thick (although it's about equal to other devices in this category that I have used), so you  may be able to back furniture right up to it, but it's no worse than a plug sticking out.I installed this about 30-35 linear feet (different floor though) from my router.  It's providing much better coverage in my home where it was weak in two corners.  The speed is very comparable to what it was before this device.  So it's providing good coverage with no speed noticeable speed reduction.  There is a nifty Analytics App, but unfortunately it's not available on all platforms.  Overall, this is typical Netgear quality and works very well out of the box.

Hefty's Extra Strong Drawstring Multipurpose Trash Bags are thicker and stronger than normal.  They can serve many purposes and although the extra strength and thickness is noticeable, I'm not sure I would have these bags as my go-to.  I tend to go for normal trash bags or ultra strength (contractor) for big jobs outside.The extra strong bags offer a nice go between, though.  They are suitable for tougher cleanup jobs inside or for general storage. They don't tear very easily, unless the objects are very sharp or have hard corners.  Things that would normally tear a standard trash bag, like cardboard don't really penetrate the extra strong bags.It's nice to keep a box of these around when you need them if it's worth the extra cost to you.  Personally, I prefer using standard bags or contractor bags when the job really calls for it.  However, these bags are stronger and thicker than your standard trash bags.

It's hard to deny the greatness of the Starburst FaveReds flavors: watermelon, cherry, strawberry, and fruit punch.  The only way to make them better is to have them already unwrapped.  The flavors are spot on, nothing tastes different, but these Starburst minis were very fresh.  They are probably about half the size of normal Starburst candies.Upon initially opening the package, very few of the candies were stuck together.  With time some more might stick, but like I said they were very fresh.  Best of all, they don't stick in your hand either.  The only problem with Starburst minis is that you can eat way too many.  But I guess that's a problem we'll have to solve individually.  :)

DII's Elegant Modern Lattice Lace shower curtain is a nice, elegant item for bathroom décor.  While personally it's a bit too feminine for my own taste, it could work in many different designs.  Best of all, it lets in a good amount of light, which is an issue in many bathroom showers.The overall design is nice and it appears to have a good quality stitching.  While lace is more feminine, the pattern is fairly neutral.  In my case, I have the white version, which is very bright and clean looking.  The shower hook holes are reinforced and for the most part it looks like the curtain can take some wear and tear without getting damaged.Overall, it's a nice quality item that lets in plenty of light (which I always consider to be a big deal).  If it fits your décor, then go for it!

Ortho's Bug B Gon Insect Killer for Lawns is simple and easy to apply and it gets the job done.  Having used many Ortho products in the past, including other Bug B Gon products, I was happy to see this concentrated liquid work just as well.Simply hook up to your hose and start applying. For larger yards, multiple bottles might be needed or you might want to consider granules.  The mechanism that connected to the hose appeared to be strong, unlike other bottles like this I've used that broke or leaked with relative ease.  This formula last up to three months, at which time you can reapply in the same easy fashion.Overall, it's easy to use and it works as advertised.

As someone that is a heavy sleeper and a habitual snooze button addict, I had my doubts about the Philips Wake-UP Light with Radio.  The design is somewhat unusual, it's more modern, but it will definitely raise some questions when people see it.  Functionality and overall use is quick and easy to learn.  For light sleepers, there is not doubt this will work.  For heavy sleepers, I think it depends on your routine, room light, and overall sleeping routine.The gentle increase of light is great (I tested it out while awake and asleep).  It really does slowly increase and turns to a very nice, room-filling light.  The light can also be used as a general light on your nightstand.  The alarms sounds are good, but I would still like to see a more normal beeping type of sound (I realize that defeats the purpose of a more gentle solution like this, but some people would prefer it).  It could still be a gradual increase of sound.  The natural sounds are nice, but there are only two, and at this price point I think a few more would be warranted.  For myself, I found that the sounds and gradual increase of light woke me up most of the time, but not all the time.  I let a lighter sleeper borrow the clock and they found that it woke them up very well.  If you are a heavy sleeper that rotates in bed and might be facing any direction or buried in the pillows (yes, I know this is sad) you might get mixed results.  I'd say their claim of 9 out of 10 users found that is work is likely accurate.The controls are nice, but being more touch oriented, the buttons can be hard to distinguish.  A battery backup, again, at this price point is expected.  In fact, it's pretty much expected in every alarm clock, but is not included.Overall, this is a nice alarm clock and it offers a nice, gentle way to wake up.  Some people might have mixed results, but for the most part I'm sure it will work the majority of users.  There are a few features that would add to its benefit, but for those wishing to have a new waking up experience, this would still be a nice unit to try.

This Sterling Silver Diamond Butterfly Pendant necklace has a nice design with a relatively small diamond setting, making it a nice piece of jewelry at a reasonable price.  The butterfly is approximately an inch across, so the piece is certainly noticeable.The sterling silver has a very nice, polished look that shines and catches the light very well.  The diamonds are not super clear, but offer some contrast to the rest of the piece.  The diamonds are a bit larger at top and get a little smaller down the line.  The design and flow of the butterfly is very nice.  The lines are very smooth and it makes for a piece of jewelry, especially for everyday wear.The chain itself is fairly standard and while there are no complaints about it, the packaging was less than to be desired.  It was extremely tangled when the box was opened.  Only a small piece of fabric was instead to protect the jewelry, so it bounced around and got tangled up.  That's a relatively small issue though.  Overall, this is a nice piece of jewelry for a starter, a small gift, or everyday wearing.

Excellent weed preventing with the added benefit of plant food.  As someone that has used Preen's weed preventer in the past, I can attest to it's wondrous powers.  But seriously, it works extremely well.  Apply it early and then again in three months and you'll be weed free through summer and fall.  If you live in areas with extended seasons or warm weather, just keep applying every three months.Application is super easy.  I usually like to do it when cleaning up the yard in early spring and applying new mulch, etc.  Keep in mind that this is weed preventer.  It's not meant to kill existing weeds, it's supposed to prevent new weeds before they start.Now, this is the first time I've used Preen that also includes plant food.  So I'm excited to see how well that works, unfortunately, I won't be able to post the results in just thirty days.  I have high hopes though, as Preen has become a brand that I know and trust and have been using for years now.

The Philips 452391 Slimstyle LED Bulb is a perfect replacement for indoor traditional BR30 light bulbs.  The output is very good, you can hardly tell that it's LED versus other types.  The coverage is excellent and the light beam is fairly wide.Once installed in a recessed can, it looks like any other bulb.  With its wide beam, it fills a room nicely, especially when you have a few recessed lights.  The color is fairly average, on the soft white side of lighting, but not hardly as warm as traditional bulbs.  It's close though.  I'd recommend changing all of the recessed lights in a room for the most even lighting color and coverage.  But if that isn't an option, you might be okay.Combined with the energy savings and dimmable capability, and this is a winner.

The Kensington KP400 Switchable Bluetooth Keyboard is a nifty keyboard that can serve multiple devices.
