Make sure to enable "Sync all cores" in the UEFI BIOS to get the accurate score because at first I was using the XMP profile and I was getting very low scores and after enabling it, everything was good.1st pass: 83.87fps2nd pass:19.76fps---------------------------------------------------------------------------------+All the games below are tested at max settings at 1920x1080. I don't have any other GPUs that I could test it against so that's why I used my main card which is the Titan:Metro Last LightIntel iGPU: ~15fpsGTX Titan: ~84fpsHitman AbsolutionIntel iGPU: ~18fpsGTX Titan: ~79fpsBioshock InfiniteIntel iGPU: ~23fpsGTX Titan: ~87fpsTomb RaiderIntel iGPU: ~22fpsGTX Titan: ~95fps--------------------------------------------------------------------------------Cons:-Pricey for a mATX motherboardConclusion:Overall, the Asus Z87 Maximus VI Gene is an excellent mATX motherboard that comes packed with a ton of amazing features, even more than some full ATX motherboards on the market if you ask me. If you are someone who's looking to build a small gaming machine that still has the overclocking potential of a full ATX board then the Z87 Maximus VI Gene is for you. The SupremeFX does an outstanding job at delivering outstanding sound quality. It may not have all the features that some of the extreme boards have but very few people use every feature that comes with the motherboard. You cannot run triple card setup with this motherboard because there are only two PCIe 3.0 slots but again, very few people run more than one or two cards at the same time. The black and red color scheme looks very attractive and the board design looks top notch as you would expect from any ASUS motherboard.AI Suite III makes overclocking on this motherboard so easy that even a caveman can do it. It literally takes one click and you are done. The 4-Way Optimization in the new AI Suite III is great for people who don't want to bother with going into the BIOS and tweaking each setting. The Z87 Maximus VI Gene has nice and strong VRMs (8+2 phase design) that can handle high volts really well (1.4v+). I was able to get my 4770K to 4.6Ghz and it handled it fine. I'm also using a closed liquid cooler (H100i) that can handle high temperatures very well. AI Suite III will automatically tune your system for the best performance without you having to go into the BIOS and playing with each individual setting. If you plan on upgrading to a Haswell CPU and are looking for a motherboard that will offer you plenty of overclocking options, then the Z87 Maximus VI Gene might be for you.The new and improved UEFI BIOS is probably the best out of all motherboards that I have seen. The amount of SATAIII and USB 3.0 ports is mind-blowing. I know many people who have a lot of devices connected to their computer and this motherboard offers you all of that. Boot times, SATAIII and USB 3.0 performance is very good with this motherboard. This board has everything you can ask for in a mATX board and more. The UEFI BIOS is friendly and has an enormous amount of options that can be overwhelming at first but give it a few tries and you will fall in love with it. You can write quick notes while you are in the BIOS for future references which can very useful and the "Favorite" option is also very good if you want to customize it with the settings that you use the most to get quick access to everything.The ASUS Z87 Maximus VI Gene retails for $209.99 (Amazon) and it does cost a little bit more than other mATX motherboards out there but it also has a ton of mind-blowing features that I personally cannot live without. ASUS has always made amazing ATX motherboards and the Z87 Maximus VI Gene is possibly one of the best mATX boards that I have ever tested. This is a very attractive looking motherboard that doesn't disappoint in any area. I'm seeing a lot of people on forums who are constantly buying full ATX boards just for gaming and they don't even use half of the features that it comes with so I think more people should buy mATX boards because they are just as

Before I start my review I just want to say that I'm not a crazy Facebook user and I usually log into my Facebook once a week or so. I rarely ever use Facebook and when I do, I usually just see what's new with my friends/family and then immediately log out. I got this phone for my girlfriend because she (obviously) loves Facebook so I thought it would be cool to buy her a phone that's made for Facebook users in mind. The HTC First is also known as the "Facebook phone" and it isn't a high end device by any means and it's geared towards users who love Facebook and aren't tech savvy.  The launcher that's running on top of Android 4.1 is called Facebook Home. You can also disable Facebook Home that comes right out of the box and use the stock android version which is android 4.1 Jelly Bean. This is a cool feature that this phone offers because some people might later decide to use the stock android version if they get bored with Facebook Home.So far from all the testing that I have done, the HTC First has a decent battery life which I wasn't expecting it because it's a mid-range device. It packs a 2000 mAh battery that it's more than enough for people who spent most of their time on Facebook. The screen on the HTC First is 720p which is great for viewing pictures or HD videos. The HTC First is a 4.3 inches device that is perfect for my girlfriend because she has small hands - she's coming from an iPhone 4S. I made her ditch the iPhone 4S and come to Android. :D The HTC First comes with Snapdragon 400 which is a dual core CPU that runs at 1.4Ghz. It has no problems handling everything you throw at it and consumes very little power when it's running; qualcomm really knows how to make great chips.Pros:+Display / Screen:The screen is bigger on the HTC First (4.3 inches) than the iPhone 4S so viewing pictures or watching videos is better on the HTC First. The screen resolution is also much sharper on the HTC First and has more pixel density than the iPhone 4S. The resolution on this phone is 720 x 1280 (342ppi pixel density) which if you compare it to the iPhone 4S is way better.+Android OS:This phone ships with Android 4.1 (Jelly Bean) which is blazing fast and never lags. If you decide to use the Facebook Home mode then you have quick access to all the Facebook stuff such as the Facebook app, messenger and instagram. You can also access all of your applications if you swipe to the left as soon as you get in the app drawer and you get all of your typical apps that come included in all android devices.+Design:The design is just like any HTC phone you have seen before. It has a nice soft touch when you hold it and has the same feel as an HTC One X which is a good thing. HTC makes really comfortable to hold devices and I like that about HTC. The phone fits really well in hand and my girlfriend loves it.+Camera:The rear camera on this phone is 5MP (2592x1944 pixels) and the front camera is 1.6MP. They both take great pictures and can even shoot 1080p videos at 30fps. I just think it would have been better if HTC put an 8MP camera instead because after all, this device is made for people who take a lot of pictures and share them with their friends/family on Facebook.+Battery:The battery on the HTC First is 2000mAh which is more than enough if all you're going to do is be on Facebook and check the web and whatnot. I tested the battery by being on Facebook and checking the web all day and so far it seems that the phone can last a full day with a single charge so that's great. Qualcomm has done an amazing job with the Snapdragon 400 because you can tell how efficient it is and how little power it consumes. The battery is non-removable if you guys are wondering.+Storage:The HTC First comes with 16GB of storage and can store a ton of pictures and HD videos. My girlfriend likes to take crapload of pictures and videos so the 16GB of storage is more than enough for her.+Processor:The Qualcomm Snapdragon 400 (Dual-core 1.4 GHz) does an amazing job at keeping the phone running lag-free. So far I have not experienced a slow down with the HTC First. The Snapdragon 400 also has no problem handling 3D games. The phone comes with 1GB of ram which is plenty for most users.Cons:My phone is a Samsung Galaxy S4 so I don't want to nitpick on the HTC First because I could come up with a ton of bad things to say but I'm not going to. The only thing that I'm going to say is that the camera could have been an 8MP camera instead. It makes more sense to put an 8MP camera on a Facebook device because people will be taking pictures and uploading them on Facebook for everyone to see. The HTC First has last year's specs and it's a decent phone for people who are on Facebook.Overall, the HTC First is a mid-range device made for Facebook users in mind. It's the perfect phone if you are the type of person who has thousands of friends on Facebook and just love to share everything with your family/friends. The battery life in this phone is pretty decent and will last you a full day if you use it for Facebook and web browsing. The build quality is very well and has a nice soft touch when holding. HTC is known for making great devices, build quality-wise. If you are someone like me that checks Facebook once a week or so then I don't recommend this phone because there are better phones out there. But if you are someone who just loves being on Facebook and staying updated with your friends/family then this device is for you.

I'm building a rig for my brother because his older card died (PNY GTX 460) and he would always complain about the card running hot and having a difficult time playing games. So I decided to go with the MSI HD7950 OC because it runs cool and overclocks like a champ. My brother is now happy because he can max any game he wants now. I was able to push the HD7950 to 1180mhz/1550mhz with 1.25 volts. The temps always stay below 75c with my overclocking and it idles at around 28c. Also, this card has 3GB VRAM which is more than enough for high resolution gaming at 1080p. I always control the fan of the card with MSI Afterburner because it gives you more control over the automatic fan settings.His previous card was the PNY GTX460 which was a great card when it was released but it couldn't handle all the modern games and started showing its age in newer games that my brother wants to play such as BF3, Crysis 3, Metro LL, Bioshock Infinite and Batman Arkham City. The new MSI HD7950 is not only faster but cooler and quieter than the GTX 460. I remember his GTX460 running so hot that it would shut down his computer in the middle of the game and I couldn't handle all the heat that it would put out so I made the right choice of upgrading his computer to the MSI HD7950. His other components would overheat because of the GTX 460.The MSI HD7950 runs super cool in his system even though I have not done any cable management whatsoever. I plan on getting another one to run in crossfire because I want to future-proof my brother's computer. At idle, the temperature hovers around 28c so that's pretty cool. While gaming, this card stays cool and quiet at 75C and I have it overclocked too. I have the fan set manually at 65% in CCC so it can keep the card cool while gaming. The fans get loud at about 70% so that's why I try to keep it at 65%. The HD7950 performs the same as the GTX 660ti/670 and AMD is getting better and better at quickly releasing beta drivers like Nvidia does. This thing can overclock like a beast which says a lot about the architecture of the HD7xxx series cards.Pros:+ Sexy design+ Whisper quiet fans+ Low temps both in idle and under load+ Overclocks like crazy+ 3 Year warranty+ 3GB of VramCons:- NoneOverall, I highly recommend the MSI HD7950 OC to anyone who wants a high end video card that plays all games on max settings. The MSI HD7950 OC is very well built, runs super cool and delivers a smooth gaming experience. It also comes pre-overclocked which is nice but I'm sure most people overclock it higher than that. I have always liked MSI because they make quality cards and have a great customer service which I prefer over some other brands. This thing can overclock like a beast which I really like. I have the card overclocked at 1180/1550 and it handles it fine.My main rig:Case: Corsair 900DGPU: EVGA GTX TitanCPU: Intel Core i7 4770K (still experimenting)PSU: EVGA SuperNOVA 1000WRam: Kingston 16GB of RAMSSD: Samsung 840 Pro 256GBMB: ASUS Sabertooth Z87OS: Windows 7 64bit

I wanted a large SD Card that was fast and very reliable so after reading online for a bit, I finally decided to get the Samsung Electronics 64GB Pro Extreme and people were reporting fast speeds on USB 3.0 interface which is exactly what I wanted. I bought this memory card for my new Samsung Galaxy Camera and it is blazing fast and has super fast read and write. My Samsung Galaxy Camera comes with only 8GB of free space and it's barely enough for me to take HD videos or store my huge collection of music.I store a huge amount of HD videos, pictures and music to this memory card and I still have a ton of room left to store more stuff. I also put a lot of HD movies in my phone because I tend to watch movies when I travel around to other places. I have a USB 3.0 card reader that I use to transfer my stuff back to my computer from my phone and I was blown away after testing the speed of this card in a USB 3.0 interface.These are the speeds that I got using a USB 3.0 card reader testing it with CrystalDiskMark:Read --- WriteSequence: 77.56MB/sec --- 38.71MB/sec512K: 71.28MB/sec --- 3.822MB/sec4K: 6.119MB/sec --- 1.011MB/sec4K QD32: 6.211MB/sec --- 1.323MB/secSo as you can see from the results above, the speed of the Samsung Electronics 64GB Pro Extreme is pretty close to what Samsung advertises it. If you decide to buy this sd card which you should if you want the best of the best then I highly recommend getting a USB 3.0 card reader because it will make all the difference in the world. This was exactly what I wanted when I was shopping for an sd card for my Samsung Galaxy Camera. I am able to transfer large HD videos (over 6GB) in less than 2 minutes. I'm so happy with my purchase!

Before I start my review of the 4670K, I just want to say that I already own the 4770K and I already know that it's more of a sidegrade over Ivy Bridge. I have written a review of the 4770K on Amazon and I will put a link in the bottom of this review so you guys can read it if you are interested. My main rig has a 4770K that I have overclocked to 4.6Ghz using 1.34 volts and I tried to get it to 4.8Ghz like I did with my 3770K (delidded) but the temps go through the roof (well over 90c) so that's why I keep it at 4.6Ghz.The 4670K that I got is for my second rig which has a 3570K also overclocked to 4.8Ghz (delidded) and temps stay below 80C using an H100i. The Corsair H100i is an excellent closed liquid cooler that I recommend to anyone who wants to achieve high overclocks with their CPUs. Before I ordered the 4670K, I already knew that the 4670K is barely faster than the 3570K and it's more of a sidegrade rather than an upgrade but I'm the type of person who likes to have the latest tech. Since the 4670K doesn't have HyperThreads, it runs a little bit cooler than my 4770K which is in my main rig. Just like when I upgraded to the 4770K, I have not been able to tell a difference with my new 4570K in all of my games such as BF3, FC3, Crysis 3, Bioshock Infinite and Metro LL etc. I wasn't expecting a big performance improvement because I already tested my 4770K vs 3770K and the difference was minimal and it's the same thing with the 4670K.Just like I said in my other review, if you are a gamer and you have a Sandy Bridge or Ivy Bridge CPU then upgrading to the 4670K won't bring you any improvements. If you got the cash then go right ahead but if you are on a budget then don't bother upgrading. Haswell does run hotter than Ivy Bridge and you will probably need to invest in a better cooler if you want to overclock it. Very few people have been able to achieve 24/7 stable overclocks (4.8Ghz and above) with Haswell and all of them have custom water cooling setups. You will also need to purchase a new motherboard which is disappointing considering the little difference that it brings to the table over Ivy Bridge. It would have been awesome if Haswell was made for LGA 1155 but it's not.The more I study Haswell, the more I think that it wasn't built for desktop users in mind but instead for laptops. I plan on getting a laptop that comes with Haswell just to see how good the battery life is because everyone keeps talking about it. Just like I said in my 4770K review, Intel has really improved the integrated graphics card in Haswell but it still doesn't deliver smooth fps in games. It still has a hard time playing old games such TF2, L4D2 and CSGO that use the Source Engine. The only reason I would upgrade to Haswell is if I was stuck on an old socket such as LGA 1156 and 1366 but otherwise, I wouldn't bother.In idle, the 4670K stays around 35c which is a bit hotter than my 3570K that idled at 31c. Under load using Prime95 (smallfft), my 4670K at 4.6Ghz (1.31 volts) stays below 80C while my 3570K hovered around 75C. There are some benchmarks that I have made so far.Cinebench 11.5 (Multi-Threaded)3570K @ 4.6Ghz = 7.524670K @ 4.6Ghz = 7.76SuperPI 1M3570K @ 4.6Ghz = 8.104s4670K @ 4.6Ghz = 8.015sI have a bunch of games installed in my computer so I decided to do a comparison against the 3570K both at 4.6Ghz. The first three games (TF2, L4D2, CSGO) are tested by using the iGPU @ 1080p since they are not very demanding, the rest of the games are tested by using a GTX 780(stock) @ 2560x1440.Team Fortress 2 - Max Settings3570K @ 4.6Ghz = 23FPS avg4670K @ 4.6Ghz = 37FPS avgCounter Strike GO - Max Settings3570K @ 4.6Ghz = 22FPS avg4670K @ 4.6Ghz = 34FPS avgLeft 4 Dead 2 - Max Settings3570K @ 4.6Ghz = 25FPS avg4670K @ 4.6Ghz = 32FPS avgFar Cry 33570K @ 4.6Ghz = 38fps avg4670K @ 4.6Ghz = 42fps avgBattlefield 33570K @ 4.6Ghz = 58fps avg4670K @ 4.6Ghz = 61fps avgCrysis 33570K @ 4.6Ghz = 29fps avg4670K @ 4.6Ghz = 30fps avgBioshock Infinite3570K @ 4.6Ghz = 67ps avg4670K @ 4.6Ghz = 69fps avgHitman Absolution3570K @ 4.6Ghz = 63ps avg4670K @ 4.6Ghz = 66fps avgMetro 20333570K @ 4.6Ghz = 72ps avg4670K @ 4.6Ghz = 73fps avgTomb Raider3570K @ 4.6Ghz = 47ps avg4670K @ 4.6Ghz = 46fps avgBorderlands 23570K @ 4.6Ghz = 95ps avg4670K @ 4.6Ghz = 93fps avgBatman Arkham City3570K @ 4.6Ghz = 80ps avg4670K @ 4.6Ghz = 78fps avgAssassin's Creed 33570K @ 4.6Ghz = 53ps avg4670K @ 4.6Ghz = 55fps avgSleeping Dogs3570K @ 4.6Ghz = 58ps avg4670K @ 4.6Ghz = 60fps avgSo the difference with the first three games using the iGPU is massive in my opinion but it still isn't enough to provide a smooth enough gaming experience using the iGPU. If we move to the other games tested with a GTX 780 then the results become disappointing. The results speak for themselves but it should indicate if you are on an Ivy Bridge CPU then upgrading to Haswell will only give you around 3fps the most. You'd better off overclocking your 3570K and getting better results than a 4670K becuase it overclocks more and runs cooler.So in the end, I think Intel has focused too much on the iGPU and forgot about the CPU part. I have said it before and I will say it again, Haswell was designed for laptops in mind and also to compete with AMD's APUs. The iGPU in Haswell still falls short against AMD's 6800K but the CPU on Haswell destroys all AMD's CPUs and APUs. Intel has done a fantastic job at improving the iGPU in Haswell and lowering power consumption but it still isn't enough to play games like TF2, L4D2 and CS GO that aren't very demanding. If Haswell was made for LGA 1155 then it would have been awesome but since it requires a completely new motherboard, it will be difficult for me to recommend it to people. If you are coming from an AMD system and want to try out Haswell then it will be a huge upgrade regardless if you are on a FX-8350 or Phenom X6 1100T. I give the same rating that I gave to the 4770K and that is a 8/10 for the tiny improvements that it brings over Ivy Bridge and the new socket.If you guys want to read my review of the 4770K then just click on this link or you can search for 4770K on Amazon and it should be the first one listed there.http://www.amazon.com/review/R23I7H2WMMBO61/ref=cm_cr_rdp_perm?ie=UTF8&ASIN=B00CO8TBQ0&linkCode=&nodeID=&tag=My main rig:Case: Corsair 900DGPU: EVGA GTX 780 (Stock)CPU: Intel Core i7 4770K @ 4.6GhzPSU: EVGA SuperNOVA 1000WRam: Kingston 16GB of RAMSSD: Samsung 840 Pro 256GBMB: ASUS Sabertooth Z87OS: Windows 7 64bit

Before I start my review I just want to say that I own the Galaxy S4, Note 2 and now the Galaxy Mega 6.3 and each one of them is unique in different ways. It's been a week since I got my Galaxy Mega 6.3 and this thing is super awesome. It has the same look as the Galaxy S4 but it's just larger. The Galaxy Mega 6.3 makes the Note 2 look tiny in comparison. The Galaxy Mega 6.3 feels like an experimental device from Samsung to see how big of a device people are willing to buy. Since we continue to buy their large phones, Samsung wants to know if we will continue to buy their phones regardless of the size. My main phone is the Galaxy S4 which I think is perfect and I won't get the Galaxy S5 if Samsung decides to make it larger than 5 inches. I think Samsung is getting a little carried away with their phones and trying to make their phones as big as possible. They just need to stop at 5 inches in my opinion.So far the Galaxy Mega 6.3 has been great and the battery life is outstanding, much better than my Note 2/S3/S4. Since the screen is 720p on this phone, it consumes less power than the S4 and it lasts much longer. The Galaxy Mega 6.3 comes with Snapdragon 400 which is a dual core CPU that has no problem handling everything you throw at it. The phone comes with a ton of bloatware as always and I always try to remove most of it because it can really slow down the phone and kill your battery.These are some of the things that I like about the Galaxy Mega 6.3:Pros:+Screen: I personally love big screens and the Galaxy Mega 6.3 has a nice 6.3 inches screen that makes everything stand out when viewing HD videos or playing games. The resolution on this phone is 720 x 1280 (233ppi pixel density) which is the same as the Note 2 but the Note 2 has 34 more pixel density than the Mega 6.3. It would have been great if Samsung put a 1080p screen on it like they did with the S4. 720p is still more than enough and you will hardly notice a big difference between 720p and 1080p on a phone.+Android OS: This phone ships with the most up to date version of Android, Android 4.2.2 (Jelly Bean) which is the fastest Android version yet. Samsung has added many new features to TouchWiz which is great but I'm not really a fan of TouchWiz. I usually just disable all the things that I don't use to improve the performance of the phone and the battery life. I just wish all android phones would come with stock android instead of coming with pre-installed bloatware and whatnot that slows the phone down.+Design: The design is the same as the S4 which I have no problems with because I love my S4 to death. If you have a Galaxy S4 and love the design of it, then you will love the Mega 6.3's design as well. Since the phone is huge compared to the S4, it feels a lot heavier than my S4 because it's roughly 200g while the S4 is 130g. I don't have a problem with the weight of the phone but I'm so used to my S4 being light and thin.+Camera: The rear camera on this phone is 8MP (3264 x 2448 pixels) and the front camera is 1.9MP. They both take great pictures and you don't have to zoom in to look at the picture because of the screen being so big. My Galaxy S4 which has a 13MP camera takes better pictures but I rarely ever use the camera on any of my phones so this is not really a deal breaker for me.+Battery: The battery on the Galaxy Mega 6.3 is 3200mAh which is more than any phone I know. It makes sense to put a large battery in a large phone because it has a huge screen that needs a lot of battery to stay on. So far it seems that the phone can easily last a full day with a single charge. I can get through the day with a single charge and still have 20% left at the end of the day. The battery life is one of the most important aspects when deciding which phone to buy for me because I travel a lot and I need a phone that can last a full day. My Note 2 needs at least two charges to last through the day. The Snapdragon 400 is much more efficient than the Exynos 4412 that's on the Note 2. The Snapdragon 400 is also a dual core while the Exynos 4412 is a quad core which consumes more power.+Processor: The Qualcomm Snapdragon 400 (Dual-core 1.7 GHz) does an amazing job at keeping the phone running blazing fast but it would have been better if Samsung put the Snapdragon 600 that's on the S4 on this phone. I have never experienced a slow down with this phone but since the screen is bigger on the Mega 6.3, it makes more sense to have a powerful CPU to handle everything that you want to do. I'm not saying the Snapdragon 400 is slow or anything but it seems like Samsung wanted to experiment with the Mega 6.3. The Snapdragon 400 has no problems playing games such GTA Vice City on the highest settings.Cons:-Not 1080p screen-Less pixel density than Note 2-Last year's specsOverall, the Galaxy Mega 6.3 is perfect smartphone for people who have large hands or large fingers but for regular users like me, it's not. My main phone will continue to be the S4 because it's perfect for me and has amazing specs. The Galaxy Mega 6.3 is a great phone and it doesn't disappoint if you are one of those people that don't care about how big your smartphone is. The battery life in this phone is almost always guaranteed to last you a full day with a single charge. I was disappointed that this phone came with a 720p screen and a dual core version but that's still more than enough for anyone. The specs of the Mega 6.3 feel like last year's specs and shows that Samsung is just experimenting with the Mega 6.3 to see how many people are willing to buy it.

I bought this PSU because I'm building a rig that needs a high quality PSU so I decided to get the Antec HCP 750W and I absolutely love it. I love all the products that Antec makes from PSUs to cases and have always bought their products in the past. I have never had a bad experience with their products and their customer service is top notch.Antec is known for making reliable and durable PSUs and the High Current Pro 750W is no exception. The installation process is pretty straight forward and you don't need me to explain how to install it because most of us who purchase these kind of things are geeks and we know how stuff works. Another thing that I love about this PSU is that it runs cool and is very quiet. My old PSUs used to make loud noises but this one is inaudible.The Antec High Current Pro 750W is an extremely well built PSU and Antec has used high quality materials that really show when you hold it in hand. It has great sleeved cables that are nice and long and it's gold certified which is a big plus for me. The warranty is 5 years which is always nice because you never know what might happen in the future. I have had many products die on me a few days after the warranty expires and it's the worst thing that can happen. Antec's customer service is outstanding. They have always been very nice to me when I have had to return a few things in the past.The packaging is also great and Antec did a phenomenal job at making sure the PSU is well secured in the box. It runs super quiet and I can't hear a thing. I even tried running Prime95 for a few hours and I haven't heard a single noise coming from the PSU.Pros:+Quite+5 Year Warranty+Gold Certified+Great Packaging+Well sleeved cables+From AntecCons:-PriceyOverall, the Antec HPC 750W is a great power supply and I highly recommend it to anyone who is looking for something reliable and durable. I have been building and fixing computers for as long as I can remember and I have had a lot of bad experiences with other PSUs but this one really got my attention. I give it a 10/10 for the build quality, sexiness, awesome sleeved cables, warranty and many other features that it has. Strongly recommended! I have always trusted Antec with their products and they are still working to this day.My main rig:Case: Corsair 900DGPU: EVGA GTX TitanCPU: Intel Core i7 4770K (still experimenting)PSU: EVGA SuperNOVA 1000WRam: Kingston 16GB of RAMSSD: Samsung 840 Pro 256GBMB: ASUS Sabertooth Z87OS: Windows 7 64bit

I just upgraded my laptop to the Lenovo T431s and I'm blown away by the built quality and the performance of this laptop. My old laptop was a Dell that had a Core 2 Duo which would overheat quiet badly but the T431s runs super cool and doesn't overheat at all. The Lenovo T431s has a 14-inch screen and weighs only 1.56 kg. This makes it great if you are the kind of person who travels a lot. I travel a lot so this is a big plus for me. The Lenovo T431s is the thinnest and lightest T Series model that Lenovo has released. This laptop doesn't just look great but it feels great when holding it in hand too. ThinkPad laptops are known for being very reliable and durable and the T431s is no exception.Lenovo has done a fantastic job at making it as thin and light as possible and it really shows when looking at it. My laptop came with an Intel Core i5, 4GB of DDR3 ram and 500GB HD which is super-fast for day to day tasks. It boots extremely fast and the screen resolution is pretty good. I just wish it came with a 1920 x 1080 resolution instead of 1600x900. Most laptops nowadays come with a 1080p screen and I don't know why Lenovo isn't making that the standard for their laptops.Since my laptop came with a HDD, I'm thinking of getting an SSD so I can see the true speed of this laptop. Putting an SSD will make the laptop even faster than what it already is. I feel like HDDs really bottleneck laptops and computers and upgrading to an SSD will make the bottleneck go away for good. I will update my review if I decide to put an SSD in the future. The screen is readable at any angle regardless of the light conditions. The laptop comes with 2 USB 3.0 ports which is super fast. I do a lot of backup and transfer large files so the USB 3.0 will be quiet fast for that. It also comes with a fingerprint scanner that's on the side of the arrow keys. It's a neat feature to have but I don't use it.The keyboard is the best thing about this laptop. It is a spill-proof keyboard which for me is great because I tend to spill sodas on my keyboard very often. The touchpad is also nice and smooth. I use my T431s for video rendering using the Adobe After Effects and it handles it like a champ. The battery life with the T431s is the best I have seen. It can easily last for more than 6 hours with the brightness turned down a little. This laptop doesn't come with an optical drive but I knew that before I got it so it's not really a big problem for me. I install most of my things from the USB port and I rarely ever use the optical drive. I have two 64GB USBs dedicated to installing programs and things like that.Pros:- Fantastic build quality- Phenomenal keyboard- Fingerprint scanner- Quiet- Runs cool- Spill-proof keyboard- Amazing touchpad surface- Light, thin and sleek- Good overall performanceCons:- 1600x900 is okay but it's not 1080pOverall, the Lenovo T431s is an outstanding laptop and is even better for someone who travels or just wants a very light and thin laptop. I have been using this laptop heavily for a week now and have not experienced any problems. I am very impressed with the phenomenal build quality of this laptop. Lenovo has another winner in their hands with this laptop. The spill-proof keyboard is the best feature this laptop has in my opinion. The only negative I can think of is the resolution which is 1600x900 but it's not a deal breaker for me.My main rig:Case: Corsair 900DGPU: EVGA GTX TitanCPU: Intel Core i7 4770K (still experimenting)PSU: EVGA SuperNOVA 1000WRam: Kingston 16GB of RAMSSD: Samsung 840 Pro 256GBMB: ASUS Sabertooth Z87OS: Windows 7 64bit

I just purchased a Corsair Neutron 256GB for one of my builds that I am doing and I'm blown away by the performance of this drive. My Windows 7 disk experience score went from 5.2 to 7.9 which is the highest it can go. Since I do a lot of backups and transfer large files, everything is so fast now compared to my old HDD that was starting to show its age. One thing to remember when installing an SSD is to make sure you connect it to a SATA3 6Gb/S port because you will not get the full speed of the SSD if you install it to a SATA2 port.The formatted size is 238GB and access and read speed are as advertised. I purchased the Corsair Neutron 256GB to replace my two years old Western Digital Blue 1TB because it was starting to show its age. Games would take forever to load and some of the programs that I use (CAD, Maya, Autodesk) would take forever to load on that HDD. I have four different SSDs at home from Intel 520, 840 Pro, Crucial M4 and now the Corsair Neutron and they are all blazing fast. I have sold the majority of my HDDs at home and only kept SSDs. I have three 2TB HDDs for HD movies and games and that's plenty for me.The installation process is very simple. You just have to make sure to enable AHCI in the BIOS (not IDE) so the SSD can work like it should. Also, make sure you flash the latest bios for your motherboard first before you install this drive. I was getting half the advertised read/write speeds but once I flashed the latest BIOS for my motherboard, it was all good. Another important thing to do after installation is to install the latest SATA drivers and chipset because it makes a huge difference. I got 100MB+ in read and write after installing the latest SATA drivers.I never get to see the entire Windows boot animation with this SSD which shows how fast this thing is. Windows 7 starts in ~8 seconds and shuts down in less than that. Everything opens immediately and games load fast and run great. I have disabled indexing, prefetch, defrag and hibernation because they are not needed when using an SSD. I have even gone ahead and completely disabled page file because most people recommend it to disable it since SSDs are already fast enough. I would recommend you keep page file if you are on a HDD but not on a SSD. You also save a ton of free space if you disable page file which is great.I have nothing but good things to say about the Corsair Neutron 256GB and since it's much cheaper than the competition, it's also a better buy than those other SSDs. Intel 520 and Samsung 840 256GB are both above $200+ but the Corsair Neutron 256GB is below $190. The Corsair Neutron 256GB is defiantly worth the price. I'm testing the Corsair Neutron 256GB with Crysis 3 and BF3 and maps load instantly. I had to wait over 30 seconds before to load the maps with my old Western Digital Blue HDD.Pros:+ Sturdy+ Great Packaging+ Blazing Fast+ Corsair Quality+ Cheaper than the competitionCons:- NoneOverall, I highly I highly recommend upgrading to a Corsair Neutron 256GB SSD if you are still on a HDD. The quick boot and super fast load of applications is amazing. The Corsair Neutron 256GB is also a lot cheaper than the competition and is as fast as Intel 520 and Samsung 840 Pro. Corsair's customer service is amazing and I have never had a problem with them.My main rig:Case: Corsair 900DGPU: EVGA GTX TitanCPU: Intel Core i7 4770K (still experimenting)PSU: EVGA SuperNOVA 1000WRam: Kingston 16GB of RAMSSD: Samsung 840 Pro 256GBMB: ASUS Sabertooth Z87OS: Windows 7 64bit

I just received this case today and my first reaction was that it was too small but once I looked at it from different angles I realized that it was actually very well designed case and Corsair did a really nice job making the inside of the case with lots of openings for cable management and rubber grommets. I bought this case for a build that I am doing and I will be using it with my brand new EVGA GTX 770.The Corsair 350D comes with dual USB 3.0 headers which is great because I do a lot of transferring files back and forth from my external HDD. The materials used to make this case feel really high quality and Corsair is known for making great cases with high quality components. The case comes with a total of five fan mounts which is great because it keeps the case running cool.Another thing that I love about this case is the dust filter. My computer is always running 24/7 and is in the corner of my room under my desk which gathers a lot of dust. I have to always clean the inside because it gathers so much dust that the temps of my CPU go up by 5C if I don't clean it. Dust filers are a must when you purchase a case these days because who has time to clean their computers very often. Another great thing about this case is that you can mount an H100i on top which is what I'm planning to do. I already have an H100i in my other rig but now I will have to purchase another one for this case.Now let's talk a bit about what made me give this case a 4/5 and I was ready to give it a 5/5 easily. So when I got the case, everything looked nice and it looked like everything was perfect, design-wise, but I was wrong. Apparently, you cannot fit a full size DVD drive which is a huge let down for me. The DVD drive will fit but it will stick out and this makes the case look ugly. The motherboard that I am using is an Asus Maximus V Gene which is an average motherboard but the DVD-drive touches the side of the motherboard when it's inserted and it sticks out. After reading online on forums, there are some people who are having the same issue and they have suggested that I buy a smaller DVD-drive. Great, now I have to spend some more money on a DVD-drive.Pros:+ Sturdy+ Dual USB 3.0 Header+ Dust filters+ Great mid-size case+ Fits an H100i on top+ Corsair Quality+ SexyCons:- Full size DVD-drive won't fit (huge letdown)Overall, the Corsair 350D is a nicely designed case that comes with a lot of great features such as the dual USB 3.0 headers, dust filter and a ton of fan mounts to keep the system running cool. Having the option to mount an H100i is a bonus but the lack of fitting a full size DVD-drive ruined it for me. I was ready to give it a 5/5 but not being able to fit my DVD-drive is why I'm giving it a 4/5. Corsair should have thought about that because there are going to be a lot of people who aren't going to be happy about this.My main rig:Case: Corsair 900DGPU: EVGA GTX TitanCPU: Intel Core i7 4770K (still experimenting)PSU: EVGA SuperNOVA 1000WRam: Kingston 16GB of RAMSSD: Samsung 840 Pro 256GBMB: ASUS Sabertooth Z87OS: Windows 7 64bit

Corsair makes some of the highest quality products in this industry and their customer service is top notch. When I first got the 650D, the case fans stopped working out of the blue and Corsair replaced them for free. I didn't have to pay for anything. I have tried many fans before and most of them have stopped working and used to make a lot of weird noises. These fans have been working great for 6 months and they do an absolutely amazing job at pushing air into my case. These fans not only looking great but they dropped the case temps by 5C.Corsair Air Series AF120 is probably the highest quality fan I have ever tested and it makes my case look sexy. The materials used on this fan seem higher quality than the ones I have tested before. I have two of these fans running in my system and it moves a lot of air inside the case. I noticed the temperatures drop by 5C against the stock fans that come with the case. It also dropped the temp of my video card by 3C. This fan can also be used on a radiator and it will make a big difference over the stock fans that come with the radiator.They are also very quiet and even under full load you can't hear a thing. The packaging is great and comes with three colored rings and that's pretty cool. The price is fantastic for the quality of fans you are getting. The fans on full load are hardly audible.Pros:+ Sturdy+ Dropped my case temps by 5C.+ Great at moving air out of my case+ Super Quiet+ Corsair Quality+ SexyCons:- NoneOverall, these fans are highly recommended to anyone who wants to get the highest quality fans on the market. The fans are made by Corsair and that means high build quality which will last you a long time. If you want to drop your case fan temps by 5C and want to drop the temps of your GPU or CPU then this is the fan to get.My main rig:Case: Corsair 900DGPU: EVGA GTX TitanCPU: Intel Core i7 4770K (still experimenting)PSU: EVGA SuperNOVA 1000WRam: Kingston 16GB of RAMSSD: Samsung 840 Pro 256GBMB: ASUS Sabertooth Z87OS: Windows 7 64bit

The GTX 770 is basically a GTX680 which isn't necessarily a bad thing but a good thing since it's much cheaper than a GTX680 and a bit faster. I have five computers at home and I just upgraded one of them to the GTX 770 because the card that I had before (HD6850) just died on me. The GTX 770 is also better designed than a GTX680 and has a nice thick PCB. I love GPUs that have thick PCBs. :DThe EVGA GTX 770 comes with a base clock of 1046Mhz and a boost clock of 1085Mhz. It also comes with 2GB of Vram that is more than enough for gaming. It handles all of my games at 1080p without an issue. It also has no problems maxing games at 2560x1400 and the 2GB Vram is more than enough for that resolution. I'm seeing a lot of people that say 2GB isn't enough for anything above 1080p which isn't true.The GTX 770 has some nice 700-series features that the GTX680 didn't have such as GPU Boost 2.0 and OpenGL 4.3 support. GPU Boost 2.0 allows raising the frequencies of the GPU above their base clock as long as there is enough power headroom and it supplies the the voltage that it requires to accomplish this. This is a nice feature that Nvidia has implemented into their GPUs because it makes their cards much more efficient than the competition. There really isn't any reason to look at 6xx series cards at this point unless the GTX 680 comes down in price.The automatic fan speed is great but I usually use MSI Afterburner to control the fan speed of all of my cards because I have more control over the automatic fan speed. The card idles at around ~32c which is pretty cool and under load doesn't go above 70c. I love the smooth experience that this card delivers in games. This card comes at 10" long which isn't the longest card out there but there are other cards that are shorter and fit into mid ATX cases. I recommend you measure your case before buying it before you run into any trouble.Pros:+ Robust design+ Whisper quiet fans+ GPU Boost 2.0+ Low temps both in idle and under load+ Overclocks like crazy+ EVGA Warranty+ SexyCons:- NoneOverall, I highly recommend the EVGA GTX 770 card to anyone who wants a GPU that can handle all the modern games without breaking a sweat. The EVGA GTX770 is very well designed and uses a quieter cooler than some other brands. The card runs super cool and overclocks like a monster. It delivers a smoother gaming experience than the competition and Nvidia makes awesome drivers. I also recommend going with EVGA when purchasing a GPU from Nvidia because they have one of the best customer service in this industry.My main rig:Case: Corsair 900DGPU: EVGA GTX TitanCPU: Intel Core i7 4770K (still experimenting)PSU: EVGA SuperNOVA 1000WRam: Kingston 16GB of RAMSSD: Samsung 840 Pro 256GBMB: ASUS Sabertooth Z87OS: Windows 7 64bit

The N13 from Asus is a great little device that is capable of streaming Netflix on HD which is exactly why I got it. I have had it for about a year and it hasn't failed me. It's pretty easy to setup and has excellent signal strength. It has never dropped my connection so far and that's a huge plus. My previous adapters have always died after a few months of usage but this one has held up quite well so far. I have a lot of walls in my house and the range of the N13 is pretty solid.It connects fairly quick with my router (RT-N56U). I like the USB extender that comes with it. Asus also makes high quality products and they have a great customer service which have always been kind to me when I have had to RMA a few of my products.Pros:+ Easy to setup+ It's from Asus+ Fast speeds+ Capable of streaming Netflix on HD+ Plug and Play+ Great signal+ USB Extender+ PriceCons:- NoneBeing able to stream Netflix on HD is a huge plus for me because most of the adapters that I had tried before would have a hard time streaming and they would lag badly. The Asus N13 is by far the coolest wireless adapter that I have in my house. I get full signal strength with the N13 from the other end of the house. I have a lot of walls in my house which can make it difficult of the signal to get though but the N13 has no problems.My main rig:Case: Corsair 900DGPU: EVGA GTX TitanCPU: Intel Core i7 4770K (still experimenting)PSU: EVGA SuperNOVA 1000WRam: Kingston 16GB of RAMSSD: Samsung 840 Pro 256GBMB: ASUS Sabertooth Z87OS: Windows 7 64bit

I've had this router for a about two years now and it is still performing great. It hasn't let me down yet which I am surprised because my previous routers have all died within 2 years. The RT-N56U has everything you want in a router. It's fast, has great range, and provides a very stable connection on both the 2.4 and 5ghz radios. The user interface is very user friendly and pretty straightforward. I have my Samsung Galaxy S4 hooked up to this router and I get crazy speeds on both 2.4Ghz and 5Ghz bands. I can get maximum Wi-Fi speeds in any room which is pretty nice and the Gigabyte network port is also useful.The Asus RT-N56U has two USB ports to connect external USB HDD and a printer. Asus has a very good hardware and strong networking team so this product is best for home use with gigabyte network port. Asus always makes outstanding products and they have a great customer service. I have never had an Asus product fail on me (knock on wood) and I will continue to purchase their products.The user interface in RT-N56U is very easy to get around and has every single feature someone could want in a router. I'm using this router as a standard wireless router and I have over 10 devices connected to it via wireless at any given time and it never slows down. I always do a lot of multiplayer gaming, download torrents, and stream HD media quite heavily and it handles everything without an issue. It overheats every now and then when a lot of things are going on but it's not a deal breaker.Pros:+ Blazing Fast+ Great Range+ Gigabyte network port+ Easy to set up+ Dual Band+ Constant Firmware updates+ USB Driver Support+ Slick DesignCons:- Overheats every now and thenOverall, the RT-N56U is a great router for anybody and comes loaded with a ton of features. It's very well designed and it's sexy to look at. The user interface is very well made and it's pretty easy to set up. Asus is constantly releasing new firmwares to improve the performance of the router and fix any problems.My main rig:Case: Corsair 900DGPU: EVGA GTX TitanCPU: Intel Core i7 4770K (still experimenting)PSU: EVGA SuperNOVA 1000WRam: Kingston 16GB of RAMSSD: Samsung 840 Pro 256GBMB: ASUS Sabertooth Z87OS: Windows 7 64bit

Intel leads the world with microprocessor innovation and now they are leading the world with their SSDs. I have upgraded all of my computers at home with SSDs and most of them are running Intel's 520 SSD. The leap in technology that the latest SSDs provide is the most exciting upgrade for a PC in years. Rarely has an upgrade made such a dramatic change in performance. These new SSDs from Samsung, Intel, Crucial truly represent a quantum leap in computer technology. And now that the price is less than $1/GB, the upgrade is a no-brainer. I highly recommend upgrading to an Intel 520 SSD if you are still on a HDD. The quick boot and super fast load of applications is amazing.I sold my old Western Digital 500GB HDD since all of my computers in my house are using Intel 520 SSD. It was very simple to install and just make sure to have AHCI enabled in the BIOS so you can see the true speed of the SSD. Make sure you flash the latest bios for your Motherboard first before you install this drive. I was getting half the advertised read/write speeds but once I flashed the latest BIOS for my motherboard, it was all good.I never get to see the entire Windows boot animation before it makes it to desktop. Windows 7 starts in ~10 seconds & shuts down in less than half that time. Everything opens immediately and games load fast and run great. Games install and uninstall within a few minutes and programs less than a minute. I have disabled indexing, prefetch, defrag because they are not needed when using an SSD.When you buy an Intel SSD, make sure to download the SSD Toolbox from Intel's website which is super handy for updates and optimization. It has a nice friendly interface that's not overwhelming. It is a great tool to update the firmware of your SSD, optimize your OS and perform routine maintenance. I have nothing but good things to say about the Intel 520 SSD, and it is worth the price. I'm testing the Intel 520 with BF3 and maps load instantly. I had to wait over 30 secs before to load the maps with my old HDD. The warranty is 5 years which is more than enough. Intel has another winner in their hands!Pros:+ Fast Write and Read Speeds+ Fast boot times+ Programs/Games install blazing fast+ Constant firmware updates+ Great for MP games that have huge maps to loadCons:- NoneThe Intel 520 SSD is one of the best SSDs you can buy in the market and delivers crazy write and read results. It's also a bit more expensive than the competition but it's also worth the money. Everything from programs to applications are blazing fast and install/uninstall in just a few seconds. Also, if you are a gamer and play a lot of multiplayer games such as Battlefield 3 and Crysis 3 now you don't have to wait minutes for maps to load, it's almost instant. Overall, if you have the cash for a high end SSD, then the Intel 520 SSD won't disappoint you and it's very well worth the money.

I recently purchased a GTX Titan for my main rig and I'm blown away by its performance. I moved my GTX 780 into my second rig which had 2x HD7970s before. I couldn't handle all the terrible micro stuttering and crossfire drivers with AMD. The GTX Titan is designed to max games at crazy high resolutions but it will handle anything at 1080p without an issue. I play games at 2560x1600 and it does a phenomenal job at maintaining 60fps+ in all of my games. You'd need multi-GPUs to play games at that resolution but that's where the Titan separates itself from the rest.So far the card has been amazing. As you guys know, the card has an outstanding build quality. It is one of those things where you have to physically see and touch it to appreciate the quality. The clean look will make your build look amazing. Most of AMD's cards have plastic housing which makes the card look cheap and ugly. Big thumbs up to Nvidia for the cooler designs which make this card stand out from the crowd!I'm really surprised with the overclocking capability of the Titan because I have managed to overclock mine up to 1210mhz and it's been stable in all of my games and benchmarks. The temps stay below 73c while playing games. Battlefield 3 and Crysis 3 look stunning at 2560x1600 with my monitor and the 6GB VRAM helps a lot. Nvidia has another winner in their hands and now it's time for AMD to step up their game. If you are an enthusiast then the GTX Titan is worth every penny and you know you are getting a good deal when buying from EVGA because nobody can beat their customer service.The automatic fan speed is great but I usually use MSI Afterburner to control the fan speed of all of my cards because the automatic fan speed doesn't do a great job at keeping the card very cool when it's under load. The card idles at around ~28c which was roughly the same as my GTX780. Stress testing it with Furmark makes the temps go up to 79c. Furmark is an unrealistic benchmark and the card will never reach that temp while playing games. I love the smooth experience that this card delivers in games and now I don't have to deal with all the crossfire issues that I had with my previous cards.Pros:+ Sturdy+ Quiet fan+ Future-Proof with 6GB Vram+ GPU Boost 2.0+ Single GPU+ Low temps+ Overclocks like crazyCons:- PriceOverall, I highly recommend the card to anyone who wants to try out Nvidia's fastest single GPU. It's very well designed, uses probably the best cooler ever designed which makes the card run super cool. It delivers a smoother gaming experience than any other card I have tried. Also, you can't go wrong with EVGA because they have one of the best customer service in this industry.My main rig:Case: Corsair 900DGPU: EVGA GTX TitanCPU: Intel Core i7 4770K (still experimenting)PSU: EVGA SuperNOVA 1000WRam: Kingston 16GB of RAMSSD: Samsung 840 Pro 256GBMB: ASUS Sabertooth Z87OS: Windows 7 64bit

The Corsair 900D has finally arrived in my house and I'm blown away by this fantastic case. I can safely say it's the best full tower case in the market and there's no other case that looks this sexy. The 900D is enormous; you can fit a ton of radiators and still have room for more. The amount of options for cable management is mind blowing.This case has everything an enthusiast wants in a gaming case. You will find that a lot of thought was put into engineering the Corsair 900D and it really shows when looking at the case. Carrying this case when it's fully loaded is almost impossible because it gets so heavy with all the components inside. Cable management is very good with this case and Corsair has done a fantastic job at providing us with so many options for cable management.I'm upgrading from a Corsair 650D which was an amazing case but I moved it into my second rig. The fans that come with the case are sexy and quiet. You can hardly hear them when they are spinning under full load. With the Corsair 900D being so huge, it's easy to create a clean build with a lot of fans, custom cooling, etc because of the space and cable management options. The side window panel is great because you can view all of your components from outside.The tool-less design, cable management and the magnetic side panel dust filter make this the best case for enthusiasts. There's just so many features that this case has over other cases in the market. Airflow in the case seems to be pretty good and I know this case was mostly designed for water cooling but it does a great job at air cooling as well. I'm currently using a 4770K at 4.6Ghz which generates a lot of heat and this case seems to be doing a good job at moving the air out of the case. I'm using a Corsair H100i in push/pull configuration to cool the CPU and it fits perfectly in the 900D. The front three fans are intake and the back is the only exhaust. My temps with my 4770K at 4.6Ghz in idle hover around 32-35 and under load stay below 80c.Pros:+ Sturdy+ Quiet+ Big (could be a con for some but not for me)+ Widowed side panel+ Magnetic dust filters+ Amazing airflow+ Cable management+ Space for water-cooling+ Tool-less design+ SpaciousCons:- Doesn't cook me dinner.So the Corsair 900D is by far the sexiest case I have ever owned and I have owned a ton of cases before but none of them comes close to the 900D. I have never seen a case like the 900D that provides so many options for cable management, radiators and fan mounting options for enthusiast people like myself. The amount of radiators that you can put in the 900D is mind blowing. Dust filters play an important role in the 900D because they can keep your system running cool and prevent it from gathering dust. I wish my other cases had a dust filter because I'm so tired of opening them up and cleaning them. I highly recommend the Corsair 900D to anyone who wants the best enthusiast case on the market!My main rig:Case: Corsair 900DGPU: EVGA GTX 780CPU: Intel Core i7 4770K (still experimenting)PSU: Corsair AX850Ram: Kingston 16GB of RAMSSD: Samsung 840 Pro 256GBMB: ASUS Sabertooth Z87OS: Windows 7 64bit

Arctic Silver 5 is probably the best thermal compound that I have ever used, and I have used many. I have used it both in CPUs and GPUs and it does a phenomenal job at cooling my components. It keeps my 4770K very cool both in idle and under load. At idle the CPU stays around 33C and under load it hovers around 76C which is overclocked at 4.6Ghz. I'm using an H100i from Corsair to cool my CPU and it works very well with Artic Silver 5. The CPU stays below 65c while playing games such as Battlefield 3 and Crysis 3 on max settings.I know there are people out there who just go straight ahead and use the pre-applied thermal paste that comes with the CPU and get horrible temps. If you are going to spend a lot of money on a high end CPU then you might as well spend a few more bucks on a quality thermal compound. It doesn't add much to the cost of a build and it's worth it in the end because you will get much lower temps than with pre-applied thermal paste.Even when using Prime95, the CPU still stays very cool thanks to this awesome thermal paste. I use the pea method and have always gotten good results. I know some people use the single strip method right in the middle of the CPU and spread it out but I have found that the pea method works better.I did some comparisons against the pre-applied thermal paste that comes with most CPUs/GPUs and found out that Artic Silver 5 dropped my temps around 7-10c. Artic Silver 5 comes with plenty of paste that can last a long time. Make sure you do it right because some people have their own methods which sometimes works and sometimes doesn't. If you don't apply it right, you may even get worse temps than before. Putting just the right amount of thermal paste between your CPU and your cooler makes all the difference, trust me.My main rig:Case: Corsair 650DGPU: EVGA GTX 780CPU: Intel Core i7 4770K (still experimenting)PSU: Corsair AX850Ram: Kingston 16GB of RAMSSD: Samsung 840 Pro 256GBMB: ASUS Sabertooth Z87OS: Windows 7 64bit

The GIGABYTE GA-990FXA-UD5 is extremely well designed and it's absolutely awesome to look at. Everything is spread out that you have enough room to work with. It supports big air coolers like Noctua D14 and doesn't block the ram sticks. Updating the bios for this motherboard is a piece of cake. You download the bios, reboot into bios and it will automatically load the file from your hard-drive/USB and you are done. Gigabyte has done a fantastic job of creating an amazing motherboard and providing a ton of features for overclocking your CPU.I'm blown away by the quality of this motherboard and Gigabyte has always made high quality products from graphic cards to motherboards. This motherboard is so well designed and the bios is easy to work with thanks to the UEFI technology. Overclocking with this motherboard is super easy and I was able to get my old CPU (960T) to 4.2Ghz with no trouble at all. Just change the multiplier in the bios and you are all set. The heatsinks over the VRMs are big enough that keep it nice and cool.I have always liked AMD for keeping the same socket and having reasonable prices with their processors. AMD said that they will keep AM3+ socket even after Steamroller is released which is great because we don't have to spend money on buying a new motherboard. Steamroller will bring a ton of improvements both to IPC and will lower the power consumption quiet a lot.This motherboard supports the newest FX Processors and will support Steamroller when it gets released. Vishera CPUs work great in this motherboard and overclock great too. You just need to update the bios that Gigabyte will release in the future. Gigabyte is very good when it comes to releasing bios/drivers/firmware for their products. Overclocking in this motherboard is a piece of cake and the 8+2 phase VRM power design helps a lot in overclocking.The GIGABYTE GA-990FXA-UD5 also supports 3-way CrossFire or SLI which is great if you are a multi-graphics user. It also comes with 6 native SATA3 ports and has support for RAID 0, 1, 5, 10. I recommend this motherboard to anyone who is looking to get the best AMD motherboard on the market. The Asus Sabertooth 990FX is also a very good motherboard and they are equally good. I had my old Phenom X4 960T at 4.2Ghz (1.46 volts) using this motherboard and it had no problem handling it. If you plan on upgrading to Steamroller when it's released, then this is motherboard will support it.Pros:-PCIe 3.0x-USB 3.0-UEFI Bios-A ton of SATA ports-Easy to Overclock-3-Way SLI/Crossfire-8+2 Phase VRM-Sexy color schemeCons:-None, really.The Gigabyte GA-990FXA-UD5 is one of the best motherboards for AMD that Gigabyte has made. It comes with a ton of SATA ports and comes with 8+2 Phase VRM that can handle a ton of volts like a champ. Overclocking with this motherboard is great and I have seen a lot of people push the Thuban CPUs up to 4.2Ghz using this motherboard. It has an amazing design and can support up to 3 way SLI/Crossfire. If you run multi-GPUs then this motherboard is great for that. The bios is also super easy to work on and update because of the UEFI technology. I highly recommend this motherboard to all AMD users who want a high end motherboard.My main rig:Case: Corsair 650DGPU: EVGA GTX 780CPU: Intel Core i7 4770K (still experimenting)PSU: Corsair AX850Ram: Kingston 16GB of RAMSSD: Samsung 840 Pro 256GBMB: ASUS Sabertooth Z87OS: Windows 7 64bit

I use this processor for 3D rendering and gaming and it does an outstanding job. I have it overclocked to 4.9Ghz using 1.48 volts and it is prime95 stable. Under load, temps never go above 55c and in idle it stays around 26c. I love overclocking this CPU and I will keep it until Steamroller is released. This CPU just plows through everything especially when playing games such as BF3, FC3 and Crysis 3. It runs around 50-60% usage when playing BF3 on max settings.I have always liked AMD for keeping the same socket and having reasonable prices with processors. Even though the processor does not have eight true cores, it's fast enough for gaming and applications. CPU-Z recognizes it as 4 cores/8 threads which is true. I'm using an H100i to get it overclocked to 4.9Ghz and it keeps the CPU very cool. The power consumption at 4.9Ghz is 302watts which is very high. The stock cooler is only good for stock settings but if you are going to overclock it then you need an aftermarket cooler.The FX-8320 also loves higher ram frequency and I have my ram overclocked to 2133Mhz and it's blazing fast. Vishera pulls less power than Zambezi and Steamroller will lower the power consumption even more. Vishera is up to 20% faster than Zambezi depending on the CPU load. It's not as fast as Sandy/Ivy Bridge or Haswell but it does its job very well. Intel has a huge power advantage over AMD because they are on 22nm with Ivy/Haswell and even on 32nm with Sandy Bridge they lowered the power consumption dramatically. Steamroller will be at 28nm while Broadwell will be on 14nm and it will be difficult for AMD to catch up to Intel.Overall, Vishera is a great CPU if you are on a AM3/AM3+ socket and does great in modern games and applications. It wins in some multi-threaded tests such as in the latest x264 and POV-Ray because they utilize all the cores available. Vishera loses in most single-threaded performance tests against Sandy/Ivy Bridge because it has weaker cores but makes up for it in multi-threaded tests. Power consumption is also a big negative for Vishera because it draws considerably more power under load compared when overclocked. It's a great CPU and I would recommend it to any AMD user.Pros:+Overclocks like crazy.+Strong in games+Supports 1866-2133Mhz Ram+Cheap+Works in older sockets+Excellent multi threaded performanceCos:-Power Consumption-Performs poorly in single thread applicationsThe FX-8320 is a powerful chip that can handle everything you throw at it, from games to heavy applications. If you are a 3D artist or an animator that uses applications that utilize all cores available such as 3Ds Max, Maya, CAD or Zbrush then the FX-8320 will go above and beyond to satisfy your needs. The FX-8320 also overclocks like beast and can handle overclocks of up to 5Ghz. I have seen people push this thing up to 5.3Ghz with water cooling and get crazy benchmark results. It does great in games that utilize all cores such as BF3, Crysis 3 or Metro LL. The only downside to Vishera is the power consumption and the performance in single thread applications. This chip works in older sockets but you first need to check with your motherboard manufacturer to see if there's a bios update.My main rig:Case: Corsair 650DGPU: EVGA GTX 780CPU: Intel Core i7 4770K (still experimenting)PSU: Corsair AX850Ram: Kingston 16GB of RAMSSD: Samsung 840 Pro 256GBMB: ASUS Sabertooth Z87OS: Windows 7 64bit

I had two of these cards in crossfire before I upgraded my main rig to the GTX780 and they were monsters. I had absolutely no problem maxing any game with 60fps+. These cards are now in my second rig which I use for gaming and they still run like beasts. I was able to push both of my HD7970s to 1200mhz/1600mhz with 1.25 volts. The temps always stayed below 70c with my overclocking and they would idle around 26c. Also, this card has 3GB Vram which is more than enough for high resolution gaming even though some people claim that it isn't. I used to play BF3 at max settings at 2560x1440 and the vram usage was around 2GB so it's more than enough.My 2x HD7970 used run pretty cool in idle around 26-28c and under load when playing games it would go up to 69-71c. My old HD6970s used to go up to 85c and they were quite loud. The automatic fan speed doesn't do a great job when the card is under load. I have to manually set the fan at 65% to keep the card cool. I usually use MSI Afterburner to control the fan speed of all of my cards because the automatic fan speed doesn't do a great job at keeping the card very cool.When playing modern games such as BF3, FC3 and Crysis 3, the temps stay in the low 60s which is relatively cool for this card. Stress testing it with Furmark makes the temps go up to 76c. This card has absolutely no problems at maxing BF3 or any other game for that matter. I tested it by playing BF3 at maximum settings at 2560x1440 and the fps stayed around 65fps.Pros:+ Sexy design+ Whisper quiet fans+ Low temps both in idle and under load+ Overclocks like crazy+ Made by Sapphire+ 3GB of VramCons:- NoneOverall, I highly recommend the HD7970 to anyone who wants a high end card that plays all games on max settings. The Sapphire HD7970 is very well built, runs super cool and delivers a smooth gaming experience. Sapphire also makes quality cards and has a great customer service which I prefer over some other brands. This thing can overclock like a beast which says a lot about the architecture of the card. I have the card overclocked at 1200/1600 and it handles it fine.My main rig:Case: Corsair 650DGPU: EVGA GTX 780CPU: Intel Core i7 4770K (still experimenting)PSU: Corsair AX850Ram: Kingston 16GB of RAMSSD: Samsung 840 Pro 256GBMB: ASUS Sabertooth Z87OS: Windows 7 64bit

I have had this motherboard in my HTPC for a few months now and I absolutely love it. It's been stable and hasn't given me any issues. I previously had the 5800K in this motherboard and I had it overclocked to 4.5Ghz with a few mouse clicks. I recently upgraded to the 6800K and this motherboard has let me overclock it to 4.8Ghz using around 1.48 volts. This board has 8 phase VRM which makes it awesome to overclock using this board. I have seen some people push this thing up to 5.3Ghz using this board with around 1.58volts which is incredible if you ask me.I use my HTPC to watch HD movies and do some light gaming and it absolutely handles everything I throw at it without a problem. I have also overclocked the ram to 2400Mhz because the 6800K benefits quiet a lot from higher memory speeds. I have also overclocked the NB frequency to 2000Mhz and have noticed a smoothness in both games and applications.The Asus F2A85-V Pro is a really high quality board at a decent price and I'm very impressed with Asus because they really know how to make amazing motherboards. The BIOS/UEFI is great and packed full of features and offers extreme features to overclock your CPU. This motherboard comes with 7 SATA 6 Gb/s ports which is one of the features that I love from this motherboard. The Asus F2A85-V Pro comes with two PCIe 2.0 x16 slots which is also very nice. It also has two PCI slots just in case for your older devices and three PCIe x16 slots.When I had my 5800K on this motherboard, I was able to get it to 4.5Ghz without a problem. The 6800K on this motherboard overclocks like crazy. I even pushed it to 5Ghz using only 1.51 volts with a CM212+ and this motherboard is able to handle it perfectly fine. The temps were too high so I went back to 4.8Ghz but if you have a good air cooler or water cooler then you can get it 24/7 stable at 5Ghz.Overall, this is a great motherboard to get and it will be even better when Kaveri (28nm) is released which will include massive IPC improvements and will work on this board with only a bios update. Kaveri will also lower the power consumption drastically and will overclock a lot higher than Richland. The Asus F2A85-V Pro is probably the best FM2 motherboard you can buy but it's also expensive but it's worth it in the end because you are getting a quality product that is durable and very reliable.If you want to build an HTPC for HD watching movies and doing some light gaming then this board will be more than enough for anything you throw at it. It has a ton of features for overclocking which is always nice to have. Another great thing about APUs is that it seems that more software developers are supporting OpenCL to take advantage of the GPU to accelerate performance so this will bring huge performance improvements to AMD's APUs in the future.Pros:-Will support Kaveri(28nm) when it's released-Runs cool-Three PCIe x16 slots-Slick design-A ton of SATAIII ports-Handles high overclocks-UEFI Bios-Sexy color scheme-From AsusCons:-NoneOverall, I highly recommend the Asus A85X F2A85-V PRO motherboard to anyone who is looking to get the best AMD FM2 socket motherboard on the market. Not only handles high overclocks like a champ but it's also future proof because it will support Kaveri when it's released which will be on a 28nm die. Kaveri will bring huge improvements to the table and will feature a much faster GPU. It's a great motherboard to get if you want to build an HTCP for watching HD movies and doing some light gaming.If you guys are interested in reading my review of the 6800K then just search for 6800K on Amazon and it's the first review listed there.My main rig:Case: Corsair 650DGPU: EVGA GTX 780CPU: Intel Core i7 4770K (still experimenting)PSU: Corsair AX850Ram: Kingston 16GB of RAMSSD: Samsung 840 Pro 256GBMB: ASUS Sabertooth Z87OS: Windows 7 64bit

I previously had a 5800K in my HTCP and I was more than satisfied with its performance but now I have the 6800K in my HTPC that I use to watch movies and do some light gaming and it works like charm. It handles everything I throw at it without a hassle. Since the 6800K supports memory speeds of 2133Mhz, system memory speeds are important because both the CPU and GPU share the same memory interface and this is very improvement if you are a gamer because it can boost your FPS quiet a lot. I noticed a smoothness when playing games coming from the 5800K that ran at 1600Mhz.The stock frequency of the CPU is 4.1Ghz (1.4 volts) but it has a nice turbo of 4.4Ghz which is great. And the stock frequency of the GPU is 844Mhz (1.25 volts). The stock settings are more than enough to handle anything but I have mine overclocked to 4.8Ghz and it flies. It runs relatively cool with the stock cooler without needing to upgrade to an aftermarket cooler. I even tried overclocking it to 5Ghz using my CM212+ using 1.51volts but it generated a lot of heat so I went down to 4.8Ghz. I also overclocked the GPU to 1020Mhz from stock 844Mhz using around 1.34 volts and games are much more smoother now.The motherboard that I am using to overclock my 6800K to 4.8Ghz is the Asus A85X F2A85-V PRO which is the best motherboard you can get for FM2 socket. The Asus A85X F2A85-V PRO has 8 phase VRMs which makes it awesome to overclock and it can handle a ton of volts without a problem. I have seen some people push the 6800K up to 5.3Ghz using this board with around 1.58 volts which is incredible if you ask me. I highly recommend getting the Asus A85X F2A85-V PRO if you want the best FM2 socket motherboard. The motherboard will also support Kaveri (28nm) when it's released which will bring a ton of improvements and lower power consumption.Let's talk a bit about the power consumption at 4.8Ghz because it really is amazing how little power this thing consumes. In idle, it consumes roughly 8-9 watts and under full load it consumes around 108-110watts. Even though Core i3 Ivy Bridge is at 22nm and has better power consumption than Richland which is at 32nm, I still think the power consumption is more than acceptable.I am able to play games like Team Fortress 2, Left 4 Dead 2 and Counter Strike GO without a problem at 1920x1080. It can even handle some modern games at medium settings which I think is amazing. I'm really impressed with the APUs that AMD has been making.Here are some benchmarks that I did against the 5800K both overclocked to 4.5Ghz. I wanted to test both of them at 4.8Ghz but I couldn't get the 5800K anywhere near 4.6Ghz without crashing and the temps going through the roof so instead I dialed it back at 4.5Ghz.SuperPi5800K @ 4.5Ghz = 1394.66 Seconds6800K @ 4.5Ghz = 1244.22 SecondsCinebench 11.5 (Multi-Threaded-GPU)5800K @ 4.5Ghz = 37.54 FPS6800K @ 4.5Ghz = 45.38 FPSCinebench 11.5 (Multi-Threaded-CPU)5800K @ 4.5Ghz = 3.266800K @ 4.5Ghz = 3.87All the games that I have tested so far have been at max settings except for Metro LL and BF3 which were unplayable. The resolution is 1920x1080 using the iGPU.Metro Last Light - Medium Settings5800K @ 4.5Ghz = 17FPS avg6800K @ 4.5Ghz = 19FPS avgBattlefield 3 - Medium Settings5800K @ 4.5Ghz = 21FPS avg6800K @ 4.5Ghz = 24FPS avgTeam Fortress 2 - Max Settings5800K @ 4.5Ghz = 59FPS avg6800K @ 4.5Ghz = 64FPS avgCounter Strike GO - Max Settings5800K @ 4.5Ghz = 61FPS avg6800K @ 4.5Ghz = 68FPS avgLeft 4 Dead 2 - Max Settings5800K @ 4.5Ghz = 55FPS avg6800K @ 4.5Ghz = 57FPS avgOverall, the improvements over the 5800K makes this worthless to upgrade so I wouldn't upgrade if I was stuck on a 5800K but if you are thinking about building an HTPC then Richland is the way to go. As you can see from the results above, the improvements in games and applications is less than impressive. What I like about AMD and their APUs is the fact they still use the same socket (FM2) which means you will be able to upgrade your APU in the future to the one that will use the steamroller cores which will be bring a ton of improvements and lower the power consumption drastically. The iGPU in the 6800K is also much faster than Haswell's iGPU and will play games a lot smoother. The driver support will also be better than Intel because it will be directly from AMD. I give this APU a 4/5 just because of the tiny improvements over Trinity. I don't have a lot of time now but I will update my review once I do more tests.If you guys want to read my review of the Asus A85X F2A85-V PRO then go to this link and it should be the first one listed there.http://www.amazon.com/ASUS-240-Pin-Motherboards-F2A85-V-PRO/dp/B009F1DUAM/ref=cm_cr-mr-titleMy main rig:Case: Corsair 650DGPU: EVGA GTX 780CPU: Intel Core i7 4770K (still experimenting)PSU: Corsair AX850Ram: Kingston 16GB of RAMSSD: Samsung 840 Pro 256GBMB: ASUS Sabertooth Z87OS: Windows 7 64bit

I went into Best Buy today because I need a DVI to VGA adapter but the cheapest one I could find there was $12.99 so I walked out of there. I went on Newegg and immediately found this and purchased it. It was half the price of what Best Buy was trying to sell which really isn't a surprise because Best Buy is known for having ridiculous prices. I don't understand how they are still alive in this industry with those ridiculous prices.The reason why I needed a DVI to VGA adapter is because I'm using three monitors off a Sapphire HD5850 and I used two of these adapters to connect my side monitors and they work flawlessly. My middle monitor is connected with a displayport to VGA adapter and so far I have had no problems with these adapters. They work perfectly and do what they are supposed to do.

Noctua makes possibly the best fans on the market. I have never had a bad experience with their products and they offer a 6 year warranty on their products. Their customer service is also amazing. Most fans will not last you that long; most fans stop working after 3-4 years if you are lucky. This is the reason you buy these fans because you know they will last you a long time and you always have the warranty as a backup option in case it dies out.This is probably the highest quality fan I have ever tested and I'm more than happy with my purchase. While they do cost more than the competition, they are also made with better materials that last much longer than other fans. I have used two of these fans as a case fan to cool my system and it moves a lot of air inside the components. I noticed the temperatures drop by 2-3c against the stock fans that come with the case. The best of all is that this fan can be used on a radiator and it will make a big difference over the stock fans that come with the radiator.They are also very quiet and even under full load you can't hear a thing. The packaging is great and comes with a lot of useful accessories. Includes all the low noise adapters you need to silence the fan without a fan controller. The build quality is top notch. It moves a good amount of air while being very quiet.The only negative about it is the cost and the color scheme. I personally don't care about the colors because they are inside my case and I rarely see them so it doesn't bother me that much. If you have the cash for it then I recommend you get a few of these fans because it will make a big difference in terms of temperatures.Pros:+ Sturdy+ Dropped my case temps by 3C.+ Great at moving air out of my case+ Super Quiet+ Can be mounted on a radiatorCons:- Color scheme- CostThe Noctua 140mm fan does an amazing job at moving the air out of the case quickly without getting your components to overheat. It will also drop the temp of your components which says a lot about the quality of the fan. It's also whisper quiet ever under full load. Since the fan is so efficient and quiet, it make sense to mount in your radiator if you are running a water cooling setup. I highly recommend the Noctua 140mm to anyone who wants the best fan on the market. I know the color scheme isn't the best thing about this fan but don't let that fool you.My full rig:Case: Corsair 650DGPU: EVGA GTX 780CPU: Intel Core i7 4770K (still experimenting)PSU: Corsair AX850Ram: Kingston 16GB of RAMSSD: Samsung 840 Pro 256GBMB: ASUS Sabertooth Z87OS: Windows 7 64bit

I'm pasting this review from my website but you will have to go to my website in order to see the benchmark results because I cannot put pictures in Amazon reviews.
