This book was written shortly after our latest financial crisis and the dust had not yet really cleared. All we know is a bunch of instruments in the form of securitization of really bad debt will not pay.The book looks at the human cost of such actions which tries to make it personal but the macro and micro never really meet. I credit Katz with attempting to warn us of future calamity but human nature abhors a vacuum and that vacuum is made of up conflicting wants and needs, risks and rewards, foibles and facts.

The premise, pace and execution in the first half of the novel deserves a five star rating. The intrigue and action kicks off right away and really takes hold. Two Brit pilots find themselves down behind enemy lines during WW2. While evading their pursuers they make it onto an SS hospital train where they assume the role of wounded officers. Eventually they end up in a psychiatric clinic...how this works with the language and other issues is inventively thought out. And their stay there is harrowing for many reasons. It was positively gripping.The latter half of the novel moves us forward in time to the early 1970's. This covers the fate of many from the clinic. Unfortunately, it went on too long and was overly treated. It felt somehow defensive and aspired to be more complex than it needed to be. The resolution works but your patience will be tested to reach it. This is why the three star rarting. The novel had its impact though, I still think about the equal amounts of bravery and fear needed to pull off the initial deception in order to survive.

Bernie Gunther leads one interesting life. In this tenth book in the series, author Kerr once again places Bernie in incredible circumstances within real historical events. This plot involves Goebbels, Yugoslavia, the Swiss, and a beautiful movie actress. If that seems original, it is not in 'Philip Kerr' terms. He has created a formula for the series. Goebbels is used much like Reinhard Heydrich and Heinrich Himmler have been in the past novels. Bernie often gets flung to weird geographies to investigate both civilian and military crimes. The scenes in Yugoslavia employed in The Lady from Zagreb are vivid and disturbing (a foreshadowing of that country's disintegration decades later). The Swiss provide enigmatic twists and Bernie's love interest, well, is a love interest.One aspect is growing tiresome and that is Bernie's constant morose, tired explanation of how much he loathes the Nazis. Yet, he continues to work for them, aiding and abetting their doctrine and actions. His Berlin humour and cop demeanour only gets him so far. Kerr does explore moral issues and the evil of man but there must be a reckoning at some point. The series has not been chronological. Earlier novels explored post-war Bernie but it will be fascinating to see how Kerr eventually winds up the man's life.

I read this in paperback when it first came out. My memory of that turn through the pages was favourable. In this second pass, it did not hold up as well. Since the original publication there have been an overwhelming number of post-apocalyptic and dystopian novels written. What first appealed in The Culled was the premise even if the execution was rough and a little off-putting. This time the cults and factions in a much changed world came across as absurd rather than threatening. Readers should know that this became a series so may choose to tough it out to see if it improves.

A young adult time travel novel you say. No doubt it will be simplistic even juvenile. It is bound to tread familiar ground. These statements could not be farther from the truth. In fact, the only clue to this being written for a younger audience is the complete lack of expletives. I actually found this refreshing and not for prudish reasons but for the author's need to be more selective in word choice.So many aspects of this book work. The plotting is fresh, intriguing and entertaining throughout. There are layers of decent complexity and surprises that run to the very last page. We follow teenager Jack Lund back in time. Jack is on a mission to right a horrible wrong. There is such grit behind this premise that, once again, the YA classification does not seem accurate. I must admit that I rushed the book. It felt as if I was flipping pages like I did in my youth when when a new comic arrived on the stands. Hautman gives the reader, regardless of age, credit for their intellect. This was fun, fast and entertaining. I look forward to rereading it in time. By the way, after finishing it I read more about the author and love his quirky biographies on Amazon and his website.

My fellow reviewers have pointed out that Valhalla reads like a Clive Cussler novel. It also reminded me of Matthew Reilly adventures. It is unquestionably formula but well done formula. All of the required components are present:- an ancient artifact that could change the world- an evil man with means- a highly capable military man- the love interest who is often a scientist- globe trotting locales- plenty of gunfire- a race against timeYou get the idea. It is also helpful to throw in some references to the Nazis and feature special forces units. Valhalla treads familiar ground but does it in a capable, entertaining and pleasing way. It is a fun escape best suited for a rainy afternoon or as an airplane read.

J.L. Bourne is to blame. He is a major contributor to the explosion of all things zombie this past decade. His series of Day by Day novels follows a military man in a much changed world. The proliferation of similar plots and situations has been staggering since he reinvigorated the 'last man on earth' premise. Now we have the Arisen series by Glynn James and Michael Stephen Fuchs, The Remaining series by D.J. Molles and many, many more.So it was with some hesitation that I invested time in Lundy's series. After all, how new and fresh could it be? The genre is now largely a furious plagiarism of the same characters and stories. This thesis held true once I had read the exploits of cut-off military personnel in Afghanistan. They are truly caught behind enemy lines. So it is really nothing new and no more than serviceable in style, substance and plot. However, my big learning is that I love the premise so will forgive the repetition and so-so quality. In this regard, I am a pliable sucker.

There is definitely curious value in this thriller. As it was published pre 911, in early 2001, the disgruntled militia-type villains seem almost quaint now. It is fascinating to read about such nostalgic threats. The author also keeps the plot going...and going. Just when you think (or hope) it's over, it finds another incredulous thread to pull. These include the most laborious inter-agency wrangling between the FBI, CIA and ATF. Then there is vague back story that prompts a CIA assassin to romp around. A tightening up by a rigorous editor would have been great.

This is definitely an interesting premise for an anthology. The editors and contributors cover the centuries with various tales of military horror. Like most collections there is a range of quality but still overall value. Out of the sixteen, I enjoyed:- Blackwater that conjured up creepy sea creatures (not the private military contractor)- Maberry contributes a Joe Ledger story that is one of the best written and paced- Special Operations Interview was creative and the setting on a Pacific island during WW2 compelling- Making Waves also takes place during WW2 but in an interesting alternative reality where magic and sorcery are weapons- A Tide Of Flesh has the Brits fighting zombies (of all kinds) in India- Snipers save the day in Afghanistan against zombie-vampires in Death at 900 Meters- Eric S. Brown pits reservists against rampaging Bigfoots in Hold the Line- an Austrian tank crew barely escapes a long buried terror during the invasion of The Soviet Union in The ShrineMilitary and horror make for a solid mashup. This collection inspired me to write one for fun...Mr. Maberry, may I send it your way? :)

The novel is cool that is undeniable. It is set in a coming New York that reels from terrorism. The resilient and the designer-drugged have stayed on. It features an anti-hero who dispatches folks for a fee and with a box cutter (a bit of a curious terrorist link right there). The characters are post-apocalyptic noir and their language is clipped, staccato-like as some sort of ode to texting and tweeting.I loved the first third. It was incredibly paced and highly compelling. I resigned myself to buying the next in the series. That is until I read the rest. What began so well become repetitive and ho-hum. In other words the sets and the costumes could not save the play. The drug angle was all too familiar and none of the characters including the main elicited much empathy or sustained interest. Yet, I must conclude it was still cool and perhaps the second will be all the cooler. I may tune into find out.

The three stars may seem harsh given I loved the premise and most of the execution. It comes up short on length (no pun intended) and the resolution was abrupt and unoriginal. Everything else rocked like an M16 on full auto. There is plenty of testosterone given the military and ghoulish activity. I enjoyed Curran's over the top descriptions of various weird doings in Vietnam during the war. If anyone knows of similar works please let me know. Cheers!

It took me a few months to summon the courage to buy and read Dead Bait. Outside of a tiny bit of claustrophobia, my biggest fear are creatures below the surface. I blame my brother for taking me to see Jaws when I was ten. The book is a scary guilty pleasure that is uneven but in a good way like the Creepy and Eerie comic books from days gone by. In fact, this would have made a great graphic short story collection.The standouts for me were: Chum Bucket as it featured a leviathan and those always 'get me'; The Test Drive had a Stephen King vibe and surprise; and Lobster Stew that was by far the best written and imagined. Death Roe drew you in and taught you not to take things that are not yours...especially mermaid eggs. I think I live in Canada because for much of the year our water is frozen.

The five stories in this collection were gorier than expected. The Price You Pay and Murder in Chains were much like the Saw movie franchise. Magic Eyes was enjoyable but predictable. The Watcher was subtle and the most interesting. Weeds by Stephen King may seem familiar as it was one of the stories in the movie Creepshow (King himself played the lead). Even at the low price of less than $3, I would not recommend this short anthology.

This is a book rich in the detail of youth, innocence, fun and the love of family.  An adventurous girl and her younger brother find a suitcase, and decide to use a part of their summer vacation on the farm in Canada where they live to find out where it came from.  The mystery itself is delicious, satisfying and unexpected.  The journey along the way took me back, in a powerful way, to the days of my own youth in the 50s and 60s when we played outside with our brothers and sisters all day as long as there was sunlight.  The children are real: smart and full of energy, but not clever in an unbelievable way as I sometimes see in other books for young readers.  Their days on the farm include wandering through the fields, family suppers, the presence of farm machinery, visits to town and the local library, swims in the dugout and trips to other landmarks familiar to anyone who grew up on a farm.  Norma Jean and her brother Howard often have to complete daily chores before play, and a watch dog is their frequent companion.  It was a joy to spend time with Norma Jean and her extended family, which included grandparents and an uncle.  Their Dutch heritage is also an interesting aspect of the story.This was so much a visit to my own days of innocence--even though different in many of the details--that I didn't want it to end.  It was sweet and funny, poignant and full of family love as it was back then. I became immersed in the mystery and wanted to see how it would end. If you grew up then, take a visit back.  If you're younger, take a trip through time to see what it was like.  It's a very good story for children of any age, and adults will find the writing refreshing, assured and full of love.

I love to think about heaven and wonder what it will be like, so I was attracted to this book.First of all, there is a problem with the Kindle edition, which seems to affect the first chapter only.  In the first chapter there are some embedded fonts.  At the very beginning the font is very black and rather big, and you can't adjust it, then, at location 40, it switches into something that looks very much like a typewriter font.  But by the second chapter, you can fix this by going to the TOC and then choosing Chapter 2.  Then it becomes customizable.As to the content of the book, it was very sweet.  There are many lovely anecdotes of common people that he uses to help us understand his points.  However, I didn't really learn anything new.  If you know the Bible reasonably well, you already know that heaven is a place, people you know will be there, we'll have bodies, there is a book with your name on it, etc. Is there an actual book?  D.L. Moody says there is. He is very literal.  But I have to say, he does make those things seem wondrous.  You can feel the heat in his passion.  At the end of many sections, he ends with poetry, or lyrics to hymns that are simple and rhyming.All of his arguments are based on scripture, and in most cases, he gives you the verses.  He does little if any extrapolating, although he does say that we are with Christ the moment we die, and are not unconscious waiting until the end of the age, as some believe.Remember, this book is old.  Victoria was still Queen, as he mentions. But really, that's a part of its charm!

Be careful!  Many of the reviews of this book contain spoilers.  This review doesn't.This book I would call an amusing trifle.  I downloaded it from the Project Gutenberg website and I found few errors apart from occasional blocks of space in the middle of a chapter.  The story moves at a fast clip. There is a lot of "woe is me" from one character that gets a little much, but in the middle of the book there is a plot twist that creates a great deal of suspense.  It was a fun ride, a good beach read.  I read a lot of Victorian literature, including Dickens and Wilkie Collins, George Eliot, and others, and while this is not even close to that level of writing, it's still a good, light distraction.It contains some author intrusion in the form of moralizing, but that is typical of the time, and I didn't mind.  The story revolves around a young woman whose father dies, leaving her penniless.  An earnest young man offers for her and she marries him.  It could have turned out well, but then temptation arises in the form of a handsome rascal.  After that are many twists and turns.  Read it to find out what happens!

I've read three of the Jack Reacher books and I thought I'd write a review for those who are new to the series.Is Jack Reacher a man you can root for or is he a cold blooded killer?  Is there a lot of graphic sex and gratuitous violence?Jack Reacher is a tough guy and a little bit of a loner and a drifter.  But he doesn't have an attitude and he is capable of having feelings and relationships.  So he's not a cartoon or a stereotype--he's fully fleshed out, a "real" person.  I do like him.  He does a lot of violent things, but he has a moral code.  His moral code is that he stands up for the good people and the bad people are disposable.  And there are some really, really bad people in the Jack Reacher novels.  The situations can be quite disturbing if you're sensitive to that kind of thing.  However, I find it is pretty easy to skip over the violent parts without losing the thread of the story.There is usually a romance that heightens the stakes, and the stakes are always very high, creating a lot of suspense.  But the suspense isn't unrelenting.  There are areas where Reacher has to do research and interview people, and there are conversations and ruminations.  The romances are sweet and sexy, and there is nothing graphic, gross or crude.  The bad guys sometimes act out sexually, and those scenes are disturbing without being crude. I skipped over them.As for language, I really don't remember there being much.  As tough as Jack Reacher is, and as evil as his opponents are, Lee Child somehow gets by creating realistically violent and even evil situations without reverting to profanity or obscenity.The books are gripping and I get very involved in the stories and find them hard to put down.  Good writing, well-formed characters, solid plotting, suspense and a little romance keep me wanting to read more.

I loved "It's A Dilly" and still have some, even though they stopped making it quite a few years ago.  This product is close, but does not quite make it.  Compare ingredients:McCormick It's A Dilly:Onion, garlic, dill weed, lemon peel, dill seed and jalapeno pepper.Engage Organics It's a Dilly:Garlic, sesame seed, dill, lemon peel, jalapeno pepper and STEVIA.That's right.  No onion, and they added sesame seed and STEVIA!  Ugh.  I can always taste the sugar substitutes in everything.  This may be all right with you if you use it in recipes that call for a bit of sweetness, but if you're looking for a more savory taste, this might not do it for you.  I use the McCormicks mainly in otherwise bland canned soups, and it really jazzes them up!  But now, I've got to taste STEVIA.  Bleech.  Not even sure it's safe.This is a nice company though, and I got a sample packet of several of their other spices when I received my order, along with a welcoming note.  I hope they read this and take out the Stevia.Why did you do it, Engage Organics?  Why, why, why???

I wouldn't compare this to Harry Potter, which is filled with angst.  It is more like Narnia, which is lighter in tone, while still teaching important life lessons in a non-didactic, entertaining way.  It is filled with realistic child characters, figures from mythology, and battles between good and evil.  Our heroes are teenager Kendra who is a gentle goodie-two-shoes type, and her younger brother Seth who is brave and mischievous.  Their bickering is very realistic (although a little more funny and clever than I remember being) and entertaining.  I thought the author was good at creating situations that were genuinely difficult and which required love, discernment, courage and a growing maturity.  I could never guess what was coming next, and though the books are very suspenseful, the author did a great job of interweaving action with quieter moments of wisdom and strategy.  The creatures and the world he creates are very compelling and intricate.  I grew very fond of them.I read all five books through in a row, and though it's been a few days since I put them down, I still think about the characters, the world they lived in (which was beautiful), and the dilemmas they faced.  Very good, full of wisdom, fun and action.  Children (both boys and girls) and adults alike will love this story.Each of the five books was equally good.  A excellent series in the young adult fantasy genre.

I heard the author interviewed on the Evidence 4 Faith podcast.  This is a podcast that is very committed  to the idea that the best reason for believing Christianity is because it's true--that there is evidence for it, that it's rational to believe it.  This book does a good job of illustrating exactly that.  It is very, very logical, but also straightforward, and while the laws of thermodynamics are not simple concepts, he does a good job of making them accessible as part of his argument.I think this would be a good book to read for anyone who wants to be able to answer challenges by agnostics, or just to help friends who are searching.  It is also a good read if you want to love God with your mind.  It's entertaining, intelligent, and amusing.As a fan of graphic novels, I don't find the illustrations as artistic as they could be, but they are workman-like and do the job.  That's the only reason I gave it four stars instead of five.

I ran across this book while I was browsing on Amazon one day, and was struck that one reviewer called it one of his favorite books of all times.  When the trilogy came up as the Amazon Daily Deal, I bought it, and while I can't call it one of my favorites of all times--that accolade would go to a book by Dickens or Trollope, or perhaps "Middlemarch," but weeks after I read it, I'm still thinking about it.  Images from the book, particularly the parts that took place in Persia (in the eleventh century!) still are with me.This is a stand out novel, one that captures the imagination and is full of adventures and interesting characters and amazing settings.  There is danger and risk and lots of suspense, but the protagonist is equal to them all, and I found that highly satisfying.  Love, loss, passion, exotic settings, and also you will learn a bit about being a physician way back when before antibiotics and cat scans.Read it and enjoy the ride.

My favorite stylus is a free one my husband picked up at a trade show.  It has some heft to it, whereas these styli are lightweight.  But they seem solid, the colors are nice, and they work well for what I need them for--to doodle in Draw Something on the iPhone.  They come with a microfiber cloth and a couple of lanyards so you can attach the stylus to your phone.I also really appreciate that the seller--The Friendly Swede--really stands by his products.  Look at the more critical reviews.  He responds to several, if not all.  That gave me the confidence to purchase his product, and I'm glad I did.

I read Peri Taichert's first novel, The Clovis Incident, for my book group and it was a fun read.  It was fresh as first novels often are, partly due to the author's lack of polish.  Still, it was good enough that I looked for another.  This one is better, with a tighter plot and a more confident writing style.  Her books remind me a little of those of Janet Evanovich--with less sex and romance.  Her protagonist, Sasha Solomon, is spunky and amusing, and the books are grounded in the culture and people of New Mexico.  The writing style is breezy and the book is a quick read, appropriate for beach, airplane or bedtime.The Kindle edition has a few problems.  The term "m-dash" actually appears in the text (that's an proofreader's word for the dash longer than a hyphen), and one chapter has the opening paragraph printed twice.  Another chapter, Chapter 52, left out paragraph breaks, so the whole chapter is one long paragraph. And there are some scattered typos ("one" instead of "on," for instance.)  I'm hoping the publisher or author will see these comments and see that the Kindle edition is corrected.I'm giving it four stars because it was very likeable.  It does not compare with the depth and intricacy of Tony Hillerman's novels, but it was a good read, entertaining and relatable.

Reading the Amazon community reviews, I can see there is a wide divide, and while I appreciate some of the criticisms, my advice is to just jump into this novel and enjoy it.  If you're a woman, like I am, and a casual sports fan who knows enough about baseball to be able to visualize what the author is describing, you will like this novel because it will give you a deeper appreciation about baseball and sports, and because you'll have the opportunity to spend a large amount of time with some very interesting men.  As a woman, I always wonder what it would be like to be a man, and wonder how they think and feel and how they talk when no women are around, and this was a very satisfying way to experience that.Another reviewer said that the book had a 1950s vibe, and I think that's because there isn't a lot of vulgarity or swear words.  There is some frank sexuality (both homo- and hetero-sexuality) but it's not too prolonged, isn't gratuitous, and is easy to skim over if you want to.I loved the novel.  My niece is a professional athlete, and the challenges, practices and training these athletes went through seemed authentic to me.  I didn't think it was pretentious.  I didn't think the author was showing off his vocabulary, and when I was in college, we tended to refer to mythology or history or whatever it was we were studying, which is what these students do.  Maybe some of the things he described were a stretch, but when you're reading a novel, you have to accept the reality the author creates--if he's skilled at creating it, which this author is.When I got near to finishing the novel, I set it aside for half a day, because I didn't want it to end.  I didn't want to leave these characters behind.

Infectious disease physician Mark Crislip keeps a blog and this Kindle book is a collection of his first year's posts.  I enjoy medical writing for the inherent drama and the opportunity for learning, and I happened upon this book and decided to give it a try based on the five good reviews and the price of 99 cents.  I thought it would be good for desultory reading in between my more serious reads.  But I found myself reading it straight through.  I was a little disappointed at first, because I was hoping for more case histories, and the first 40% of blog posts are more didactic, but Dr. Crislip's personality won me over.  He's a self-admitted smart ass and a terrible punster, but that's the kind of humor I like.  I also learned a lot about what it's like to work in a hospital, as Dr. Crislip covers topics such as hand washing, MRSA, how to pronounce "debride," and the controversy over vaccines (dumb-asses don't get them).At about 40% through, he really hits his stride and the blog becomes funnier and the stories are mostly about patients.  The case histories aren't thorough--you don't get names or nationalities (unless that is related to the disease in question),and you don't hear the patients talk.  You get their salient symptoms, and if you are a medical student, you might be able to guess at a diagnosis, and you will learn some of the questions that may appear in your boards.  If you're not a medical student, some of it will be over your head.  There are quite a few acronyms--some I was able to figure out (CXR = Chest X-Ray), some I couldn't.  But it didn't interfere with my enjoyment of the posts.Also, as the author freely admits in his description, there are quite a few typos, and almost all of the apostrophes are wrong, wrong, wrong.  But the personality that seeps through the writing is winning enough that you forgive it all.I recommend this collection for anyone who enjoys medical writing or would like to get an idea of what it is like to be an infectious disease doctor working in a hospital environment.

I know that Winston Churchill referred to his depression as a "black dog."  So I understand the idea of using an actual black dog to explore the idea of depression.  But my very visual brain could not stop trying to understand how a dog could continuously and comfortably stand and talk and hold a tea cup.  Yes, he drinks tea, somehow holding the cup with his paw.  The tea spills out of his mouth, of course.  So was this a literal dog or a figurative dog?  Both, it seems, and that's where I lost interest.I hate the genre of magical realism.  I like fantasy and I like literature, but the magical realism hybrid is a beast best handled by an experienced and gifted writer, and this first time novelist was not that.  I did not find the characters interesting, and had to keep re-reading; my mind would drift off as I lost interest.  I stopped reading about a third of the way through.  It wasn't worth it.  I agree with some of the nay-sayers as well that her writing had a forced feeling to it.  Some of the metaphors were very awkward.I gave it three stars because I didn't finish reading it.  I didn't think it was fair to rate it too low.

This app is an excellent app on the iPhone, so I know that the software developers know what they're doing.  However, the Kindle Fire platform does not work as well.  I don't have the problem other users do with not having a SAVE button.  Just type in your note, hit the collapse keyboard button and the back button and your note will be saved.  Databases have always worked this way.  However, it should be one step, not two, so maybe a DONE button (like there is on the iPhone) is called for.  I'm guessing that can't be done on this platform.  Also, on the iPhone, you can collapse your notes so that you are looking at categories titles only.  If you limit yourself to 11 categories, you can see them all on the screen without scrolling.  On the Fire, it's just all your Note titles listed with the category names to the right. Anything more than 20 notes will be off the screen.  They are in category order, though, and you can select to view by category, but again, that's two steps when it should be one.The app is good for saving bits of information.  I use it to store all the little bits of information I don't want to forget:  restaurants I like; quotes I want to remember; codes, numbers and passwords; hours of operation of various businesses; dates to remember (like when I moved to my present home, when my piano teacher died, when I got the eaves painted); movies I want to watch; and books I have read.  You press the plus button to add a note, type in or select your category, type in a title, type in your content, press collapse keyboard, press the back button and you're done.  That's all there is to it.  (Of course, on the iPhone you can dictate your note--if you have the latest version phone).It's a simple, unfussy app without a lot of options, which is what I wanted to store my notes.  4 stars for the Fire.  5 stars for the iPhone.

As an adult, I occasionally read YA books because I find them fresh and largely free of cynicism, graphic sex and needless violence.  Also, it's fun to relive those days without actually, well, reliving them.  This book was no exception.  The book was fun; written in a breezy first-person narrative.  I won't describe the plot, as others have already done so.  I have read the preceding reviews, and I don't have a quibble with them.However.  The paranormal aspect of the novel feels tacked on.  Kelsee is suffering from classic anxiety attacks, but about a third of the way through the book, she realizes they're not anxiety attacks, they're the ability to manipulate time.  I had downloaded this book to my Kindle weeks before and had forgotten it was supposed to be paranormal.  The shift took me completely by surprise, mainly because the author had not prepared me for it.  It was as if she got bored with her own writing and wanted to pump it up.At the beginning of the book, Kelsee's mother is portrayed in a very negative light.  She is almost a caricature:  overbearing, egotistical, annoying.  After Kelsee's realization of her power, the mother is more realistically drawn--she is now seen to be hurting by Kelsee's preference for her father, and still smarting from the divorce.  This also feels like a weird change.  I'd almost bet the author put the book down for a while, then came back, and instead of starting over, wrote a different kind of novel (a better one) for the last two-thirds of the book.  Then, at the end of the novel another twist is added in which seems like another tacked on bit, probably suggested by the publisher in case they wanted to add sequels.The characters of the mother (in the last 2/3 of the novel), and the best friend, as well as of Kelsee herself, are pretty well drawn and their situations are realistic.  I think girls will like it because of this.  But for adults, it falls short.  The plotting is haphazard, some character lines are developed but not seen through, the dialogue sometimes a little glib.  But it's cheerful, earnest and does not drag.  Definitely worth the $2.99 price tag.

Just so you know, the year he's describing is the year that he was hired for several months to work as a staff writer for the show.  He didn't work there the entire year, so the actual "on the set of Seinfeld" is only a part of this autobiographical narrative.  That being said, we do get tiny snatches of conversation with and insight into the actors who play Elaine, George, and Kramer, along with a couple of glimpses of Jerry and Larry David.  Having been a fan of "Curb Your Enthusiasm," I enjoyed the Larry David scenes.  There are also some tidbits of interest about specific episodes.  The writers each worked in their individual offices, so there is no table time where the writers bounce ideas off one another.  What is the more interesting thing about this story is the peek into the life of a struggling actor.Fred Stoller is an engaging writer.  His story moves along at a nice clip and there are many chuckles to enjoy. The descriptions of his mother are really funny, and some of his friends are amusingly weird.  I felt that I was hanging around with a friend who was catching me up with his life:  we sat at a coffee shop and I was content to just listen and laugh.As an aside, just in case he reads this, he describes a funny use of words by his mother as a malapropos.  The word he really wanted was "malapropism."  I didn't even know malapropos was a word.  I thought he was committing his own malapropism by using it.  So thanks for teaching me a new word, Fred Stoller!  But you might want to change it.

I bought this novel looking for something that would bring me the same pleasure and stimulation I got from the BBC series "Downton Abbey."  I was disappointed.  Although the writing is not bad, and quite good in spots, the characters are not well fleshed out and it comes off as a romance novel, with a feisty and misbehaving young woman as its hero.  It does take you back to a time and place, but without the sense of urgency I should have felt for the protagonist whose parents are stuck in Austria at the time of the Nazi occupation and who is forced to enter service at a country manor house in England after having lived a privileged life.The premise sounds good, doesn't it?  I gave it a chance, reading about 30% of the book, but it just did not hold my interest.  It had aspirations, as another writer noted, to be another "Rebecca" or even "Atonement" in its plotting, but it is a shallow book.  The characters are not well formed--I don't get a sense of who these people are.  Not much happens.  However, if you are looking for a romance novel that is a quick read, you might enjoy this.  If you don't like the romance genre, give it a pass or wait until it's available at the library.

I liked the set--especially the battery-powered buffer. It worked really well, and the tea tree lotion and scrub were also nice. HOWEVER, the buffer is not well constructed. The switch did not work unless I held it in place, and after only the second time I used it, it died completely. I tried changing the batteries thinking maybe it used a lot of power, but nothing. Very disappointing as it did a good job of buffing off dead skin.I read another review on the Bed, Bath, and Beyond website by another person who had the same experience with the buffing tool.  After 30 minutes, it died forever.

Watch out for a five-star review entitled "A beautiful story" by Iman, a young woman from the Netherlands.  The review gives away a major plot point.  Do not read that review if you have not yet read the book.Jamaica Inn is a very well written gothic novel.  Our heroine finds herself in a situation that is really terrible, and for me the book would have been intolerable if it were not for the fact that the main character, Mary Yellen, is a plucky, courageous and smart woman. The situation she finds herself in is terrible to think about, and makes the stakes very high. The characters are are well formed and interesting, and the setting is Cornwall, which becomes a character in itself; a brooding presence.Although sometimes referred to as a romance, Jamaica Inn has very little of the usual romance novel trappings.  It's more about how women can be strong and intelligent and not give in to their situations, written at a time when women were still being looked down upon as helpless beings who were not very smart.Spooky, thought-provoking and sometimes infuriating, this book seems like the spunky younger sister of the novel Rebecca.  If you haven't read Rebecca, you'll definitely want to after reading Jamaica Inn.

This is a collection of 20-30 minute yoga videos.  Our host is Chaz, who is fun, engaging and humble. He tailors his videos according to email requests, so you'll find yoga for headaches, yoga for anxiety, yoga for skiers and snowboarders, along with some generic workouts and flows.  Chas describes himself as a real person-- not a "rubber band"--in other words, he has tight hamstrings (although not as tight as mine).  He does a good job of guiding you through the practice in a quick and efficient way.  The sessions include warm up poses and an ending shivasana.  Drawbacks are the opening pitches for show sponsors (by Chaz), and the reading of the emails, but it's done quickly so I usually spend that time getting my mat set up and tying back my hair.  Also, there's a feature to star your favorite routines, but it doesn't work on the Kindle Fire.  The stars disappear.  And Chaz stops to explain things once in a while which could get tiresome if you used that video a lot.  And the volume on the Fire is so low that I had to buy an external speaker so that I could get it loud enough to hear over a little bit of household noise.  You can hear it without a speaker if the room is absolutely quiet.You can watch a video on yogamazing.com if you want to see if Chaz is your cup of tea.

First of all, this was written for the Wii Fit before the Wii Fit Plus was available, so it doesn't address any of the Plus exercises and games.  In fact, some of the exercise names were different back then.Secondly, this book is very short: about 81 page turns on a Kindle.I have been using the Wii Fit Plus program for about eight months now, and am frustrated with a few exercises (snowboard slalom and the balance bubble) and was hoping this book might help me advance in these exercises.  It did not.  Most of the descriptions are minimal; many just reiterate the game's initial instructions or what the trainer tells you.  Cheats include putting something heavy on the balance board for the Lotus Focus. (He doesn't recommend this, but this is juat an example of one of his cheats, and there aren't very many of them--perhaps as few as three.)  His very short hints for the yoga poses are things that yoga beginners already know, and include instructions the trainer gives you.  Perhaps there was no trainer back then?By Googling, I found a hint for the skateboard game.  The suggestion was to hang your toes off the board, which really helped me advance through several levels.  This is the type of hint I was hoping for, but there was nothing that helpful.I am also sick to death of the Wii Fit trainer telling me I'm "very shaky."  My balance is good, and I have a theory that my low weight might have something to do with the shakiness, so I was hoping to find more information about the way the balance board works, so that I could stop this from happening.  I did not.The author does put together an exercise routine for you, grouping the exercises into body areas exercised. But the Wii Fit Plus will create an exercise routine for you automatically, so I didn't find his suggestions helpful.I gave the book two stars instead of one because I appreciated the author's helpful tone and clear writing.  He did suggest putting your foot in the center of the balance board when doing the one-legged exercises, and I will try that. And possibly this was more helpful for Wii Fit users before the Wii Fit Plus was available.
Cute, insubstantial piece of fluff (ha ha).  Looks great on the Amazon Kindle iPhone app.

I liked my Kindle 2.  I only had one problem with it.  The 5-way controller broke.  I read a lot and use the controller quite frequently to make notes and look up words.  Amazon sent me a new Kindle immediately on my extended warranty.The Kindle 3 is a worthy upgrade, particularly if you use the CONTROLLER a lot.  The new controller is better and seems more durable.  It's very intuitive to use, very simple.  There was no adjustment period for me.Other changes:KEYBOARD.  The keyboard has been simplified to include letters and a few other buttons, such as menu, home, back etc. with the numbers now relegated to the SYM box.  The keyboard itself is tacky where the other one was smooth, making it easier to type on.  The keys are closer together, but that doesn't affect the ease of typing.  The Home, Menu and Back buttons have been moved to the keyboard area, and are rectangular in shape, to distinguish them from the letter keys.PAGE TURNS.  The only controls at the side are now the page turns, so there is a next page and a previous page on both sides of the Kindle, which I had often longed for.  These page turn buttons are much smaller, and it might take you a few page turns to get used to where they are.  It's easy to turn pages, and much quieter. You don't have to push the buttons inward anymore, and I doubt you'll ever pick up the Kindle by the page turn buttons, inadvertently turning the pages, which was the main trouble with the first generation Kindle.  The page turns are also noticeably quicker.SIZE.  It is smaller and thinner, but no so much that it feels fragile or insubstantial, especially if you buy a cover for it (which I recommend).INK.  The e-ink really is quite a bit darker.  It was dark enough for me in the Kindle 2, but I suppose it's a little easier to read in low light, and the words of Jesus in the red letter bibles are easier to read as well.WIFI.  I bought the wifi only version, and it was incredibly easy to set up.  You only need the name of the wifi network and the network password.COLOR.  If you have a choice, I would recommend the white if you use the keyboard a lot.  It's hard to see the keyboard at night with the darker color, even if you have one of those covers with the built-in light. You can't get the wifi-only version in white, unfortunately.TYPE FACES, etc.  You can now choose from a regular, condensed or sans serif font, and line spacing of small, medium or large.  It doesn't look to me like there are any larger or smaller sized typefaces.  There is nothing different for Text-to-Speech.That's about it.  I am very happy with all the changes. I recommend upgrading if you use the controller a lot because it will break eventually.  Also if you need faster page turns and darker text, these changes are noticeable, and would justify an upgrade.  Otherwise, continue to enjoy your Kindle 2.

Wow.  Roger Allam is amazing. This was the best audio book I've ever listened to.  His reading was perfect and he created distinct and very engaging characters with his voice alone. This was my first Jeffery Archer book and I was totally gripped by the story of a man who takes on the identity of another in order to avenge a wrong.  There were a lot of twists and turns and interesting characters who were fun to love or hate.  I highly recommend the audio version of this book.  I got it at the library, but I think it's well worth the asking price.  I will look for more Roger Allam audio books.

This book provides 365 recommendations for books to read, ranging from older classics, such as The Odyssey, to more contemporary books, such as Lonesome Dove and even quite recent picks like Water for Elephants.  The recommendations are for mostly fiction, but there are some non-fiction picks as well, such as Why We Can't Wait by Martin Luther King, Jr.  There are even a few collections of poetry--Lawrence Ferlinghetti and T.S. Eliot are among the poets included.I'm not sure why it's arranged as a devotional--with one title to each day of the year, but no matter.  For each day you will find the title of a book, the opening sentence of the book, a synopsis of the book which includes a summary and a musing on the reasons for the book's popularity or significance, and an ending quote from either the author of the book, a reviewer or a fellow writer.My only complaint is that the date the book was published should have been prominently displayed.  You can usually find it in the summary, but it takes a bit of scanning.  Also, in the introduction there was no explanation for the basis on which the books were chosen or the thought behind the organization of the book.That being said, I do like the picks.  Most of my favorites were included (The Once and Future King, Bonfire of the Vanities, The Woman in White, Middlemarch, Bleak House, To Kill A Mockingbird). If you're very well read, you have probably read about half of these or more.  But I think everyone will find reminders of books they wanted to read, suggestions for books they had never heard of, and a way to find out if you've already read the book.  Also, it's a godsend for book clubs who struggle to chose the next book.I bought the hardback and it's a very handsome book in green and red, nicely bound.  The pages are not of particularly high quality (not slick and shiny), but it looks like the book should hold up for many years.

I have read about two or three books by Sue Miller and I really like her writing.  However, I didn't like this book.  I listened to the audio version that was read by Blair Brown.  I like her rendition.  She has a good voice for reading--smooth and intelligent.  She doesn't do men's voices well, but that's my only complaint.I didn't find the story compelling.  I can see that others did, but it felt to me as if nothing happened, which is usually not a complaint of mine.  (I loved "Gilead.")  I listened to most of the book, but took it back to the library after I had finished listening to about 90% of the story.  I just didn't care enough to finish it.  Also, I read some of the reviews on Amazon and saw that it had a bad (sad?) ending, so I decided not to finish it.One quibble abot the audio.  It did not inform the listener of the ending of the CD.  I appreciate it when they tell me "end of CD number one."  Especially when I listen in the car.

This is my first Robert B. Parker novel, and I'm listening to it in the car.  My attention has been spotty, as I get distracted by my driving and thoughts, so I won't review the story.  I will say that the reading is very well done.  Joe Montegna handles both men's and women's voices well and attempts to give each character a distinctive voice.  He's not always completely successful at this as there are many characters, but he brings out the subtleties of the dialogue nicely.  I thought his characterization of Hawk was especially well done.  The only thing I didn't like was all the "he said" "I said" and "she saids."  This is easy to filter out when you are reading; a little harder when listening.  But if you like audio books, this is definitely good quality.One quibble:  I wish all audio books would add a statement like "end of CD number 1."  It's just a courtesy that I would appreciate.

I read this book for my mystery book club and I was not disappointed.  I found the book compelling, intelligent, and full of interesting situations and characters. It was a long book, but I didn't want it to end!  It's refreshing to read a book that's modern but doesn't contain graphic depictions of sex or loads of profanity.  The book is written in first person by a Christian man, and his protagonist, Talcott Garland, is a Christian man who struggles to follow his faith the best that he can, often failing yet never giving up.  The story includes conversations with a preacher that are serious discussions about what it means to be a follower of Christ.  There are also confrontations (a lot of them!) with colleagues and family members who have their own reasons for objecting to some of Professor Garland's behavior.  I found him sympathetic and frustrating, just like people in real life.Reading this book also affords the reader the opportunity to crawl inside the mind of a black man in America.  How does he view white people?  How does he perceive that white people view him?  Along the way, you might be surprised to find you have some prejudices of your own (I was).The language is erudite but not ostentatious--the author is not showing off (as I often felt William Styron was); both the author and his main character are educated and intelligent men who work at a university.  I learned a few new words (apercu and kilim), but it's not one of those books where you have to look up every third word.It's good to read a book that is concerned with ethics and morals and that is really about something.  The mystery was good too--expertly crafted so that I could guess part of it but be mystified by other parts.  The solution was satisfying, but left a few loose ends, again, just like real life.

I've read quite a few Victorian novels, including the works of Trollope, Dickens, Eliot and Wilkie Collins.  This isn't Collins' best or most compelling work (those honors belonging to The Moonstone and The Woman in White, of course), but it is still entertaining, well written and a pretty quick read.  The story revolves around an adopted deaf and dumb girl, her adoptive parents and the mystery of her biological parentage.  The characters are well drawn, but there is no grand love story as there usually is in Victorian novels.The Kindle version I read was just fine.  The dictionary worked, the font was fine, there were very few typos.

Smells strongly of ammonia, which I guess is mostly what it is.  I've had it for about a year and I opened the jar yesterday to see a mess.  The elements had broken down and there was a bunch of heaven-knows-what floating around in it.  I live in California where there are no extreme temperatures, so I don't know what happened.  I had another jar of jewelry cleaner that didn't do that.

I love the sleek look of this flash drive. It's easy to put on a lanyard or on a keychain with its own ring. It looks very quickly and holds a ton of documents, pics, etc. It has a very slim profile, and just looks very classy. I would recommend!

This service station kit comes with two cars. It has an elevator, a gas pump, and a drive through carwash. The car wash is really cute. It has the roller that comes down and washes and then has the sliced piece that looks like the drying part fluttering. Of course, this is all using imagination, as no water is involved. It is made of sturdy wood, and will last to pass on to future generations. My grandson absolutely loves this and can't wait to play with it when he's at our house.

This nativity set is beautiful. It is the famous Lenox ivory, with beautiful gold trim. Batteries are included in each figure, and when they need replacing, there is a little door you open with a screwdriver. It uses size LR48 batteries when your included ones run out. You would need one battery per figure. I am going to set these on my piano. I love the soft glow and quality look of Lenox.

I would give this more than five stars if I could. That's how much my grandson likes it. It's huge, which makes it very impressive, especially to a little boy. It speaks, flashes lights, and, in three steps, turns into a race car. My grandson carries this everywhere and even sleeps with it. This would make a great gift. Highly recommend

This blouse is a medium thickness, and has a slightly loose fit. I got the lavender, and it is a pretty color. I especially like the three-quarter length sleeves. It's a nice blouse for everyday with jeans, or under a jacket with a suit for work. It washes well, and I wouldn't hesitate to recommend.

The Smart Toy Bear is like a robot inside a cute, cuddly teddy bear! It learns your child's favorite games, songs, etc, and before long, they are chatting together as best friends. My granddaughter fell in love with this bear and now carries it everywhere. I feel it will be the big 'it" toy this Christmas, as the commercials are already airing for it on television, so get yours early! The child in your life will be very grateful and excited to open up this new buddy during the holidays.

This toy is typical of Playschool, tough plastic toys that last.  My grandson is a Transformers ultra-fan and he loves it. This play set is large and has many compartments to store the hero "High Tide" or hold the villian (sold separately).  There is also a large moveable crane attachment that will rescue all from the briny deep.  Some adult assembly is required, but it's a fun set your child will enjoy. Highly recommend.

This is a great microphone to use with Apple iPhones or other Apple devices. It does not work on Android. The mic is standard size for a mic and looks professional. It feels good in your hand. The recordings are great. They sound clear and crisp. I just think this is an incredible idea, and a good price, also.

This SOG compact knife was bigger than I expected, but is so light it weighs as much as a small pocket knife.  The blade locks in place when open and is "cut yourself" sharp.  My only apprehension about this knife is the blade does not similarly lock in place when closed.  With the skeletal handle I would be afraid of a key or coin getting in it and jarring the blade out loose in my pocket.  To test I stuck a key in it and the blade moved so the point stuck out.  Not cool when unsuspecting hand reaches in your pocket.

This is one of the nicest scents I have run across in quite some time. It reminds me of Estee Launder's Beautiful, but it's not as strong and smells better. The bottle is a generous size, plus you get two purse sprayers. Keep one and give one to your mom or daughter. I believe this fragrance is good for all ages. It also comes in a beautiful gift box.

This is a very nice watch. It comes in a plush gift box with a sleeve over it. The face itself is raised, and there is not really enough contrast between the hands and face, which makes it hard to read sometimes. The band was huge, and even though I have very thick wrists, I had to have two links removed and then it fit perfectly.  In order to set the time, you have to unscrew the pin, set the time, and then screw it back down. I assume this has something to do with the waterproof feature. I gave it five stars because it's such a classy looking watch and keeps great time. I highly recommend this Swiss watch.

This is a beautiful watch. I was impressed from the time I opened the nice gift box. The watch is in the "boyfriend style" meaning it follows the current trend of an oversized face. The face is between a typical sized women's face and a typical men's. The five minute markings are easy to read. The pretty bezel and the bling on the twelve mark are just extra special touches. I would highly recommend this watch for yourself or a gift for other's.

This ball does not bounce when it comes from the box. It needs air and since I do not have a pump, or a stem, my family was very disappointed. I would expect it to be playable from the box, and need air at some point later on. It does have a good, gripable surface, but it is smaller than a regular basketball. If you buy this ball and don't have a pump and stem, do yourself a favor and order those, too.

This Zebra is larger than I expected. Any baby that can sit well without assistance is going to love this. I tried it out with a neighbor's grandchild. He, of course, preferred to have an adult play along with him, but was also very happy with playing with the cubes by themselves. They have parts in the cube that can be turned, and he liked that part. The bright colors also got his attention as soon as we got it out of the box. It appears quality made as one would expect from Fisher Price. I would recommend.

Huggies are a quality brand in diapers, miles ahead of most store brands. They fit nicely around baby's chunky little legs to prevent leaking. The inside of the diaper is very cushy, almost like quilting, and does feel drier even after baby as wet it. This protects baby's bottom from being right against the wetness. I would recommend these. I gave a box awhile back at a baby shower, and they were really appreciated, so these make a great gift for the new mom.

SoundTouch 130 was a breeze to setup, and that is a plus.  Compared to clunky wired surround sound systems, this literally just had one wire from the base module that runs to the sound bar and high speed HDMI master out that runs to the TV.  All of your components, cable/satellite, game consoles etc.  plug into the Bose base unit and pass-through  to the TV through the single high speed HDMI out.  The base unit allows for 4k pass-through to the TV so you are future proof on any new 4K equipment you may decide to add in the futureAs far as sound, this unit is not going to beat your wired 5 or 7 point surround sound systems, it just physically impossible.  This is a single bar that sits in front of your TV and a wireless rear sub.  That being said, the sound this produces is LIGHT YEARS better than anything your TV speakers alone could pull off.  It does a good job of simulating right and left channel speakers that really do at times give you the sense the action is happening just to the left or right of you.  This action however all still feels INFRONT of you and you won’t get that bullets whizzing by and hearing them behind you sense you do with a formal rear speaker surround sound setup.The wireless sub produces some decent bass but I was bit disappointed given the price of this unit.  I expected a much deeper, shake the floors sub for a unit in this price range.  It does produce some great lows and is pretty compact and easy to place but for me anyway, I feel it is a bit lacking.  A big plus for the sub though is its wireless signal does not interfere with my home wifi router like some cheaper brand wireless units have been known to do.  Nothing is worse than turning on your surround sound only to find you can’t stream the movie because the signal is jammed by the wireless speakers!Another nitpicky complaint from me is the display on the front of the unit is small and hard to read from a distance.  There has been more than one occasion where I’ve had to get up and walk towards the TV in order to read the display to adjust sound settings.  It would be nice if the display could travel through the pass through and give me a display on the TV itself.This unit does have the Bose SoundTouch unit which syncs with a separate smart phone app which allows you to stream your streaming music services, music  from your phone or internet radio services.  It does a solid job at this and setup was as easy as plugging the SoundTouch unit into the base unit and downloading the app.  Had it up and running in less than 5 min.  Nice feature for music during  parties.All in all it does a solid job for a sound bar but don’t be mistaken in thinking this is a 1 for 1 replacement for a proper 5 or 7 speaker surround sound.  If you are new to surround sound or looking for a minimal install, small footprint sound solution this Bose unit is going to impress you.  If you are looking for a true cinematic experience, you will find this unit lacking.

The UE Boom speaker really delivers. The volume can go very loud if wanted. I thought the sound was awesome, especially the bass. I compared this with my bluetooth Bose speaker, and it was very little below it in sound, and definitely much lower priced. I really can't review the battery life, because I used mine in short intervals which I haven't kept track of, but after several of these, it's still going.

Huggies is a well-known, reliable brand of diapers, and I really liked these. They fit nicely around the legs to prevent leaking, but are not binding. They are very absorbent. I got the newborn size and they fit well. I would highly recommend these soft diapers for your newborn.

This is an epilator, which means it tweezes out the hairs. They recommend that you squeeze a bit of shower gel into the top and the spinning causes it to foam, this does make it more comfortable, but not enough. However, I did try it dry and it was painful. I think it does it's job, but it's not without some discomfort. I prefer a razor.If you like an epilator, Panasonic is a good brand. But I would pass on it.

If you have a Star Wars fan in your family that likes art, this Crayola Star Wars Light Up Box is for you. It contains an actual lightbox that works surprisingly well. There are a few transparency sheets, like teachers use for overhead projectors, plus tracing paper. To draw you have a pencil included, and a small set of gel pens to color with. I have to say I think I enjoyed doing one and lighing it up as much as my granddaughter did! This is just really cool.  I gave four stars because I wish there were more tracing and transparency sheets included.

I really like that these pads are very absorbent while being thin and comfortable to wear. The long length prevents leaks better than the shorter version. The adhesive holds fast to underwear. Always is a well-known brand and makes high quality products. I would recommend these moderate control pads.

OtterBox is the best way to protect the investment you have in your phone. I personally LOVE the Otterbox and have it on two of my devices. This is a one piece OtterBox that snaps on. It is rigid and has raised edges in the front to protect the screen, too. This would make a great gift, also.

This Otterbox case is a pretty cool way to protect your Samsung Galaxy S6 phone.  The "commercial" packaging has come a long way.  It wasn't like a Chinese puzzle trying to get it out.  This black leather case is very chic.  The card slot securely held a drivers license and a credit/debit card.  I didn't try to stuff anymore in it.  I would recommend this product to anyone interested in nice looking sleek phone protection.

This Otterbox case is a pretty cool way to protect your phone.  The color is described as Chic Revival and while the pictures make it look dark brown, I would call it maroon colored.  The no frustration packaging (cardboard box) was very easy to open.  The genuine leather looks very classy, and the card slot tightly secured a drivers license and a credit/debit card.  I didn't try to stuff anymore in there.  I would recommend this product to anyone with a Samsung Galaxy S6 phone.

This interactive electronic toy is quality built and very simple to understand and operate.  It has three simple games that increase letter recognition and word building.  The game actually senses your child's skill level and adjusts up to five increased level settings.  This game system is good for kindergarten prep.  There are two volume setting on the power switch (low and high setting).  I would recommend for age 4 and up.

This shower caddy looks very classy. The finish is beautiful. It was easy to install, by hanging it over the shower head. My problem with it was the way it swings from side to side depending on how well one places the shampoo bottles. It has to be balanced with the weight to hang straight. I ended up replacing it with my old one.

Barbie has a horse! She is a really pretty Barbie, with a denim vest, pink leggings, a pink, ruffly top, and boots. The horse is poseable and can stand on its own.  The horse has a pink saddle and a pink winner's ribbon on its mane. She can hold this to pull herself on the horse, which walks and jumps.  The mane is plastic and cannot, therfore, be brushed, but she's a real beauty. The horse does have a brushable tail, and Barbie has a brush to carry out the job. My granddaughter is eight, and she absolutely loves this Barbie. She takes it everywhere. It comes in a box about 18 x 14 x 4 (the actual box, not the shipping box) with clear across the front. Who doesn't love Barbie?

This Barbie edition is the coolest I've seen! Her hair is streaks of red and blonde. She has a cute dress with a purple sparkly asymetrical top and layered red and denim skirt. She also has cute lavender boots that are split up the back so they are easy to put on and pull off. Her guitar is the coolest part-purple with red flowers. My granddaughter said it was love at first sight. I agree. I had Barbies as a girl, and honestly, who doesn't love a new Barbie!

This toy train is perfect for the train enthusiast aged three and up.  The engine and passenger car together are about 18 inches long and made of hard plastic.  The passenger car doors slide open to allow "Cars" character passengers easy access for their train ride to anywhere.  This is a nicely detailed toy that even an adult could enjoy.  I know my grandson will enjoy it.

These are excellent quality fabric. They are soft and not stiff at all. They are long pants with the outside pocket at hip length ( hard to see in the picture Amazon has.). They don't have any stretch but fit as expected. They look well constructed, like they could take all the play a little boy could put them through. I would recommend.

This Ubbi diaper pail is made from sturdy steel, with a rubber seal around the lid to prevent release of odors.  There is a locking access door in the top that allows access to place soiled diapers but denies access to curious young fingers.  The best feature is the interior bag ring that will hold any standard tall kitchen bag securely.  I would recommend this pail for anyone looking for a quality diaper pail

Playschool's Fold 'n Go Busy Elephant is a quality toy, and you don't have to worry about product safety with Playschool (They are a well- known brand.). It is about 2 feet tall, and has a pocket, a rattle, a clicker on one foot, a squeaker on the other foot, a mirror on one hand and a peek-a-boo flower. It folds and one ear becomes the carrying handle. It makes crackly sounds from one ear. It is soft and has a terry-like cover. I like that you can put it in a pillow case and machine wash. This toy was a big hit with the toddler in our family. I would recommend this for the baby or toddler in yours.

OtterBox makes the most durable, protective cases for electronic devices in the industry ( in my opinion.). I have owned several OtterBoxes and have never had a device damaged while in one. This Symmetry case is simple to install, provides that excellent protection, and looks quality in both form and function. I would highly recommend for your iPad Air.

I desperately wanted to like this book, but overall it was so boring. There were big sections I had to force myself to keep reading. The best parts were Scout's recollections of her childhood, so I can see why the publishers said to write To Kill a Mockingbird about that, and not about Scout as an adult. She was a much more interesting child. I did not like what she did to Atticus, and I hated the ending. I would recommend keeping the love for Mockingbird and skip this one.

What's not to love about a George Foreman grill that can be used indoors, but also outdoors for a family barbeque. It comes out of the box and is easy to assemble and begin using.  The grill has a tray that catches oils and fat from the cooking meat. It is right along the front which makes it eady to remove and clean. It is all electric so when you use it outside, no propane is needed. It has a stand which makes the whole unit about three feet tall. The cooking surface will hold eight burgers easily and maybe more.  It is really easy to clean, as all George Foreman grills are. I really like this grill and we use it often.

This Fisher Price Laugh and Learn Activity Zoo is a bit hit for babies and toddlers. It is Fisher Price which means quality made and safe for children. We have many Fisher Price toys at our house that have been psssed down to younger cousins three to four times, and they are still fine. This zoo has three levels that you can use to set the activity level for 9 months up through toddler. It plays so much music and sound effects - kids love it! It has buttons, sliders and other gadgets to keep little fingers busy. Teaches them shapes, colors and much more and rewards with a "Good job" when the answer is correct. You can't go wrong buying this one.

These binoculars are great for children. My grandchildren love them. They magnify better than I expected, and are extremely durable. Perfect for nature viewing, my grandchildren did a lot of birdwatching. They are perfect to take hiking or camping, and they make the trip much more interesting to children. These binoculars would make a great present for a child's birthday!

Fisher Price has made a hit with toddlers with this little scooter. It has plenty of buttons that play songs and make sounds, keeping little fingers busy. It is easy for most toddlers to get on and off. It rolls smoothly and the sound effects are great. I would recommend this as a great gift for the little guy or girl in your life.

This is a very handy strap to own. Not only can you use it for tying up electrical cords and cables, but it can be used for a lot of other things. I walk with a cane, and I carry a folding cane when I am traveling. This strap was the perfect size to hold the cane together after folding. I then used it to secure my laptop bag on top of my suitcase. I think it's very handy to have and highly recommend.

Fisher Price monster dome has several component pieces that can be arranged in different configurations.  Set comes with two cars (a truck and jeep).  There two launchers and a loop.  You have to avoid a shark and circle of flame.  Says its for 3+ but I would say older than that, like 4 or 5 to really enjoy it. It'sFisher Price so you know it ishigh quality and safe. It kept our grandchildren entertained for an entire afternoon.

One needs to be very careful ordering Icebreaker beanies because some are double material and reversible as this product is, and some are very thin single layer merino wool, others are heavier weight merino or merino combinations.  At the time I ordered this two layer beanie I knew it was reversible with two different colors, and that the two layers would obviously make for a thicker beanie cap, so I'm happy with it for damp/wet weather or when in general I want more head protection.  This double layer beanie fits my large head snugly yet is thin enough to wear comfortably under a close fitting shell hood.All-in-all I now own five Icebreaker beanies and all serve a purpose, great fitting and warm products, easy to wash when needed, and I'm especially happy I haven't lost one yet because they do fold up to a small size.Konrad.

Walk my active English Springer Spaniel 2.5 miles daily on average according to my Fitbit.  I usually wear the Thorlo Hiker Heavy cushion sock for the thick cushioning I find comfortable on my 74 year old feet.  This Walking Crew sock has the same padding design as the Hiker just a bit less thickness overall so now I have the choice of medium or thick cushioning for better shoe fit.  Sock construction quality is very good, as are all my Thorlo socks.Using the moderate cushion walking sock for around a year and I now own five pair along with a dozen Hikers.  One Walking sock has some minor unraveling on the elastic top that worsened because I pulled the thread [yup, dumb move, I almost heard my Mother telling me never pull a loose thread] but I don't see this as a design flaw, no other problems noted.Konrad.=========06 January 2015 edit note:There is a listing for "Thorlo Walking Crew Sock" on amazon.com which I believe is the same sock as this listing.  Same color selection, same material composition [82 per cent acrylic/13 per cent stretch nylon/5 per cent spandex] for both socks, just different main heading description.  It turns out that for both listings I own five pair of brown and three pair of blue socks bought over past two years because I'm satisfied with the light weight cushioning for some uses over the thicker cushioned Thorlo Hiker socks which are my general standard sock. Very satisfied customer.Konrad.

My wife and I both read the David McCullough book years ago and we thoroughly enjoy watching this series.  Superb casting, acting, sets and costumes..  One example of drawing us in the drama was  the smallpox inoculation scenes that made my blood run cold. We'd give it six stars if possible.Konrad.
Title says it all, fit was odd and material was scratchy, not up to the quality of the dozen or so other MK products I've bought over the past two years, so I returned it.Konrad.

Long-time Thorlo sock wearer [use the Hiker KX version most days] owning over two dozen pairs of varying weight and material composition Thorlo socks.  This weight work well for me on days I want/need a thin sock with some stretch as these have 7% Spandex.My last few pairs of Thorlo's show higher quality control than socks from 2012 when I got two pair with untrimmed threads and poor stitching, so I'm giving this pair five stars for good fit design, quality control and constriction.====================Update: 26 april 2015I'm liking these socks especially for in-house use with slippers, so bought four more pairs of Thorlo's, two black and two grey color.  My rating remains at five stars, fit is good and quality control remains high.Konrad.

My order of 12 glass jars of Muir Glen pasta sauce arrived at my doorstep yesterday via UPS and ALL jars were intact!!I call this a miracle because my past experience with ordering Muir Glen products has resulted in MANY dented cans [and missing and burst plastic bottles of MG ketchup] and calls to amazon customer service complaining about poor packing and the resulting damage to contents.  This order was packed no differently than previous orders yet crumpled brown paper used as packing material for the shrink-wrapped flat did the job this time around.I'd like to think my packing complaints worked for better handling by UPS, but my suspicion is I just got lucky!!In any event, the sauce tastes superior IMO to the Ragu/Classico that I can buy locally so I'm giving it five stars.Konrad.

I bought a X-Large Black Crest Hoody for myself, and a Mens X-Small Red Crest Hoody for my wife.  So far we're using both of ours during most of April for 1-2 hours daily for walks in the cool morning hours.  The Crest is made from a very thin fabric identified as Pertex Equilibrium, and it has no insulation and needs a merino long-sleeved tee shirt or a Westcomb Sphere top under it for warmth.  It has a two-way zipper I find very useful.  The single chest pocket is useful for a tissue or my dogs whistle, I usually wear cargo pants so do not miss a lack of pockets.The Crest makes a great windbreaker and has easily shed some light spray from Sierra snow showers, but if I'm expecting real rain or snow I'll wear my Westcomb Cruiser LT.  As a windbreaker and as a very small package I can stuff into my pants pocket if it gets too warm and I don't want to wear it, the Crest is perfect so far.Konrad.

I have a Westcomb Cruiser LT in XXL and it fits just fine, but this Westcomb Focus was way too large so I returned it.  This jacket was certainly not an athletic cut as Westcomb jackets usually are advertised. Because the material on examination was visually similar to basic Eddie Bauer or LLBean rainwear I decided not to reorder an XL and pass on this Westcomb product.Konrad.

I'm a user of TASC long and short-sleeved tee shirts, I own six and my wife has one, all great products in terms of material, design, and comfortable fit.  But this is a one-time purchase because this pant is not really compression and fits too tight in my crotch.  I'm 6'1''/220 pounds and XL is just long enough in the leg, fits my waist, has some give to the fabric, but does not have a front fly.  An okay product just nothing great so I gave it three stars.

Bought this small kettle for my wife to make tea or coffee in single servings.  She reports it is easier and safer to pour boiling water from the V60 Hario into a cup or small mug  with no spillage or splashing than from our larger volume kettle.Konrad.

I can't quote numbers but it is obvious to me from operating both that the processor in the Roku3 is faster than the processor in my Roku2XS when I switch channels and commands.  Setup was easy using my existing Roku account.  Line-of-sight between remote and box is not needed to use the 3 so I put the box behind a sound bar.

=============================Comment added on 31 October 2013-AmazonBasics lists three different antennas under one sales entry point but there are major differences in antenna size and reception.  Selecting the right antenna will make a difference in the broadcast [OTA] signals your television set receives.  My advice is begin by using this site[...]  [antennaweb dot org]and follow the steps using the ZIP code for your location, and then choose which of these three antennas might work best for your local area.======================================I considered the Mohu Leaf products but decided on this AmazonBasics model because prior buys of AmazonBasics cables has proved their worth as a product line to me, saving 15 dollars over a similar Leaf was a plus.  I used a zip code based search service to see how many channels are available in my geographic area, 18 in total.  With the AmazonBasics amped antenna 16 is exactly what I receive after removing some duplicate non-HD repeater signals and learning two listed stations are private and coded.  Excellent reception as I'm approximately 10 to 30 miles away from the originating signals.Unpacking was easy as was connecting the cable to my television set, selecting channel signal type to "Antenna", and running "Auto Program".  Bingo!, bright and clear picture and sound on the first try placing the antenna on an inside wall about six feet up.I choose the amplified antenna because of my location and signal reception concerns, in hindsight I might have been able to use the AmazonBasics standard non-amplified antenna, but I went for the possible boost in reception performance for my location and distance from signals.Very satisfied with antenna and results.Konrad.

Without a doubt the worst tasting prepared instant coffee drink I have ever had the displeasure of drinking, it is a bad blend of chemical tastes.!!  Followed the instruction to use hot water at less than boiling point so I know I made it correctly and package date is 14.08.2014 well within expiration.  I used another packet to make coffee for my wife and she took two sips and tossed it down the drain.  Might save the remaining packets for emergency use, or may just toss them in trash.Not worth the money I paid for it.

Bought this on October 03, 2011 and used it about once a month since then for a one, two, or three egg salad.  Like the two-way slice feature but its best for small eggs, not extra-large or jumbo.  It doesn't fit easily in a kitchen drawer so it goes in a cupboard.  It is difficult to clean because of all the small spaces clogged with egg.  Just now three wires pulled loose and I'm not even going to try and repair this OXO egg slicer, I decided out it goes to the trash.  It will not be replaced, going back to using a fork or a knife to cut or slice hard-boiled eggs.Konrad.

Never read the Wallender novels, teleplays have interesting story lines along with superb acting, cinematography is integral to conveying moods.  The Wallender family relationships are complex bringing an uncommon depth to the stories.
