I plan on viewing seasons two and three spread out over perhaps one episode per month, not to prolong the enjoyment rather to allow my senses to recover because I find I've been drawn in the Branagh Wallender character more than say watching "Morse" episodes.Konrad.

Very nice casual non-dress shorts for around home, especially for the amazon price.  In the past I preferred 100 per cent cotton shorts but four pair of these shorts have convinced me Champion's Rugby short 50/50 blend works for me, nice soft finish, and a good fit that hasn't shrunk in drying machine.  Pockets are slightly shallow and I certainly would not trust my wallet to these pockets but they're fine for Kleenex and a small pocket knife!  I really like the elastic waist band stitched to the shorts fabric because it doesn't curl.  My wife checked the stitching and commented they're very well made with no loose threads to unravel,  certainly better than my prior brand where threads pulled loose and needed trimming or repair.  Nice as they are I'm not allowed to wear these out with my wife as they are too casual, but then again I'm old enough to know better anyway, i.e., I've been well-trained [LOL].Five stars are for fit, construction, nice soft and comfortable material, and amazon price.

Tablet charger is plugged into this and it lays nicely on the counter top charging.  No one seems to hit the extension cord the way the charger used to get hit in passing so less strain on the wall connector, or, for four bucks and change for this extension I may not need to have an electrician replace a damaged wall outlet.  At least that's my theory and reason for buying a one foot long heavy duty extension, and until proven wrong I give the Tripp Lite one foot  cord five stars.Konrad.===========13 March 2014 UPDATE: five star rating remains because this extension cord lets the charger lie on the counter.  Seven months of use and no problems.

Using a Roku 2 XS connected to a Sony 40 inch LCD television.. Reception/signal worked fine with the Amazon Basics HDMI six foot cable I've been using for 18 months, but I needed to try a different, more flexible and slightly shorter, HDMI cable after I moved the television and components around.  Canare cable arrived in an easy-to-open plastic clamshell with both connector ends capped with plastic caps, cable is slightly more flexible than the Amazon Basics HDMI cable it is replacing which is good because now the small and light weight Roku sits flat instead of being slightly elevated and the remote reception is improved.Konrad.

I don't need eyeglasses for reading or distance, a magnifier is useful for fine print, but not this one because the 6X inset magnifier intruded into my field of vision so much I was unable to use the main 2X magnifier.Product was returned.K.

No other way to say it, I sweat a lot on summer walks, walks I have to go on daily because I have a dog to keep active year-round.  I've never been able to tolerate Gatorade type products, I much prefer water as a fluid replacement, and I've unsuccessfully tried making homemade electrolyte replacements.  The formula of these tablets seems simple enough that the ingredients don't look like they're going to damage my system as long as I only use one pack of two tablets along with water.  Most, but not all days, I take 1-2 tablets about half way thru the walk along with water, and so far I've noticed no stomach upset after taking Medi-Lyte tablets, and I can say I've noticed no headaches after returning home from the walks this past June/July, but that might just be a coincidence.  My intention is to carry Medi-Lyte packs year-round, cold weather dehydration is a concern of mine.My suggestion is look up the product at the company website[...]and form your own judgement about this product for your use.  They work for me and are convenient in packets to carry in my pocket and store some in my day pack.  Price is very reasonable at under six dollars for 100 tablets in 50 sealed packets.Konrad.

I have long been a fan of Walter Mosley, especially his Easy Rawlins series of mysteries.  Mosley's fiction is sufficiently insightful and grounded in intuition born of real-world experience that, at its best, it can change the way we view the world.  The revised vision is unlikely to be uplifting, but it's certainly more accurate, truer to the way things really work.One of the reasons that Mosley's work is so compelling is that, in contrast to any other author of noir-like fiction known to me, Mosley is Black.  Thus Easy Rawlins is a rare character, indeed: a Black noir protagonist in stories usually set in the '50's or '60'a, before or in the midst of the mid-Twentieth Century civil rights movement.  Rawlins understands what it means to be Black in a deeply racist society dominated by Whites, enabling him to teach us lessons that many of us otherwise would never learn.To his credit, however, Mosley's protagonist, Easy Rawlins. is no social and cultural one-trick pony, beating us over the head, however skillfully, with race-related wisdom, insights, and abominations.  Rawlins is an astute and sensitive observer who recognizes that poor Whites are nearly as powerless and generally disadvantaged as poor Blacks. Not infrequently, he comes close to making the observation that social class, as manifest in the development of the capitalist system,  is the fundamental phenomenon that determines who does well and who does poorly even more decisively than race.In Mosley's non-fiction book Workin' on the Chain Gang he takes the leap intimated in his Easy Rawlins series, and invokes class as more fundamental than race in determining who we are, what opportunities are available to us, and what we become.  Though he doesn't put it in just this way, Mosley's position might best be captured by paraphrasing the Black sociologist O. C. Cox in his book Caste, Class, and Race:  the primary difference between Blacks and Whites in our capitalist society is that Blacks have been more thoroughly proletarianized.  Blacks are, in other words, more effectively divorced from ownership and control of the means of production and finance, and they have less control over their lives.  Cox's book, however, was published in 1950, and writing fifty years later Mosley sees that the difference between Blacks and Whites has dramatically diminished.Mosley has never been shy about putting things directly and without a political coward's equivocation.  Thus, having acknowledged the place of slavery in the development of the United States and much of the rest of the world, his judgment that capitalism reduces both Blacks and Whites to the status of slaves may be unexpected, but it's not shocking.  Mosley's controversial, even inflammatory, point is that profit is the only fundamental value, and markets are the only sacred institutions in a capitalist context.  In a way that is obviously suggestive of Marx, Mosley maintains that the capitalist world reduces human beings to the status of commodities, things that can be rendered in dollar terms, depending on the value of the labor that went into producing them.Mosley, however, rejects the idea that he is a Marxist or that he can be neatly subsumed by any other political-economic label.  I think he prefers to see himself in the role of a non-violent humanist, one who wants to promote freedom in a world that already has the technological wherewithal to provide material abundance for everyone.  We miss this chance, however, because, for the capitalist system with its small set of shakers and movers, this is not the most nakedly profitable way to proceed.Whether we agree with him or not, Mosley's analysis is an act of courage, given that he may very well alienate prospective readers of his fiction, perhaps sharply diminishing his royalties.  Even if he's already wealthy, by taking this risk Mosley makes it a good deal less likely that he will be judged a hypocrite.While Mosley's analysis of capitalism, complete with the devolution of people of all races to slave status, is interesting and unanticipated, it is also thoroughly derivative.  The bulk of the book, however, is devoted to discussion of five ways in which individuals and nascent groups can transform our world such that freedom, abundance, and the chance to fully develop our innate potential characterizes everyone's life.  Each reader can make his or her own judgment, but I found the transformative tools proposed by Mosley to be hopelessly lame.  In fairness to the author, however, Workin' on the Chain Gang takes on the pattern of countless other social commentaries and proposals for reform:  an incisive, even original and compelling analysis, followed by obviously ineffective proposals for remediation.  We're pretty good at diagnosing social ills, but curing them is beyond our capabilities.I've benefited from everything I've ever read by Walter Mosley.  In spite of my serious doubts as to his sometimes utopian proposals for thoroughgoing and beneficial reform, Workin' on the Chain Gang is a book that merits a broad readership.  It's a book in which Mosley can justifiably take pride for its embodiment of cultivated intelligence and a forthright stance.

Terry Eagleton is one of my favorite authors of the exposition of ideas and theoretical developments in social and cultural theory from the point of view of a student of the humanities.  I've read more of Eagleton's books than those by any other author of comparable material, and I've always found him insightful, informative, and challenging but accessible.Eagleton's prose style is uniquely sophisticated, neither trendy nor distorted by the constraints of a particular persepective, and he's written knowledgeably about every influential social and cultural theory that comes to mind.  Whether writing about modernism, post-modernism, psychoanalysis, structuralism, post-structuralism, the close reading of the Leavasites, or any other distinctive body of literature, Eagleton's style has remained largely unaltered, avoiding surrender to locutions, affectations, and fantastically elaborate conceptual frameworks that may be peculiar to the body of work he's discussing.  Eagleton understands that writing about Marx doesn't oblige him to adopt Marx's often turgidly Hegelian prose style, and the same applies to the distinctive modes of written expression peculiar to other authors.  This is all to the good.It seems, however, that all of us, whatever our lines of endeavor, are subject to youthful indiscretions, especially when we get caught up in the most fashionable and ostensibly powerful manifestations of our work at a particular time.  I suppose this is as good an explanation as any for Eagleton's 1976 book Criticism and Ideology, better, I think, than the account offered by Eagleton himself in this edition. In this early volume Eagleton adopts the concepts, approach to theory, set of pertinent issues, and mode of presentation of Louis Althusser and his Structural Marxist acolytes, and he endeavors to make them his theoretical foundation.  Sadly, a really bad call!In truth, Structural Marxism was an influential project that was not totally without value.  Its unapologetic denial of simple-minded notions of free will, while retaining the illusory reality of individual freedom, was exemplary.  Much the same is true of the notion that material experience precedes and takes precedence over consciousness, and that individuals may be construed as unself-conscious props that maintain the multifaceted social structures that create them.While Althusser pushed the ideas of relative autonomy and determinant in the last instance too far, he disabused us of over-simplifying the still instructive base/superstructure configuration.  Commonsense instrumentalism, moreover, was eliminated once and for all by Althusser's Structural Marxism, and he invoked the concept production in a way that lent itself to application to literary studies.Nevertheless, I can't see much in what I've just attributed to Althusser that was not explicitly stated, or at least clearly implicit, in Marx's own work. In addition, to glean even this much from Althusser forces the reader to try to come to terms with a maddeningly unreadable convoluted exercise in literary self-indulgence masquerading as theoretical rigor.  Anyone who has Read Althusser's best known book, Reading Capital, will immediately understand my point.Althusser's strained efforts to write theory with meticulous precision rendered his prose, for all practical purposes, unreadable.  Much as with Althusser's work, a good deal of Eagleton's Criticism and Ideology is needlessly difficult and pointlessly obscure.  While Criticism and Ideology is not without merit, too much of it is an extraordinarily tedious exercise in conceptually excessive sleight-of-hand that, when all is said and done, presents us mainly with a rigid framework of static ideas whose interrelationships are as numerous and slippery as they are hopelessly obscure.  Is Literary Mode of Production (LMP) a useful concept?  You tell me.  After a while, I get sick of being told "you may think <this>, but I really mean <that>," with qualifications, of course.Remarkably, however, the first thirty pages of Eagleton's third chapter approach intelligibility, and may have some genuinely interesting things to say.  It's as if Eagleton had tamed Structural Marxism and made it work.  The discussion explaining the simple causal models at the bottom of page 68 is especially interesting.Abruptly, however, the material that showed promise and prompted me to briefly second-guess my thoroughly unfavorable assessment of Structual Marxism as a monstrously clumsy joke, a parody of needlessly dense and proudly inelegant theoretical work, gave way to the same old Althusserianism.There's more to Criticism and Ideology than Eagleton's uncharacteristic surrender to Structural Marxism, but the cryptically annoying Althusserianism seems to have spoiled it for me, and I'm afraid I failed to do it justice.  However, elsewhere Eagleton has written so much that is so good that it's easy to forgive him the sins of Criticism and Ideology.  After all, any of us can get caught up in a fashionable mode of discourse and theorizing, especially when we've struggled mightily to use it in the way of its master, and find that, whether or not we're making sense, we get favorable responses from others who have taken the same route.  I had a very similar experience using Harold Garfinkel's ethnomethodology in the '70's and early '80'.In any case, I don't know why Criticism and Ideology is back in print, perhaps for historical interest.  I suspect that Eagleton would just as soon forget that he wrote it.  I spent more time than I like to admit with this relatively short book and found it to be a source of enormous frustration, with little of intelligibility or interest to say about either criticism or ideology.  Eagleton's references to Raymond Williams seem oddly out of synch with -- even unrelated to -- my reading of Willaims' Marxism and Literature.  Perhaps this is because I spent too much time trying to decipher Eagleton's Althusserianism, neglecting less contaminated parts of the book.  Irritation and understanding don't go hand in hand.

Christopher Datta's novel, Touched with Fire, is the first book in a trilogy set in the Civil War Era.  In the first volume, the protagonist, born Ellen Smith, or simply Ellie, is in many ways the unfortunate personification of the inevitably corrupting influence of slavery on all other institutions.Ellie herself is a loving, good-hearted, but painfully reserved young woman, who, though a slave, is white.  This anomaly is explained by the fact that both her maternal grandmother and her mother were raped and impregnated by their white masters.  Ellen was born, thus, as a quadroon, one quarter black, and her skin color was as white as any of the slave masters or their other children.Nevertheless, as far as Whites were concerned, Ellie was Black, and as far as other Blacks were concerned, she was uppity.  After all, Ellie worked in the plantation mansion of her white father, and she wore the hand-me-down clothes of her white sisters.  In a limited sense, she was advantaged, but at great cost?Her father bore her no affection, in fact he sometimes looked at her lustfully, as if he might rape her much as he did her mother.  In his view, she was not his daughter but his property, much as any other slave. a commodity that could be used, bought, and sold.  Unloved by her father, Ellie longed to feel her mother's warm and affectionate embrace, but her mother had been sold to a planter who lived much further south, and Ellie was never to see her again.  Slavery had destroyed their loving relationship, leaving her effectively orphaned and alone.Deemed legally and culturally unfit for White society, and rejected by envious Blacks who did not understand her true status and circumstances, Ellie was a marginal person with no ties to anyone, save those constitutive of slavery.  While many suitable males found Ellie attractive, she rejected them and the prospect of marriage.  Ellie was determined not to bring children into the world as slaves to live the kind of fettered-by-evil existence that she lived.  Beyond that, she, any man she might have married, and any children she might have borne could be sold to anyone at any time, thus fracturing whatever family they had managed to create.  The uncertainty of slave life was inconsistent with the settled and cohesive existence implied by concepts such as family and community.Ellie did not want to bring into the world children who, by force of law, would be denied even a rudimentary education.  Moreover, her experience with organized religion, as it was available to slaves, had brutally convinced her that their White masters had rendered even the church an institution where Black slaves could be systematically exploited with impunity.  What sort of life could Ellie offer any children she might bare?Nevertheless, she and a fellow slave, William Craft, met, fell in love, and married through a series of chance encounters, some of which, ironically, further emphasized the brutality of slavery. However, much as she had feared, Ellie and William were forcibly separated.  Much of the book recounts Ellie's efforts to return to William in the hope of setting him free and resuming their marriage under far more auspicious circumstances.It makes little difference what parts of Touched with Fire are concretely accurate and what parts are fiction.  Taken as a whole, I found the book's primary contribution and source of interest to be the ways in which it graphically, and true to the spirit of the times, illustrates the corrupting influence of slavery for all institutions and relationships.  Religion, marriage, the family, the nature of labor, the system of property holding, the mode of commerce were all grotesquely distorted by the ugly transformation of slaves to the status of commodities to be used as plantation owners saw fit.The influence of slavery in the corruption of language, especially when referring to abstract terms such as liberty and freedom, is fascinating, and developed by the author with suitably sardonic humor.  For northern abolitionists, these terms were inextricably tried to the elimination of slavery and the freeing of Blacks.  For southern planters, however, the same abstract qualities were used in emphatic reference to avoidance of the intrusion of northern interests, whether morally motivated abolitionists or economically acquisitive manufacturers, into the business of slave holders.  For the southern aristocracy, freedom and liberty were best understood as the freedom to own slaves and the liberty to use them as they chose.  This was the foundation of affluent southerners' way of life.Touched with Fire is unusual in my experience in that it properly addresses the abomination of slavery as a perniciously destructive caste/class phenomenon in conjunction with what passed for suitable sex roles at the time, a contentious topic even today.  It may be saying to much to assert that a determined woman is the physical and martial equal of most men, but Touched with Fire tacitly raises that possibility.  As with race, one is prompted to wonder how much of the differences traditionally ascribed to men and women were more a matter of socialization than intrinsic capabilities.Touched by Fire is an extremely interesting and well-written book.  The author is an insightful observer of the human condition, and he has an uncanny historical intuition.  Touched with Fire is a book with much of value to say about human nature, life, and the institutional arrangements that constitute specific kinds of societies.  Even for those who do not read the second and third volumes in the trilogy, the first volume is remarkably instructive in unexpected ways.

SM Smith, author of the novel titled The Fourth Amendment, writes quite well.  He has a smooth-flowing,easy-to-read style that carries the reader along, requiring very little effort.  Given that the book is about cyber-security in its most up-to-date manifestations, the occasional use of unfamiliar technical terminology is virtually inevitable.  Nevertheless, Smith makes sure that the technical material doesn't get in the way of the reader's comprehension and entertainment.  The author has a welcome talent for invoking the most arcane ideas in ways that enable the reader to understand them well enough to maintain a comfortable pace without feeling that he or she has missed something of importance. Smith's prose style is so uncluttered,straightforward, and direct that it sometimes seems almost glib, but that's nothing to complain about.  I think that all readers prefer a quick and easy read to something that's slow, awkward, and needless convoluted.Substantively, however, The Fourth Amendment is a bit misleading, bringing to mind the notion of bait and switch.  Yes, I think we all agree that Fourth Amendment issues have become far more salient with the advent of the digital age, but that's a pretty vague notion.  Specific instances in which the Fourth Amendment is of primary concern are few and far between in Smith's perhaps mistitled book.  It's true that the protagonist, cyber-sleuth Chris Storm, is sensitive to the point of "boiling" when she suspects that organizational superiors or colleagues are not sufficiently attuned to Fourth Amendment protections.  Truth be told, however, the events she finds so upsetting rarely occur.I suppose, however,we could say that given the nature of her work, Fourth Amendment concerns always have a high profile.  That, however, seems to be cutting the author too much slack.  As things stand, we've got a pretty good book that makes one wonder if the author was looking for a title to give all that he had written a focused meaning.  As a result, when specific Fourth Amendment questions are raised, they seem adventitious, oddly intrusive, and put there for no good reason other than to give the book a catchy name.  It's also a bit too predictable that as the book develops, Kris' commitment to a strict constructionist interpretation of the Fourth Amendment begins to wane.While Smith writes quite well, his rendering of an espionage thriller is disappointing.  The Fourth Amendment, especially the novel's first half, might best be described as bland.  The author is talented, to be sure, but he invests entirely too much into describing the clothes, hair styles, and office and apartment furnishings of the characters we meet.  Some of them, especially Chris, are nicely developed, but I think this would have been a much more interesting story if Smith had devoted more of his estimable authorial resources to substantive issues rather than ancillary details.  Clearly, Smith wants to tell us that his most important characters on the right side of the law are young, affluent, Ivy League, urban, professionals.  But his descriptions of the sartorial incidentals that bespeak their status occur too frequently and soon become uninteresting, even boring.Sure, there is some action, adventure, violence, and duplicity in The Fourth Amendment, but the book remains short on excitement and anticipatory tension.  As we move toward the end, the novel offers some pretty wild and far-fetched people and predicaments.  It's not bad material, but it's too little, too late, and too contrived.  It seems that, with a few exceptions, Smith spent too much time making the case that digitally dazzling people like Chris and her subordinates, Mindy and Joe, are the only ones worthy of serious consideration, and that those of lesser or different attainments, as well as older folks, are gross and otherwise fatally flawed.  Why else, at a formal banquet for the mayor, insert a fat, gluttonous, middle aged, traditional union boss uncaringly dragging his necktie through his gravy?  Why else make the bumbling, inarticulate, thoroughly hapless and corrupt Public Advocate be the only character in the book who is explicitly a political liberal, maybe even a champion of Romney's 47 percent?  OK, these may be examples of sub-texts, but when they remain undeveloped they serve the same purpose as cheap jeans bought at Wal-Mart, the sort of thing that Chris and her colleagues wouldn't be caught dead wearing.  They're just labels.SM Smith is a talented writer, and he gives ample evidence of being generally well informed.  Furthermore, he knows enough about computer technology and the value of large data bases to write convincingly about cyber-sleuthing, online crime, and similarly up-to-speed issues.  It would be really useful, however, if he got an editor who would aggressively insist that he stay on topic, not dither unduly with incidentals, and further develop his unstated but pretty obvious assumptions.  After all, everyone has biases, but a writer who betrays his or hers must put them to good use.This review is not especially favorable, but there is a good deal of merit to Smith's novel.  Unfortunately, there is a lot about it that is annoying and disappointing.  Smith might step back, take stock from a variety of vantage points, and next time not sell himself short with a book that's a lot less engaging than his talent might have made it.

Heather Voight's book Passionate Crusaders is a valuable addition to the body of scholarship that has come to be known as Holocaust Studies.  Voight's volume, however, is very different from work such as Doris Bergin's masterful War and Genocide.Bergin reports in graphically brutal detail the nature of the Holocaust itself.  She shows us the routinized butchery organized by its perpetrators, the immeasurably painful price paid by its millions of victims, and the modernized effectiveness of the social machinery that made killing on a truly massive scale a logistical possibility.  As an account of the twelve-year triumph of evil as a continental phenomenon, War and Genocide is gut-wrenching, heart-breaking, and takes an emotional toll on any normally sensitive reader.Voight, by maddening contrast, documents the studied indifference of all but a small minority of international bystanders.  Even though the U.S. State Department sought to suppress pertinent information, the nature of the Holocaust was no secret in the United States or elsewhere.  Nevertheless, until the last two years of World War II, organized opposition to the Nazi's final solution and sustained efforts to rescue and provide aid to Jews and others targeted by Hitler was a small-scale and private matter.  Not until the January of 1944 did FDR, at the behest of the Secretary of the Secretary of the Treasury, create the War Refugee Board (WRB), an under-funded agency with a staff of thirty, that had little independent clout, and came with powerful bureaucratic enemies already in place.In spite of the widely shared judgment that the WRB offered much too little much too late too accomplish its humanitarian ends, it Executive Director and other officials and operatives took their jobs very seriously, indeed.  They struggled to contrive ways to provide direct or indirect assistance to Jews in, or headed for, the Third Reich's death camps, and did so with substantial opposition from within their own government.The WRB also had to contend with the unfortunate fact that anti-Semitism was a persuasively shameful attribute shared by many Americans.  This helps to explain why FDR was in no hurry to act to aid victims of the evolving Holocaust.  As with most politicians, he placed political expedience above other considerations, and by his nature he seemed not favorably disposed toward those ethnically different from his understanding of the wholesome nature of ordinary Americans.  Taken together, these two factors may help to account for his willingness to ignore the tightening of immigration quotas to the disadvantage of European Jews, as well as his endorsement of internment of Japanese Americans, and his failure to champion the cause of oppressed Blacks.The more we learn about the Holocaust the more tarnished become the reputations of FDR and other politically significant Twentieth Century American's of prominence, including Edward Stettinius, Sumner Welles, and John J. McCloy.  Even when it was clear to all that the Nazis were defeated, men such as these continued to give voice to the disingenuous mantra that the best way to diminish the toll paid by the most inhumanely oppressed, the ones virtually certain to be victims of the ongoing slaughter, was to devote all resources to the war effort, diverting nothing to save the condemned.  Whether motivated by anti-Semitism, poor judgment, or the popular belief that America should be preserved for Americans, these State Department officials did all they could to thwart and stall the best efforts of the WRB.  Voight's book provides a detailed and disturbing lesson regarding the ways that special interests, pernicious prejudices, and simple miscalculations of one set of bureaucrats can be turned against the good work of another, something that occurs daily on an international stage.In spite of functioning in a generally hostile environment, by the author's estimate the WRB contributed to saving 130.000 lives.  Some prominent historians have placed the number as high as 200,000.  Those saved were not limited to the relatively small number who escaped the death camps and their gas chambers, but included those who survived beyond the defeat of the Nazis because they received food packages distributed through the joint efforts of the WRB and organizations such as the International Committee of the Red Cross.  Furthermore, the WRB's efforts at psychological warfare, aimed at persuading Nazi officials and their underlings of their culpability and the certainty that they would be dealt with as war criminals prevented the execution of an indeterminate number of Jews.  The WRB also became familiar with the judgment that any Nazi, however zealous he seemed, could be bought, and they occasionally put that information to good use.  The WRB was tenacious, innovative, and courageous in carrying out its mission until the very end of hostilities.It's true that 130,000 saved is an unimpressive total when compared with 6,000,000 lost.  But who, other than the most doctrinaire neoclassical economist,  is sufficiently audacious to place a value on even one life.  Truth be told, in view of the opposition and opportunism it encountered domestically and internationally, the WRB achieved an impressive record of success.I noted at the outset that Voight's book was maddening when read with Bergin's War and Genocide.  That so little was done in comparison to what might have been accomplished elevates frustration and shame to new levels.  Still, the WRB must be credited with doing the work of people with humane principles, not dissuaded by petty biases or personal gain, but motivated by bravery and recognition that one human being has as much right to live and prosper as any other.  The efforts of the WRB remove a bit of the tarnish from America's otherwise failed response to the Holocaust.  Thanks to Heather Voight's clearly written book based on her skillful scholarship, all Americans can take pride in the work of the WRB. A good book that merits a broad readership.

Dennis Lehane is a prolific and talented author of prose fiction dealing with crime, criminals, victims, and those trying to set things straight. The quality of his novels ranges from really good, as in Live by Night, to one-of-the-best-ever, as in The Drop.  Prayers for Rain is comfortably situated somewhere between the two, roughly comparable to Gone, Baby, Gone.When I first started reading Lehane, I characterized his work as noir or neo-noir. It has the gritty, street-wise appeal of books written by noir pioneers from the '30's and '40's such as still-read authors like Dashell Hammett, Raymond Chandler, and James M. Cain.  The noir characterization usually fit pretty well, subsuming harsh qualities and themes including official corruption, personal betrayal, gratuitous cruelty, and deep-seated cynicism that was readily understandable as a product of badly flawed characters and the ugly contexts in which they lived.  The protagonists were suitably imperfect and a bit jaded, but they were basically decent and valued decency, on the odd chance they found it in others.In the case of Prayers for Rain, however, I'm not sure that the noir characterization fits.  In fact, that may be true for all the books in Lehane's Kensey and Gennaro series.  The main characters, Patrick Kensey and Angie Gennaro, are just too engaging and have too much fun.  Furthermore, while there's nothing sloppily sentimental about it, they really love each other.  Gennaro, especially, can be acerbic and hard-edged, but it's part of her playfulness, a bit brassy but clever and innocuous.  Just part of her fundamentally good-hearted personality.This odd couple of sometimes mis-matched private detectives and lovers, moreover, is especially adept at making interesting friends.  None are headed for sainthood, but they're the kind of folks you can count on, they've got your back, and are as resourceful as difficult circumstances demand.  In Prayers for Rain, Bubba Rogowski is exactly the kind of pal that Kensey and Gennaro need:  tough as nails, well-connected with the mob, violent, and about ten times as smart and skillful as he usually seems.  Bubba is exactly the sort we would expect to find in a noir atmosphere if he weren't such a true-blue, take-a-bullet-for-a-friend sort of guy.Great fun, true love, faithful comradeship, AND they all love dogs -- this is not the stuff of noir!  Still, there's enough nastiness, violence, back-stabbing, and double-dealing that Prayers for Rain comes close.  So I'll equivocate a bit and call it semi-noir.  However we label it, Lehane's novel is quite good.It's also long, well over three hundred pages, more than a hundred pages longer than The Drop.  In the case of Prayers for Rain, however, the extra length is all to the good.  The story is heavy-laden with interesting characters who interact in fascinating, sometimes hard-to-fathom ways, and the added pages assure that the characters are given the attention needed to enable us to understand them and their reasons for being there.  Motel owners Warren and Holly Martens are two of the most unexpected and charming minor characters readers will ever encounter.  Psychiatrist Diane Bourne is one of the most sinister.  And attorney Vanessa Moore is one of the sexiest.  Lehane's novel is full-to-the-brim with interesting people, and though they make his book long and not particularly stream-lined, they add substantially to its interest.Prayers for Rain is also quite complex.  So much happens that seems so unlikely that readers may judge it to be unrealistic, and it probably is.  However, Lehane is sufficiently skillful to prevent his story from becoming inaccessibly confusing, and he eventually manages to pull it all together into a coherent whole.  There are no dead zones or pointless sections that try the reader's patience, one of the difficulties with the second half of Live by Night.  Something eventful and pertinent is always happening, which may explain why the book is so long and complex.  Yes, long and complex but always readable and never boring.Early in the novel we also get to see what Kensey can do on his own, during a six month period when the couple has split.  He does well enough, but the book is a lot more interesting when the Kensey and Gennaro, haltingly at first, get back together.  Their animated effort to get more information out of Dr. Bourne is hilarious.  She sees through it, but given the circumstances, a performance as effectively choreographed as theirs has to  be unnerving.While there is plenty of fun and a big bundle of surprises in Prayers for Rain, there is also a good deal of compelling sadness, and a villain who is impossible not to hate.  Prayers for Rain has, by my count, three important substantive outcomes.  But however it ends, a novel fraught with more kinds of pain than a normal reader can imagine, will inevitably leave scars, as well as wounds that never heal.  Noir, neo-noir, semi-noir, whatever the literary characterization, this is a very good novel, probably the best of Lehane's early work, and I enjoyed reading it.

Walter Mosley's Easy Rawlins mysteries give us high-quality noir from a Black man's point of view, and Black Betty may be the best novel in the Easy Rawlins series.  Inevitably, there are differences in plot and thematic emphasis when compared with traditional noir produced by White authors, but Mosley clearly appreciates the noir genre and keeps it pretty well intact.  Noir, whether produced by Mosley of any other capable author, say Dennis Lehane, is deeply cynical.  In a world fraught with corruption, duplicity, greed, vindictiveness, and violence, cynicism seems to be a rational response.However, as with noir pioneers such as Dashell Hammet, Raymond Chandler, and James Cain, Mosley's noir is replete with valuable gutter-level insights and the wisdom of the downtrodden that transforms it into something more than just entertainment.  In Mosley's work, genuinely useful lessons about life are typically manifest in his very skillfully developed characters and the ways they behave, think, and feel.  The noir protagonist himself, in this case Easy Rawlins, is a case in point.  Easy is no saint.  He couldn't be after coming up the brutally hard way as an orphaned Black child in a world dominated by Whites who, for the most part, regarded him dismissively, with contempt, and often as not unalloyed hatred.Nevertheless, Easy found favor with poor but nevertheless generous and loving people of his own race, and as a bright kid he grew into the sort of man that a fair-minded and decent person would respect.  Yes, the odds remained against him, his best friend was gratuitously homicidal, education-intensive white collar jobs were beyond his reach, and his wife left him taking their daughter.  But Easy had long-since learned to persevere, and in a modest, low-key way he prospered.Perhaps because of the lonely destitution of his childhood and the loss of his wife and daughter, Easy lovingly put together another family.  An Hispanic boy in his early teens and a Black toddler, cast-offs and orphans that Easy took in and made his own.  The value that Easy places on the innocence and love of two little kids puts him squarely in the tradition of the noir protagonist.  No, Sam Spade and Philip Marlowe didn't have children, and neither seemed interested in starting a family, but both men valued decency and people who were capable of unselfishly caring for others.  As with Easy, they were men to whom sentiment was not alien, but they were never duped into reveling in cheap and phony sentimentality.  Spade, Marlowe. and their kind were individualists and loners, but they understood friendship in a heart-felt, even if restrained sort of way.  Easy Rawlins fits very well into the category of noir protagonists.In Black Betty, as with Mosley's other novels, race is a conspicuous theme.  It's not as forcefully front and center as in Little Scarlet, but any novel set in the '50's or '60's with a Black protagonist and a predominately Black cast has to take race seriously.  Otherwise it's disingenuous trash.More than in his other novels, Mosley also recognizes the advantages and injustices of class, depending on one's position in this merciless hierarchy.  Poor Whites may have one less strike against them than poor Blacks, but Easy readily acknowledges that they struggle just as hard, and they, too, are demeaned and abused by the authorities and the wealthy.  No, poor Whites and poor Blacks are not allies by any means, but they share similarly difficult lives.Mosley is not afraid, moreover, to explain behavior, character traits, and overall world views in the terms of a social determinist.  He hasn't been intimidated by the favored chorus that sings the praises of individual responsibility as superseding all other factors.  Easy understands the obvious but much too often rejected notion that we are largely experiential products of our social context.  He doesn't use this insight to excuse harm that malefactors do to others, nor does it diminish the his appreciation of kindness, honesty, and a good heart.  However, he usually has a pretty good idea of how people got to be as they are, and he realizes that self-conscious decisions have less to do with it than many assume.  Life has taught Easy a lot about how the world works, enabling him to get by more intelligently, expecting neither too much nor too little of others, enabling him to do a pretty good job of avoiding betrayal and disappointment.The unexpectedly favorable development of Easy's relationship with a White lawyer named Saul Lynx is a nice tough that shows us how Mosley avoids stereotypes.  True to the noir tradition, an ordinary little guy who barely manages to stay afloat financially proves to be possessed of substantial courage, resourcefulness, and good will.  Just when we had him firmly pegged as nothing but a sleazy, small-time, marginally effective operator, Lynx, in a thoroughly believable sequence of events, turns out to be a force to be reckoned with on the side of virtue.Betty Eady, the woman who gives the novel its name, is a complex character whose deep blackness, in ironic contrast to aesthetic convention, contributes to her compelling beauty and sensuality.  Easy has known her, though not well, since he was a boy, long enough to see that her youthful brashness and sexuality were later more than matched by her mature love for her children and her self-sacrificing commitment to their safety.  Betty is a strong woman for whom the confluence of her overwhelming physical appeal with race and class costs her a great deal.  Much of Black Betty chronicles Easy's search for her at the behest of her employers, a dubious group who, for the most part, mean no one well.The ending of Mosley's novel takes awhile to unfold and is complex, culminating in a mixed outcome.  As the best of the Easy Rawlin's novels, Black Betty is loaded with interesting characters, and gives Easy an opportunity to show that while he is a caring and decent person, those who mistake him for a fool or a lightweight or overlook him entirely pay a suitable price.  Black Betty is a fine novel by any standard, and it can change the way we think about our world.  A powerful book that shows us noir at its best,

When I read Hard Luck Hank: Screw the Galaxy I was thrilled!  Just what we've long needed:  A science fiction hero who is also true to the noir genre!  It inspired me, for better or worse, to come up with the designation "neo-noir," just to emphasize that this stuff is really futuristic.  Somehow I missed the second volume, but when my brother sent me a copy of the third, Hard Luck Hank:  Prince of Suck, I approached it with trepidation.  The first volume was so good that couldn't imagine Steven Campbell or anyone else maintaining that level of high quality entertainment for very longAs I started Prince of Suck, I said to myself, "Yeah, I was right.  He's slipping badly.  Not much left in the tank."  But it didn't take long for me to notice that I was chucking to myself while sitting alone, and sometimes laughing out loud.  It's a tough call, but the third volume in the Hard Luck Hank series may be even better than the first.  In any case, it's certainly different.Sure, there are some interesting parallels between the two, after all this is still Hank and he's still the story.  As before he'd rather negotiate than fight, but he's perfectly willing to kill if it seems like the sensible thing to do.  And he's tougher than the immensely tough and overwhelmingly strong guy that he was before.  In fact he's a lot tougher, a lot stronger, and, sad to say, a whole lot slower, in large part because his body weight has increased by several tons.  His oft repeated disclaimer, "I don't do steps," is literally true.  In the first volume his bulk gave him a decided preference for elevators rather than stairways, but now he doesn't have much choice.  And even some elevators can't handle him.How did all this happen?  And why does it make me love the guy even more than I did the first time around?  While it's true that Hank has the extended longevity of a Mutant 4, even he is finally running out of time.  Hank is OLD!  Steven Campbell ingeniously contrived a rendering of that concept -- OLD -- to fit Hank, but in the abstract his account is really suggestive of what's happening to the rest of us who are getting old; it fits me better than I like to admit.  Getting bulky, slow, gradually losing some of our senses, such as taste and smell, becoming ham-handed and losing dexterity, developing an aversion to getting up in the morning or even getting up out of a chair ... I could go on, but you get the picture.The one thing conventional geriatrics don't share with Hank is getting tougher.  This guy has become practically invulnerable.  Not much of anything can hurt him, or even get his attention.  As if we needed added emphasis that Hank is almost impossible to move and physically insensitive, when one of his newly recruited female Kommilarie, a beautiful redhead with a galaxy-class body, stands in front of him and strips down to her boots, Hank seems not to notice!  Probably just as well.  A guy whose weight is best measured in tons could pose a real danger if aroused by a normally pneumatic woman.  Besides, once he's down, Hank has a tough time getting up.  Even his super strength is barely a match for his enormous weight.However, the one thing that will grab Hank's attention is a heart attack.  He has them more or less routinely.  They may put him out for a day or two, but then he somehow heals and gets going again, waiting for the one that will take him out for good.  Remember, though, this is the same guy who in the first volume twice spent a month in a coma after unfortunate misadventures first with a Dredl L robot, and then with a distant relative's antique pistol that exploded when he fired it.  A tough guy, yes, but even Hank has limits, including a finite life span.While in many ways -- strength, toughness, preference for negotiation over violence -- the Prince of Suck Hank has lot in common, even if in exaggerated form, with the Screw the Galaxy Hank, something truly fundamental has changed.  Hank, much like noir heroes we know, maybe Sam Spade, is now, more or less, on the side of the law.  In fact, in Belvaille Hank pretty much is the law.  He's the Supreme Kommilarie, commanding a contingent of four or five hundred lesser Kommilarie, whose job it is to maintain law and order, keep the peace, kill the worst of the worst or send them to the section of an orbiting prison known as the Royal Wing.  Being Supreme Kommilarie is a tough job:  his underlings are untrained and undisciplined; Belvaille is an ethnically charged tinder box; feral children run amok; nobody knows quite what's going on in the South End, just that it's good place to avoid; there are more criminal gangs and bosses than anyone can knowledgeably count; and to top it all off, Belvaille continues to have air, water and other absolute essentials only due to the efforts of an old, easily distracted genius named Delovoa, and at the sufferance of Garm, once the top security official and Hank's girlfriend, who somehow has come to own the City.Furthermore, as if more were needed, while it's the Kommilarie's job to enforce the law, there really is no law.  Hank tries to be evenhanded and reasonable in making it up as he goes along, and his long-celebrated negotiating skills are repeatedly put to the test.  Given that Hank's Kommilarie are vastly out-numbered by a multiplicity of bad guys and crazies, his ingenuity is tried beyond any sort of practical limits, and sometimes it's best just to let contending factions fight it out and kill each other off.Still, Hank has come to realize that he want's the best for Belvaille, wants it to be a decent place to live and raise children while earning a decent living.  He soldiers on with super-natural patience and the noir-like pragmatism of someone like Philip Marlowe, or Easy Rawlins.  Along the way he participates in the best parody of true-blue, cocksure, circular reasoning of free marketeers I've ever read.  Those Ank's are a caution!To sum it all up, Steven Campbell is at least as good as he ever was, and Hank is at least as engaging and funny.  A noir (or neo-noir) super hero for the ages.  I gotta get a copy of the volume I missed.

Raymond Williams was a brilliant and learned scholar from a Welsh working class background who devoted most of his professional life to making our shared world, in its myriad manifestations, understandable in an evolving Marxist context.  Williams, however, was not doctrinaire in his commitment to Marx, never imposing a nonsensically sanctified status on everything Marx wrote.  Nor, to my knowledge, did he side with those who saw a sharp distinction between the early Marx, ostensibly a humanistic philosopher, and the later Marx, a hard-nosed materialist scientist.When reading Marxism and Literature, it is easy to see that Williams based his presentation on material that Marx produced throughout his life, from the Economic and Philosophical Manuscripts of 1844 and the German Ideology through the Grundrisse, Capital, and Theories of Surplus Value.  As best I can determine, Williams regarded the work of the early Marx to be just as committed to materialism and the socially constituted nature of human beings, their language, culture, classes, and class relations as anything he wrote later.  The pattern of references in Marxism and Literature is clearly consistent with this judgment.Marxism and literature is a willfully condensed book, nearly devoid of examples to illustrate Williams' theoretical assertions, and it is quite dense.  The material itself is inherently difficult, and when offered with deliberate compactness and an aversion to all but the essentials, it becomes even more difficult.  For readers unfamiliar with much of anything Marx wrote, Marxism and Literature may prove to be inaccessible.  Even for those who have read substantial portions of Marx's writings, and who are familiar with related work, such as that offered by the Frankfurt School and the Althusserian structuralists, may find this book heavy going. Many of the concepts that are commonly used by Marxist students of literature are not due to Marx but to others who followed him. Thus, while Williams was an accomplished prose stylist, when he chose to make Marxism and Literature no more than half as long as it might easily have been, he demanded the reader's unwavering attention and thoughtful participation in the innately demanding social process of bringing his account to life.Much of Marxism and Literature is written in a point-counterpoint manner.  Williams introduces a crucial concept, say language, and then acknowledges others' rigorous scholarly efforts to come to terms with this idea, often finding favor with a Marxist audience.  While Williams is never acerbic nor given to shredding straw men, he then proceeds to explain the deficiencies in the work of others, and provides a more thoroughly Marxist alternative.Some of Williams' correctives are straightforward and easy to follow.  In the case of language, for example, which he discusses brilliantly and at length, he begins with the simple observation that language cannot be reduced to the status of a tool used by human beings to facilitate cooperative activity.  Instead, language is constitutive of human beings.  There are no human beings without language, and language is produced only by human beings.For readers new to Marxist literature, the use of the idea of production in this context is unlikely to be troublesome.  However, when Williams judges the production of language, as well as the creation of human beings, to be manifestations of material production, this usage may generate confusion for those unaccustomed to this way of thinking.  The notion of materialism in instances such as these refers to something that others have referred to as material practice.  Both human beings and the language constitutive of them are produced in social interaction.  They are products of ongoing social relationships, thereby giving priority to behavior occurring in specific social settings rather than to fixed ideas whose provenance is unsettled.Throughout Marxism and Literature, Williams returns again and again to the judgment that others fail to fully understand the social, the material, the productive, and the relational nature of the world in a suitably thoroughgoing way.  Invariably, however, Williams emphasizes that we must understand these processes in the historically specific social contexts in which they occur. Williams is a determinist but not a crude one.  He understands the importance of the manifold class-based and other variable contingencies in which determinism is present.While there is nothing really new about it, Williams treats Gramsci's concept of hegemony in the most compelling and informative way that I have read.  Many others have invoked hegemony in a variety of contexts and then left it as self-explanatory.  Perhaps it is, at least for those who have read Gramsci.  But I'm glad that Williams gave it a thoughtful rendering.  Nevertheless, as with other concepts, Williams admonishes us to avoid reification of hegemony.  It exists, yes, but only through production by active and material social relationships among human beings in a particular time and place.  A particular form of hegemony, moreover, contributes substantially to creating that time and place in ways that permit change and variability, rather than being crystallized and static.  An example of the latter sort of lifeless concept would be Zizek's "social conscience" as used in Living in the End Times.  In contrast to Zizek, as Williams matured, his Marxism became more sophisticated and more useful.Whatever its many virtues, Marxism and Literature can be annoying.  Williams' use of parentheses, sometimes containing an uncomfortably long line of words that cost us our train of thought, is excessive.  Furthermore, with or without parentheses, sentences that are longer than most paragraphs could easily have been avoided.  In addition, Williams' aversion to concreteness may make one suspect that while this is indeed a book about Marxism, the place of literature is, at best, ancillary.  This may be the primary limitation of William's fine book.Marxism and Literature is an instance of exemplary Marxist scholarship.  I think it also illustrates the ironic fact that things written by others, purportedly in a Marxist tradition, are commonly more difficult to understand than anything Marx himself ever wrote.  As such, it gives the reader a chance to decide if he or she is really interested in what pass for Marxist treatments of literature given the issues raised over the decades.  After all, it's entirely possible that one will find Marx or any other original thinker fascinating, but not be interested in what their adherents have to say about literature or any other practices commonly subsumed by the notion of the aesthetic.  As it turns out, that's where I find myself, something I never expected.

Michael Schmicker's clean, uncluttered, unpretentious prose style is ideally suited to writing a novel.  Though his off-beat and fascinating book The Witch of Napoli runs over three hundred pages and is thematically complex, it is also a quick and easy read.  His use of opposing ideas from the realms of the sacred and the secular, mystical and mundane, harmonious and conflictual, uplifting and scandalous, romantic and realistic could have easily devolved into an inaccessibly messy tale told by a tongue-tied idiot and of no interest to the reader.  Schmicker, however, writes in a disciplined and straightforward fashion that enables him to handle complicated and difficult material in a comfortably lucid manner.Though The Witch of Napoli is topically varied, the underlying story is fundamentally familiar:  the desperately poor, downtrodden, and thoroughly disadvantaged against the wealthy, aristocratic, and institutionally favored.  Schmicker gives these abstract factors concreteness in a context where the real attainments, as well as the new-found arrogance, of Late Nineteenth Century science are confronted by the mystical and inexplicable in the form of miracles performed by a semi-literate and deeply parochial Italian psychic and medium.One might readily conclude that such other-worldly phenomena had been discredited with sufficient frequency and decisiveness that they would not merit the attention of serious men of science.  However, there seems always to be a popular audience eager for mystical sensationalism, especially when the events in question have defied the best efforts of the most learned and accomplished to explain them in conventional physical terms.As presented by Schmicker, the antagonists in The Witch of Napoli might be taken as metaphors for conflicting classes:  the effectively disenfranchised and destitute on the side of tawdry mysticism, with those born to wealth, status, and institutional favor championing science.  Even the Catholic Church, at the direction of the Vatican, placed itself in the awkward position of supporting science and its devotees.  Evidently, the Church preferred maintaining its monopoly on all things remotely spiritual over the sacrilege of giving aid and comfort to people of the sort that celebrated the achievements of Charles Darwin.The antagonism between poverty and privilege, ordinary ignorance and scholarly attainment is emphasized by the humbly remote provenance, indecorous countenance, and sometimes vulgar simplicity of Alessandra Poverelli, the mystic to whom supernatural powers were attributed.  By sharp contrast, her arch-rival and brutally egotistical nemesis, Nigel Huxley, was a wealthy and well-born English gentleman, a product of his country's best schools and universities.  Huxley was the sort to whom well-bred decorum and patrician social niceties were second nature.  He was also vicious and vindictive, incapable of acknowledging the virtues and capabilities of a proletarian challenger to his position on much of anything, especially his judgment that the powers of psychics, mediums, and other mystics were instances of ignorance and charlatanism.Fittingly, the most intense and disturbing scenes in The Witch of Napoli are carefully orchestrated encounters pitting Alessandra against Huxley.  When all is said and done, however, it may be difficult to assign glorious victory or ignominious defeat to either combatant.  Much is lost, much is gained, and life goes on.Schmicker nicely avoids banal and tedious stereotypes when he portrays Alessandra as a woman a bit past her prime but possessed of mature beauty and innate charisma that turn the heads of many men far above her station.  That some of the most decent and admirable come to love her deeply, something she learns to reciprocate, provides a charming and believable antidote to the pain and conflict that suffuse much of the story.  The genuineness with which she revels in the role of Tante Alessandra is a tribute to her generosity of spirit and appreciation of real love when she is able to trust enough to let it through the barriers of scar tissue created by soul-breaking injuries inflicted throughout most of her life.The book's narrator, Tommaso Labella, though only a teen-aged journalist-aspirant just a few years and a few lucky breaks past being a Neapolitan street urchin, is Alessandra's companion and primary source of emotional support.  He responds to her in a quietly erotic way that he keeps to himself.  Rather than present Tommaso as existing in slavishly bewitched thralldom, however, Schmicker given him a good deal of latitude to be the teenager and budding reporter that he is.  Tommaso, in his way, loves Alessandra, but he also understands her limitations, though he rarely underestimates her character and strength.  His efforts to become a truly objective but ambitiously employable journalist sometimes cast him in the role of a mediator of the class conflict between Alessandra and Huxley.The Witch of Napoli is a very well written, thematically multi-dimensional, and unfailingly interesting novel.  Without question, it was produced by an accomplished professional who set out to entertain his audience, leavening his account with enough humor to make it palatable, and keenly attuned to the ambiguous and uncertain nature of our world.  It's not easy to persuade readers to cheer for rough-edged mystics over polished practitioners of institutionalized science, but for me Schmicker pulled it off.

Raymond Chandler's novel Farewell My Lovely is the second of his books featuring private detective Philip Marlowe as the protagonist.  Farewell My Lovely is a first-rate read for fans of noir fiction who don't mind working through a story that seems a bit more complex than necessary.  As with his first novel, The Big Sleep, Chandler manages to tie everything together at the very end, but the last thirty or so pages seem pretty cluttered.  This is a very good book might that have been even better if Chandler hadn't introduced so many ancillary themes with so much detail.  Still, cluttered or not, none of the ideas that contribute to making Farewell My Lovely a complex whole are lacking in interest or originality.  Moreover, this is the sort of fiction that leaves the reader with a sense that he or she understands the world a little better for having read it.  Chandler was a careful and insightful observer of everyday life, and therefore so is Philip Marlowe.Readers familiar with The Big Sleep, however, may conclude that over the course of a year or so Marlowe has lost some of his linguistic sophistication and become a bit more flinty, hard-edged, and off-handedly glib.  He still values character, civility, and decency when he finds them, and from time to time he's still unexpectedly sentimental.  Nevertheless, it seems as if the time that passed between Chandler's first and second novels has made Marlowe more cynical and less likely to regard the feelings of others with at least a modicum of sympathy.  Marlowe seems to have become more world-weary, and he's certainly accumulated a lot of beatings, both physical and psychological.  Truth be told, one wonders how a guy can take so much punishment and keep coming back for more.  Perhaps one of the few deficiencies of Chandler's fiction as manifest in Farewell My Lovely and his other novels is that no one can survive as much abuse as Marlowe, bouncing right back after a good night's sleep and a substantial breakfast.Marlowe is a good looking guy in hie early thirties, a sharp dresser who fills out his clothes nicely, and women like him.  It's hard to escape the impression, however, that he works so hard at making a modest living the it's unlikely that he often has a really good time.  That may be one reason why he drinks so much.  I don't think that Chandler wanted his readers to suspect that Marlowe was a drunk, but he's got a thirst for booze that rarely seems to be completely quenched.  Maybe that's just a trait that Marlowe shares with other noir protagonists, guys like Dashell Hammett's Sam Spade.  Booze is one of the incidental but distinctive elements of the noir environment.  Still, the brutal life Marlowe lives and the alcohol that may be his one ever-present and reliable pleasure may prompt readers to ask the same question that some of Chandler's lesser characters often put to Marlowe:  why doesn't he get into a less damaging and more lucrative line of work?  Marlowe never gives a satisfactory answer.Younger readers may be troubled by the way racial and ethnic minorities and gay people are talked about and treated in the world inhabited by Marlowe.  But Farewell My Lovely was first published the year before the U.S. entered World War II.  Even the military was segregated.  The word "gay" had not yet acquired meaning with regard to sexual orientation, and abortion was almost unthinkably immoral.  None of this makes the book outmoded or obsolete, however, unless history and its interpretation are also outmoded and obsolete.  Social and cultural anachronisms, however objectionable, were constituents of Marlowe's commonsense environment, things with which he had to deal.To Marlowe's credit, he was one of the few who noted the obvious injustice in institutional recognition of crimes against whites contrasted with failure to acknowledge the equally serious consequences of crimes against blacks.  Marlowe was a product of his time, but he was able to see the hypocrisy and inequity to which most were blind.  Perhaps his understanding of the injuries inflicted on members of devalued groups contributed to his cynicism.  It's good that he was still able to see the merit in, and maybe even feel some affection for folks like the Belvedere City detective he nicknamed "Hemingway."  Marlowe had not yet been robbed of his ability to appreciate well-meaning, basically honest plodders.I think The Big Sleep is a little better than its sequel, but Farewell My Lovely is still a five-star novel.  Chandler was not perfect, but he's original and writes quite well.  And Philip Marlowe is still a quintessential noir protagonist.

Raymond Chandler's novel The Big Sleep is anything but.  With prototypical noir private detective Philip Marlowe as the protagonist, Chandler's novel grabs the reader's attention and doesn't let go until the very end.  Yeah, we're all headed for the big sleep soon enough, and nobody knows that better than Marlowe.  He moves in circles where death comes early to a lot of folks, both good and bad.Marlowe sees the underside of life at its ugliest and most dangerous, but somehow he manages to avoid becoming a mean-spirited cynic.  He's got a cynical streak, sure, but there's a lot more to him than just cold, dark skepticism, doubt, and mistrust.  Almost in spite of himself, Marlowe is the kind of guy who, though he's hard as nails, cares about cadaverous old men whose basic decency is belied by wayward adult children, spoiled by excessive wealth and unnaturally nasty to those who refuse to give them exactly what they want.Marlowe, in fact, cares about a lot of people that we'd expect a hard-boiled private eye to dismiss as the products of bad choices, mishandled opportunities, and not worth the trouble.  He's a tough guy, a sharp dresser, attractive to women, smart and street-wise, but he's not arrogant.  Confident, sure, but not a showboat or the sort of person who takes advantage of others who are impressed by his reputation and desperately need his services.Chandler doesn't tell us much about Marlowe's background.  He once worked as an investigator for the Los Angeles County District Attorney, but that's pretty much it.  I think we can infer from what we read that Marlowe went private because he didn't want to be constrained by excessive rules and regulations as to how investigations were to be done.  He's got a good head for his line of work, so why let himself be hamstrung by red tape and undercut by the political connections of the rich and famous?One thing Marlow might have done but systematically avoided was using his skills and reputation in amoral pursuit of big money.  Instead, he charges a modest daily fee plus expenses, and this is a guy who lives in a small apartment with a bed that pulls out of the wall.  He could have gotten a lot more, but he's comfortable, well put together, with suitable transportation, money for decent restaurants, and he doesn't miss not having a secretary.  Modest and frugal almost to a fault, but he doesn't do without anything he really needs.  Besides, there is substantial gratification in having the admiration, even when grudging, of high officials in what we now euphemistically call the criminal justice system.One of the things that is especially interesting about Marlowe, complete with his unexplored background. is the fact that he's not just another semi-articulate gumshoe.  His thinking has the complexity and sophistication of a genuinely literate and polished operative.  When he characterizes a story he's been told during the course of an investigation as "... a little pat.  It had the austere simplicity of fiction rather than the tangled web of fact," it becomes clear that he's not the sort who is at a loss for linguistic concepts that enable him to think things through unhampered by lack of wit and learning.  The guy is smart, savvy, and well-suited for the complex intellectual labor that comes with his job.Marlowe likes the ladies, and they, for the most part, like him.  However, even when he's in a circumstance to pick an choose, he puts the job first, not compromising his position by succumbing to temptation.At the end of The Big Sleep, Marlowe mourns the loss of a woman he found especially appealing with a couple of stiff drinks.  Sadly the scotch just makes things worse, but he takes what comfort he can in having enabled a dying old man to salvage his pride.Marlowe is a street-level philosopher who is keenly aware that eventually everyone "just slept the big sleep, not caring about the nastiness of how you died or where you fell."  He didn't kid himself:  he is part of the nastiness, as are all the best  noir protagonists.  But like he said, so what?  When you're dead, you're dead.The Big Sleep is a pretty complex novel with some interesting, likable, loathsome, and indifferent characters.  The best part of Chandler's book, however, is Philip Marlowe:  the quintessential noir protagonist. Marlowe is a great character, and The Big Sleep is a fittingly titled first-rate read, complete with dated references to what we then called "smut."  How tame when compared to today's porno!I really enjoyed reading The Big Sleep, and others will, too.  The story is detailed and plain-spoken enough to be realistic, but the main attraction and primary source of interest if Philip Marlowe.

Early in Joseph Conrad's novella Heart of Darkness, its protagonist and narrator, Marlow, muses on the conquests of the ancient Romans and compares their worth to the colonial empires of his time.  The Romans, he opines, relied on brute force to achieve their expansionist aims, thereby diminishing the potential value of the conquered lands, giving the victors only a tenuous hold, and diminishing opportunities for exploitation.  Modern colonialism, by contrast, imposed efficient organization, systematically administered for long-term possession of the conquered territory and organized in ways that sure-handedly pumped value from the colonies to the homeland.  Marlow succinctly used fewer words, but the forgoing spells out his meaning.But the story Marlow was telling referred to properly modernized administration of colonies only very briefly, in passing, in a way that was very easy to miss or simply pass over as of no consequence.  After all, as the Heart of Darkness develops, it becomes abundantly clear that its focus is on a man named Kurz, an agent of British commercial interests, the most successful procurer of ivory to be shipped back to England and transformed into enormous profits.Kurz has acquired the status of a mythical hero, a man seldom seen but often said to be a universal genius, perhaps the most articulate and knowledgeable orator on the African continent.  One wonders what his eloquence has to do with procuring ivory, but Kurz's vocal prowess is rumored to have risen to the level of a compelling instrument of persuasion that captivated others, convinced them that his interests were theirs, that he deserved unquestioning devotion in exchange for the wisdom he imparted, and he did this even in dialects known to few Europeans.  Kurz is a charismatic figure who had mastered the undocumented mysteries of leadership and was at home in the densest, darkest, most forbidding jungles, where he sometimes moved alone for long periods.Kurz was not simply a fortune hunter and representative of Western commercial interests. He had become a non-religious missionary, a prophet of modernity in unexploited lands among a population resistant to the imposition of alien economic practices and their organizational and technological manifestations.  Kurz was an agent of Marlow's efficient administration and profitable organization of the captive colonies of modernizing Europe.However, even in the early 1900's, doubts had begun to surface as to the unqualified virtues of modern civilization and its unquestioned superiority to traditional societies.  The unanticipated loss of a sense of community, the demise of a feeling of shared belonging, and the troubling dissipation of a culture constituted of a common set of values, standards, and legitimated ways of doing things painfully introduced what recent writers have characterized as a homeless mind.Conrad wrote the Heart of Darkness just a few years after the French sociologist Emile Durkheim first used the concepts anomie, or cultural deregulation, end egoism, or social rootlessness, both giving rise to a variety of forms of social pathology, such as anxiety, depression, suicide, and homicide.  Durkheim was among the first to call attention to the unacknowledged costs of modernization and large-scale development of technology-intensive social systems.  Soon, however, the uncertainty, isolation, superficiality, and ambiguity of modern society were the stuff of some of the finest fiction of the 20th Century, produced by Modernist authors such as Virginia Woolf, Ernest Hemingway, and others of comparable stature.Seen in light of emerging doubts as to the neutral benevolence of modernity, Conrad's Kurz may best be understood as one who came to the heart of an Africa that was still untouched by modern civilization and began using his hypnotic eloquence to persuade indigenous people to give way to the demands of modern efficiency and profitability.  However, as he became increasingly aware of the little-understood virtues of traditional people and their way of life, contrasted with the destructive strains inherent in modernization, he struggled, became torn, faltering, spiritually vague, and deeply uncertain.  He still had his gifts, but he realized that the heart of darkness need not be in the African jungles, but might very well be in the heartlessness of modern society.  No wonder the indigenous population was terrified when Marlow sounded the steam whistle on his boat.  It was just the sort of ugly screech that marked the changing of shifts at a modern factory or mine.  Marx himself acknowledged that steam power was the essential force in large-scale modernization.Hearkening back to Marlow's seemingly innocuous reference to the virtue of efficient administration, Conrad gives us Kurz as one no longer convinced that the payoffs of modernity are worth the costs, but he sees that it may be inevitable.  The prospect of heartlessness is a heavy load to bear.

I got drafted into the Army in 1965 and served two years of active duty.  I lucked out, however, and didn't get sent to Viet Nam.  I doubt that I realized how fortunate I had been until I visited the Viet Nam Veterans' Memorial in D.C.  More than 58,000 names of soldiers, sailors, Marines, and airmen who had been killed in a pointless war of choice fostered by "the best and the brightest" chicken hawks occupying the highest levels of the U.S. government.The fact that I never saw combat and thought the war was an atrocity are two reasons among many that make Tim O'Brien's book The Things They Carried difficult to evaluate.  I think there is merit to his claim that fictionalized accounts can sometimes make important points with greater impact and truer feeling than straightforward reporting.  But it takes an enormously talented and disciplined writer with an abundance of personal experience to make it work, the sort of author whose best output calls into question the truism that "a picture is worth a thousand words."In the first few sections of his book, I think that O'Brien manages to pull it off.  I was especially impressed with the very personal "On the Rainy River," that bore what I took to be truthful and moving testimony to the struggles that many experienced when trying to decide how to respond to a draft notice.  I was too poor, disconnected, and mixed up to have considered going to Canada, but I remember staying awake the night before I reported, trying to convince myself that the so-called domino theory had undeniable merit, and concluding that the loss of South Viet Nam would ultimately be of greatest benefit to the expansionist aims of what we then called Red China.At least in my case, moreover, O'Brien's conclusion that the driving forces of embarrassment and shame could have been decisive in making my decision seems right on target.  At the time, being drafted was something that had happened to so many of the people I knew, grandfather, father, uncles nephews, cousins, and friends.  Not going was not a realistic option, but that didn't mean i didn't struggle with the decision, and almost decided to go AWOL my first day in the Army's reception center for new recruits and draftees.I was also struck my the author's descriptions of death:  instantaneous, mutilating, and ugly, something that prompted those still living to play head games with themselves to deal with it.  I thought O'Brien's account of his response to his first kill, the slender and well-favored young man whose face was destroyed by a fragmentation grenade, was overdone.  But then I caught myself and asked "who am I to make that judgment?"  Briefly, in other words, I had forgotten that I was reading fiction, a literary rendering of a dramatically condensed version of what really happened, an account intended to give us keener insight and deeper feeling than a purely descriptive report of events as they actually occurred.I began to read The Things They Carried more critically, and while I was still favorably impressed, I also had doubts about the claim that O'Brien's fiction was as powerful as he intended.  As the book took a mystical turn and rocks and trees were given life in the form of the production of music, both indigenous and widely varied western forms, I began to have trouble understanding what the author was trying to do.
