I can imagine that troops in the bush, acutely aware of the hidden death that could be surrounding them, ready to strike at any moment, would be so hyper-vigilant that they would see and hear traces of things that might not be there.  After all, each of us contributes something of ourselves to what we sense and know.  But as far as I can tell, the author seemed to have something else in mind.  And with the arrival of Mark Fossie's seventeen year old girl friend, fiction began to turn into fantasy, and O'Brien's intentions became even more obscure.Once the girl was there, however, I suppose we can accept her remarkably rapid adjustment to that forbidding and dangerous place, and her willingness and ability to take on the duties of an Army medic.  However, when she joins a nearby Special Forces unit and becomes deeply involved in the mysteries of late-night patrols for purposes that are not revealed, the author's message becomes hopelessly muddled.  It's as if she had found something sacred, or at the very least a good deal more solid and real in this totally alien place than elsewhere.  Perhaps this is meant to suggest the mystical quality  that a thoroughly unfamiliar setting is granted by those put down in the middle of it.  Whatever the explanation, I think it has the unintended consequence of trivializing war as experienced by regular soldiers.A minor point, I suppose, but one day I hope writers and reporters will stop attributing super-human powers to the Special Forces, Navy Seals, and other special operations groups.  I recently heard a former member of the Russian Spetsnaz characterize them as specialists rather than soldiers.  By reflexively assuming preternatural capabilities of a handful of specialists, we diminish the real battle-tested prowess of regular soldiers, the people who actually fight wars and do so with skill, strength, and courage.The Things They Carried is by no means a bad book, and I'm sure Tim O'Brien has plenty of talent to spare.  Still, while his book offers keen insights and there are instances where it approximates the author's objective of using fiction to better represent reality, all things considered it was a bit disappointing.  I don't regret reading it, but perhaps more than most novels, it's best read critically, and with the knowledge that there are as many compelling Viet Nam War stories as there are Viet Nam War veterans.

Thomas Harris' novel Red Dragon is well written, easy to read, without an unduly large number of names and locations that the reader has to remember to follow the story line.  While Harris' book is not gratuitously violent or artificially sensational, the violent crimes committed are described in vivid detail, including unique and unexpected findings that tend to insidiously get under one's skin.  Even before I knew the story of the Red Dragon himself, I was feeling a bit uneasy.  I was unnerved by the graphically depicted horror of the crimes themselves, yes, but even more frightening was the simple fact that such monstrous events could occur just about anywhere to just about anyone.  It shouldn't be that easy to slaughter families, but Harris makes clear that in his world it is.  People living in upper middle class neighborhoods with upper middle class resources who, in spite of their attainments, turn out to be defenseless when confronted with a ruthless and determined predator.Harris is not inclined to devote a lot of attention to character development.  We know enough about the protagonist, Will Graham, and his family to understand how difficult it is for all of them when the FBI calls him out of retirement to help them with the Red Dragon killings.  Graham has demonstrated his uniquely insightful ability to get inside the heads of serial killers in the past, and while his effort have been invaluable, they have also taken a heavy toll on him, his wife, and his stepson.  Graham now lives a comfortable life doing a man's work and enjoying his family in an almost idyllic setting.  The reader can decide for him or herself, but if I had been Graham I wouldn't have risked it all by going back, even temporarily, to the kind of work that had once proven so costly and could very well do so again.  Beyond that, however, we don't know much about Graham, but what we've got seems to be enough.  The only thing missing is whatever it is that motivates him to take such dangerous risks, especially when his family is understandably opposed.Whatever the author's inclinations regarding character development in general, his treatment of the background and all the unhappy, sometimes hideous, factors that went into the development of the Red Dragon is exemplary, genuinely persuasive in its detailed explanation of the creation of a monster.  Some readers may judge that Harris has told us more about the life course of Francis Dolarhyde than we really need to know, but I think that understanding someone as complex, vicious, and ultimately delusional as the Red Dragon merits no less than what Harris has judiciously given us.  Once we've read the author's account of Dolarhyde's history, his transformation into someone as abnormally brutal and psychologically deformed as the Red Dragon seems almost a foregone conclusion.  Becoming the Red Dragon was a way for him to survive while bearing the wounds and crippling limitations inflicted on him since birth.  If this torturous process didn't work out, it was as much a matter happenstance in a world of undetected traps and unforeseen opportunities as anything else.  Otherwise, given Dolarhyde's perverted but estimable intelligence and steely determination, he might have gone on as the Red Dragon indefinitely.Just as the crimes he committed, Francis Dolarhyde's Red Dragon will get under the reader's skin.  The thought that there are inevitably others who were formed much as he was is really quite sad and certainly frightening.  The author's originality in in documenting the life of Francis Dolarhyde is impressively original and makes for fascinating reading.  Dolarhyde's visits to the St. Louis Zoo and the Brooklyn Museum are especially interesting and skillfully rendered.Readers who have acquired an intense interest in Hannibal Lector may be disappointed that he is not given more attention.  However, he plays an important role, plays it well, and giving him more coverage would be mistake.  In this instance, a little bit of Lector goes a long way.While Red Dragon is well written by a seasoned professional who knows how to get the reader's attention and hold it, there were times when my attention briefly flagged and I thought the author was trying too hard to make his novel convincing and realistic.  Still, while Red Dragon may not be a perfect book, it is very entertaining, and Harris skillfully avoids sentimentality in all the places where lapsing into that mood must have been very tempting.  A good read.

The Power and the Glory is a beautifully written novel produced by a master prose stylist who knows that profound insights, eternal truths, and the ambivalent nature of our moral world are best rendered accessibly, in ways that all readers can readily follow.  First published in 1940, Graham Greene's novel pits the justice sought by the Mexican Revolution against the traditional teachings of the Catholic Church.The Church was and remains a conservative force in the Third World and elsewhere, it's typically unspoken alliances with the forces of reactionary repression and exploitation guarantee its continued existence and largely unchallenged influence regarding political issues that can be reckoned in religious terms.  Oft-made decisions to leave worldly matters of justice, fairness, and equity to the profane political realm defined by differences in material and social power serve the status quo well.  In the meantime, the Church nominally restricts itself to the search for eternal salvation through fostering adherence to narrowly construed religious strictures governing personal morality, and the Church is rewarded accordingly.  Who knows, perhaps the Iron Curtain would still be standing if the nations of the Soviet Union had sought an accommodation with the Church.  After all, there is nothing new about ideologically contradictory alliances in pursuit of mutual survival.The Power and the Glory is set in the 1930's, during the long-running Mexican Revolution.  Led by Madero, Villa, Zapata and other still-revered revolutionary heroes, this was an uprising of the Left.  Its proponents were irrepressibly hostile to the traditional paternalistic and grossly inequitable organization of Mexican society. They sought equity and self-determination in the material world, a place of unspeakable poverty and suffering for all but the privileged few, priests and higher Church officials among them.As a result, the revolutionaries sought to abolish religious teachings and practices.  Their efforts were sometimes clumsy and of dubious value, for example requiring that all who had been priests get married, and making wine and other alcoholic beverages illegal.  So much for communion wine.  In addition, however, the Revolution was seeking to eliminate the dissolution and chemically engendered escapism that made many Mexicans unreliable compatriots.As portrayed in The Power and the Glory, the material aims of the Revolution were not even crudely approximated.  Too many of those who ostensibly served the Revolution did so in a perfunctory and self-serving way.  High officials in the military and the national police  were ineffectual, indifferent, and simply corrupt.A conspicuous exception was the young Lieutenant in Las Casas whose spit-and-polish military demeanor betokened a powerful commitment to the Revolution and its aims.  The Lieutenant's hostility to the Church was as strong as one would expect of a politically astute indigenous Mexican of Indian heritage who came of age during a time when the social and cultural wherewithal of Catholicism were in the service of the wealthy elite, completely ignoring the plight of the poor.  The Lieutenant was also, however, a man of intelligence and good judgment who understood that even his nemesis, the so-called Whiskey Priest, was not without inoffensive qualities and posed no real threat to the Revolution.Greene's protagonist, the otherwise unnamed Whiskey Priest, personified the evils of a religious denomination that was protected by the state.  In a perhaps exaggerated form, the Whiskey Priest represented the Catholic Church as the revolutionaries understood it:  corrupt, exploitative, hypocritical, and an enemy of the Mexican people.  The most interesting and wonderfully insightful struggle in Greene's treatment of these revolutionary times occurs within the mind, heart, and soul of the Whiskey Priest.Yes, he is guilty of the sins attributed to him and still more.  As a priest he was no danger to the reactionary regime served by the Church, but he also failed to meet the modestly comforting, even if ultimately self-deceiving, spiritual needs of his parishioners.  He had no political agenda, but he had gluttony, drunkenness, and sloth, and he fathered a daughter in a brief, almost accidental and seemingly passionless departure from celibacy with a peasant woman.Ironically, however, it is the priest's encounters with ordinary people living in poverty and without prospects that manifests his destiny.  As a priest, he has an obligation to love all members of the human race deeply, spiritually, and uniformly in a contemporary emulation of Christ himself.  However, the Whiskey Priest, as he seeks to recover his lost decency and come to terms with his vocation, realizes that he can never love anyone as much as he loves his illegitimate daughter.  Though she despises him and taunts him mercilessly, the child's welfare and happiness are of greater concern to him than anyone or anything else.For most of us, this would be readily understandable:  we love our children above all others.  But for a man trying to return to priestly righteousness, this is selfish and worldly, cause for continuing anguish.Similarly, being hunted by the police for what he is and for minor offenses such as possession of brandy, he spends a night in a crowded and unimaginably filthy Mexican jail.  In spite of the filth, stench, and undisguised carnality of the place, he feels comradeship with the other prisoners, whether they be murderers, rapists, petty offenders, or prisoners-by-mistake.  They are genuine, needful, and hostile in honest ways.  A sharp contrast to the ostentatious piety, the sterile and indifferent sanctimoniousness of officials of the Church.That the Church is corrupt and corrupting becomes unmistakably clear when, after he is released and seeks refuge in the north, he is asked to briefly adopt the role of a priest once again.  Almost immediately the false piety and unquestionable sense of moral rectitude return.  He again, for a day, becomes a personification of the bastion of false conservatism and ally of political reaction that was his Catholic Church.The Power and the Glory is a brilliant novel that raises questions and offers insights not to be found elsewhere.  Whatever his failings, the struggle of the Whiskey Priest with himself is powerfully instructive, and he is one of the most interesting protagonists to be found in 20th Century literature.

Nathaniel West's novel The Day of the Locust is extraordinarily powerful, a deeply troubling depiction of life in the United States and perhaps much of the world.  Initially, I found it difficult to decide if West's uncomplicated but blinding insights pertained just to the U.S. in the late 1930's, or if they were better interpreted as a commentary on the human condition.  However, whatever the book's degree of universality at the time it was first published, as the decades have passed and globalization has proceeded, The Day of the Locust seems more and more applicable to an abundance of people who live in America and far beyond our borders.West's prose style is neither complex nor otherwise difficult.  He writes in a direct, straightforward way and does so brilliantly.  His ability to enable us to see the people, places, and events he addressed is unsurpassed in my experience.  As I read his brief novel, I began to realize that West permits us to do more than follow a narrative and understand a story, but to visualize it as well.  Thanks to West's skill with the written word, I am confident that I know what Faye Greener looks like at her most sultry and her most pathetic.  I can see her father as his health fails and he dies.  Tod, Homer, Earle, Miguel, and the others are palpably real people, distinctive, living configurations in my mind's eye.Someone less skillful than West could easily convince us of the ugly brutality of cockfighting as it occurred in a make-shift fighting pit arranged in an unexceptional lower-middle class garage.  But only a rare and remarkably gifted writer could present it in a way that forced the violence of the fight on the reader in an almost viscerally painful way.  Only a rare and remarkably gifted writer could enable us to see the badly over-matched red bird as its dead head flopped loosely and pathetically to one side while its opponent picked at the eye that was still intact.Using Hollywood as a metaphor for the rest of the U.S. and perhaps the world, enabled West to use a place of fantasy, fraud, and cultural propaganda to vividly display the fact that confused, troubled, and unfulfilled lives, for most of us, are the norm.  To search for more by responding to the phony promises of California, or working harder, or being a paragon of virtue, or otherwise exerting one's self to attain a modicum of happiness will almost certainly bring disappointment.Tod's attempt to locate Faye, the effort that leads him through cardboard Parthenon's and contingents of soldiers wearing armor fashioned with construction paper very effectively illustrates the lack of substance in the world of glamour and excitement that we sometime seek.  The fact that Tod, a studio artist, had designed some of these special effects is especially telling.  To a greater or lesser degree, with greater or lesser effectiveness, we are all complicit in the cheap and tawdry process of deluding ourselves, striving for the conviction that whole, substantial, and fulfilling lives can be ours.  But how could it be otherwise.  We're all born into a world of worthless mystifications and sterile bromides, taught to think using self-deceiving catch-phrases and meaningless cliches.  The only cognitive tools we have to make sense of the world are already part and parcel of its delusional ambience.One might imagine that this treacherous and painful set of circumstances could give rise to an organized revolutionary effort to take back the promise of a decent life.  But we don't have the intellectual and affective equipment, and besides, it would be treasonous.  We see the lack of self-fulfilling wherewithal and the inability to fend off damaging social arrangements and cruel cultural artifacts with heart-rending, but also pathetically annoying clarity in Homer.  His hopeless loneliness, profoundly injurious vulnerability, and complete lack of effectiveness present in brutally concentrated form the shared human condition as West understood it.  This is not the stuff of which revolutions are made.  Instead, it eventually gives rise to noxious well-springs of bitterness and resentment, better suited to creating a lynch mob than an organized cell of subversives.The Day of the Locust is the sort of book that takes a toll on the reader.  Whether or not we see ourselves in its pages, the disappointment, desolation, and despair in which it finds it characters is awful to behold.  Nathaniel West's death at age thirty-six cost American literature and our cultural character a great deal.

Quentin, the protagonist in Arthur Miller's play After the Fall, is a successful attorney with accomplished friends and colleagues who is sufficiently attractive to women that he has fewer affairs than he could have if he were interested in attaining the status of a sophisticated urban rake.  Much to his discomfort, however, Quentin's life is heavy-laden with moral quandaries that lie heavily on his conscience.  Some of his internal struggle is of his own making.  After all, he did have an affair, promised his wife, Louise, that he'd break it off, but reneged on their agreement.Understandably, Louise is resentful, and restoring trust is always difficult and sometimes impossible.  Because of Quentin's betrayal and her disappointment, she has concluded that he does not love her, doesn't take her seriously, and that he discounts her importance as a distinctively interesting person.  One suspects that Louise imagines, probably with good reason, that Quentin had long since ceased to regard her as someone of value, easy to ignore, not quite a whole and feeling human being.Beyond that, After the Fall is set in the 1950's. Quentin and his friends, prominent and successful as they are, have been forced into the ranks of the victims of anti-communist hysteria fostered by self-seeking,reactionary politicians.  They have been called before Congressional committees to answer for what may have been membership and participation in subversive organizations.  None is completely guilty, but none is, in a strict sense, completely innocent either.  They have been idealists, perhaps inexcusably naive, who wittingly and unwittingly served the interests of America's enemies.  Ironically, their primary protection from adverse consequences is the U.S. Constitution, specifically the First and Fifth Amendments.As time passes, however, and the pressure builds, the solidarity among members of the group diminishes.  Some, including the tough and decisive Mickey, agree to testify openly and, as they put it, to "name names."Another of their number, Lou, a successful academic under siege at his university, can find only one lawyer, and one friend, namely Quentin, to defend him.  When Lou buckles under the stress and commits suicide, Quentin is secretly relieved.  This troubles him.  After all, he and Lou were good friends of long standing, and Quentin feels a sort of survivor's guilt, knowing that Lou's death relieves him of the damaging suspicion that he is a traitor defending a traitor.Quentin's relationship with Lou had become immensely more difficult when Lou admitted that he had written a well known book in which he had lied about law and the legal system in the Soviet Union.  He did so because he had not yet given up on Communism, and subsequently he was afraid to publish a truthful book, thereby revealing his past political indiscretions.In a sense, this episode typifies the kind of moral complications that beset Quentin's life.  The investigating Committee was composed of hypocrites, bullies, and liars.  The friend he had been willing to help was weak, ambivalent, and not without blame.  His other friends were of little value, too concerned with their own prospects to be reliably courageous.  Just what was the right thing to do, and just what was the upstanding way to feel?  No easy answers, and perhaps no answers at all.For Quentin, power took two forms.  One, understandably, was the ability to ignore the demands of his over-burdened, guilt-ridden conscience.  The other was through his personal presence and demeanor as they produced real change in others.  Insofar as Quentin had any power at all, he seems to have been much more effective at wielding the latter form.  When he first met Maggie, for example, his unexceptional but genuine efforts to help her yielded, as she later tells it, a transformation, enabling her to take herself seriously and confidently pursue what seemed to be her own best interests as a self-aware and talented person.When they get together four years later, however, Maggie eventually makes it abundantly clear that the love of one person for a badly damaged other is not enough.  Quentin makes extraordinarily selfish mistakes, to be sure, but the quasi-domestic maelstrom of conflicting feelings and harrowing events seem worse than his failings deserve.Quentin, Maggie, Louise, Lou, Mickey and all the others whose lives are beset with guilt, turmoil, disappointment, and real danger seem to be the products of a world where durable standards and lasting relationships are not to be found.  Right and wrong seem hopelessly confounded and confused, and the cultural basis for establishing and maintaining satisfying and reliable ties among people has been lost.  That life is a struggle, thus, should come as no surprise.Given that it's widely recognized that After the Fall is autobiographical, with Quentin representing playwright Arthur Miller and Maggie representing his wife-for-a-time, Marilyn Monroe, it's easy, and, in good part, correct to imagine that their chaotic lives and circumstances have little to do with the rest of us.  Nevertheless, we all share a socially complicated and uncertain world beset with cultural thinness.  As a result, for us, too, it should come as no surprise that life is a struggle.I think that After the Fall is a badly flawed play, complete with three elevated levels of staging that permit introduction of images that are of no value and may be pointless distractions.  Furthermore, Arthur Miller's portrayal of Marilyn Monroe, even if perfectly accurate, is a betrayal of trust and, in that sense, obscene.  Alive or dead, we all deserve better.  Still, After the Fall is a play worth reading, especially now that the sensationalism surrounding it is long past.

My favorite modernist novelist is Virginia Woolf.  Reading and re-reading her best known books, Mrs. Dalloway and To The Lighthouse, has taught me how to approach this genre, identifying distinctive themes and formulating reasonable and satisfying interpretations.When Virginia Woolf, in her own beautiful prose, employs her characters to unself-consciously manufacture social reality, they do so using the tools available at the time:  a composite of social conventions and cultural artifacts that are innately transitory, though they feel undeniably timeless and unmistakably real.  She proceeds in a way that is discernible to careful readers but doesn't smash it in their faces.  There is no doubt that life is inherently meaningless, interpretable only through the meanings that her characters create in ways that are taken for granted and only very subtly evident.We also see the effects of the catastrophe that was World War I, and the technology-intensive, rapid transformation of social relations that accompanied and followed the War.  In time, the world of culturally shared meanings becomes quite different from traditional beliefs and practices.  Still socially constructed and mutable, they constitute a new reality, as seemingly reliable and true as that which came before, an epistemological transformation of commonsense that Woolf captures with elegance and insight.It would be foolish and perversely doctrinaire to expect Hemingway's modernist fiction, as manifest in The Sun Also Rises, to mimic the work of Virginia Woolf.  However, while she manages to deal with modernist themes and issues with remarkable literary skill, Hemingway, sadly, can't seem to pull it off.  His ostensibly lean and masculine prose too often strikes me as just plodding indifference.  Maybe even a lazy caricature of himself.The themes of modernism are there, more or less, but they exhibit themselves with uncaring decadence and dramatized brutality.  With occasional ancillary exceptions, the characters are vulgarly obvious aesthetes, frenetic seekers of meaning and purpose that just isn't there and that they don't know how to create.  Their levels of chronic self-absorption run deep and disclose nothing to grab hold of.  These are characters who seem incapable of coming to terms with the world as they find it, and perhaps consequently are obsessively concerned with affectations and gossipy exchanges over drinks of various kinds in a seemingly inexhaustible collection of cafe's.  They bring to mind the aimless fidgeting of hyper-active children.The narrator and protagonist, Jake, is a determinedly solicitous cipher, everyone's best friend, who comes to us out of nowhere and has no life apart from his "crowd" of privileged characters.  Perhaps a bit more abstemious and a bit less conspicuously aimless that the rest, his war wounds have left him helpless in crucial ways.  One wonders just what Jake, and for that matter the rest of the "crowd," is seeking beyond comfortable idleness and, eventually, the excitement generated by artfully staged and savagely manipulated blood sports such as bull fighting.Hemingway's characters seem to be devoid of insight, blinded by the modern world with its limitless but transitory possibilities.  They chat about going to England, South America, the U.S. and anywhere else that might occur to them, but they have no compelling reason not to just stay where they are.  They could write books, and some do, though it's unclear that quality rather than the familial connections of the wealthy gets the occasional book into print.  Besides, what would they write about?  It seems that all they know is each other, and their conversational exchanges are typically so tedious and banal that knowing each other is not knowing very much.  Yes, the fact that their lives are fraught with the tedious and the banal could be the basis for a novel, and perhaps that is Hemingway's point, but if it is, he made it in a tedious and banal way.The characters, moreover, are little able to appreciate the beauty in much of anything unless it takes the painfully brutal form of a bull bred for fighting goring an awkward, defenseless steer in just exactly the right way.  The steer was put in the ring to give the bull something to do, a diversion, the same empty purpose that bullfighting itself serves for its audience.  Something sufficiently ugly, merciless, and unforgiving to penetrate their protective shells of effete indifference.  Ironic that the responses of Hemingway's characters of privilege, with the exception of Robert Cohn, whom the others tolerate but nothing more, is so much like that of the rural peasants attending their annual festival.  Diverted from ennui or diverted from hard work and hardship, apparently there's not much difference.Robert Cohn, moreover is a mystery.  Oddly, this pathetic hanger-on is the only member of the privileged herd that has mastered a blood sport, the sort of attainment on which Hemingway placed an inordinately high value.  But Cohn's skill as a boxer is of no value when it comes to getting what he really wants.  His restraint in tolerating the vicious taunts of Mike and occasionally some of the others, renders his physical prowess pointless.  Besides, Cohn lacks the passionate killer instinct that is the hallmark of a worthy blood sport practitioner.  One wonders why he's there, doing little or nothing but absorbing punishment.  Certainly the mercurial and spoiled Brett is not going to turn her amorous attention toward him, resuming their long dead affair.There is a great deal of descriptive material in this novel, covering cities, villages, cathedrals, distinctively Spanish mountainous terrain, fruitfully flourishing wheat fields, the skin tones of peasants and the wealthy, and a good deal more.  But Hemingway's treatments of even the most inspiring and colorful natural phenomena and man-made artifacts are pretty conventional, lacking in interesting detail, unless a matador is killing a bull.  Perhaps this limitation is one reason why I found myself longing for a narrative.  Modernism is averse to narratives, unnatural patterns of temporal coherence that introduce meaning that is nothing more than an imposition, a conceit that prevents us from seeing the world as it is.  The Sun Also Rises is so substantively sparse, however, that the absence of a narrative leaves us groping for a clue as to why it was written.We live in a world that is cruel and brutal by its very nature.  Why we feel the need to introduce dramatized exaggerations that yield still more pain and lethality and call it an occasion for a waspish game of bridge or a week-long drunken festival topped off by the slaughter of bulls is a mystery.  The psychological and physical savagery that we control is of our own making, but so what?My favorite novel is The Old Man and the Sea, a book of rare beauty and infinite wisdom.  Perhaps in his earlier work, The Sun Also Rises included, Hemingway was developing his art, discovering how to write like a genius.  Otherwise, I can't think of a good reason for writing something so pointlessly empty as this novel.

Dashiell's Hammett's classic the Maltese Falcon provides a template for the hard-boiled detective, or more generally noir novel that came into its own and acquired a substantial audience in the U.S. in the first half of the 20th Century.  The underlying background assumption for Hammett's novel is illustrated about half way through the book when protagonist, Sam Spade, tells a story about an ordinary guy walking down a city street past a construction site and coming within a hair's breadth of being killed by a falling cast iron I-beam.  The guy draws the obvious but genuinely profound inference that chance rules the universe and, more to the point, the trust we put in everyday conventions and social relationships is misplaced.  Any of us could be destroyed at any time, and to trust is to place one's self at exaggerated risk.The story of the hunt for the jewel encrusted statue called The Maltese Falcon makes Spade's point in a variety of interesting, sometimes startling, sometimes troubling, and sometimes implausible ways.  If Sam Spade trusts anyone it's his secretary, girl Friday, and perhaps latent love interest Effie Perine.  Beyond that, even the woman with whom he has an affair and who at first seem the embodiment of fresh-faced, even if misused innocence, the woman with whom Spade thinks he may be in love, turns out to be not only a bad risk, but capable of lethal violence if it's in her interest.It's especially intriguing to hear the exchanges between Spade and Brigid O'Shaunnessy near the end of the book.  He really thinks he may be in love with her, but he wonders just what that means.  Brigid swears she's in love with Spade, and he suspects that she might be telling the truth.  But what can Spade -- or anyone -- do if the woman he loves may or may not be trustworthy?  That's a tough one, and Spade wrestles with it, his heart and body telling him one thing, while his street-wise commonsense, tainted with decades of hard-earned cynical wisdom, tells him something else.Dashiell Hammett's prose is clear and uncomplicated, well suited to a no-nonsense character such as Spade.  OK, the author tells us a lot more about the centuries-long history of the Maltese Falcon than we really need to know, but perhaps this is done in the interest of verisimilitude, persuading the reader that the small statue really is something special.Spade himself may be a bit more of a caricature than a prototype.  The guy drinks a lot, chain smokes, seldom sleeps, and never exercises, but he's still got a lean, sculpted face and a well-trained prize fighter's muscular body, except, maybe, for the sloping shoulders, Spade's one physical concession to world-weariness.  He packs a precisely targeted, devastating punch in each fist, and for a big guy he's remarkably nimble and quick.  And the ladies like him.  He's a lot more Robert Mitchum than Humphery Bogart, but either, in his own way, would do quite well portraying Sam Spade.How a private detective like Spade got to be on a first-name basis with the District Attorney in a city the size of San Francisco is a mystery.  But Spade seems to know everyone, and everyone knows Spade.  He's remarkably well-connected, something he puts to good use in his work, which seems to be pretty lucrative.I suppose the most conspicuous villainous characters may be caricatures as well, but Hammett renders them so skillfully that it hardly matters.  In the movie version Sidney Greenstreet played a Mr. Gutman type to perfection, with Peter Lorre doing a great job as someone like Joel Cairo.  Brilliant casting, though neither Greenstreet nor Lorre were as repulsive as Gutman and Cairo.Toward the end, this cast of characters and a few more turn The Maltese Falcon into a pretty complex story, but it's all to the good.  Sam and Effie are back in the office doing mundane things, real life stuff, in other words, and then Iva shows up.  But as we recall from earlier in the novel, Iva's pretty mundane, too.  After all, petty annoyances and mixed feelings are inescapable parts of real life.The Maltese Falcon is an interesting and very well-written novel that paved the way for the full development of the noir genre.  It won't knock your socks off, but it's a good read.  I liked it a lot.  But, then, who's to say my judgment is trustworthy ... ?

These fit well and I do like the thickness especially for doing household tasks that might require a cleanser that could cause a skin reaction.  I like the fact they are powder free and can be used on either hand.I have found them to be very durable and sometimes I just rinse them off to use another time depending on what I am using them for.I never thought about using these types of gloves until I received a box and now I can't imagine not using them.  Back in the day we had the old, thick Rubbermaid gloves that fit terribly and were always too big and even washing dishes was a pain because they would fall off.  Not these!  Love them!

I wanted these for around the house for use when cooking to cleaning countertops to bathroom cleaning and they are perfect for that.  A little short in the wrist, but that's okay.  My fingers are long so they would probably fit someone else a bit better.They are quite durable.  I can use one for different tasks and still not have a problem with it tearing, etc.  I like that they are powder free and can be worn on either hand.This box will last me for years and I am glad to have them.  No more continual hand washing while preparing foods.  Much easier and quicker to replace a glove or to just rinse it off depending what the food is! And, I use a lot of hot peppers and onions in my cooking so to say these save tears is an understatement!

Geez, INVICTA, this is a nice looking watch so why not put it in a black presentation box - anything other than the normal egg yolk yellow box which clashes so badly with the coloring of the watch and actually cheapens it in my opinion.  The box just does not do the watch justice but deters from admiring it..........just a thought.............This watch is big and bold and heavy so it is definitely for the person who can wear it and wear it well.It weighs approx 165 grams!  The band is almost 7/8" wide.  The face of the watch from side to side is almost 1-7/8".  Top to bottom the case is almost 2" long.  With a soft tape measure the inside diameter measures approx 9" so this will fit a large wrist.  And, for a smaller wrist, there is the mall jeweler to remove links.If you are truly looking for a large, impressive watch I would consider this one.  The plating is a good color - it's a rich looking color. The price point seems very reasonable.  INVICTA always shows these huge markdowns so I am not sure what the correct retail would be, but this purchase price seems more than fair.But, the yellow presentation box is just awful!

These are a decent quality and they are handy to have.  I use them to dry my hands rather than paper towels. They are not super absorbent, but they do the job.  They are just an everyday, usable utility towel.  I don't think I would want to be wiping the counter down with them, but that's just me. For that I will continue to use paper towels.  Easier to throw away and no continual washing to keep them clean and germ free.Price is good for the amount and size you get.
Not absorbent, sheds, thin, poor quality.  Doesn't even make a good duster - just smudges stuff around.  I would pass on these.

We are seniors and the idea of falling while taking a shower is always foremost in our minds, especially when one of us has balance issues.I have tried a lot of shower mats over the years and most have hit the garbage can in a matter of weeks due to mold or not sticking to the tub, etc.As there are no instructions on how best to use this mat, I am very grateful to the reviewer on here (PhotoGraphics) who goes into detailed 'before use' instructions. They are excellent and boy, do they work.  I did clean the tub bottom, I did add hot water and 1 cup of vinegar and I put the mat in upside down for a couple of hours. As the tub drained I turned the mat over and pushed down on it to get as much suction as possible.  The result was no curl in the mat from shipping, very little odor and good - VERY GOOD - suction.  We live in a dry climate so mold is not an issue, but I will pull it up once a month to clean, again using the advice of the reviewer who said to put hot water in the tub and then pull from one end - works great! We have two bathrooms and I have a different mat in each bathtub.Less one star because of the lack of instructions on how to make this mat work the way it should!

WhenWhen I read a book these days it is strictly for enjoyment, entertainment and escape.  I want some time away from news, economic and health pressures.  I don't want to read something serious or mind boggling.  I don't care if it is factual or not or appears too far out there to be believable.  I want to like the characters and the plot line. As I said, I want to get lost in a book for however long it takes me to get serious again.I found that with Nine Lives.  I had not read any books by this author prior to Nine Lives.  All I knew was it had a cat(s) in it and that appealed to me.I enjoyed reading it.  I thought it well written and it caught my interest early on.  It was an easy read and that was what I was looking for.  I will be reading other books by this author because as I stated earlier, I just want to be entertained and I was.

Wish these would have been around in my day - I loved my stuffed bears, but this Smart Toy Bear is on a whole new level for children and their bears.  It's like having a little friend that responds and in a cute, intelligent manner.We have a neighbor child who visits with her mother and she is always bored since no small children live here.  Well, not now!  Now she looks forward to coming over and I know her mother is buying her a Smart Toy Bear for Christmas so she can have her own all the time.This little girl has so much fun with the bear - it's a joy to watch.The price might seem a bit high to some and it will cost more to add features, etc., but I do recommend this bear.  I have watched this shy little girl come out of her shell and when she is playing with the bear, she laughs and talks and just has fun.  She does not care about tv or anything else.

My husband has always worn Thorogood or Red Wing ST boots and they are not inexpensive.  These Stanley ST boots are very well made and he actually said he thought they were more comfortable than the Thorogood he has been wearing. Now, that's just him.  Everyone will have their own experience, but he is very pleased with them and the price is great in comparison. They are a heavy boot, but that is to be expected with ST boots.They also are a very nice looking boot!.

REALLY incredible tasting chocolate bars................I had not tasted Scharffen Berger candy before receiving this box and oh my, it is indeed quite different and creamy and to die for good! I was drinking a hot cup of coffee when it arrived and it was the perfect pairing - that and a good book which I also had...........a perfect combination!I am the kind of person who can't say no to a good candy, but this is so rich that I could barely get past half a bar - I did, but it was almost too much at one time. This is not a gobble down chocolate, but one to be tasted and savored............it is THAT good.This is the perfect gift box assortment that is well packaged before mailing and arrives in a quality presentation box.  But, I would also be tempted to include some or all of the bars in a gift basket of assorted items of coffees, teas, cookies, fruits, etc.  The bars are individually wrapped so they are perfect for a basket gift.The calories are high, 440 to 480 - and the sodium is high, from 25 mg to 120 mg, depending on the flavor selected, but the taste and texture are excellent.I really do recommend this gift box for a special gift for yourself or for anyone you care about :)

I started using kitchen scales some years ago and find them very useful for dividing up bulk purchases of meat, veggies, etc.And, with health issues in our family, I also find it necessary to weigh some foods and after a while it just becomes second nature and it's so easy to do with this Accuweight scale.  It's easy to read, it's easy to clean, it looks nice on the counter and it's easy to sanitize as I weighed a little cat on it before calling the vet so she would know how much medicine to dispense for her!  Now, that saved me from having to take this little girl in the carrier in the car and stress out the both of us so I love the scale if just for that.  The cat weighs under 10# so it worked splendidly.I did place and weigh a washcloth separately under her before weighing her.AND, I had to mail some medical records and did not want to wait in line at the local post office so I weighed the manila envelope on the scale and knew exactly how much postage to use - I cannot tell you what it meant to me to avoid the post office!It's just a great, functional scale that is also very accurate.I was sent a scale from the manufacturer at no cost to use and review.  I love it!

I have very fair skin and I left this on for 40 minutes and I got a natural looking light tan color that I am very pleased with.I have tried several of the XEN-TAN products and each time using one it gets easier.  I have not had a problem with streaking or with the color rubbing off on clothing or bedding, but for the first hour after applying I wear a loose sleepshirt and throw a sheet over my recliner just in case.  So far, no problems.I have learned to exfoliate prior to using any of the XEN-TAN products because it makes the application so much easier.I think this is an excellent product with a pleasant fragrance that does not bother my respiratory issues.  It is easier to apply if using the mitt that is available separately or something similar.  At least it has been for me.I have never been to a tanning salon and my days of being in the sun are long over, so this is a really nice way to look healthier!

Didn't even know anything like this existed and my husband's laptop has just been sitting collecting dust.........well, not any longer and no longer his laptop either.  Now that I have this little beauty, the laptop goes with me and for a disabled person, that can just mean sitting in a recliner rather than at a desk so there are now things I can do and I no longer have to sit at my desk and rely on the PC. For me, it is working perfectly.

This is a really nice looking, classic watch.  I buy bracelets that are 8" and this watch fits me perfectly with a nice drape - it does not fit snug.  It has a fold-over clasp.It weighs approx 90 gm.  The watch face is approx 1-1/4" across and the band is almost 3/4" wide.I set the time and it is working well.I am a senior gal and I don't have any problems reading the roman numerals.  The date is tiny, but really, how many times are you not going to know what the date is?  By the time you get out of bed and get your act together you will know the day and date - or should, anyway :)This is a nice everyday watch that could be worn with jeans as well as that little black dress.It arrives in a very nice black presentation box - great for storage or gift-giving.

We have never had a problem when using a Linksys product and this VPN Router was no exception. We have a small home business and the set-up was relatively easy with no need to contact customer service.  So far everything is running well.A well made product!

This watch comes ready for gift giving in an Invicta presentation box.  They do it nicely with all their watches and this one is no exception.The watch is large and masculine in it's presence.  If you are looking for a watch that can go from cut-offs to a suit, then you might consider this one.  It's impressive and it might not have all the bells and whistles as some others have, but if you are not looking for that, then at this price point this is a great watch.

I am not ghost pale, but close to it and with freckles and I have senior skin that at one time did way too much real sun tanning......I have tried several of the XEN-TAN products in the past couple of months and was pleased with the performance of all of them, but this one is definitely my favorite because of the foam.  It's easy to apply, especially with a mitt and it fades so naturally it just seems 'real'!  I only apply it to my face and neck and arms as I wear slacks most of the time.  I have found that putting my facial moisturizer on my skin before applying the XEN-TAN helps the coverage even better.I love this and NO ORANGE!  None......zip.......nothing.........just a natural glow.....love, love, love it!AND, it does NOT dry out my skin or flake as some tanning products can do.

You just can't go wrong with Purina!  I grew up on a cattle ranch with cats, dogs, calves, chickens eating Purina products and we had the healthiest animals around.  Seriously.Over the years I have fed my dogs and cats Purina and sometimes wavered and tried other brands, but almost always returned to Purina.Lately I have been able to try some very expensive brands and natural brands and holistic brands and our 4 inside only cats would try them, maybe, and maybe spit them out or go back to the bowl a few times before totally ignoring them.When I opened this bag of Purina all 4 cats were waiting for it to be poured into bowls and started 'scarfing' it down.  They also do that with the Purina Complete we buy on a regular basis for inside and outdoor ferals we feed.  We have bowls out 24/7 for cat grazing and the only other dry foods we have out is Purina Gentle and Iam's Original Chicken.  Purina is preferred.The texture is interesting and different and the cats seemed to like that.I wish the bag was resealable but I always put the food in plastic containers for storage as soon as a bag is opened so it isn't a big deal.

This is the perfect read for me as I recently stopped using Windows Vista ( I know, dinosaur era here) and started using 8.1 and this book has been a major help for me in understanding my computer better as well as how to use it.  I am seriously not a computer person and wish I had read something like this book a long time ago.........One of the reasons I was afraid to give up Vista was being afraid of the 'unknown' in something else.  If you are anything like me, then this book will be a big help to you because it covers so much.Now, Windows 10 doesn't look as intimidating as it once did.

None of the 4 indoor only cats seemed to like it.  It does have a strong smell and that seems to deter them from other brands as well.I love the small kibbles which resemble some kitten food kibbles and I thought they would love that, but not so far.We have 5 ferals in the backyard we feed so it will not go to waste, but I am really surprised our cats would not try it or if they did, not eat more than one kibble.

Wow!  Extremely fresh tasting as in perfect for holiday gift giving for yourself or anyone - great to have shipped to recipient because of the tin inside and it being carefully packed.If you already love these and you buy this tin for a gift but you are having it shipped directly to yourself, then do not open the tin, period.  One bite and you'll be sitting, clutching the tin, daring anyone to get within arm's reach! - lol - okay, so that was me a few hours ago :)  I can't remember smiling as much as I did while scarfing these little morsels down.........but, I am a big fan anyway.Seriously, this came well packaged on a hot day - 90 degree plus - but they were not melted, just a bit sticky.  I put the tin in the fridge for a few hours.This is a great gift idea for shipping or to buy and place the contents in candy dishes around the house for a party - holiday open house, etc.  Be advised - better buy 2 or more though because they won't last long :)Just a really enjoyable candy!

I love anything in lavender/purple shades and the ombre coloring on this shower curtain is no exception.  It's bright and fresh looking and paired with a clear shower curtain liner it works beautifully.It would work in almost any style of bathroom, but with colors like this, you are pretty limited as to towel and rug color choices.  Shades of lavender/purple/white are about it, but it would make for a really pretty and fresh looking bathroom.It's a good quality curtain and the fact it can be washed makes it even better.  The price is reasonable when comparing it to similar shower curtains in the marketplace.

I am giving it 5 stars because it does work well for me.  I have mobility issues and because of certain medications I tend to shake at times so the Amope is perfect for me.I agree that the price point is high compared to other similar products on the market, but it all depends on what a person needs and if they get professional manicures/pedicures, etc.  For me, I would pay the price just to be able to do my nails and have them look nice.

It's shipped without any staples in it or to put in it.  I had some that fit, but not many at one time.  It worked, then it didn't, then some staples bent so I would say it's cute and will look nice on a desk that doesn't require a lot of stapling..UPDATE LESS THAN 24 HOURS AFTER RECEIVING IT - IT'S IN THE TRASH!  I tried putting more staples in it and it would not close.  The next thing I see is about 2" of spring wire extending out of the stapler that had come off of the round metal at the bottom that should fit under the staples.......there was no way to fix it so in the trash it went.Definitely not a good purchase in my opinion.

I have been wearing Anne Klein jewelry for many years so was looking forward to getting this watch and I was not disappointed!It really IS a beautiful, classy looking watch.  It measures approx 7-1/2" long end to end and weighs approx 60 gms so it has a nice weight to it.  The band resembles a woven band I had on a vintage Longines watch.  It is like a wheat pattern.  It is a solid band, yet flexible.  The watch face is approx 1-3/8" from edge to edge.  It has roman numerals and it is easy to read.  It has a second hand.  So far it is keeping perfect time.  The band itself is approx 5/8" wide which nicely enhances the large watch face.  So many watches now have a large dial with an itty bitty band that just looks silly.I think Amazon's price is very reasonable considering the quality of this watch.  The high end retail stores will no doubt offer it at a considerable amount more, especially with the holidays around the corner.I put this watch next to my 14k gold one and the color on the Anne Klein is an almost perfect match.  It is a warm, rich color, not at all brassy as some are.I wear an 8" bracelet and this watch fits me perfect with no draping, but it is not snug either.  Just a good fit.  With the extension piece removed the watch measures about 7" end to end so will fit a smaller wrist.I love this watch and I'll be wearing it all the time!  What a great gift for yourself or someone you care about :)

Having said that, I am currently in a chocolate lover's happy coma induced by eating 3 of these bars and allowing my husband to have 2...why not 6 in a box?  Would certainly be more fair for sharing :)These are great tasting with lots and lots of almonds, BUT over-priced in my opinion and should come way down in price during the holidays at local supermarkets.This is not a good item to buy for shipping in summer months.  It was delivered via USPS which was much better than sitting on a UPS truck waiting all day for delivery, but the box - triple boxed from Amazon - still contained almost 5  melted chocolate bars upon delivery to me.  I put the box in the freezer for a little while but then the fancy gold wrapping got stuck in the now solid chocolate making a mess to try and eat.Definitely a great gift to give someone, but I would shop locally for a better price and/or buy separate bars and put them in a basket with other items for a gift :)4 stars because of the price.........

I have never seen a watch for left handed people before and maybe it wasn't intentional to make it that way, but it works great for those of us who are lefties.My husband tried this on and wore it for awhile, but it just wasn't for him so I tried it and I love it.  It's definitely a unisex watch, especially with us gals liking the larger watch faces these days.  It's easy to read and it looks nice on, if you like black bands and watch faces.  I would love to see the company make it in other colors like white and pastels as well as brown, green, etc.  I would definitely buy a couple.So far it is keeping excellent time.  I am happy with this watch and again, if you like a larger dial, then this is a good watch for you. I am not finding it too heavy to wear either.  It is not a light watch, but it is balanced with the width of the band enough that the weight is distributed evenly, at least for me it is.

A gift for yourself or for someone who really loves to shave with a superior quality electric shaver.My husband has been using Philips Norelco shavers for a long time, preferring them over two other top name brands. This is the first time I have seen and heard him really 'like' the shaver.  And, then comment to me on what a smooth shave he got and how quiet it is to use and on and on and on......he definitely is happy with it.It's a beautiful shaver to look at as well and it fits nicely in the hand. And, honestly, I didn't see 'for men only' written anyplace on the box and I wanted to try it on my legs - just try it.......wow - now I want it :)It does have a higher price point than some, but comes with an excellent warranty and if it holds up as well as is stated it does, then in the long run it will be less expensive to use than those that require frequent replacements.

okay, it fits in the palm of the hand nicely, but when I want to use tape I want the dispenser sitting on the desk facing me so I can tear off the tape at the length I need.  When trying to do this with the WANT:D Tape Dispenser, the dispenser pulls forward and the back end lifts off the desk.  Yes, it has a soft 'grip like' underneath, but it doesn't keep it from pulling forward when in use.  I have a glass top on my desk.I did not have the problem with the installed tape that some other reviewers had.  Mine started correctly and has not split. I did have a problem cutting the tape because the cutting edge seems off a bit on mine and I have to pull down with some force to get it to cut properly and then I nipped my finger on it. I am just not sure about the durability of the dispenser with a lot of use. For that reason I gave it three stars.  I just think it's a bit pricey for what you get.

I wanted a smaller printer, but one that could make excellent photos as well as regular printing and this is it.  Actually, the photos are superior in quality, they are that good!  I compared a couple to professional ones I had done and wow, there is little if any difference and 99% of viewers would not be able to tell which was printed where.The printer itself was easy to set up and I had no problems doing so.  Absolutely love that it is wireless.I have to agree that yes, the replacement ink will be a bit costly but for me, when I compare it to professional printing for what I need, it will work much better for me and I am in control of my pictures with no wait time.Based on my using this printer and looking at the results of all printing I did, I highly recommend the Epson XP-830.

and, because my doctor said I am at the age where I need to be taking it.  It is more reasonably priced than the product I was buying online from a shopping network.  MUCH more reasonable.I have been using Viva Labs products for several years and have always been pleased with the quality and the packaging.Supplements vary with each person as to whether or not they actually make a difference in the quality of life, etc.  I can't say for sure these are helping me as I take prescribed medications, but I feel confident that the quality is there and  I know my body is lacking in different nutrients, so I will continue to take them.

I have used Viva Labs products before and have always been pleased with the quality and packaging so I wanted to try the Protein Powder, especially since we have health issues in our family where low sugar is a priority.It definitely took some getting used to and  I did end up with sludge the first time I tried to mix it in juice.  I decided the easiest thing for me was adding it to smoothies along with frozen fruit, etc and that works.We are trying to eat healthier and add supplements to our diet that are beneficial.  This will be one of them.

I doubt it would be a great bag for backpacking, however, because of the weight.For all around camping usage I'd say it's a great pick for a sleeping bag.  Nice and comfortable and two of them can be zipped together.This is a unisex bag in my opinion and can be used by anyone!

And, when they are happy, I am happy!  They were gathered around as they normally do when a bag is being opened and this time they were eating it as it poured into various small bowls and onto the counter. That is unusual because if a dry food does not smell right to them, they walk away.  My first experience with a velcro closure - makes it easier to squeeze excess air out of the bag before closing, but I will eventually put it in a locknlock carrier.Honestly, I haven't fed our cats Hill's Science Diet in a long time.  They have been eating Iam's and Friskies Complete dry food for years. (Fancy Feast canned).  Our Maine Coon/Tabby girl has been having bowel/urine issues sporadically for about a year and it's the fur causing it.  Prescription meds have not done anything but give her the 'runs' and I sometimes forget to use her hairball medicine on a regular basis.  We have 6 indoor cats.  I am saying this because now I am anxious to see if this HSD dry cat food will help her pass the fur easier.  I brush her daily, but she is just one giant 'Cousin IT' (Addams Family reference).I will update after we use this food for awhile.  I really hope this helps her as well as the others!

They are not only pretty to look at and comfortable to wear, they are well made and look substantial without being heavy.  They are not flimsy by any means.They catch the light and have a nice shine, not at all brassy or overdone.The leverback closure gives them a more classic look and of course, a much less chance of losing one.

My husband has been wearing these for yoga as well as on the treadmill and then just for leisure wear.  They are excellent quality, well made, comfortable and fit nicely.  He said they move with the body so there is no awkward bunching, etc. They are easy to wash and dry and look like new afterward.A sample was sent to use and review and I can honestly recommend these shorts based on our experience and the fact we intend to purchase another pair.

I am a bright color girl, so I was disappointed that the colors were not as vibrant as shown in the website picture. They are the same colors, but muted. Now that's just my personal opinion and the colors have nothing to do with the sturdiness of this tote. I am sure there are many people who would appreciate the muted colors rather than have them bright!It is a nice quality canvas material and it is well made and stitched.  Appears to be very durable. The zippers open and close with no 'stickiness'.  There is an abundance of room in this bag!  Laptop/tablet room, books, wallet/handbag, folders - it could carry a lot.  Nice pockets for cell phone, etc.It's a perfect sized tote for just about anyone for office, school, anything.I was sent a free sample to use and review.

I wanted to try this product to use for doctor's appointments because I never seem to remember anything past the first few words.  Some doctor's don't like being recorded so I didn't ask this time.  I had the recorder in my purse and since the appointment had to do with the results of tests I had done, it was important to me to understand the findings and the solutions.The recorder is easy to set up and use and it does a good job for what I wanted it for.  I don't know about music recordings, because I won't be using it for that, but for getting a voice recorded, it works really well.I was asked to use and review this recorder and after doing so I would definitely recommend it.  It's small and compact and would fit in a pocket, a clutch, tablet case, etc.

We are in the SW and we have ants ranging in size from itty-bitty to average.  Some bite.  We didn't use a spreader.  We found the ant hills (small, in the grass and near the edge of the patio) and poured the granules on top of them. The sprinkler system comes on every morning so we were hoping that would allow the granules to go deeper and evidently it did because two days later, no ants to be seen.  If this really works like that whenever we see a problem, it will save us from having a professional come in every few months to spray and bait the ant hills with his granules. I will update in a few weeks/months as to how we are doing because we are always having ant problems.

These are shipped in a clear plastic bag with no instruction as to how to use them nor are there any care instructions included.  I think consumers would appreciate having both.I have been using them for a couple of weeks and they take a bit of getting used to, but are quite comfortable and do ease the pain.-review sample received-

As I got into THE PLUMED BONNET, I wondered if it would be a rerun of THE FAMOUS HEROINE.  Two middle-class heroines, both intimidated by the aristocracy.  I learned there was little similarity between the two.THE FAMOUS HEROINE was almost farcical...quite funny in spots.  An agreeable story though I grew a little tired of Cora's continued angst every time she met a "title."  Heavenly days, she was associating with "titles" on a daily basis.  I grew seriously tired of Francis' ongoing broken heart.  Nonetheless, it was an amusing story.THE PLUMED BONNET was a horse of another color.  A very good story with remarkable depth considering its length.  Both characters were well developed.  We learned of Stephanie throughout the story; we mostly came to know Alistair during the latter part of the tale.  I thought that was quite an interesting way of developing his character...and it was done very well.Both stories were a pleasure but the second was far more impressive.  The first lighter, the second with more meat on its bones.  Both written with a light hand.Enjoy your reading! :)

James meets Sophronia at an inn and it's fake love at first sight.  He's dodging matchmaking mamas and must attend a house party littered with them.  Sophronia is reluctantly on her way to her cousin's home to care for his six children and an alarming number of chickens.  She and James strike a deal ~ they'll pretend a betrothal and attend the house party in concert with her maid and his mother.  After the party, the two will leave together, James to his wandering and Sophy to the cottage that's her payment for the masquerade.  After a suitable period, James will tell his mother that Sophy has died.  What a plan!There is word play that was pleasant.  I learned words I'll never use.  The games that were played were moderately entertaining.  The story didn't exactly flow seamlessly; it seemed to me that the author was trying too hard for "funny."  Clearly, she succeeded with everyone but me.  I did enjoy two or three chuckles.  Overall, the prose seemed stiff, stilted.I only have two major complaints:1)  Sophronia, who is reputed to be very intelligent, seduces James because she wants "to have one experience to take with her into spinsterhood."  Where have I seen that stupid stunt before?  Dumb bunny.  No thought for the surprise package she may take with her to the cottage.  This never fails to irritate me.  I know I'm being an old grouch but I just can't stand idiocy.2)  "Thingy."  Where did that come from?  It wasn't a word in Victorian England.  This bobble wasn't a deal breaker for me but it was the last straw.And the whole thing was a bit too cutesy for me.(No VP badge...I purchased the book and returned it.)

While a sweet, gentle romance does unfold within the pages, this is more an historical novel, in my view.  Even Ms.Kelly says that romance is secondary to history in her stories.  And this is an excellent historical novel.  The blurb, btw, is very good and tells you exactly how Douglas ends up in the small Scottish village by the sea and his meeting Olive.The novel is written at a measured pace.  Actually, as it began, I didn't know if I would like it.  But I persisted and was rewarded by a very good story. The friendship between Douglas and Olive is entwined within the larger story of a poor village that has had the added burden of evicted Highlanders thrust upon it.  Those poor Highlanders are a small sample of those many wretched victims of the Clearances.  The lairds betrayed their clans in the most brutal, cruel way.  According to histories I've read of these abominations, Ms. Kelly, in no way, exaggerates the terrible events.Then think of an impoverished village suddenly finding these ill-equipped, starving Highlanders in their midst.  But through the actions of one man and one woman, the fabric of the community is gradually made whole.  And their friendship continues to blossom.I didn't feel a sigh at the end...much of the subject matter was too serious.  And the romance, while it did slowly evolve, did so inconspicuously.I do agree with Amazon Customer in suggesting Mrs. Drew Plays Her Hand as an excellent read.  There are others, as well.  Ms. Kelly has much to offer in the way of superior reading.Enjoy your reading! :)  .

No blurb, no nothing, I bought this on hope, alone.  I know Ms. Marshall can write, her Hester Waring's Marriage (The Dilhorne Dynasty) is outstanding.Athene is beautiful, clever, not in clover financially, and illegitimate.  Though some suspect her irregular birth, no one actually knows and it had no effect on her childhood.  Now grown, Athene's dream is to make a grand marriage, and she's given the chance to travel to London for the Season as companion to a younger school friend, Emma.  Athene's youth as a companion is explained by the fact that Emma's a wimp who would be stifled by an older woman.  Okay.At their first ball, they meet the kind, lightweight Adrian who is a wealthy Scottish earl and his cousin, Nick, who owns a castle in Scotland...we're not told if he's an heir or younger son.  Adrian is immediately dazzled by the gorgeous Athene, Nick is immediately suspicious of her.The story follows the usual predictable formula with the addition of Louise, Athene's old friend, who is a missing marchioness but is masquerading as a French modiste.  Louise may be the heroine of an up-coming novel.  Then the reclusive Duke of Inglesham takes one look at Athene and enters the story.  His involvement is immediately transparent to the reader but Nick is jealous (he's not suspicious now, he's in love.)  Athene has dumped Adrian and he has moved on to Emma.There is very little character development, we're left with loose ends because, I guess, this is only Book 8 of a SIXTEEN-BOOK SERIES.  Sixteen books of superficial stories, undeveloped characters?We're left with an unsatisfactory get-it-over-with HEA plus an HEA for a secondary romance that was so undeveloped it was invisible.  Maybe that story will be in another book of the series, maybe not.After having read HESTER WARING'S MARRIAGE, it's hard to believe Paula Marshall also produced this.(This book was returned.)

Thirteen years ago, Mary, 17, and Russell, 20, fell in love during an enchanted summer.  Both brilliant mathematicians, their enthusiastic studies were accompanied by their growing awareness of each other as love bloomed.  Then, suddenly, their love and hopes were dashed, each thinking the other guilty of betrayal.Mary immediately wed a man much her senior and spent the years using her talents assisting her scholar husband.  Russell, constantly demeaned by his father who denied him every opportunity to do something meaningful, spent those years as an idle heir of his father's earldom.They meet at a house party, all those years later, still smarting from the old hurts.  Mary, now a widow and Russell, a vaguely unhappy and dissatisfied gentleman.  Tensions ease, a tentative rapport is established, and the first seeds of Russell's revolt are sown.  He travels north to a neglected estate, encounters Mary who is also traveling to a home in the area and further blossoming ensues.The story of Russell coming into his own and the gradually unfolding romance were interesting and lovely.  Russell and Mary had unraveled the deceit of years ago about half-way through the story.  There were other characters and other loose ends, and that's where it got swampy for me.  The last 25% was awash in too many characters with too many loose ends.  The author did her job and tightly tied every single one.  It was as if she checked them off a list amid a morass of words.Anyway, for those interested, this is a clean romance.  And I can strongly recommend another by this author,  Hester Waring's Marriage (The Dilhorne Dynasty),  a marvelous novel.Enjoy your reading! :)

Every Metzger novel has an original premise and I like that.  This one was amusing for a while.  There were the usual stock characters and cute animals.But a little bit goes a long way.  Repetition eventually grew tiresome...not funny.  The h can't accidentally hit the H three times and keep me laughing.  The H can't repeatedly wreck his clothes and still be amusing.  The valet constantly threatens to quit but is soothed by enormous pay raises.  The heroine's mother is a narcissistic  lush with the intelligence of a pea.  Her character is really a caricature.  Nanny and her everlasting knitting needles.  The twins are wild to the point of irritation.The people and events intended to be funny eventually weren't.  This was an okay time passer but now that I've finished the story, I'm just tired.

Daniel is estranged from a witch of a wife; he's conflicted about his vocation, though he doesn't fully realize this for some time; now he has arrived at Haddondale to assume the mantle of local vicar.  Lady Kirsten is smart, out-spoken, and has had two broken engagements.Honestly, I can't think of much to say.  While I'm not a fan of 'vicar' stories, this was written well enough to hold my attention to the end.  Daniel is a lovely man, Kirsten is an admirable woman.Much of the story consists of Daniel, with Kirsten's assistance, taking several local boys in hand and teaching them.  (I wish I'd been so perfect with my own.)  There is a little anxiety surrounding Daniel's nephew but Daniel solves that problem with perfect aplomb.  Increasing angst relating to the nasty wife surfaces from time to time but Daniel will find the perfect solution for that too.  Kirsten comes up with perfect ideas of her own.  They were involved in one circumstance that was something less than perfect, but being perfect, Daniel explained it away to perfection.In fact, they're just perfect.  Not real to me.This made such an impression on me that, by the time I began writing this review, I had to look up the heroine's name.  I'd forgotten it.

First, I can guarantee this novel works very well as a standalone.  Turns out I'd read the previous two books some time ago but had forgotten everything.  (I only remember the novels I really love or really hate, and those two didn't make the cut in either direction.)  So there.  You'll be just fine without having read the first two.  I liked this one.There once was a girl in want of thirty pounds.  Thus began the saga of Laure Seraphine Edouard Lecroy-Duplessis/Laura Edwards/Gemma Holyrood.  Laura, daughter of a French comte murdered during the Terror, escaped to England with her mother and brother.  Penniless, they were spurned by her uncle, the Duke of Saltash.  (He's a nasty piece of work.) Laura and her mother work as seamstresses for a theater company; Laura's brother, Jack, longs to become a physician; Laura needs that thirty pounds to provide for Jack's education; and Gemma Holyrood is born...star of the stage!  This is where Rushford comes in.  He courts her nightly in the green room with no success.  No man succeeds.  Gemma smiles and flirts...that's it.  But Jasper Rushford is our persistent hero.  Jasper is a good person; he's kind, witty, good-natured, and the soul of honor.  He's on the outs with his parents, adores his half-sister, Sophy, and likes her husband, Tom.The whole famdamly comes together when Tom invites Jack to Suffolk with a view toward Jack becoming the local physician.  Jack prevails upon Laura to visit, Jasper's in attendance too, natch, and things get interesting.The story continues apace.  Saltash rears his ugly head.  You know his type ~ wouldn't give his destitute sister-in-law's family a pence, but now he's pitching a fit because Laura took to the stage.  That might ruin his daughter's debut.  So, he becomes increasingly threatening...dangerous, actually.  What a pig.  But Jasper will save the day, I just know it!The story moves briskly along; the dialogue is crisp, much of it witty; pleasing narrative; only a few anachronisms strewn like the occasional rock on a path...stubs my sensibilities but no damage done.  All in all, a good tale!Enjoy your reading! :)

That's the ending of a little ditty that turns out to be of some significance in our story.The first in the trilogy, Claire, After All (The Penwarrens Book 1), was pure delight, the second book was a miss for me, but the sparkling dialogue and narrative returned in force in this novel.  I liked it a lot..Rose, the daughter of the H/h of 'Claire', is independent, compassionate, and charmingly direct.  Dr. John Merton, 5th Duke of Quill is kind, compassionate, and reclusive.  The third character of interest is Baroness Juliana de Anselme.  The three come together when the Baroness' carriage hits a young boy who had darted into the street, Rose dashes to his rescue, and John dashes to help.They collaborate in smuggling the child into Rose's cousin's home, arranging plausible reasons for John to appear and sneak up to the child's bedroom in order to care for him.  Naturally, the three become good friends.Of course, there's much more to this tale amid some delightful dialogue and narrative.  And you definitely want to know what "...the vision of a woman with a long green tail" has to do with all this:)  Hint:  A lot.I read this via Kindle Unlimited.Enjoy your reading! :)

There is nothing wrong with the writing, e.g., the words are strung together properly.  It's a perfectly nice saccharin tale and the protagonists are perfectly nice people.  The real advantage I see to this novel is the insight it offers into the background of John, 5th Duke of Quill, who has a starring role in the following novel, JUBILEE ROSE which I liked a lot.In this story, Abby once expressed impatience with frustration and tedium.  I share her pain.  It was a task getting through the last 25% of this.  Zero tension~incomplete character development~nothing happened...oh yes, Gus ran off, but was quickly found so there went that flurry of excitement~there were brief hints of preachiness and prayers which annoyed.The entire story may be summed up:  Abby cares for Chloe and Gus~they keep Gus' dog hidden~they avoid the duke~Gus runs off~they find him~ William is in and out~so is John~HEA.  My life is more interesting than this!I really liked CLAIRE, AFTER ALL and JUBILEE ROSE.  Don't know what happened here.I read this via KU.

And that's Minerva!  This grand story began with a prologue filled with pathos and ended with an epilogue that had me laughing out loud.  And in between it was all about Minerva and Ashe.A beautifully sensual story, not cut-and-paste sex scenes that are yawners.  No, this was sensual and it required writing of originality...which it had, in spades.  Very well written, every scene was evocative and a pleasure to read.  In fact, I enjoyed the story immensely.The Hellions fit in perfectly with the Scoundrels.  Minerva and Ashe were wonderful characters, sufficiently complex, but they didn't beat me down with angst.  Nor did the story.  Of course, the road to a HEA had its bumps and snags and I'm not going to talk about them.  Mum's the word:)  I will only say there were a couple of interesting, startling plot twists.I will say I really liked this introduction of The Hellions...all very different men, all with their own stories.
