It was fun visiting with some of the others in "the group" and I particularly enjoyed the appearances by Jack Dodger (actually, I can't help laughing:)This is the quality story I expected from Ms. Heath.Enjoy your reading! :)

This was a pre-order for me and I anticipated a really good (probably great) novel.  Didn't quite work out and I'm sick about it.A newly-minted earl with a dilapidated estate laden with debt, Devon began life in this story as a cold-hearted rake.  But we soon began to see his growth into a responsible, pragmatic peer and landowner.  He became quite likable.Kathleen, on the other hand, was a pain in the neck.  I never warmed to her.  The only Kathleen I saw was brittle, sharp-tongued, judgmental, forever jumping to wrong conclusions, hypocritical, whiny.  Not likable.The novel was uneven to me, up and down, largely because just as we were trundling along with a normal Devon, the mood drastically changed when unpleasant Kathleen popped up.  Why couldn't there have been a little more development of Devon's and Kathleen's thoughts and relationship?  Just add a few pages to tell us what's going on with the H/h.  Then again, a thousand more pages probably couldn't have made Kathleen bearable.The secondary characters were very likable and I was particularly intrigued by the budding secondary romance.  In fact, this novel seemed designed to set up that romance and others to follow.  To stand on its own, as just Devon's and Kathleen's story, it doesn't approach others written by Ms. Kleypas, in my opinion.  I look forward to the next novel.

Sebastian, the newly-minted Marquess of Manwaring, had secrets from his past and the reputation of a rake.  Katherine, his uncle's widow, appeared aloof (she was actually shy) and had a secret of her own.After a sojourn abroad, Sebastian had returned to England determined to live a normal life.  But wait!  As soon as he got off the boat, he was challenged to a duel by a furious father.  So much for normalcy and his hopes for making romantic headway with Katherine.I liked the satire in this novel.  There was some humor and occasional witty repartee which I also enjoyed.  There was some slapstick, various dogs, and numerous misunderstandings on the way to an HEA.Sebastian began life in this story as the quintessential rake in his mid-thirties but later came across more like a teenager...who pouted...a lot.  After that, the Grand Passion just seemed a bit fatuous to me.Those who enjoyed the first in the series may like this one as well, although there are more scenes with serious overtones.Enjoy your reading! :)

I love the Georgian Period and Ms. Veryan clearly knows it well.Captain Gideon Rossiter returned home to turmoil.  His father had been ruined financially, Gideon had been dumped by his betrothed, and the tale was the story of his efforts to 'fix' things.  He came to believe there was a conspiracy afoot and off we went.I liked Gideon. His love, Naomi, struck me as a lightweight.  Gideon's father seemed a bit thick.  Other secondary characters, most of whom were likable, were introduced.  I understand they will feature prominently in succeeding books and had roles of varying importance in this novel.The story was slow to start.  At times, the mystery was quite good though it faltered occasionally.  Sometimes, the love scenes seemed to come from out of the blue ~ not much preparation by the author ~ and they were a bit syrupy for me.  And the gadding about!  Did we really have to visit every single inn and pub in London?  I'll grant you, they were frantically hunting for Gideon's sorry brother, but it went on and on and on.  A certain amount of that can heighten excitement and suspense; too much grows tedious.  Then, too, the plot seemed to wobble.  There was some humor, the most entertaining involving the most irascible character, August Falcon.  The duel was a riot.But there were three things that made little sense to me:1)  Picture a woman wearing a ball gown with  those wide panniers, standing on a ledge 15 INCHES wide.  She's facing the wall but the next thing we know, she has her back to the wall.  Wearing that getup, how did she turn around?  No way, Jose.2)  Gideon presents a cryptic note, an appointment book and a chess piece to Bow Street and is outraged that they won't arrest the nobleman from whom he'd stolen the items.  We know their significance but it's awful thin stuff for Bow Street.3)  ***SPOILERISH***  Gideon's friends are on the scene of the denouement, nab some bad guys, yet no one sees the villain?  They don't hear him?  Naomidoesn't hear him???  Seems a little lame.Then we have Rossiter's downfall.  That was nothing more than a personal grudge, with a couple of chessmen thrown in to tie the story to The Jewelled Men.  The connection could have been written much more adroitly, imo.It has been a couple of days since I read this story and I'm still annoyed ~ by the poor plotting, shallow heroine, dense father, the many inanities, the generally poor execution.I understand the other novels in this series are very good.  Hope so.

What really struck me about this novel...in a good way...was the natural progression of the sweet love story.  From beginning to end, it was realistic and proceeded at a gently steady pace.  Nothing rushed.  And that's not all that won the prize from me.  The narrative made for such smooth reading ~ the dialogue was clever, witty, and fun ~ the characters were real, normal, and likable (oh, the cousin was a goofus but he was good for comic relief:)For most of her life, Claire had been required to manage her father's household so, naturally, she was a "managing female."  Not in an unpleasant way,  though.  She loved her family and she dealt with them with wisdom, kindness and humor.Symonton had suffered a bizarre disappointment in his youth at the hands of an "evil woman," so he was cynical regarding the fair sex.  Well, poor guy, he found himself a little flummoxed by Claire.  We could see that he just didn't know which end was up where she was concerned but he was determined to play it cool. lolIf you're looking for something deep, serious, angsty, with villains, this isn't for you.  As the author said, herself, she intended this to be a lighthearted tale.  She succeeded beautifully and that's why I'm giving it 5 stars.  She wrote a story that was exactly as advertised, it was just what I was looking for, and I liked it a lot.  I was surprised, actually.(This is yet another story I've read via Kindle Unlimited.) (1)(1)  10/26/15:  I have since purchased this novel.  Just finished JUBILEE ROSE, the third in the series, and enjoyed it enormously.  I'm increasingly impressed by Ms. Hasley's gifted writing and I *love* her characters.Enjoy your reading! :)

After suffering three duds in a row, this little story was a breath of fresh air.  I enjoy this author's prose ~ she writes with a light hand, an easy, flowing style, with sly wit and gentle humor.There's no heavy breathing here.  The romances (there are three) are actually peripheral to the story and they're rather wooden and abrupt.  This is largely the story of the dynamics of the inhabitants of the small village of Piddledean (!) whose staff of life is news.  They've been awaiting the arrival of the lord of the manor for years, they have learned the Battle of Waterloo has been won, and now dashing young Lord Charles Ramsey has suddenly appeared to take up residency at Greymere at last.There is much hustle and bustle, flurries of notes to and fro.  And amid all the twitters of excitement, Katherine is ensconced in her late father's study, frantically trying to finish his latest gothic novel.  As she has discovered these novels to have been the main source of income for her family, she must quickly become an author and take up her father's reins.In addition to the amusing activities of the Piddledeanians, the uproar of the lord's arrival, and Katherine's literary struggles, the author gives us a small glimpse into the angst suffered by authors during the creative process.  That is, *good* authors.  I'm convinced that readers are the only ones who suffer from many of those written works sailing under the false colors of "novels."  But I digress.Not deep.  Not complicated.  This is a happy little slice of village life, interesting characters, a little action here and there, written well, and there are no irritations.  At this point, that was a major consideration for me ~ no irritations.  Well, maybe one ~ I wish I could have said "Piddledeanians" more than once in this review.(I had the pleasure of reading this via Kindle Unlimited.)Enjoy your reading! :)

A penniless widow, Eve has arrived at Willomere to chaperon the earl's two American nieces.  Fitz, the earl's charming, devil-may-care brother is also in residence.  Reputation is everything to Eve.  Fun is everything to Fitz and he sure isn't interested in marriage...affairs are his style.There is a good mystery within the somewhat rambling story.  Lots of secondary characters, tertiary characters ~ the book is loaded with them.  There's a French balloonist who crash lands on the property, breaking his leg, so he's part of the crowd.  We have a measles outbreak that incapacitates one of the nieces, several servants as well as Sabrina, a narcissistic witch who lives down the road and is married to a kind older gentleman.  Oh, Colonel Willingham drops by too.  He was Eve's late husband's (that's Bruce...he's also part of the story) commanding officer.  Lotsa people.Amid all these doings Eve begins receiving increasingly threatening letters, the house is broken into, Neville is charming Lily, and a romance develops between Eve and Fitz.  Here's where I wound up with major squawks:***SPOILER***1)  "Reputation is Everything Eve" is so charmed by that rascal, Fitz, she decides to heck with it...she wants one glorious experience to take with her into old age, so they have at it.  And there isn't just one "glorious experience," they go at it like rabbits.  If she isn't preggy by now, I'll eat my hat.Anddd, she knows from day one that Fitz has *zero* plans to marry her, he just wants an affair.  What's an illegitimate kid going to do for the "reputation" she supposedly values?  Not to mention future employment?Why do authors write such dumb-as-dirt heroines?  I'm tired of them.2)  Meanwhile, Neville, who has had an understanding with Priscilla (yet another character) for years is about to bail on her and take off for Gretna Green with Lily, thereby wrecking the reputations of both girls.  A real upstanding kinda guy, isn't he?  Why did the author make Neville such a sleazebag?***END SPOILER***The author did some acrobatics and all's well that ends well.I put this book aside a number of times before finally finishing it.  Even aside from my issues with it, I was just never really engaged by it.  The mystery was interesting but the story moseyed and wandered too much.  Too bad, I really wanted to like this.

The first 30% was devoted to the 'honorable' hero's lustful thoughts and plans to seduce his ward's governess.  Meanwhile, the heroine, who had suffered a violently cruel marriage, was having lustful imaginings about her boss.  I'd say she had made an amazingly quick recovery from her recent ordeals or she's a glutton for punishment.At the 30% mark we finally see an inkling of a story...but only an inkling.  Then it's back to the lustful stuff.  Then a tiny smattering of story.  Then a Big Misunderstanding.  Then on to full blown sex ~ no worries about consequences.  Then there's the Big Secret.  Then he proposes and she tuns him down~an earl marrying a governess is not done, plus she's lugging around the Big Secret.  Then we have the appropriate gnashing of teeth.  Then back to story where the Big Secret is revealed.  Then another Big Misunderstanding.  And so it goes...and they live happily ever after.If you think this review is confusing, try the story...no, don't.  What I thought to be the plot turns out to be a loose end to sell the next book, and the one after that...  And I didn't even go into a host of other issues with this work.I read the reviews and couldn't believe this book could possibly be so bad.  Well, it was.  It is.  It's one of the worst I've ever read.This made me long for a good ol' mediocre 3-star read.

This was an obvious take on the Oxford progeny.  The story began in usual Layton style ~ good dialogue, sparkling narrative.  The pace quickly slowed, however, and the plot wandered.  It became a bit draggy and cumbersome.  Still, it was fair reading until the mid-point.**SPOILER** That's when we learn that Lord North, a viscount, was ADOPTED!  That is impossible among the peerage..  Always has been.  I read along hoping the author would somehow fix the problem.  She fixed it all right.  It was subsequently revealed that he was his father's by-blow...a BASTARD.  Another impossibility.  Heirs among the peerage must be legitimate.  And remember, Lord North is represented to us as a viscount, ergo, member of the peerage.  **END SPOILER**I give a pass on a lot of foul-ups in novels written years ago.  But these mistakes are monstrous.The thing is, even before the internet, Ms. Layton obviously did considerable research, even of some relatively little-known aspects of the period.  It wouldn't have taken more than five minutes with a book to get the BASIC FACTS OF HER PREMISE straight, but she didn't.  I'm mystified because it left her entire story with no foundation at all.These aren't little things ~ they destroy the whole fabric of the story.  We're left with nothing...Lord North was the hero, for pity's sake!  I don't expect a lot in the way of plausibility in HRs.  But this one, no.  This story is not improbable, it's utterly impossible.  Even if set aside the inconvenient facts and just talk fairy tales, where the impossible happens, still, even at that level, this is only mediocre.Many of us are anxious to read Ms. Layton's books that are now being released.  It might be wise, though, to use the services of a knowledgeable and ruthless editor prior to publishing.What a mess.  I returned the book.

As I began reading the first page, I thought oh, no, first person~groan.  I invariably hate first person where we're usually stuck with knowing all about that person and nothing of the other characters.  Well, not to worry here.  Ms. Wolf has the talent and the range to encompass any writing style.  And the imagery in her novels (including this one) is spectacular and so real.  I'm not crazy about mysteries, either, but this one sure had me engaged.Yes, the hero is handsome, rich and perfect.  Yes, the heroine is poor, struggling and perfect.  But we were given a complex story.  My stars, had the H and h also been complex, flawed, etc., the novel would have been 1,000 pages long!  Anyway, despite their perfection, the H and h were real to me...they were just fine.My only quibble...a very minor quibble...was how abruptly the mistressing, the arrangement, was sprung on us.  Maybe I was just slow on the uptake, though.  Anyway, the h had some sense so I got over it.Since the show has already been given away in a spotlighted review, I'll chime in with my two cents worth:  Had the villain been put on trial, it is entirely likely...*very probable*...he would have been acquitted.  There was no proof!  Instead, his punishment by the H was singularly appropriate.Yes, it's not difficult to identify the villain, but I remained hung up on the wrong target.  I never did quite manage to solve the puzzle.  So, Ms. Wolf certainly succeeded in making a good mystery-cum-romance out of this.  The pacing didn't always move at a gallop but it remained steady enough.So, two things that are usually real turn offs for me...first person and mystery...and darn, I liked the story!Enjoy your reading! :)

A quality standard historical romance, *not* a quality Survivors Club novel.  With her history, Imogen's story should have been a knock-your-socks-off kind of story.  It fell flat for me.Percy was a perfectly nice man, a bored man.  He met Imogen and they had an affair.  Instead of thoroughly exploring their romance, we were beset by his tribe of relatives and friends.  Who cared?  All their goings-on detracted from the story.Then ~ and this was a major issue for me ~ Imogen didn't tell her whole story to Percy at the ball.  She told him (and us) a small part...a teaser, and waited until nearly the end to tell him the rest of her experience.  This totally destroyed the emotional impact of what should have been a wrenching, emotive revelation.  Like a leaking tire.And where were the other Survivors?  We didn't see a single one until near the end.  Instead, we were stuck with that gaggle of geese Percy called 'family.'I originally planned to give this 4 stars because it is quality HR fare, but changed my mind because it was a pretty poor effort for the Survivors Club .  I think Balogh did Imogen dirt with this one.As for the preview of George's story...well, if that was designed to entice, it doesn't.  It doesn't even make sense.Btw, I did buy this novel from Amazon but there's no Verfified Purchase badge because I returned it.  Really upset and disappointed.

I think a reader who has not read True Story (The Deverells Book 1) may enjoy this novel, and it does fine as a standalone.  The author is very gifted.  But I had read True Story, a remarkably superior novel, and  the plot of this one struck me as deja vu lite and I was disappointed.Nice, strong hero ~ gutsy, admirable heroine.  The story was okay, the dialogue pretty fair, sometimes sparkling.  The novel gave the author the opportunity to tell the story of the least complex "cub," Storm, while giving us an epilogue, of sorts, for True and Olivia.Now on to the hell-raising Deverells!  I hope they will prove this a brief aberration.Enjoy your reading! :)

So often, with series, the grand culmination of it all ends up fizzling.  This story definitely did not do that.  The romance, itself, lived up to all the great expectations readers have been living on, seemingly forever.  Now we know why Olivia moped all those years.  I would too.Through the artful use of flashbacks, we saw the sweet love between Lyon and Olivia and their sublime sense of oneness develop.  Truly one soul.  Really one of the most moving love stories I have read.In general, the story of Lyon and Olivia was beautifully written, expressing the intensity of a great love.  The love story was very satisfying.  There were also scenes of exquisite imagery sprinkled here and there as well as engaging dialogue.After finishing the novel with a gusty sigh, I took a step back and realized two things ~ 1.  During their leave taking five years earlier, Olivia's words didn't ring true.  There were a number of things she could have said without resorting to a cliche.  She simply didn't stay in character.  That entire pivotal scene seemed lacking.  2.  The ending was contrived and had an element of unnecessary humiliation.  The collateral damage left a bad taste in my mouth.  This from kind Olivia?Despite those caveats, I was so invested in the characters, I accepted everything with just a couple of blinks and a moan.  The love story was truly lovely and very emotive.  I can't stress that enough.I also liked the epilogue.  A nice wrap-up.Enjoy your reading! :)

(No Verified Purchase badge here because I borrowed the ebook.)Matthew drove this story.  He was a wonderfully sympathetic hero ~ steady, kind, intelligent, yet strong.  A widower, his was a lonely life.  And into his life came Theresa, who touched my heart ~ her strength of character had enabled her to overcome years of adversity and shame.This was a character-driven novel.  Intense, yet written with a light hand...it didn't plunge me into a morass of angst.  It's a story of two admirable people who had each suffered many years from mistakes in their youth.  They've done the best they could to right their ships and live honorably.  And then they met.Their story was engaging, stimulating, with dollops of humor throughout.  I was particularly impressed that the characters were so *real* ~ no stick figures in this one.  Of course, there was a bit of mystery and excitement too.  I was really blindsided by the resolution of the mystery!I had just one quibble:  Given her history, I was surprised that Theresa was ready for sex at about the 40% point, after not much wooing.  It seemed to me that it would have been more reasonable to have expected a slowly-developing relationship and  some serious courting by Matthew.In many ways, Matthew reminded me of Worth, from Worth Lord Of Reckoning (The Lonely Lords Book 11).  I loved Worth too.Enjoy your reading! :)

This began well.....it was funny and engaging.  Then it fizzled.  Too many UNsensual sensual scenes...just stiffly written.  Characters only superficially developed.  Very predictable plot.Plot holes galore ~ 1.  You're telling me a powerful duke doesn't have the wherewithal to put paid to his heir's machinations?  Instead, he's all scared and worried?  Definitely not duke-ish.  2.  The h's cousin, an earl, just floats around not doing much, instead of immediately straightening her out on proper behavior in England.  Not earl-ish.  3.  The h persists in thinking she can become a governess.  Is she crazy?  4.  Her extreme naivete beggars belief.  No one her age could conceivably be so profoundly innocent.  5.  Her instant recovery from an extremely harrowing ordeal makes no sense at all.  None.  6.  There are more, but you get the drift.  Illogical.I can suspend my disbelief with the best of them and if I'm told I'm in for a fairy tale, I won't expect things to make sense.  There was no warning label on this one.Other than that, it was okay.

Ralph, Lord Adversane, hired an impoverished gentlewoman, Lucy, to pretend to be his fiancee during a house party.  Ostensibly, his reason for this was to quiet those who had nagged him to remarry following the death of his wife two years prior.  In truth, his reason for the gathering was to ferret out the reason for his wife's death...she had fallen to her death.  He had been with other guests at the time but thought he may have driven her to suicide...or was she meeting a lover?  In hopes of learning the truth, he decided to replicate the house party during which the wife had died.He chose Lucy because she strongly resembled the dead wife.  He had a wardrobe identical to that of the wife's made for her and didn't tell Lucy of his scheme.  At that point, the whole thing began to seem a little creepy to me.The story became more overwrought page by page.  And it wasn't helped by poor research that had the dead wife's parents pushing Avendale to marry the late wife's sister.  While not impossible, that would have generally been considered incestuous, illegal, and any children illegitimate.  I can't see a baron taking that chance.If you like the style of a Mrs. Radcliffe Gothic, with little foundation in reality, you may enjoy this.  I didn't.  The story moved slowly with much repetition.  The h's character was rather well drawn but the H was wooden...and o/c he carried the Big Secret of his scheme through most of the story.

This was tons of fun!  A sweet romance and a rollicking adventure.  Jonathan is a viscount who writes biting satires under the pseudonym, Dash ~ among others.  Tally (Lady Talitha,) a gifted caricaturist known as Mouse, collaborates with him on his latest effort, "Town Bronze", a novel in serial form that has the ton all abuzz.Tally and Jonathan are grand as are their friends, Cat and Richard.  Naturally, all the characters can't be nice, so we have Jonathan's fiancee, Clea ~ a nasty piece of work, and her sidekick, Miles ~ equally unpleasant.We have humor, great characters, a blooming romance, traitors, spies, abduction, some funny escapades, and some surprises.  You'd think that with all this going on, the plot could get lost, the story could ramble, but it doesn't.  The tale moves as fast as I can read and turn pages, and the whole thing makes perfect sense and is true to its period.FYI, there are only kisses and embraces here.  This one is all about telling a good story...telling it well.Enjoy your reading! :)

The premise caught my eye and I was pleased that the story took place outside the usual ton milieu.  Our characters were gentry, not peers, and the story took place in, and around, their home in the country.The novel began well ~ it was interesting, amusing, and the dialogue was entertaining.  The tale began to bog down, though, about a third of the way into it.  The dialogue petered out and it became more narrative, more 'telling.'  And much of that narrative was beside the point and did nothing to move the story forward.  For example, while I was interested in learning *something* of the horses, I did sometimes wonder if I were reading a horse story rather than a romance.  The same applies to the passages that prosed on about Caroline's daily activities and her thoughts surrounding them.  She was bored and so was I.Yes, there was danger, but it didn't raise my heart rate because of the excessive narration.  The mystery was pretty good.  The romance was rather wooden.  The plot was patchy ~ I couldn't decide if the romance was the plot with a mystery subplot, or vice versa.  It really seemed to be two subplots.Despite the miles of introspection, the characters were insufficiently developed.  We knew a little more of Caroline, but it was largely superficial.In my opinion, what could have been a very good story really suffered from 1) non-stop narration/little meaningful dialogue, 2) the equally endless introspection by the H and the h, 3) vague plot, 4) lack of a ruthless editor.  These factors resulted in a novel that moved very slowly with stilted writing.  Actually, before setting out to write this story, a strong outline would have been helpful.And it's "chord," not "cord," btw.  Spell check doesn't solve everything.(I received this book via Kindle Unlimited.)

This was such a pleasure!  An actor living as a gentleman and a gentlewoman as an actress.  And a grand story was built around this premise.  Of course there was a nasty villain to lend excitement.I'm reading these three stories completely out of order and can assure you that the two I've read...this novel and Regency Road Trip, a novella have been grand standalones.  Maybe I missed something but it didn't feel like it.(I received this via Kindle Unlimited.)Enjoy your reading! :)

OLT didn't leave me with anything inspirational to say about this little story so I'll just say ditto to what she said.True, there was no massive character development...the story was too short for that.  But I knew the characters well enough to be satisfied.  They were fun to be around.  Their trip on a quest for a new heir was fun and the two romances were delightful.(I received this via Kindle Unlimited.)Happy reading! :)

FYI, no sex in this novel.  This is a very good story - a debut - by a talented author.  Jerome, Lord Orbury, is truly a prince among men.  And Lady Sophia...ah, Sophia.  She shows such kindness and gumption.Sophia was terribly victimized and abused.  Following the death of her husband in a duel, disowned by her family, she retreated to the countryside where she turns her home into a sanctuary for unwed mothers who have been cast off by their families.  Jerome wanders into this situation when he approaches Sophia to buy some property and helps her when a crisis ensues.The scene shifts to London where the property deal will be pursued and we begin to see the malicious hypocrisy of the ton.  Very well drawn for us is the utter helplessness of women of the era as well as the ignorance in which they were kept.  As Sophia said, "Usually the law is made by good men, men who would never deliberately hurt the helpless, but because they would only use the laws well, they don't set safeguards in place to stop men who are not as good as they."This is not a heavy book.....one to drag you into the doldrums.  There are some very intense scenes but they are nicely balanced by charming scenes and the lovely progression of Jerome's and Sophia's love story.The bedroom scene was enchanting and made me love Jerome all over again.The story was well written, the plot was very interesting, and the author told us what we wanted to know about the characters.  I liked the novel a lot.The only quibble I have is with the copy-editing and that's not the author's fault.....it happens all the time during the transition of a work to Kindle.  The blips weren't enough to interfere with my enjoyment of the novel.Great new author!(I borrowed this book with my Kindle Unlimited subscription.)Enjoy your reading! :)

I began this captivating series with the third novel, The Eyes of Love (The Carlisle Chronicles Book 3), and was immediately seduced by this author's exquisite gift for imagery and fine story-telling.  I highly recommend that novel, by the way.This story began with an event that will have you rolling your eyes and thinking oh, no, this is going to be ridiculous.  But it's not, not when you come to know the heroine's unconventional family and her eccentric, scholarly father.  Our strong heroine is matched by our strong, kind, caring hero.I must say the early part of the novel was a bit slow going for me.  In retrospect, I think that was entirely because of the "event."  I simply wasn't prepared to take the story seriously.  As I continued to read, however, the story became interesting and quite lovely.  And Melanie Fairfield does write beautifully.FYI, Ms. Fairfield relies on writing, not sex, to portray her characters.Enjoy your reading! :)

I don't have a thing to complain about here.  This story entertained me, kept me interested, and made me happy.  What more can we ask of an HR?  The writing was just fine.  The misunderstandings which I've seen complained of here were not the sort we typically see in these novels ~ those annoy me too.  But here they were a non-issue.....sweet and funny, actually.Yes, this was a marriage of convenience.  Yes, Tallie was utterly naive and innocent.  And yes, Magnus was cold.  But how they evolved!  And that was the enchantment of the whole story.  I loved it.Enjoy your reading! :)

Golly, who wouldn't love this?  It was so pleasing to see where the romance of the very nice Lord and Lady Avery blossomed:)  Using the language of flowers was a particularly nice touch.I began my "Jude Knight Experience" with her second novel, so I'm not surprised by the unusual premise of this story.  Jude Knight excels at the unusual.I read this little story way before, or way after, Christmas but it was exactly the sweet, happy story I needed after having just read a very intense novel.BTW, I strongly recommend A Baron for Becky.  That's Ms. Knight's second novel and one of the best I've read.Enjoy your reading! :)

Having very recently read the stellar A Baron for Becky, I know Jude Knight is an exceptionally talented author.  In that marvelous novel, the premise was unusual, the plot was clearly defined, the characters well developed, the writing was seamless, and the historical details were spot on.  I loved that story!  But I don't know what happened with this one.I couldn't get a grip on the plot.  There was a plot, a sub-plot, a sub-sub plot, a sub-sub-sub plot...  There was no focus.  We had a myriad of characters but knew little about them because of the excessive plotting.  There were villainous characters galore about whom I learned far more than I wanted to know.  They contributed some extremely distasteful passages and the detail added nothing to the story.  The many side stories and villains were probably meant to lend excitement but they lent irritation instead.I hung in there until the last 30% when the story just became Minerva Press-ish.  That did me in.This novel was in desperate need of a ruthless editor.Now you'd think that after my complaints, I'd be through with Jude Knight and the Redepennings.  WRONG.  I think Ms. Knight has the makings of a brilliant author and I love the Redepenning family.  I look forward to ENCOURAGING PRUDENCE (David's story) and to A RAGING MADNESS (Alex's story.)ETA:  Now that I've calmed down, I'm reminded that this *is* a debut novel and this author is capable of truly superior writing.Enjoy your reading! :)

If you want a different kind of Regency tale, this is it.  Different in a good way...told from the perspective of a gently-reared woman, raped just a few days after her 15th birthday and thrown out by her father as "ruined."  Becky, our heroine.....and she is a heroine.....lived the next nine years with the most courage and dignity I've ever beheld in a novel.  I'm in awe of her.  You may think my opening lines foreshadow a sad, gloomy downer of a story but it's nothing of the sort.  This novel was utterly absorbing and I could not put it down.As reviewer Penny Black says, this is something of a triangle.  The Marquis of Aldridge, a secondary character, is strongly featured during the first half while Hugh, Baron Overton, comes into his own during the latter half.  Hugh is anything but pleasant when he meets Becky, but she's a remarkably strong heroine and Hugh is essentially a kind man.  All three characters are very likable.This novel is well written, the plotting is excellent and the characters are very well developed.  And the historical details!  My word, Ms. Knight didn't put a foot wrong in this regard.  She got the facts straight, and something I really liked....she gave us details but didn't bury us with them.This is a new (to me) author I look forward to following.  Very promising.Enjoy your reading! :)

Leave it to Ms. Farrell's brilliant writing to explore a familiar theme and make it hers!  The book description gives you good background so I'll just offer my thoughts.Such a dear, entirely believable, story of two very dear people caught in the throes of a tragic circumstance for Simon, our hero, while Judith, our heroine, is in a tenuous circumstance of her own.  The story evolves as Simon struggles to deal with his blindness and Judith helps him.You wouldn't think this would make for an engrossing read, but it does!  The emotions of both Simon and Judith are explored in depth...the author puts us in their heads.  It's a story that is happy and poignant at the same time, with moments of humor throughout and delightful secondary characters.I was distressed to see a review seriously criticizing this lovely novel because Simon shook, then slapped Judith at a highly emotive time.  Yes, I was briefly shocked too...this was entirely out of character for Simon who was a kind, gentle soul .  But then I realized.....PTSD, anyone?  Ms. Farrell's writing is often subtle...she allows us to think without hitting us over the head with the obvious.  I wish that reviewer had been a little more sensitive to the nuances of that event and I hope you won't be put off by it.  BTW, while Judith did apologize...she instinctively understood...Simon was extremely remorseful.This is another to join my growing collection of Marjorie Farrell novels.  Such an exceptional writer lending such insight and depth to her stories and characters.  And we can always depend on spotless research of the era.Enjoy your reading! :)

This was my first adventure with Tracy Grant and it was quite a ride! :)Set during the Peninsular War, much of this exciting tale takes place behind enemy lines in Spain then moving on to Portugal, finally progressing to England during the latter half.  I was enormously impressed by the novel's pinpoint historical accuracy and Ms.Grant's ability to capture the feel of the peninsula during this period.The story was complex and interesting.  My stars, we had enemy soldiers/Spanish guerrilleros/attempted murder/abduction/intrigue/treason/political machinations/spies!Actually, this is one romance where I would have been happy to dump the romance, a little overwrought in my opinion, and just get on with the very well told action and adventure of the story.Very happy to find a new-to-me author who really knows her stuff historically and can tell a good story.Enjoy your reading! :)

Well, this is the darndest thing!  I've just read a lovely, interesting novel that I enjoyed ~ I really did ~ and I'm sitting here thinking now what? what do I say?  I'm *never* in this fix with a Grace Burrowes novel.  There's usually something that gets me in a real tizzy...often in a good way but not always.  Not this time, though.  This isn't a 'tizzy' kind of novel.  While this novel doesn't approach the brilliance of The Captive (Captive Hearts Book 1), The Traitor (Captive Hearts Book 2), or The Laird (Captive Hearts Book 3), it is nonetheless a very entertaining, interesting story.What this is, is a very well-written novel with some of the lovely passages I think of as trademark Burrowes ~ turns of phrases unique to her.  It is an engaging, sometimes fascinating, story involving sheep (who knew?) and Nita's gift for healing.  It's Nita's use of that gift to all and sundry that has her family bent outta shape.  And here's Tremaine.  Half Scottish, half French nobility, all intriguing.  Orphaned, he grew up in the Highlands and developed his skill as a canny Scot merchant.  He spies Nita and it's pretty much all over for him.  Oh, he'll squirm and struggle but we know he's done for.  And he's on the family's side regarding Nita's medical activities, so trouble could be brewing.It is a story, as well, of the interesting, and entertaining, family dynamics of Nita's irrepressible family.  Some outlying characters are included and all the characters are explored with satisfying depth.  The tale also gives us doses of humor just when we need it.It tells us of the essential helplessness of women of the time.  It touches on the harm done some young boys in the English public schools of the era.  It gives us insight into the appalling medical quackery that often prevailed in the countryside of the era.  Even the changing economy is dealt with.So, you see, there is a great deal here to sink your teeth into besides just a simple romance.  It's anything but simple...but a satisfying love story it definitely is.  And the love scenes are so beautifully sensual.I look forward, with relish, to the other sisters' stories.Enjoy your reading! :)

The blurb is haywire btw.  As I said, this was whimsical ~ downright silly in parts ~ and I liked it.  It's told in first person, from 19-year-old Elizabeth's POV.  First person usually gets on my last nerve but it worked here.  I was Elizabeth's confidant and I enjoyed being confided in.  It endeared her to me.Though granddaughters of a duke, Elizabeth and her sisters live quiet, unassuming lives in the country and are treated as commoners by the village folk.  Now the estate on which they've been allowed to live has been inherited by a sophisticated marquess, Lord Dearborne.  "Nicky" is the epitome of the London ton ~ and he's also a valued secret agent of the Crown during this time of Napoleon.  He arrives and, thankfully, allows the girls to continue living in their cottage with the housekeeper.  Then, he pretty much ignores the girls...or so Elizabeth thinks.Almost immediately after Secret Agent Nicky's arrival, strange doings begin to occur, what with spies showing up in the area, and Elizabeth is the curious type.  I'll tell you right now that while Elizabeth had plenty of sense, she was naive and she had some off-the-charts TSTL episodes.  Like I said, think "whimsy."This was written by the author who gave us The Windflower.  This story, too, is charming, with wonderful dialogue.  I liked it a lot.Don't expect any torrid gasping and heaving here.  There isn't any.  This tale was written many years ago, so we're left with our imaginations, prompted by lovely writing ~ loved the wordplay ~ and entertaining dialogue.  I had fun reading this.

After your Fitbit falls off onto the sidewalk for no earthly reason, you may consider buying these.  They work.They strike me as extra-thick, extra-wide rubber bands but they're a whole lot cuter.  And very easy to handle.

Honestly, I could just say,  "What Susan Smith says."  Her review is outstanding and spot on.  I have only a few comments to add.First ~ For those of you who shy away from angst-laden novels.....and I'm one of you.....I don't think this is a big issue here.  Ms. Farrell leavens the serious and the dire with ample doses of sweetness, humor and just plain interesting.  I was mesmerized and couldn't put the book down.Ms. Farrell's research was so meticulous that she even managed to work into the sub-plot a little known law affecting gambling debts.The writing was utterly seamless, the story was developed carefully, and the growth and change of the characters were portrayed elegantly.  Remarkably, the story was presented within faultless historical context as were the thoughts, attitudes and expressions of the characters.Finally, the love story was believable and ultimately endearing and satisfying.  The sub-plot also gave us another engaging romance that was fun and sweet to read.Brilianty written!Enjoy your reading! :)

There was an extremely unusual twist here to a familiar theme that made this story do a complete 180 for me...in a good way.  It may have been done before but I'd never seen it and it was a lulu.  It definitely enhanced what could have otherwise been a plain vanilla story.Kate and David were good people who had to deal with David's grasping, conniving step-mother and his worthless half-brother.  This, on top of the nightmares and the unremitting pain David suffered from a serious war wound.  But there were pleasant secondary characters too.  And though this was a quieter, a little more somber story than the Barbour norm, it was interesting.Both Kate and David felt great insecurity with each other's feelings and this led to many misunderstandings which were frequently unresolved due to temper flare-ups.  Endless misunderstandings are a bone of contention with me...I want people to stop mousing around and just spit it out.  The vulnerable state of their emotions, though, made their confusion somewhat more palatable.  Still, they eventually got on my nerves.Otherwise, this was a sweet, interesting story.  It moved at a good clip but carefully enough to develop the plot and the characters.  The plot twist I mentioned earlier, with the changing dynamics between characters, absolutely SAVED this story for me and made it a pretty nice afternoon read.If you don't have my problem with ongoing misunderstandings in a story, I think you may like this a lot.  (I know I can be way too picky:)Enjoy your reading! :)

For sheer entertainment value I'm giving this 5 stars.  I got 5 stars worth of pleasure from it plus the WORLD'S GREATEST PROLOGUE!  No wonder Ms. Michaels laughed as she wrote this.  I wish she'd write more farce...she's really good at it.  And please remember everyone, this IS a farce, meant to be improbable...not the standard soulful, serious HR fare.  This is for fun and it's written so well.I loved Bram and Sophie, both having suffered from their parents' indiscretions.  I loved the secondary characters, those close to the H and h.  The other characters (uncles -ha!) were a hoot.  Loved seeing them squirm.  Then, of course, there was the klepto monkey (to go with the klepto aunt:) and the indiscreet parrot.I particularly liked that, in the end, things even worked out for Cecil and Constance, Bram's and Sophie's parents.  That was wrapped up very nicely and made me feel happy.A reviewer likened this to Heyer's THE GRAND SOPHY and I, too, can see that, sorta.  And I was reminded of Metzger's farces.  BUT.  A big BUT here.....Ms. Michaels wrote this with her own gifted style and this story is unique...and fun.  The sweet love story should satisfy the most hardened critics.  It made me sigh and smile...and I'm a pretty jaded reader.  And what fun it was to see Sophie's joie de vivre on every page!Oh. I said nothing about the plot.  There are plenty of rehashes out there so I'm pretty sure you don't want to yawn your way through my poor effort to retell the story.Enjoy your reading! :)

"I have always thought the questions we ask ourselves more valuable than the answers."This is a superb sequel to the magnificent RED RED ROSE.  Though, in my opinion, not quite the equal of the first novel, it is nonetheless exceptionally good.  This isn't frothy; it invites the reader to think.  That's not to say it's a heavy tome ~ far from it!  There's humor in all the right places.Ms. Farrell's ineffable writing skill allows us to know the characters so well...to be them...that we find ourselves there, sharing their journey.  Jack, having served behind the lines in Spain during the Peninsular War, now finds himself back home in England with a title, loaded with the debts that came with it and in need of an heiress.  Anne, a pragmatic soul and heiress of a mill owner, is in the market for a title and she has a list!  Unfortunately for Jack, he's the darkhorse and all because of his innate charm.  He's not a rake, he's just naturally charming ~ a lovely man ~ but Anne takes a dim view of his charms.  Poor guy.  But our Jack is indefatigable.Amid the fun of the wooing going on, we see Anne become increasingly knowledgeable of, and involved with, the human element of one of her inherited mills.  She is naturally kind and compassionate and it's interesting to watch the gradual development of her awareness and her conscience regarding her employees.  She is beginning at square one, after all.  She has been sheltered her entire life and the mills have been nothing more than debits and credits to her.  I like Anne.There is much more to this nifty novel than all I'm droning on about.  A lovely, fun romance.  An unexpected and sweet romance between two secondary characters.  The frequent appearances of Val and Elspeth Aston...integral to the story, actually...as well as their happy, comfortable relationship with Val's father.  That made my heart sing.Such a pleasing, satisfying, interesting story!Enjoy your reading! :)

A friend told me this is a splendid novel and I'd really enjoy it.  No kidding!  This was one of the best I've read in ages.The setting is mostly Portugal during the Peninsular War.  I like military history and am fascinated by this particular period, so I was raring to go.  What immediately struck me, though, is that the author didn't just paint this with broad strokes ~ she put us "on the ground" so to speak.  Such research!  She even makes us see what a close-run thing, politically, this campaign was for Wellington, a circumstance often ignored by authors.Val Aston, our hero, was drawn with such depth and insight, I'm still amazed.  The same was true of Elspeth, our heroine, even though there was less space devoted to her.  Remarkable.  This was true, as well, of the secondary characters...even Val's dead mother.  I loved the good ones and hated the villain.  There was a great deal of dialogue which I liked very much.  The author didn't take the easy path and just tell us.The love story evolved quietly and beautifully.  I was touched by Elspeth's tender understanding of Val during their first love scene.  She instinctively knew Val was at the end of his tether.Ms. Farrell managed to poignantly and sensitively portray Val's emotional struggles with his bastardy.  She also conveyed the horrors of public schools of the era as well as the dire plight of homosexuals of the time.  These portrayals in no way detracted from the story.  Rather, they added to it ~ they were related in a spare, matter-of-fact way.Timing.  I rarely mention this in a review but Ms. Farrell's timing in this story was exceptional.  Had a certain event occurred during very late pages of the story, I may have been in a funk for a week.  As it was written though, I lived, got through it and later came to understand the reasoning for it.Beautifully written, wonderful story.Enjoy your reading! :)

In her zeal to portray the horrors and inequities of the justice system of the period ~ which was well done ~ a salient fact was overlooked that impacted the entire romance.Much, much, much was made of the fact that a marriage between  Lucy, the governess, and Lord Granville would destroy him socially and politically.  What nonsense.  It clearly states in the opening chapters that her late father was a baron.  Though impoverished, he was nonetheless a Peer of the Realm.  So that whole "I'm in service and would ruin your life" won't wash.  Granville was an earl, very wealthy, influential and she was a baron's daughter.  Their marriage would have been gossip, maybe, for about a week and that would have been the end of it.  So the whole theme of the star-crossed lovers falls apart at the outset.  Actually, even had she not been a baron's daughter, it would have worked out.  Peers married commoners, they married mistresses, life went on and they were still invited to ton parties.The subject of parental neglect by the nobility was also a pervading theme.  But I'd like to have met the governess who gave her noble employer a talking-to and wasn't out the door in five minutes.  Well, Lucy did it!  ...I can suspend disbelief just so much.  Had the writing been more adroitly done, this part of the story may have been more successful.Granville had no spine.  On the one hand, we're told what an arrogant nobleman he is.  On the other, he repeatedly craters to his witch of a mother.  He even bowed to the governess's demands about his children.  Lucy's brother, William (now a baron, though that's overlooked) is a worthless plague on humanity but all Lucy and her sister see is the angelic child he was ~ NOT the countless lives he destroyed.  And they're supposedly so *concerned* about injustices done to ordinary folk.Several parts of this were heavy, the writing was ponderous, and the plot.....well, I've already given my opinion of that.  The errors in the epilogue were addressed by the author elsewhere, so they get a pass.

I'm not happy about the company I'm in with my rating, but I'm an actual reader and this is truly a 5-star novel for me.  Wonderful story.  One I will enjoy rereading.  Given my opinion of the story, it would be unfair to award fewer stars.Gently born, Daisy had been through hell from a very young age.  Her father sold her to a brute and she was terrified of the marital act.  Sure can't blame her.  I saw a review criticizing her dogged determination to marry Geoff.  I don't.  He was the only man who had ever been kind to her and in her naivete, she thought he was too old to want intimate relations with her.  She would feel safe.  That was both laughable and pitiful.  Even after having been brutalized for years, Daisy was such an innocent soul.I also saw a remark about Daisy's unruly temper.  Well, I didn't see any evidence of Daisy pitching fits.  She was spirited and had gumption.  Had she not had those qualities, she wouldn't have survived.  And her vulnerability was all too evident throughout the story.And then there's delightful Leland ~ a viscount with a mother from hell.  His childhood hadn't been a walk in the park, either.  He covered his insecurities with charm and wit.  And, boy! was he a master of both...and a genuinely nice man.Without rambling on and poorly retelling a lovely, lovely story, I will say the seduction scene was the most sensual and beautiful I have ever read.  I once read another I thought was glorious.  This tops even that.This is a beautifully written story with grand, well-developed characters and an absorbing plot.  Yes, there was a villain and I saw a remark about how that's been done to death.  Well, yes, and haven't most plot devices?  I thought it was necessary here.I'm shocked that there aren't scads of reviews of this deserving novel.  I hope you won't be put off by the lukewarm reviews you read here.  This is a grand story and I loved it.Enjoy your reading! :)

I recently read Gypsy Lover, the only Layton novel I'd never read and thoroughly enjoyed it.  A fun, sweet story, beautifully written, of course.  Naturally, I had to immediately reread THE RETURN OF THE EARL to refresh my memory of how the saga had begun.I'm very sorry to say this did not reflect the Edith Layton to which I'm accustomed.  The plot waffled, the dialogue seldom had the trademark Layton crispness.  There was just no zip to the story.  There may have been personal matters responsible for the letdown in quality.  I don't know.  It's puzzling.Despite all that, I *am* glad I read it because it does set the stage for the 4-book series and it *is* an okay novel.Enjoy your reading! :)

For some strange reason, I kept steering clear of this novel.  I think the title just conjured up ridiculousness to me.  What a mistake!  This proved to be an interesting and an entertaining story.Meg is on a two-week hiatus from her job as companion to a young twit who has just run off.  While supposedly staying with her old governess, Meg is actually trying to track down the girl so Meg can at least salvage a reference from her employer.  Along the way, she encounters Daffyd who has been commissioned to the same purpose by his aristocratic mother who is the nitwit's godmother.Much of the story encompasses their journey, their growing friendship, admiration and respect for each other.  We spend a night at a gypsy encampment with Daffyd's grandmother and half-brother.  Later, we pause at the grand estate of Daffyd's other half-brother, an aristocrat through and through.  Eventually, we arrive at the London home of Geoffrey, the Earl of Egremont.  Such a good, kind man and Daffyd's "father of his heart".I am so appreciative of Edith Layton's attention to historical detail and the astonishing degree of accuracy she accomplished.  Just consider ~ she didn't have the benefit of the internet.....her research was done with books and documents.  Makes me appreciate her work that much more.Anyway, I'm glad I read this.  Really an entertaining, non-angsty story with likable characters.This is Book 3 of the series.  The others, in order, are The Return of the Earl (Avon Historical Romance), Alas, My Love, and How to Seduce a Bride.Enjoy your reading! :)

This is my favorite novel by Edith Layton.  It is a beautiful love story, carefully developed throughout the story.  FYI this story is the exact opposite of THE DUKE'S WAGER and THE DISDAINFUL MARQUIS.  Not remotely similar.  Here we have an honorable hero...a good man.After a horrible first marriage, Morgan didn't care for a repeat.  But he did need to select an heir from among three distant cousins.  The three were invited to Lyonshall to become acquainted and to eventually be interviewed by him and a selection made.Among the three was Anthony, a radical young twerp, accompanied by his older cousin, Elizabeth.  Gently bred, the two lived in poverty~Elizabeth worked in a millinery shop.  Their family scraped together the means to outfit Elizabeth and Anthony as aristocrats, a pretense that bothered honorable Elizabeth.The other two candidates were dour Richard and a chubby youngster, Owen, brought by his mother, Isabel.  Though on the fringe of society, Isabel was a schemer and all but a lightskirt.  The other two people who made up this houseparty was Lord Beverly, Morgan's lifelong best friend (I loved Bev) and a late, unexpected arrival, Lord Kingston, who had become Morgan's friend when they were both hospitalized during the Napoleonic Wars.Heavens, this review is just dry as dust and I LOVED the story!  Maybe I should have just left it at a "beautiful love story."  It was; it was romantic; there was scheming (don't forget Isabel;) there was excitement; there was villainy; there was pathos.  There was a sublime conversation between Morgan and Elizabeth together with some beautifully-written, heartrending passages.This is, by far, my favorite Layton novel, very emotional and romantic.  I apologize for such a dud of a review.Enjoy your reading! :)

I thought I'd found a 'different' kind of Regency, and the settings and characters are out of the ordinary.  But I was ultimately disappointed.The h behaved like a dimwit.  Can't blame the H when he had his way with our round-heeled Sophie, then only offered to provide for any consequences.  After all, he hadn't professed love ~ that was all TSTL Sophie.There were several plot twists ~ enough that I sometimes lost track of the plot.  I think "disjointed" is the word.  It was as if the author stopped writing and returned to it with a passage irrelevant to the previous one.Funny.  When I first read this long ago, it seemed pretty fair.  Times change.  For readers who enjoy lots of sex and some make-believe, this could be just the ticket.

I read this long ago and subsequently reread it.  It was anything but formulaic...it was actually rather odd.  It was deftly written, the plot was interesting, the characters written with depth.But I couldn't really connect with the characters.  I can't say I didn't like the novel...it was interesting.  I just couldn't become enveloped in it.  I think I reread it in order to try to feel it and never did.In my limited experience, this is the strangest HR I've encountered.  Many reviewers were enchanted by the story and the characters and I don't want to rain on anybody's parade.  The story was interesting but I couldn't manage to feel the emotion other readers felt.  I was watching but not feeling.  Just never felt comfortable.

Ms. Lynne can sure tell a story and the mystery kept me guessing all the way to the big denouement.  The characters were developed well and the progression of the romance was nicely written.  A little too much harping on his being a beast but that was okay.Unfortunately, my enjoyment was tempered by historical errors that were distracting.  In my opinion, an author who writes a period novel should know the people of that time and place.  Dukes are not my lorded; gentlemen always wore waistcoats, most definitely to formal affairs; the misquote of Shakespeare was coined several years after the time of the story; and then came the last straw ~ "slacks".  Just a few minutes' research could have made all the difference.Today's authors have the internet so I feel cheated when they can't be bothered to even google.  Contrast that with authors who wrote years ago, had to research the hard way and they got it right.(I received this through Kindle Unlimited.)

These are a man's memories, not a novel or a scholarly tome.  So how can I presume to "review" such a work except to tell you what the book gave me?  I've read a diary of one who was crushed in the Warsaw ghetto but this account is the first I've read by someone who survived it and also lived on the "Aryan" side.One reviewer described this as chilling and I must disagree.  I found it tragic and haunting.  Brutes can be found everywhere.  What was chilling to me were the managerial minds that calmly, pragmatically, dispassionately planned the murders of millions upon millions of fellow human beings.  Jews, of course, were their first focus, along with gypsies and homosexuals.  But don't forget, had the Nazis defeated the Soviet Union, millions of Slavs would have also been in the crosshairs for extermination.  So it's those average-looking men who planned this in meticulous detail who are chilling to me.  Particularly horrifying is that their actions couldn't even be explained by madness.  No, most led perfectly ordinary lives "outside the office."This is certainly a testament to Dr. Reicher's courage, determination and sound common sense.  And even though the Reichers lived this for six terrifying years, it's impossible for me to relate.  I don't think I'd have the fortitude to live in constant terror for all those years with nerves drawn taut every second, suffering constant abuse.  But the Reichers did it.These memoirs are also unique in that Dr. Reicher first experienced the Lodz ghetto.  He was also acutely aware of the pogroms *after* the war perpetrated against the pitifully few survivors who had already lived through hell.Dr. Reicher made a thought-provoking point..that there were three groups of people ~ a small group of the vicious, a large group of 'neutrals' who didn't want to become involved, and a small group who helped.  And they were from every strata of society.  This made me pose the question to myself ~ in which group would I fall?  I know I wouldn't be among the vicious but would I have had the moral and physical courage to be a helper?  These memoirs make you think.  Not an easy read but worthwhile.  If he could live it, I can read about it.

Metzger threw us a curve in this one.  A good one.Of course, "Stony" didn't want to marry.  He couldn't afford to and he refused to marry a girl for her dowry. Good for him!  Ever a perfect gentleman, he fell into a perfect way to support himself and his stepmama ~ older gentlemen found that Stony was the perfect escort for their wives and daughters to the events dear to their hearts and boring to the papas.  Stony received "gifts" in return.  He was really a lovely man and everyone was happy.Immensely wealthy, Elliane didn't want to marry ~ she'd been put off the notion by an endless stream of fortune hunters.  But her sister was missing,  Ellianne was in London to find her and found she'd need entree to the ton, hence a note to Stony.This proceeded in the typically fun Metzger style.  The usual off-the-wall characters were present, with many smiles and LOL moments.  Metzger steered off course from the strictly comedic style we're used to by throwing in a serial killer...and she did it darned well too!  No, it wasn't hard to figure out the villain, it was his denouement that was interesting and had my delicate nerves twitching:)All in all, this was another Metzger pleasure.Enjoy your reading! :)

The premise of this story was good but there a lot of words that didn't accomplish much...didn't move the story along or help the characters.Julian was a marvelous letter writer and he and Viola had often corresponded.  How nice if there had been snippets of his "beautiful letters" throughout the story to lend some insight into Julian, the man.  Instead, he was generally a wooden character...not always, but generally.  We knew his three wives had died but we didn't know how until the middle of the story.  When we learned the causes, it seemed nonsensical that he should be  living under a mantle of guilt and be the subject of superstitious and malevolent gossip.  He was frequently grumpy.We didn't know a whole lot about Viola, either.  She had three brothers, she worked on her father's farm until he grew rich.  She had been engaged and then she wasn't.  It wasn't until later in the story that we learned why.  She was vivacious.That's about it for the characters.  The story crept along during the first half though the pace did pick up midway.  The story would have been much shorter with tighter prose.  The pace would have benefited, as well.  There were some laughable anachronisms, two or three yanked me out of the story ~ "har-di-har", ?  "He took off his belt..."  Men of that class wore braces under their waistcoats...not belts.  He would have torn off a strip of her petticoat in that circumstance.  I know I'm yammering and moaning about this but it bothers me when an author isn't very well acquainted with the period and place about which she's writing.***SPOILER***I loved the epilogue!  We finally got to read one of Julian's letters.Despite my moans, groans and gripes, it was an okay story...nice time passer.(I obtained this through Kindle Unlimited.)Enjoy your reading! :)

Same old thing.  The whole time I was reading this I kept thinking I'd read it before.  I had ~ in about a dozen other stories.  Secret childhood friends, boy and girl fall in love, can't marry because boy's father is a coal merchant and girl's father is an earl.There was no real romance.  The flashbacks finally got on my nerves.  The "love" scene was gross.  There was a spin near the end that made the plot *slightly* different.  Yawn.I can generally count on Balogh but I swear she churned this out over her morning coffee (one cup.)It was short:)

Alone, Jane is penniless and shunned by society due to deplorable actions by her late father.  Soon to be homeless, she has no desirable choices left.  Now, Benjamin, a viscount, fashionable member of the ton and secret agent of the Crown, has offered a solution to Jane's thorny problems.  She will "die", reemerge as her French cousin, Lillilanne, and help the Crown's secret committee unmask the traitor who has stolen two vital dossiers.As crazy as this all sounds, it actually made sense and I thoroughly enjoyed 89% of the story ~ sufficiently glued that I stayed up until 3AM reading.  The story is very well written.  The plot, and sub-plots, had me gasping and turning pages.  Handsome Benjamin was a tortured hero.  There was humor.  I enjoyed the chapter headings that were snippets of Fordyce's Sermons to Young Women.  "Lillianne" played her role to perfection.  There was mystery.  There was a sweet, slowly-developing love story.  I absolutely loved the story to the 89% point.If you can put your disbelief completely out to pasture, you should enjoy the last 11%.  I won't ruin what may be a wonderful reading experience for you by adding a spoiler here.  I'll add that in a comment below.For your full reading pleasure of this novel, I strongly recommend that you first read the preceding story, Once Upon a Wager (Crimson Romance).Enjoy your reading! :)

This was a happy surprise for me.  After reviewing my first Stuart novel which was a bad experience,  a reader suggested that I may enjoy the House of Rohan series.  Well, a long while later I sucked it up and read this one, SHAMELESS, and it was a darn good novel!  Naturally, I began with Book 4, not Book 1.  Maybe I lost something, I dunno, it seemed like a good standalone to me.  At any rate, I didn't see any alarming gaps that left me in left field.Interesting, reading reviews of some who had read earlier books in this series and were disappointed in this one as a result.  Maybe I began with the right one, after all, because I liked this novel.Widowed twice, Benedick wasn't a rake (but he was a hunky alpha:)  he was in London for a little sex (he'd been without for several months,) and to find a biddable, uninteresting wife who could produce an heir and then fade into the wallpaper.  Benedick was in for the surprise of his life when a lovely virago named Melisande sailed in to retrieve the demirep he had summoned.  Melisande was a wealthy widow who was on a mission to save soiled doves.This story moved at a sprightly pace, there was wit and I really liked the H and h.  The plot revolved around a take on the old Hellfire Club and it was interesting.  Of course, near the end it devolved into some unbelievable Mrs. Radcliffe-ish scenes but I went with the excitement.I was interested in the sketch of Brandon and Emma.  Hope to read their story.Enjoy your reading! :)
Nice folding Dryer for compactness.

These are very bright for a "AA" battery flashlight. They are compact, they zoom and the switch is push button. I have about 10 of these and have given another 8 away. For the price $3.50 to $4.00, you can't beat them. Only one problem..... Chinese quality. I have been refunded for 5 or 6 other bad ones. Either did not work or bad lenses. If you get a good one, you are good to go and you will be impressed.
Handy extra and does the trick.
I've been taking for a while. Good stuff.
Nice compact cleaning kit. i purchased to be able to carry with me, in my Camelbak.
Large clamps, but a good size to have when you are into hobbies. These are hard to lock in, when trying to hold something, The require a lot of pressure to lock.
These are vey handy for tight places. I like the tapered better than the full cotton ends.
This is good paracord for the price. I have had better, but paid twice the price. This is strong 7-Strand and should be fine for anything you want, except jumping out of planes.
These are better than you average magnesium fire starters.
Handy picks for guns and knives.
This stuff works well and now I have the big bottle for some serious camping.
These are nice for the price. I purchase these to give away. I like NKJV the best.
Nice handy bit set to have. Not the highest quality of steel, so if you are really going to torque on something, you may want higher quality.
These are nice shorts and at a good price. I purchased a blue pair also.

This worked well to treat my Candida, but after a year I became resistant to it and it was no longer effective. I rotate meds for the Candida treatment. Colloidal Silver is the best, but is expensive.
Great old movie. I always loved his brand of humor. If you are up for a silly old Dangerfield movie, this is the one.

I have used about four bottles of this product and I still have reservations about it's quality. One bottle started to turn to a lighter color part way through and one bottle turned almost clear, by the time there was 1/3 left. My research on Colloidal Silver tells me that color change is improperly suspended silver and when it does that, the product becomes less effective or not effective at all. The key is the small silver particles being suspended in the liquid, for proper absorption in your body, when taken.The same thing will happen to Colloidal Silver if it freezes. It will turn clear and will appear a little cloudy at the bottom. When that happens.... the bottle is Ruined! This MediSIVER  may be less costly, but it has never happened to the 10 or so bottles of MesoSilver  20 ppm Colloidal Silver, 500 mL, which I have taken. I have chronic Candida and Colloidal Silver seems to be the best treatment for it. I have become resistant to many of the other products and treatments for Candida.There are other good quality Colloidal Silver products out there, just be careful and do not buy it if the bottle is tinted as it is most likely and impostor (Silver Ions). Also, do not attempt to make it at home with an Ion Generator. That is also Silver Ions, and is not nearly as effective.UPDATE 10/01/15: I LEARNED SOMETHING NEW TODAY.... One should avoid taking the silver with a metal spoon, since metal causes the silver ions to lose their positive charge, rendering them worthless for holistic purposes. I have also raised my rating to four stars, as I have been having better results with the product quality, after 15+ bottles.
Frog Lube is the best, for knives and guns. This is a good combo, with the cleaner and the Frog Lube in a convenient tube dispenser. I use this on my guns and knives.
Nice pouch for extras. Attaches to your molle panel. Unzip and the front drops into a small shelf, suspended by poly-cord. Velcro on the front, for extra attachments.
Interesting movie. Purchased for my daughter and we watched it together. She loves this movie.

I have used this in the past. The color change is a great idea. I purchased this to have a brush, to apply my industrial strength super glue. Bob Smith industries is 2 oz for only $12 and is much stronger. I will empty the container and place the BOB SMith super glue in it. It gives me more control.

I purchased two of these, to use as knife danglers. Will fit a regular belt or a wide strategic belt. Most knife danglers are designed to slide onto your belt from the end as is this one. I have an extra small paracord loop on the sheaths of all of my knives, for easy belt mount and trade out. I also have a standard leather snap loop, belt key holder. The draw back is, a lot of chrome dangling from it.This is flat black in color and is very well built, thick metal.

These are bulky folded up, but are easy to deploy. There is no real good way to make plastic handcuffs compact for carry. These are most likely the best way. They are reusable and they won't cut into the wrist. Size 7.5"L x 1.5"W folded as seen in photo.
Great little cutter. Lightweight and strong. Easy to stick in your pocket or in your pack.  Size 4 1/4L x 1 9/16 W.

The size is smaller in diameter than you would think. I don't see how you could make a good looking paracord fob out of this size. However, it does have it's uses. This will fit through a smaller knife hole or attach something larger. This could also be used as super-heavy, super strong string, in some applications.
This is a great size. The plastic holder makes the sharpener a good length to hold on to, while sharpening. It folds back into the plastic for when not in use.

These are great and they are affordable. You get 10 in a pack and they each cover 1 square foot. They also last 2 years. I purchased for my knives I keep in a couple of large ammo boxes and other metal items which I store.
Nice heavy duty rings, for what ever your need is. Nickel plated is a great durable finish. I do recommend these.

I have used commercial grade superglue in the past and was impressed at it's strength and value. This is no exception to that opinion. This is a much better value for two ounces -vs- what you pay for .54oz, and the quality of this is much better.

These work for most anything you want to bind, hold together, attach something....etc. I purchased these for some of my knives, to use where a leather snap ring should be. It keeps the knife from flopping around, when carrying it.

I enjoyed reading the continuation of Ceony's story. I'm enjoying the magic in this series, and it was fun learning more about the different types of magic in this world. The plot moved along well without the draggy tendencies of the first book in the series, and we dug a little deeper into the characters.The biggest negative for me were a couple places where Ceony makes some very irrational decisions. It's a standard in this type of book that the hero has to face down her enemy alone. This is convincing when there's no help around. It's not convincing when there's a whole room of master magicians just behind a closed door and the hero randomly decides now would be a good time to go tackle the evil magician solo. I like Ceony's character generally, but that moment didn't work for me.Overall, I'd recommend this if you enjoy light fantasy. Do start with the first book in the series, though--this one requires you to read it in order.

I've had my Fitbit about 4 weeks now and am loving it.The Fitbit Zip is a step up from a basic pedometer. I couldn't justify one of the pricier options, but I liked that the Fitbit zip automatically updates and could be synced with my Weight Watchers account. It's helping me accurately track my activity level and motivating me to be more active.I've found the Zip to be pretty accurate in counting steps--somewhat dishearteningly, since I learned pretty quickly that I had been grossly underestimating my activity level. It's accurate on my exerglider and just walking around the house. A 45 minute Zumba workout measures at about 4000 steps, which seems about right to me.I had a little trouble initially getting the Zip to sync with my WeightWatchers account, but after the software downloaded an update it works fine. You do have to have a certain baseline of activity to earn activity points, so it takes a while for points to show up. If I Zumba first thing the morning my activity points don't track right away, but by the end of the day I'll have 3 points added to my account. It appears to me I have to have in the neighborhood of 5000 steps before activity points start showing up.This is a nice tool and it's motivating me to stay active. I'd recommend it to anyone looking for a basic activity tracker.

Juliet Marillier's books are an auto-buy for me, and her latest title didn't disappoint. I could hardly put down Dreamer's Pool and I'm looking forward to seeing what she does with this series.Dreamer's Pool introduces us to Blackthorn, a prisoner bent on revenge. She's spared from the executioner by a visitor with a surprising offer: serve him for seven years and live. But there are conditions--including leaving her dreams of vengeance behind.Dreamer's Pool follows Blackthorn, Grim--Blackthorn's protector and friend, and Prince Oram. The story has some romance, but focuses mostly on Blackthorn and Grim's journey and the mystery that they must work with the prince to unravel. Nothing is ever simple when the fae meddle with the lives of humankind.I really enjoyed this book. The viewpoint characters all have distinct, interesting voices. The setting is interesting, and the plot is well-paced. If you've read any of Mette Ives Harrison's books you may see the twist coming, but Marillier puts her own spin on it.Readers who are familiar with Marillier's more recent books such as Wildwood Dancing and the Caller series should note that this is not a YA title. With Blackthorn and Grim Marillier returns to adult fantasy. Dreamer's Pool has a darker tone more reminiscent of the original Sevenwaters Trilogy. But it's a thoroughly enjoyable book I'd recommend to any adult fantasy lover. I'm looking forward to more adventures in Marillier's new world.

I loved the first book in this series and had really looked forward to this one. Unfortunately, I didn't enjoy this book as much as I had hoped.In Destined for Doon Kenna is called back to Doon to help her best friend overcome a new threat to the kingdom: a black plague that only Kenna can see. But returning to help Vee also means Kenna has to face Duncan--the prince with whom she shares a calling and chose to leave behind.All that is an interesting set up, but the book failed to deliver for me. The threat of the black fungus/plague never seemed that threatening to me--partly because of Kenna and Vee's attitudes. "A black fungus is surrounding the kingdom and may turn us all into zombies? Let's paint our nails and have a party!" I get the whole "celebrating life" idea, but the two main characters came of as immature and superficial. The danger took back seat to the boy drama in this book, and the spiritual themes of forgiveness seemed shoehorned in.Then there was all the kissing. There's a lot of heavy kissing in this book--some between an engaged couple; some between Duncan and Kenna. One scene involves passionate kissing between two characters, one of whom is drunk. Kenna is not shy about checking out Duncan's body (even salivating over his belly button? really?) and the guys comment on the girls' tight pants, etc. Most YA novels these days do include some romance and sexuality, but the detail in the descriptions is more than I would be comfortable with a younger teen reading. Readers should also note that while this book is put out by a Zondervan imprint (Zondervan is one of the largest Christian publishers) and is carried at least in the online catalogs for several Christian bookstores, the romance scenes in this series go beyond what I would expect to see in a Christian YA novel--or most Christian fiction, for that matter.Destined for Doon is okay, but I was disappointed in this second book of the series. Readers should also note that the book ends on a pretty serious cliffhanger. If cliffhangers bother you, you might want to wait until the third book comes out next year before reading this one. It's okay, but I had expected more.

I've really enjoyed this series, and I enjoyed reading this final book. And yet, I still was a little disappointed by the Blood of Olympus.In some ways it's classic Riordan. Heroes, gods, limited time quest, the world in danger. Check. Heroes of Olympus follows both the 7 demigods quest to stop the giants and Reyna's quest to return the Athena statue to Camp Half-Blood.
