There's plenty of adventure, humor, and a few dashes of romance along the way. It's a fun read in many ways.So, why was I disappointed?  I missed Percy, for one thing. Point of view characters in this book are Jason, Piper, Reyna, Nico, and Leo. I understand to some degree why Riordan made the narrative choices that he did, but in this final book it would have been nice to hear from Percy and Annabeth one more time.I also felt that the book shied away from showing the real cost of war. In the Last Olympian there were some losses and deaths that we felt greatly because we had come to care about the characters. We don't see that as much in Blood of Olympus. Yeah, some characters die--mostly people we don't like. And the loss of one of the seven at the end is so heavily telegraphed that we know several chapters ahead who is going to die, why they are going to die, and what the likely escape clause will be. Sacrifice loses its power when you know there's a way out. Those moments in the Last Olympian where we linger and feel the pain, the moments when characters have to make real, hard choices--that's missing.Another thing I felt Riordan let drop in this book was the issue of Percy's fatal flaw. It's been mentioned consistently throughout the series, but it never came down to that pivotal moment in this book where Percy had to choose the greater good over a friend. I think that's something we may have lost out on by not having a chapter in Percy's viewpoint.So it's a fun book.  We get an entertaining adventure and the expected (very couple-y) happy ending. There's a blink-and-you'll-miss-it mention of Riordan's next series. (Look at the title of his next book if you did miss it). If you've read this far with Percy, absolutely finish it up.  It's a good book. But it's not the book it could have been.

Vogue needs to hire some new developers.I liked the theory of this app.  Download the free app, then purchase the issues you want--including a good list of back issues.  The Winter 2010 issue of Vogue Knitting is included as a free sample with the app.The pictures look nice and I enjoyed browsing but the app is lacking functionality. As others have noted, there's no page slider.  There's also no way to bookmark pages or make notes. This is particularly annoying because the app sets the magazine back to the cover everytime you reopen the application, forcing you to flip back through every page of the magazine to find your place.  This is annoying enough when you're just browsing the magazine, but I  can't imagine trying to actually knit from one of the patterns--which are always at the back--and having to flip through the publication every time I wanted to get to the pattern.  There are a few hyperlinks that will take you to a 360 view of featured patterns, but there's no way to print a pattern. Basically all this app is good for is browsing the magazine in one sitting. I won't be purchasing any additional issues digitally until they improve the functionality. I'd expect better from a publisher like Vogue--certainly some of their competition has more to offer.

This one has been in my to-read pile for a while and I finally got to it. Honestly, I hadn't picked it up sooner because I felt like I've already read some other similar books (like Brandilyn Collins Double Blind or A Heartbeat Away by Harry Kraus). But when I finally got to Seagrass Pier I was pleased to find that Coble has put a fresh spin on a somewhat familiar plot.This is an enjoyable, suspenseful read with multiple plot threads that keep you turning pages. The romance is nice, and I liked Elin's character. Not one that's going on my favorite's list, but it was a enjoyable book.I think where Seagrass Pier lost points for me was largely in the beginning.  The plot plunges you right in with not much of an introduction to Elin or her situation. Coble does a good job of introducing Elin's backstory, but it wasn't enough for my suspicion of disbelief to kick in regarding the whole concept of transplants and cellular memory. Discovering Elin's new memories along with her instead of having it presented as a fait accompli would have helped in that regard. I also was a little thrown by the diary entries being written in third person. Who writes in their diary in third person? That may be a bit nit-picky, but it was enough to pull me out of the book.If you've enjoyed Coble's other books you'll probably enjoy Seagrass Pier. Recommended to readers who enjoy Christian suspense.

In this conclusion to the Shadowfell series Neryn's quest for the freedom of Alban takes her to the perilous heart of the king's court. As the Midsummer battle approaches, Neryn still must find two more guardians to complete her training--and grapple with the presence of another Caller.Juliet Marillier is one of my favorite authors, and I've enjoyed reading this series. Neryn has costly choices to make, but I didn't find the series as dark as some of her others (like the original Sevenwaters trilogy, for example). Neryn and her allies are concerned with doing the right thing the right way. Neryn's grappling with her conscience and commitment to acting with honor adds depth to the books. I also appreciated that the villains aren't entirely drawn with one note--there are shades of complexity here.The Shadowfell books are suitable for YA readers, though I think Marillier's adult fans will still enjoy the series. I've enjoyed reading this series and will probably be returning to Neyrn's journey again. I'd recommend them to readers who enjoy historical fantasy.

Overall I enjoyed reading The Paper Magician. I liked the world building and the concept of using paper as a base for magic. I hadn't seen a fantasy novel done in quite this way before, and I enjoyed exploring paper magic along with Ceony. I also liked the book's tone and enjoyed Ceony as a character.I did think the pacing was a bit off.  The beginning of the book proceeded nicely, but I was caught off guard when the villain made her appearance. Often in this type of book we get a couple beats where the villain threatens the hero, but is thwarted. These scenes usually establish that the villain really is a bad guy and that the hero still has a lot to learn, etc. When the villain showed up I expected that type of beat in the novel, but we got thrust into the final showdown. To me that made that section feel rushed and the following section seemed to drag.Despite the pacing, there's still plenty to enjoy about this book. If you enjoy fantasy it's worth a try.

It's hard to go wrong with shrinky dinks. There's something about watching the plastic shrink up in the oven that kids love. Most of the kits I've seen lately are more girl themed, though.  Jewelry making, lots of flowers, butterflies, etc. I wanted to find a kit that my son and nephew would enjoy and was excited to find this one. The kit includes your standard shrinky dinks, but also includes brads and pipe cleaners you can use to build 3D monsters with moveable arms or eyeballs hanging off their heads. Taking things in and out of the oven does require some adult supervision, but this is a great activity for a rainy afternoon or when you just need a little quiet.

Positives first:  this is a very nice easel.  I like that there is a paper cutter included (sealed so no little fingers can get to it).  It makes tearing the paper off of the paper roll very easy.  I wish the white board was magnetic, but even without that it's a very nice piece that sparks open-ended creative play.The whiteboard and chalkboard seem to be decent quality, though the wood does seem very light.One important note on assembly:  Both the chalkboard and whiteboard have "TOP" clearly labeled on the backside of the board so you know how to rotate the board so that the holes line up.  So far so good, except that on ours the chalkboard was mislabeled.  The side labeled "top" actually had to go on the bottom.  Not a big problem once we figured out we just had to spin the board around, but we almost broke the thing trying to get it to fit before we figured that out.  If you have problems during assembly, check that out since some seem to have been misprinted.

Positives first:  the tutu is cute and seems well made with a ribbon waistband and non-scratchy fabric. The wings look okay. I'm not convinced they're going to hold up, but that's okay. I was really disappointed with the wand, though.  The wand we received had a cardboard handle with the butterfly on top attached only by a couple of thin wires stuck inside the cardboard tube.  My two-year old carried it trick-or-treating and the butterfly fell off as we were crossing the 4 lane highway in front of our house.  For the price I wasn't expecting it to last for years, but I did think it would survive a gust of wind for at least one night.  If you're mostly interested in the tutu and wings you may not care about the wand, but if it's important you may want to plan on something different or reinforce it with tape before using.

I'm still a little in shock that I didn't like this book.Dee Henderson is one of my all-time favorite authors.  Danger in the Shadows, the O'Malley series, The Witness--I've read everything she's written and loved it.  Until now.Unspoken, Henderson's latest, is the story of Bryce Bishop and Charlotte Graham. Bryce is a Chicago coin dealer who is starting to get just a little bored with his successful business.  Charlotte shatters that boredom one evening with an unusual method of enlisting Bryce's help with selling the rare coins from her grandfather's estate.  As Bryce spends time with Charlotte, the secrets of her past begin to come out.  Bryce begins to realize that God may have brought them together and that he may be a bigger part of the solution to Charlotte's dilemma than she had originally planned.This book really did not work for me.  The plot dragged, I never connected with the main characters, and I felt the conclusion didn't make sense.  Here are the three major reasons I didn't like the book:*Bloated exposition.  The first 200 pages are about coins.  Seriously.  I applaud the author for doing her research, but I'm not that into rare coins.  There's too much jargon and too much detail.  I got tired of hearing all the details about every new batch of coins, how much they were worth, and how they were going to sell them.  I can't even say that I learned anything about coins because there was never an explanation of the terms or jargon.*Never heard Charlotte's voice.  One of the things I loved about Henderson's earlier books was getting to know characters like Sara, Kate, and Shari.  There were a few scenes from Charlotte's point of view in this book, but we never got inside her head.  I suppose this was so her secrets could be revealed like the bombshells they're supposed to be, but it left me feeling disengaged from the book.*Lack of suspense.  Henderson is known as a romantic suspense writer.  This book was really lacking in that area to me.  I could understand Charlotte dealing with trauma from her past experiences, but it never seemed that she or Bryce were in any danger that kept me turning pages.  Additionally, the main device for moving the plot forward seemed to be Charlotte telling Bryce something she had kept secret.  That's fine, but sometimes I didn't see why she felt she had to keep silent about some of the details.  There were several times when other characters said "Oh, well, I understand why she never talked about that."  I kept thinking "I don't--would you explain it, please?"I was disappointed with this book.  Here's hoping Henderson returns to form with her next book.I received a free copy of this book from the publisher in exchange for a quality review.  All thoughts and opinions expressed are my own.  I did not guarantee a positive review.

Sabrina Rice thought she understood God's plans for her life.  Then a devastating disease changed everything.  With her Olympic dreams dashed, Sabrina decided she'd never heard God right in the first place.When her life collides with troubled teen Brandy Phillips, Sabrina's coaching ability might be Brandy's last chance.  But helping Brandy means facing Sabrina's own wounds and exploring the possibility that God's plans might be wider than she had dreamed.Kathryn Cushman's books always manage to combine wonderful characters and complex issues.  Chasing Hope may be my favorite of her books that I've read.  Sabrina and Brandy are both rich, complex characters.  Cushman explores the question of calling and God's will from a variety of angles.  The book is entertaining, but it also makes you think.  I'm keeping this one around for a re-read.  I think it would make an excellent book group selection, and a short conversation guide is included.I received a free copy of this book from the publisher in exchange for a quality review.  All thoughts and opinions expressed are my own.  I did not guarantee a positive review.

With more than 90 books under her belt, Tracie Peterson is one of the most prolific authors in the Christian Fiction market.  Some of her novels I've loved; some of them are just okay.  The Miner's Lady, the latest in Peterson's Land of Shining Water series, falls in the "just okay" category.The Miner's Lady is set in the mining town of Ely, Minnesota and revolves around a family of Italian miners,the Calcaros. The Calcaros have been feuding for generations with another local family, the Panettas.When Isabel Calcaro falls in love with Orlando Panetta, Isabel's older sister, Chantel, knows nothing good will come of it.  But as her family tries to end the feud, Chantel also finds herself drawn to Orlando's older brother, Dante Panetta.  Will the families be able to make piece, or will their young love be shattered by tragedy?This book was okay, but there wasn't really anything there that made it stand out from the crowd.  Chantel seems too perfect, and I never got a clear picture of Dante's character in my mind.  The romance between them seems sudden. I also felt that there were too many plotlines going on in the book.  There's Isabel's romance with Orlando and the question of whether they can escape Orlando's father's wrath.  Then there's Chantel's relationship with Dante and the feud between the two families. That seems to have been enough to deal with, but then there's also a subplot dealing with Chantel's brother Marco and his drinking and gambling that doesn't really seem to have anything to do with the rest of the book. There's a thread where the local bar owner shows some interest in Chantal that borders on threatening, but that thread is never developed.  I just never felt a strong sense of tension as the story progressed.  It just kind of moves along until we get to the fairly predictable conclusion. Peterson fans will probably enjoy this story, but it's not one I'm going to hang on to.  Three stars.I received a free copy of this book from the publisher in exchange for a review.  All thoughts and opinions expressed are my own.  I did not guarantee a positive review.

A lot of the Christian fiction market starts to run together after a while.  It's always nice when you come across something that feels fresh.  The Gothic feel and Victorian intrigue make this book stand apart from the crowd.  If you want something a little different to read, Born of Persuasion is worth a look.The characters are always what draw me to a book, and Jessica Dotta does a wonderful job of bringing her characters to life.  Julia is complex and well-rounded, and the large cast of supporting characters is also well drawn.  Combine that with an intriguing plot, the solid  prose, and well-researched historical setting and you have a winner.One of the unique things about this book is that Julia is an avowed atheist--something you don't find often in Christian fiction books, particularly in historical fiction.  The author did a good job of exploring the reasons behind her belief and showing how that backstory complicates her relationships.  Julia's gradual softening toward faith over the course of the novel is also well done. It's not heavy handed or preachy, but you can see how her experiences slowly lead her to revaluate the existence of God.I thoroughly enjoyed this book and I'm looking forward to seeing what Jessica Dotta does with the rest of this series.  Five stars.I received a free copy of this book from the publisher via CFBA.  All thoughts and opinions expressed are my own.  I did not guarantee a positive review.

When we get it right church can be a glorious thing.  But when we get it wrong, church can also be a place of wounding.  Wounds left by the people of God can take a long time to heal.In her new book, Wounded by God's People, Anne Graham Lotz uses the story of Hagar to show us how we can find healing in an encounter with God.  In a book both deeply personal and thoroughly biblical, Lotz interweaves the story of Hagar with her own stories of deep wounding.  Her tone is warm, but also gently confronting as she reminds the reader about the dangers of bitterness and the ultimate need to forgive.I would highly recommend this book to anyone who has experienced church hurt.  Pastor's wives and other church leaders who have been wounded by their congregations may find this book a helpful and encouraging read.  It's definitely one to keep on the shelf.I received  a free copy of this book from the publisher via Booksneeze.  All thoughts and feelings expressed are my own.  I did not guarantee a positive review.

Last year I read and loved Spiritual Warfare for Women: Winning the Battle for Your Home, Family, and Friends by Leighann McCoy.  When I saw her new book, A Woman' Guide to Hearing God's Voice I jumped at the chance to review it.  It's a good book, though  it's not what I was expecting exactly.In this case the subtitle gives you a better picture of what the book is about than the title:  finding direction and peace through the struggles of life.  The book is not really about learning to hear God's voice as much as it is learning to hear from God in difficult times.  McCoy shares lessons she has learned through her struggle with cancer and family stress interwoven with what Scripture has to teach us about suffering.While disappointed that the book wasn't what I expected, I still appreciated several of the lessons McCoy draws out in this book.  I thought her sections on wrestling with God and the idea of letting God define good were well done.  She also draws comfort from understanding God's sovereignty; if God has allowed this season then God is also at work finding you a way through it.Each chapter has a short "treasure hunt" section at the end including personal reflection and discussion questions.  The appendix includes resources for helping you learn to tell "your story for God's glory" and finding ways  to share that story.  Four stars.I received a free book from the publisher in exchange for a quality review.  All thoughts and feelings expressed are my own.  I did not guarantee a positive review.

This is an action packed read.  The book starts off following Molly and Zack as they try to escape the Great Chicago Fire.  The dramatic opening definitely caught my attention and helped keep me engaged as the backtracked six days in time to explore the events that led up to the fire.Having the book set around the aftermath of the Great Chicago Fire kept the book fresh for me.  We tend to see a lot of Civil War and Western/Pioneer historicals in the Christian Fiction genre--this was the first book I remember set around this particular event.  I also appreciated that Molly had a unique occupation:  a watchmaker.  That also helped set this book apart.More than that though, I appreciated this book for the solid writing, action packed plot, and well-developed characters.  I liked the twists and turns of Molly and Zack's romance--even if I wanted to shake her a  few times for being so slow to trust.  The minor characters also add depth and interest to the story.  Faith issues are interwoven, but not in an overwhelming or preachy way.  Into the Whirlwind is another solid piece of work from Elizabeth Camden.  I' d highly recommend it to readers who enjoy historical romance.I received a free copy of this book from the publisher via CFBA.  All thoughts and opinions expressed are my own.  I did not guarantee a positive review.

I really enjoyed this book. I'm always up for a good mystery, and this one stood out from the crowd.  The period setting was nice, and I enjoyed the snappy dialogue and playful romance.  I had never heard of Father Knox or his 10 rules of murder before, but it was fun to see how the author cheerfully manages to break all ten in a single book.  This is a mystery,but it's also a book that refuses to take itself too seriously.  I'd recommend it if you're looking for a fun read.I received a free copy of this book from the publisher via CFBA.  All thoughts and opinions expressed are my own.  I did not guarantee a postive review.

There are certain plots that Christian fiction writers return to over and over again.  A Noble Groom uses one of the most popular---a young woman loses her husband, finds herself in a financially precarious position, and the hero rides to the rescue before they fall in love and overcome all obstacles to living happily-ever-after.  Two things set this book apart from the crowd, however:  the solid writing and the strength of the characterization.I really enjoyed Annalissa's character.  Even in what seems like a hopeless situation she remains strong.  I like the way her beloved fairy tales show that she hasn't given up on her dreams.  I also appreciated Carl's character.  His creativity and courage make him an interesting character.  I also liked that while the hard work of the farm is new to him, he's not portrayed as inept. He has to learn, but he's willing to work hard so he can help Annalissa to the best of his ability.  The romance between them is sweet and nicely developed, and the final action scene is a natural progression from the rest of the book--not something that comes out of the blue.I'd recommend this book to readers who enjoy historical fiction.I received a free copy of this book from the publisher for review purposes.  All thoughts and feelings expressed are my own.  I did not guarantee a positive review.

We bought this hoping to extend the life of our old mattress a little while longer while we save up for the mattress we really want.Positives first--this topper does help us get better sleep.  Before we installed the topper I had been tossing and turning quite a bit at night. I'm sleeping better with the topper and often wake up in the same position I went to sleep. I didn't have high expectations for motion isolation since we just put this on top of our old mattress, but it does seem to help.  I'm not waking up every time my husband rolls over anymore.  I've had less trouble with back pain since we began using the topper, and I feel like it's a comfortable level of firmness.  It feels very firm when you first lay down on it, but if you lay there a moment you can feel the material conforming to your body.  It does help give a very comfortable sleep.Negatives--the off-gassing with this was really bad. We kept it out for three full days before putting it on the mattress, but it still had an odor even then.  I can still smell a faint odor when I walk into the room, although it is fading.  More negatively, I feel like this topper sleeps hot.  We bought this one because it promised to help regulate your sleep temperature and keep you comfortable while you sleep, but I'm still waking up too warm. It feels to me like it holds my body heat instead of distributing it.  I'm going to try changing mattress pads and see if that helps, but I'm disappointed that the sleep cool features don't seem to work as promised.

I ordered these to use during my Zumba workouts.  They do make it much easier to glide and pivot on carpet.  I feel like I have less stress on my knees doing lunging and twisting moves.The problem is that they seem small.  I wear a size 8 1/2 sneaker, and I can barely get them on the shoe.  I can get them on well enough that they work, but I can't get them into the position as shown on the package.  They work well for me, but if you have a larger shoe size you might want to look at a similar product in another brand.

The good first:  this is a really well-done, fun book.  Pastor's Wives is the story of three women whose lives collide at a booming Atlanta megachurch.  There's Candace, the wife of the charismatic pastor who uses her power to run the church behind the scenes; Ginger, Candace's daughter-in-law who struggles with insecurity and a secret past; and Ruthie, the wife of Greenleaf's newest staff member who as a lapsed Catholic/agnostic finds herself in the awkward position of being married to a man who wants to be "married to God."  As their lives intertwine, each of them struggles with her own way with the pressures of life in the church fishbowl.  Each of them also has to answer one question:  what is _my_ purpose here.Again, this is a well-written book.  I think most readers who enjoy character driven drama will enjoy this book.  The characters are complex, the plot moves quickly, and there's a good blend of drama, humor, and surprises in the book.  Just in terms of writing style and quality I think this is probably the best written novel about pastor's wives that I've read.  That said, Christian readers who might be drawn to this book because of the subject matter should know that I would class this as a mainstream rather than inspirational novel.  There's no sex--something I know a lot of inspirational fiction readers are concerned about--but there is some discussion about porn and strippers.  Those topics come up in Christian novels as well, but the style with which they're handled here is a little more frank than readers who only read inspirational novels will be accustomed too.  It's not that it's bad or gratuitous--you'd probably "see" more just watching regular T.V., but readers who are really strict about what they read may not like those portions of the book.  Mainly though, I consider it a mainstream book because of how she handles faith issues.As far as the life of a PW, there's a lot in this book that Cullen gets right:  the feelings of isolation, the struggles with church members who don't want anything to change, the frustration at finding that your husband's ministry is more important than you are, the women who like to throw themselves at the pastor.  It's not that any of those things are true of any particular pastor's wife or that all of them have been true of my life, but these things are common.I think the biggest weakness of the book is how Cullen handles faith.  I was curious after I read the book and  looked up her bio and a couple interviews she's done.  What I found was pretty much what I expected.  Though Cullen says she worked through some of her own questions of faith in writing the book, I think the character that she is most like is probably Ruthie, the PW with a Catholic background who isn't entirely sure she still believes in God.  What that means for the book is that her writing of other characters' faith doesn't come off as entirely genuine. There's no sense that any of the characters are really seeking God and relying on God to solve their problems in the way that I and most PW's I know would confronted with the same situations.  Faith in the book is written from the viewpoint of an observer, not someone who understands and has experienced it.Despite that weakness, I found this novel to be an enjoyable read and I'd recommend it to most readers.  Four stars.

I enjoyed The Selection, but I was disappointed with The Elite.I had hoped in this book that we would find out more about America's world.  Yet because she is confined to the palace, that never really happens.  There are a few more hints about the rebels and their goals, but nothing really substantial. America's main concern continues to be the love triangle and her choice between Maxon and Aspen.  By the end of the book I didn't really care who she chose--I just wanted her to make a decision.  Even though she does make a choice at the end, I'm less than convinced she's going to stick with it in the last book in the series.  The book is okay, but there's just not the depth and world-building I'd hoped for in the follow-up.

I never knew the candy business could be so cutthroat.When Lucy Kendall comes home after her tour of the continent, she brings with her samples of Europe's best confections and dreams of making the perfect candy--a candy that will save her father's business and even top the secret recipe stolen by her father's chief competitor.  At home, however, Lucy finds that things are changed.  Her father is sick, her mother wants to sell the company, and the new advertising man for her father's rival is possibly the most attractive and most irritating man Lucy has ever met.  She is determined to save her father's company, but Charlie Clark is giving her strong competition--and someone keeps revealing her company secrets.  It's a take-no-prisoners battle, and only one candy will come out on top.I had mixed feelings about this book.  I liked the setting and the background of a 1910 candy company.  I enjoyed the descriptions of Lucy's fashions, the mention of the first presidential flight, and the humor that really did make me laugh out loud a few times.  I also really enjoyed the character of Charlie Clark.  I didn't enjoy Lucy's character as much, though.  She says at the start of the book that she doesn't want to be childish, but I felt that she acted childishly through most of the book.  She grows up a little toward the end, but it seems like for most of the book she rushes from one scheme to another, not stopping to think about who her actions are hurting.  It's okay, but not the best I've read by this author.  I think it may be a little lighter than most of Siri Mitchell's other books--most of her novels have more depth.Overall, this is just okay. Readers who enjoy period romance may like this for the fresh background, but it's not one that's going on my keeper shelf.I received a free copy of this book from the publisher in exchange for a quality review.  All thoughts and feelings expressed are my own.  I did not guarantee a positive review.

I wasn't sure what to expect when I picked up this book, but I was pleasantly surprised.  A Healing Heart is an enjoyable read with a nice touch of romance.  I really liked Mara's character, and I enjoyed  the different ways in which the author works in the theme of emotional and spiritual healing over the course of the story.  The issue of women's heart health is nicely portrayed, and I thought the family dynamics were written well.  I also enjoyed Joel's character.  It's so common in mainstream books and movies to find the "bad buy who is really a good guy underneath" or the "overgrown teenager who finally grows up by loving the heroine."  It's refreshing to find a male lead who is simply an honest, decent man.  I'm still not sure exactly what a business consultant does, but his job  gave him an interesting dynamic with Mara.  I was glad that this was a book where the relationship had time to develop.  That's increasingly one of the things I appreciate in a novel.  It's a relaxing read and might make a good book club selection.

We first met Robin Price in Wildflowers from Winter as a grieving widow trying to come to turns with her husband's death.  Four years later Wishing on Willows finds Robin building a new life for herself.  She has her family, the cafe she and her husband always dreamed of, and the son her husband never got to meet.  Though her heart still aches, Robin's days are full.  Meanwhile, developer Ian McKay is coming to Peaks on a mission to prove himself and save his father's company while helping revitalize Peaks by building condominiums downtown.  The prime location happens to be the site of Robin's cafe.  While the other owners are willing to sell, Robin can't bear to let go of the place that has brought her hope and healing. Yet, she also finds herself drawn to Ian.  Can she move toward the future without letting go of the past?I think the greatest strength of Katie Ganshert's writing is the way she writes her characters.  Robin seems so completely real and honest.  I think I'd recognize the woman if I met her on the street.  The characters are what really drive this novel.  The plot is somewhat familiar:  big town developer clashes with small-town values, but it's kept fresh because Ian is such sympathetic character who really does want what's in everyone's best interests.  The romance is okay--it's one of those plots where the romantic tension comes from the main characters fighting their attraction for each other throughout the book.  I've just gotten to where I prefer having the hero and heroine actually act as if they like each other a little while they're falling in love, but having them at cross purposes through most of the novel works okay here.  This is a good book and I'd recommend it to readers who enjoy character-driven women's fiction.I received a free copy of this book from the publisher in exchange for a quality review.  All thoughts and feelings expressed are my own.  I did not guarantee a positive review.

I think these will be useful for us but are smaller than I had expected.  I should have read the product description more closely so that's on me--they're just smaller than I was picturing.The cards themselves are about 3 1/2 by 2 3/4 inches.  The letters are 1 1/4 by 2 inches and fairly narrow--the sandpaper is only about 1/4 inch wide.  They are made out of cardstock, but it's a heavy duty cardstock and feels fairly sturdy.  They're heavier than what you'd get on a playing card or a flashcard.  The quality is reasonable for the price.At any rate, I think they are a good tactile tool for learning letters and phonics.  My son likes tracing the letters with his finger.  Today we played memory with the capital and lowercase letters.  I was also able to get a good crayon rubbing with them. Although they are smaller than I had thought they would be I think they will prove to be worth the purchase.  It's a good choice if you don't want to invest in the higher quality but more expensive Montessori style letters.
The quality looks good, but they are way too big for my 2 and 5 year old.  Maybe in a few years the 5 year old will be able to wear them.

This is the second Penny book I've read this month and it is even better than The Long Way Home, which was great. I devoured this, completing it in a day and a half (Yes, it was that suspenseful for me).Louise Penny may be one of the best writers of the psychological "mystery" suspense novel out there with her Inspector Gamache series. Of course, as anyone who has read these books know, it's really a deep portrait of the main character and his co-workers and the beloved and quirky folks who live in the "wish-it-were real" Three Pines.It never ceases to amaze me how on one hand Penny has created a bucolic and isolated setting so apart in many ways (cell phones don't work; there is no Internet available) a true break from the frenzy of contemporary city, that on the one hand houses a seemingly safe and benign community...and then, wham, introduces a plot line that makes us realize that what you see is definitely NOT what you get when it comes to plots as well as characters.Gamache is officially retired from the Surete but that doesn't mean he isn't involved in the latest (and among the darkest ever) plots that Penny has conjured up. I won't give it away but let's just say she manages to put a spin on what is one of the hottest topics in contemporary life when it comes to our safety and security.As always, the backstory behind the main plot is intriguing and gives us even more glimpses into the lives and history of the town's beloved folk. Where The Long Way Home focused on Peter and Clara, this time around almost everyone gets a lot more detail on their past lives and how it shaped them then, and now.I couldn't not rush through the book because I really wanted to know the outcome but I did savor those bits/snippets about the characters personalities that Penny slips in. I don't know about others, but the residents of Three Pines are real to me (Eileen Atkins as Ruth in a TV movie? Who could play gamache?) and I genuinely care about them, which makes these books all the more engaging.I can't wait for the next Penny Gamache book although given the publication of these two within weeks of each other in summer 2015, I know we'll be waiting awhile.Another winner in the series.

Another wonderful entry in the Inspector Montalbano series. If you're a fan, you'll enjoy this one especially as we see a personal side of Montalbano that we may not have expected.This series is formulaic but in a good way. You know what you're getting in terms of the characters and the location. Mysteries are not super suspenseful but the human dimension to whatever Montalbano and crew are working on is always engaging.These books to me are akin to the Donna Leon Inspector Brunetti mysteries, only these would be Brunetti-Lite as it were.A quick and satisfying read, and always nice to see what's going on with one of my favorite Italian detectives.

As someone with ongoing issues with my wrist, I've used Ace and other bandages for over a decade. One of the things I disliked the most was the fabric and color that pretty much scream: Something's wrong with this body part.This black fabric works well because I wear a lot of black and for the most part, my wrapped wrist (to which I do not want to call attention) seems to blend in with my dark and black clothes (Yes, I am a New Yorker. Black IS our "color.") This makes a big difference and I really like the black option (Did Ace make black bandages before? I don't know. Never saw them in my local CVS where I purchased in past.)Same quality in terms of flexibility with tension levels when wrapped loosely or tightly. Same ease of washing. Same overall Ace quality.Why, oh, why, thy needed to change the self-wrapping aspect is beyond me. All I know is that I could not master proper attachment of the clip most of the time and when I did, it still jutted above wrappings in a way I did not like at all. With a wrist, you don't want anything either on the "top" or "bottom" because it interferes with using your wrist or even resting it.I much prefer the old version of self-sticking at ends. Lies flat, smooth and it's easy to finish your wrap quickly.

I recently spent some time professionally doing research on World War I. As I told the person I was working with, "I'd love to read something that deals with how the war impacted the daily lives of the men and women of that time, especially the "real" (not rich) people who made perhaps even more sacrifices than the rich. This story, though fiction, certainly delved into the realities of war and how it affected those literally in the trenches and those back home praying for their return or dealing with the fact that many would not return.The writing style is fine and I liked the way the stories of the various characters were woven, back and forth, via letter excerpts, first-person commentary and regular narrative. Alas, I just didn't feel much for the characters. Somehow, while nailing details of the war's impact on a personal level--and deeply touching me, through very personal descriptions via the character's own words, I felt the author somehow didn't give us enough to get me to really care about these characters.It delivered in the sense that it did create a very atmospheric setting for an exploration of the human toll of war on individuals and the society as a whole. And if you have no real knowledge of the first World War and its impact--both then, over the years and even now---it's a good introduction to the society of the time and how war was experienced at all levels of society. If you've never cared much about the past, and have been bored by traditional historical nonfiction, this is a good way to whet your appetite for a real understanding of the human dimensions of war, no matter which side you are talking about.

Given the success of her earlier works, it's probably no surprise that Gilbert has now entered the self-help book genre. I can easily see how her editors and publishers might have pushed her along this path and into creating this book.  It's not without merit but it's one of those things where it might never have seen the light had it NOT been written by a best-selling author who does intersperse her thoughts with her real-life experience with the challenges of the creative process and who has the creds to speak with authority.Your response to this book is likely to be based as much on how many books/articles you've read on the topic of creativity rather than on what the author actually puts forth here--or your personal feelings about her life. If you've read a lot already, you'll know that there isn't necessarily anything "new" here on the subject but rather, as always, some clever packaging and a unique POV--and, as you'd expect of a good writer, some memorable quotes. What may keep you more interested are the various personal insights Gilbert offers on her own life and its creative path. She is honest about the difficulties and that alone helps "ground" her book and give it the credibility it needs to be a true inspiration.Big Magic is one of those titles that turned me off and not on. It's only the subtitle that drew me in: Creative Living Beyond Fear. Yes, that's the thing about creativity. It requires risks and comfort with the unknown. Fear is the killer and the dragon we must face to shape our best lives.If you come away with nothing more than a bit less fear about living your daily life as you would like, then the book is worth your time. Sometimes it's not about one's career or writing a book or screenplay or achieving world fame or success. Sometimes it's just about getting all the joy and juice out of an average day and life. All inspiration is personal and subjective. If Gilbert's work has "spoken" to you, you're likely to both enjoy and benefit from her insights from her journey. Clearly she has been living a creative life on many levels.

First off, this is not a self-help book about stress and stress relief. You are not going to pick this up, peruse it and come up with quick fixes, simplistic solutions or how-tos. That said, if you are someone who has serious problems with stress (or who is dealing with someone you care about who does), and you really want to get down and deep with it on more than a superficial level, this is a book that's worth your time.It doesn't read like a textbook, but it is written with a more  cientific and analytical approach to the various components and causes of stress and their impact on the body and our daily lives. Given all the very simplistic articles in the media over the years, you may think you know about stress. Read this and you'll really understand how much more there is to understand about how deeply it changes us on so many levels (emotional, physical) and how we can be less vulnerable to it and become more resilient (per the book subtitle).It's not an easy read, but then it's more akin to an academic textbook than a nonfiction book with stress as its topic. (Given the subject matter, it wouldn't and the density of text, it would not have hurt the publisher to have used a bit larger type. )If you are interested in the physiological, psychological and social aspects/elements of stress, this is a very interesting book. In one volume, it touches on so many key areas that are not addressed elsewhere or given short-shrift or what I call the "self-help babble approach."Check out the table of contents in the Look Inside feature of this book. You'll be amazed at the depth of topics. The section on cancer and on caregiving were especially helpful to me, along with the individual sections on hormones, specific diseases and the immune system.  I've read a lot on stress and don't believe I've ever seen so much covered and with such a unique POV and presentation, that what is offered here. It's a true primer for digging into the topic via various entry points.Sometimes, truly understanding how and what we are responding to and our behavior and choices, which can trigger or create our personal stressors, from a physical perspective, can help us get a better grip on the stressors. The author also includes sections on cognitive therapy and drugs for treatment. I don't have experience with either so I can't comment on the validity or relevance of these chapters.Read this and you'll truly understand the full impact of stress on our lives and our lifestyles. Once you grasp how the body responds and how stress is created, then, and possibly only then, can you create realistic (and not quick-fix) solutions. At the very least, you may be more aware and mindful of your triggers and thus prevent them from reoccuring or find better ways to deal with them.

Having given five stars in past to almost all the previous books in the series, I could not imagine one that would rate this low with two stars.I have devoured the previous Kinsey Milhone books and when they concluded, felt it was not only a good read but a good use of my time--and I always felt that Grafton had delivered. This time? Not so much.I can't imagine Sue Grafton letting anyone else write in this series (even parts or the entire book) as some reviewers have speculated here, but something is definitely off with this book as compared with those that preceded it. In the past, I've never ever felt bored or found a book lacking tension or its equivalent. I had to force myself to keep reading, believing, wrongly, that the plot really would develop and take on momentum. Maybe this is a style of writing today as I've now read (but did not finish, the first time ever) two other "mysteries" where literally NOTHING happened for close to 300 pages of a 450-page book. Seriously.I finished this book and as it came towards the "end" I thought I might have a book with missing pages. I'm not kidding. I could not believe we were at the end and with such an ending.This time around, a whole mess of, to me, trivial subplots (the California drought, the issue with Henry's neighbors, which I won't reveal in case someone reading this wants to read the book or is not finished, the angry and vindictive ex-wife who put one over on Kinsey) and almost no character development or character interaction beyond really minor stuff left me wondering: What is going on here? Or, more appropriately, what is NOT going on.Disappointed is to put it mildly. But hey, one book out of 24 not up to par...but I'm surprised that Grafton's editors let this one go into print as is. They do a disservice to the author, to whom I will still pledge that I will read the remaining two books in the series.This is a one-note story and it's not a compelling one. (I'm referring to the reference to a character from Kinsey's past, not the seeming main story buried in all the clutter.) And the ending...more than a little hard to believe given what we're told about one character.If this had ended as a cliff-hangar, it would have been frustrating but actually more credible. As it is, we're left to wonder: Well, does Sue Grafton have a plan that goes way beyond what is actually on these pages...is this a very very LONG runup to something better and more engaging? One can only hope.One also hopes that the last two Milhone books in the series do not follow the path/style of X.X for leaving one hanging out to dry in deep disappointment.

To those who have expressed disappointment in the author because Ms. Penny has deviated from the usual plots, etc. of the Inspector Gamache series, I say, wait, there are other books coming. And also, so sad that you truly missed out on the amazing story told here, better than even the most intense Gamache "mysteries." I truly do not understand the criticism because IF you loved the other books, how could you not love this one, too? Of course, I am biased because I loved this book even as it took me down a road that wasn't what I wanted or expected (and bravo to Ms Penny who could easily have provided a different ending that might have been more palatable for fans of the series but perhaps less realistic.)Penny's books, to me, have always been about characters and character development and the psychology of human relationships. The tales use police procedure, life in a small town and the art world as devices to bring forth the psychological development of the main characters and others who appear in a specific story. This outing really delved into the nature of various aspects of our successes and failures (personal and professional) and how they can alter the course of even the most loving relationships. This book isn't about the art world though it uses it as a hook to make many points. It's about so many aspects of how we let our lives slip away with our egos and expectations and most poignantly, the high cost of jealousy in our private and professional lives.And it's about what friends will do to help you in a time of great need. And what those friends learn along the way. I loved this tale even as  I reeled at the ending.This book was not even remotely what I thought it would be and far, far better than I could have imagined. Let's just say that if you have read the Three Pines (how I wish this were a real place although Penny brings it to life EVERY time) series, and embraced the characters, you will want to read this and you will savor it as what is, if you think carefully about what has been going on, a "logical/next" sort of step.To me, this is a great gift from the author. How I would love to sit with her and ask so many questions about what prompted this entry.This book struck many chords in me as my life now revolves around issues of vulnerability and of the need for healing, things that both the two main male characters here (Gamache and his former subordinate) face as they try to move forward after the devastating events of the series unfolded. (No need to go into them here because if you've read, you know what I refer to. If you haven't, I'm not going to reveal here.)I raced thru this book and made several notations along the way, copying bits of text here and there. It was deeply upsetting and at the same time, deeply moving and uplifting (perhaps not inspirational but realistic in way that still allows room for hope despite the despair and damage we may feel at times.)Louise Penny is more than a mystery series writer, but then anyone who truly enjoys the Gamache series realizes that the murders and police stuff (and the various bits and bobs one learns along the way about whatever the individual book theme is about, albeit interestingly told)  is just a way to focus and unravel what is, at the core, a psychological-based series about fictional characters that feel real.Three Pines may be one of the most realistic (and wished to be real-life) settings in any type of fiction.What I love most is the humanity, the compassion, the unbelievable depth of understanding shown towards the characters (by the writer) and by the characters to each other.  There is evil and darkness and pain in Three Pines. But there is love, laughter, community and more. I miss it more and more each time I reach the end of a book. Thank you, Ms. Penny. Merci, Beaucoup.

This is a well-designed and very functional pencil pouch. The material looks as if you could wipe it down to remove spills, stains (which is key given usage) and it also appears durable and sturdy so that it would resist tearing or ripping (time will tell).Plusses:>Three pockets in total. One large, full-length zippered one on back (with non see-through material)  and two on the diagonal on the front with mesh so you can see contents. You can fit a lot of stuff beyond pencils and pens in them and I can see this as a nice little cosmetic or small toiletries tote (discreet way to carry around in a notebook!)>Holes look sturdy for use in three-ring binderCons:>Price. $13+ for this? Not a good price/value ratio.  Despite its features, it's still a basic pencil pouch and there are other models out there that can deliver good looks + functionality at a much lower price. Even with its versatility for usage it's just too pricey.

If you are dealing with issues of vulnerability; if you're in a place where the struggle has become overwhelming, and you can't afford or aren't getting (for one reason or another) professional help, this is a book well worth your time. Yes, there are a lot of self-help books out there addressing these issues but few are as truly helpful, relevant and insightful as Rising Strong (great title). Brene Brown is an exceptional author whose education (how many self-help authors have a Phd and are social workers?), life work and experience have enabled her to compile a highly readable, reassuring and genuinely "will change" your headset and possibly your life after you've finished it.Unlike a lot of books on self-help, this isn't what I call all Pollyanna/think good thoughts/manifest X, Y,Z. It's about what to do when real life leaves you reeling and wondering "What next? Is there a next?" When, for various reasons, you feel incredibly vulnerable and at risk in your life, you need to read this book.Like a lot of books out there today in the self-help field, it has a clever title, chapter headings and POV (point of view). Unlike many others, it has real content and not fluff.As the subtitle says: "If we are brave enough, often enough, we will fail. This is a book about what it takes to get back up."Personally, I liked the book's anecdotes and stories. It is how real people learn and relate rather than the often dry and academic (and yes, dare I say it, "pure science" approach) material out there on the same topic. This author, in my opinion, knows how to take a lot of information and package it so that the average person looking to improve the quality of their life and willing to make an effort to understand what is going on and to implement change, CAN get accessible information.This book may not resonate for everyone but I suspect that a large number of people who've simply given up after falling and "failing" in life might find something in here to help them get up and keep going.  You take your help where you find it. It was the right book for me at the right time in my life.

Had high hopes for these but, alas, didn't live up to expectations. We have a number of cotton and/or linen dish towels (of different weaves, textures), which we've found very useful in the kitchen to wipe hands, dry dishes, mop up spills.These look as if they should be absorbent but they are not. After wiping down one glass and one dish (neither of which were dripping), these seemed to be very wet and no longer absorbing anything. Using other towels, we've been able to dry a dozen or more dishes or glasses. Tried wiping up a water spill and again, felt as if whole towel was soaked.Other issues:>They shrink, pill and generally seemed to be coming apart...and this after only one washing (and we're not talking heavy duty cycle either).They feel thinner after washing and are even less absorbent (We tested on glasses, etc before washing to have a basis of comparison for absorption. )Didn't like the weave, which did not seem to be designed for good absorption, nor the feel of the cloth. Does not feel like cotton, even after washing. Maybe this fabric has been treated with something?Our towels didn't have any bad smell when we received them.

I'm not a huge fan of short stories and I'm generally not a fan of stories about Parisians...that said, I found this series of short stories easy to read (but not necessarily easy to "get" on a light, fast read) and enjoyable even if I could not relate to or did not like the individuals. I was surprised at how I found myself wanting to know more about how/why these characters were "related."The book was far more engrossing than I imagined. There is a universality to the situations and stores that goes beyond the characters' location.The author writes well and in a style that's light but loaded with some very astute insights into the nature of relationships, marital and otherwise.These folks are not, for the most part, "happy" any way you might define it. It was fun to read thru and realize the connections. (and to see how bits and pieces in early stories led to a reveal later on.)I was most interested when I realized the author was the creator of two Broadway shows that I enjoyed. Clearly she is a versatile writer with a keen eye for human behavior.

First, it's a gel, and NOT a cream, as described. Nice, silky texture to it but comes out in quite a bit more than is needed for under two eyes, even with the lightest touch/squeeze.It moisturizes OK, nothing spectacular. (Takes awhile after putting it on to "evaporate/dry" under eye. Leave extra time if you are applying a concealer (yes, some folks will use this in daytime) to eyes.) As for the other product benefit claims, in time I've been using, can't say that I've seen a difference in my under-eye area. Perhaps my puffiness and darkness under eyes is not as severe/prominent as others for whom it has been useful.I've used a few other Garnier eye and skin care products and been pleased but every product can't be a hit. I think a great deal depends on how serious your own problem is with puffiness and dark circles. And your perceived benefit (It is all in the eyes of the beholder after all.)The problem is that a company raises expectations with a product name such as "Ultra-Lift Miracle Sleeping Cream Anti-Age plus Anti-Fatigue Eye Cream" / I'm always leery when the word "Miracle" is used to describe a product (and frankly, I don't even understand how a company is allowed to use that kind of wording in a product name or claim.).I don't know if any product can deliver the benefits that this product claims. Expecting a miracle solution to problems that can be both physiological and genetic in terms of origin may just be unrealistic.

If you enjoyed the original Inspector Morse series, be sure to see both Season 1 and 2 of Endeavour. Superb acting from the leads. A great look back to the early Morse (Morse in love!) and his origins plus intriguing look at a bygone era.This, along with the George Gently series (set in the 1960s)and Inspector Lewis series are among the best written and performed of Brit crime/mystery genre.

Note: This is an initial "review" only. Just got this. Followed instructions for startup. Simply will not connect. Shows up in Explorer and I click thru as per instructions, but keep getting error message. Go online to support page, and still no info on possible connection issues that relates to problem.I have other Seagate drives and they have performed well and were easily and quickly setup. This is a first. Thought the connection would be easy-peasy. Not so much.I'm writing this here more to get manufacturer's attention and get some help with this device.FYI: My network is up and working and other items connected are working properly. It's only this drive. There is no indication of what the issue is and I have tried several different times to get it to work.I've set up several wireless networks and set up a lot of external devices of all kinds so I'm not some newbie who can't follow instructions.The one star is not just because it won't work but because there is no real trouble-shooting info available for this specific problem (I drilled down thru a lot of pages in various places on the web site and in the online menu. No luck with identifying problem.)

All in all, this is a very good, everyday-use type of tablecloth. It's a lot nicer looking than a vinyl or plastic cloth you might choose for daily use in your kitchen or dining room (Who uses their good linens every day? Not this household, that's for sure.)I'm not a fan of polyester but this is so practical (highly stain resistant and washes well without pilling) and good looking that it really is a new favorite for our everyday table. I liked the weave and the color (light blue).  It's a welcome upgrade to everyday dining.My only con: Some of our lighter dishes did slide around a bit on it.

I had seen the ads for this product and was interested to try it. I'm a fan of matte foundations in general and anything that can make your pores "look smaller" is of interest.I found the liquid to be a bit thickish, more than I expected from a contemporary foundation (the others with mattifying properties I've tried from other brands in a similar price range were thinner). First time out, I used my fingertips to apply and smoothed out with a face sponge. I'm careful about using a tiny bit but it still seemed very heavy on my face. Worse, it created dry patches (even after applying on skin that had been freshly moisturized).Coverage was good but looked a bit fake and "thick" (for lack of better description). Color was OK (Sample sent to me was Classic Ivory).Applied using face sponge in subsequent applications, which helped a bit in terms of "lightening" up the look on my face. however, it's a waste of liquid when using this way as sponge absorbs the liquid.It seemed to stay matte/non-shiny for a bit but eventually, the shiny parts of face (nose, chin, forehead) were shining thru. I don't think there is any foundation out there that can keep a face shine free in all cases (high humidity, rain, etc.) so I can't say this is a true negative unless the only reason you are buying this is to maintain a shine-free face.Overall, it's OK but not great. I just didn't like the feel of it on my skin and the way my skin looked, no matter how carefully (and thinly I applied it. In the final analysis, it's a non-starter for my current foundation wardrobe.

As someone who has read quite a few female-lead-character driven detective and mystery novels over the years, I'm always looking for a new heroine/interesting female detective. As hard as I tried, I simply could not get into this story or the main character. Whether it's the writing style or the topic or the backstory of the lead character and her family interaction...to me, something was simply lacking. Simply was not intrigued by Fina. The story itself also didn't hold my attention but mainly because I just didn't care about Fina and the writing often just irritated me.Give me Kinsey Milhone, VI Warshawski, or the wild and crazy Izzy Spellman and her family of PIs (Lisa Lutz' Spellman series). Even the formulaic-at-this point Stephanie Plum series.Given the number of others who clearly enjoyed the book, this is just a reminder that our appreciation of any genre, whether crime or mystery, is highly subjective and personal. And not necessarily a reflection of the author's talents or skills.

We've had many oven mitts over the years of various sizes and materials but this has to be one of the best. I love the stripping that really does improve the grip. I love that it's made of cotton and is washable. I love the length (no more worrying about burning one's exposed upper wrist!).The design is straightforward yet stylish. It truly does resist both staining and having water leak through, big plusses.Of course, the main function is to protect one's hand while placing items in/out of ovens, toaster ovens and it does this very well indeed. Protection to 500 degrees is another plus. Many seem to be ineffective at even lower temps.Nothing to NOT love about this but one small issue for those of us with small to medium-size hands: It's a bit oversized (good for guy cooks) and can slip off if you're not careful. (I tend to stuff paper towels inside when it feels like it may come off. You could probably very easily sew in a piece or two of fabric to make it work.

Being able to print on Clear, plastic labels that can then be very easily (and all at the same time) attached to the tabs on these divider pockets is a great idea. But the actual execution, depending on your printer and the template you choose, can be more time-consuming--and annoying-- than simply printing out labels on either plain paper or other types of tabs and then adhering them to the tabs.There's a learning curve here even if you are used to using templates and there is no alignment sheet supplied (a big oversight to my mind and why this is three not four stars). If you've got a lot of these to do, or you need something very professional looking, it's maybe worth your time. If you are just doing a set, well, it depends on how you've previously done labels. For me, this was initially too much work and too much fussing with the printer and template.Clear vinyl/plastic page holders that are sturdy enough to hold 50 or more pages of papers are a great way to segment items in binders--and esthetically these look a lot better than the traditional type of paper/clear tab options one generally finds and uses.Just be prepared with patience and time to get things properly aligned.

I wanted to love this wireless keyboard. I've had a number of Belkin products in the past and found them to be functional, as advertised and with a good shelf life. This item? Not so muchIf you do a lot of typing on a regular basis, this will work IF you're comfortable with the keyboard (I have smallish hands and I found it to be a bit tight in terms of space for my hands to be comfortable.)  Felt squished and though I am a good, fast, accurate typist, found this keyboard a bit "tight" and restrictive. I made a lot of typos. I also didn't like the "feel" of the keys.It was easy to put together and charge. However, this case seems really really breakable. When I used it, I had something else behind it to hold up my iPad2 should it fall out of position. I would never use this as a case for my iPad. Just too flimsy.I actually find it easier to type onscreen when my iPad is propped up by the very sturdy case I already own. But then I'm not using the iPad as my primary work unit. The iPad is more for entertainment and I don't really type all that much except to fill in forms or sign-in stuff.The bluetooth worked effortlessly. Others have addressed the issue of the unit giving out in a few months. I can't speak to this as I havne't used it that long.

The quest for the ultimate all-in-one heated hair styling device continues but this one does have its merits. If you want to bulk up your style or straighten or smooth all or bits of your hairstyle, this can work well. But I don't see it adding curls, no matter how you wield it or at least it didn't yield curls on my chin-length, wavy hair. (I used it on both my "set" so it is straight hair and my naturally dried wavy hair.)I just wish all of these things were sized down a bit so they could be more easily used for travel and on the fly. (No, I'm not talking miniaturized versions. Just scaled down.)If you don't already have something in your electric hairstyling aresenal that quickly and relatively easily adds volume or helps straighten out hair, this brush could be a good addition.Pros:>Not heavy or especially bulky; was easy for me to handle and to use on my medium-length (to chin), wavy hair>Heats up quickly>Quickly adds volume to my dry hair>Good for touchups post gym or in morning when I've "slept funny" on my hairCons:>No temperature setting>Can overheat and cycle off>You have to be careful how you hold and place it so you don't burn yourself>Glove does not work well with bristles on brush>Think it should only be used on damp, almost dry, or dry hair to be effective. (This is NOT a dryer.)

I had so hoped these would be a tasty, low-cal, healthy snack that I could take with me on the fly.Alas, this is not the case. Taste is the key element here and all of these were totally tasteless, if not tasting like cardboard or foam, to me. (Exception: freeze-dried tangerines, which had a faint orange-y taste to them.)I couldn't get thru eating either the pears or apples. Had to spit them out.I used the tangerines in a salad with dressing and they added some crunch and flavor. I could eat them but I wouldn't as they just don't provide much in way of fiber and they don't fill you up. (You could easily end up eating several packs if you were hungry.) not a good use of calories, no matter how small.Taste is obviously subjective as some folks seemed to have liked these. Because I have not tried any other freeze-dried snacks, I can't say how they compare to other products on the market.It might be worth it to try one pack first before you consider ordering this many.

To put it in context, I rarely if ever read books by or about celebrities. Diane Keaton is an exception. Thinking she might have a new or thoughtful take on the subjects (aging, beauty), I picked up this book (which is a quick, easy read if you're not looking for more than something to do on a day when you have nothing else to do).I hate saying it's disappointing, but it is. That is, to be fair, a comment perhaps more about me as a reader and the expectations I bring, than it is on the writer. Perhaps I just never found anything too new or profound in Keaton's observations, comments and thoughts about the two key topics.If my best friend had written this, I'm not sure I'd have found it any more interesting.Maybe the real issue is that I wonder why any of us would spend so much time dwelling on certain things.All I know is that I felt a bit sad and depressed reading this. I thought Keaton was perhaps more confident about herself than is the case given what she wrote here.If you come with no expectations, have a few free hours and like Diane Keaton, it may be worth your time. Particularly if you are someone who enjoys ruminating about aging and beauty as seen from the perspective of a Hollywood star.

After a recent inpatient surgery, I suffered excruciating pain and severe nausea and vomiting (to the point that I had to be hospitalized).Since I had the same surgery (albeit under general anesthesia) twice, two weeks before and did not have any of these problems, once I recovered I suspected that something had changed in terms of anesthesia during the procedure and post-op drugs. Everyone at the hospital kept saying: "No, no. It's not the anesthesia." But I am super drug sensitive, something doctors neither seem to understand nor take seriously, and I knew that the only variable in all of this was the drugs (type, quantity and when administered).After verifying what I was given in the third surgery, it was clear that it WAS the anesthesia. At that point, I wanted to  educate myself on other aspects of anesthesia. This book, which is written in a way that seems to be more consumer friendly and educational than a truly medical book, really helped.In my opinion, if you want to make a truly informed decision about surgery (or other procedures) that require anesthesia, it's worth your time for you or your patient advocate (not the hospital one but the friend or family member who serves as yours) to review the contents of this book.You may learn more than you want to know, but...better to know than become a statistic. That's my thinking.At the very least, you will be able to ask more pointed and relevant questions (although again, you tell doctors things and they still seem to either forget or ignore what you said...a real concern. Maybe you need to text them everything to get their attention.)in advance of any procedure (where you have that option).It can also help you better understand the process and, hopefully, reassure you on some levels. (Any professional medical doctor will tell you that ALL procedures and any type of anesthesia have risks. No matter how minor or major the  procedure.)I wished I'd had the opportunity of reading this before my procedures.This book isn't for those who belong in the "I don't want to know about it" group. It's for those of us who want to educate ourselves, work better with our doctors to ensure accurate and safe procedures and better understand what is involved with the administration of anesthesia, which is a key, if not the key, componenet of a procedure.I think this book belongs on the bookshelf in any home where an adult or child lives. Because you never know when you'll need to know this information right away!

Most of my to-do lists are inputted via various software programs on my computer so I can easily update them and then print them out and/or save in PDF form for access on the fly.However, there are some personal projects, etc. for which I still use old-fashioned paper notebooks or lists, notes, etc. (I love Moleskine but oh, my, the prices.)I like the size of this notebook. The format works for what I call "mind-map dumping" (basically free-flow listing of ideas for an indivdual topic, project, etc.) that allows me to add bits on the fly. It's great for keeping track of top-of-mind stuff and miscellaneous bits I want to use for a project, idea, etc. (It's a paper take on MS One Note, if you will.).I would tend to use the whole notebook for a multi-faceted project (interior design ideas, a year's worth of gift ideas, etc.) and inspirational stuff.It gets three stars because the paper used for individual pages is thin and any kind of ink bleeds thru to the other side, making the "back" page unusable. I've switched to using colored pencils and using this for journaling (text) and hand illustrations. I would prefer using my super-thin tipped Sharpies but they bleed thru.If you are aware of its limits, and not expecting this notebook to replace an electronic format, it can be a frequently used tool to capture and store data, bits, etc. that is easily accessible (no electricity or charging required) at home, in the office or on the fly.

It's not really "green" to use disposables but in real life, there are times when you need the option of a good paper plate. Plus, because these are so sturdy and you can use just one plate to heat (microwave) and serve, you are saving both paper and water for washing regular dishes. In the past, we heated up stuff on the paper plates which were then soggy and falling apart and required another regular (non-disposable) plate for serving or eating. That is wasteful.I love the sturdiness of these especially as we use them to reheat a lot of food that has liquids and/or some greasiness. The liquids don't seep into the plates and you can then serve and/or eat from them as needed. Saves water (for washing by hand; we don't have a dishwasher) and time. Plus, we've cut down on a lot of spills and stains. (You have to be careful taking most regular paper plates out of the microwave as stuff often leaks or seeps over the edges.)The size (8.5 inches) is great; neither too big nor too little. Definitely helps with maintaining healthy portion size. Would prefer all white rather than the colored pattern but since we're not using these for a party or decoration, it really doesn't matter.We use these in the apartment, for picnics and when we travel. At about $.065 per plate, they aren't cheap but you get what you pay for. You could easily, depending on what you place on it, reuse these by wiping them off or shaking off crumbs.Some reviewers noted that the plate surface gets "sticky" in the microwave. We have used extensively in microwave and have not had this problem.These have become our new "go-to" disposables and it'll be hard to revert to the traditional cheap and flimsy white paper ones.

I've been looking for an easy way to segment a variety of papers and consolidate them in a single "carrier"  that I can take with me and use on the fly.This folder almost meets that need completely.I love the three interior pockets, which allow me to separate papers as needed. (I love that there is a half-moon overlap at top of page that ensures that letter-size pages won't fall out.). The extra wide space for labeling is great, too.Where the product is not so great:>>If you plan to use these together, the tabs are not staggered. They are all on the left side.>>If you plan to tote (or move) these around (whether in briefcase, tote, handbag, etc.), these don't hold up all that well. They're easily "bruised" and quickly get a battered look even if you're careful in handling them.I really wish these were more durable. They would be more appealing if they were made of that nice plastic you see on some file folders. More stain resistant and overall more resistant to just basic wear and tear if you take them with you. This material is just not sturdy enough in material construction and "weight."

It's been years but I remember using a similar dry, shake-on product (this. was way before you could buy shake-on seasonings for popcorn). I remember because we used it on baked and mashed potatoes and popcorn instead of butter and it really tasted like butter. Even guests couldn't tell the difference.This product, however, does not taste anything like butter (regardless of how much we used) on vegetables (steamed, so there was liquid), mashed or baked potatoes or air-popped popcorn.  Perhaps we're used to the more intense flavor of the "I can't believe it's not butter!" spray that we use on all of these. Or it's just lacking seasoning power.We tried using it with the above-mentioned butter substitute spray and STILL didn't get any flavor boost when we shook the dry powder on after spraying.I sprinkled a bit onto a plate, wet my finger and tasted it. Tasted flat and bland.Maybe I got a bad batch? I don't know. Just one person's opinion.

We've got about a half-dozen Swingline staplers in our home and home office and I've used even more at work over the years. Most have held up pretty well to heavy-duty usage in terms of amount of paper and frequency of use. Rarely had jamming issues. All sizes took same standard staples.I haven't had this model long enough, or tested it rigorously with batches of multiple page items, to determine it's functionality and stability (as in it won't fall apart) if used very frequently and/or for heavy usage for multiple-page sets. Who knows if this construction and material will stand the test of time but if, for some reason, you need a "gentler" stapler, this qualifies.As for being "50% easier" to use. How is that measure? By sheer grip/force needed? It is lighter in weight and you just need a gentle touch (if it's placed on a surface) or a squeeze (if used while in hand) but that may have more to do with material (plastic) than some specific construction trick.It's easy to load and uses standard size staples. I've read that others have had issues with jamming, but that hasn't happened so far. You never know with staplers but one has high expectation for the Swingline brand.$13 is a lot for what is something that has a plastic body. Let's hope it's sturdy plastic.After playing with it for a bit, I realized that unlike other staplers, this doesn't "open up" so that you can use it on flat surfaces. That's not a negative, IF you don't need it to do that. But that option is one that most of us do use (if only periodically) and are used to from other models. One wonders if the omission of this feature was deliberate or could not be incorporated with this design.If a light touch is your primary need and you're not using this in an office situation that requires a lot of hand stapling (or flat stapling), this could be a good option.
