However to really appreciate the light touch (whether 10% or 50%, it has to be relative to whatever model you were using!), you'd probably have to be using it enough for your hand to appreciate the difference.FYI: If you plan to mostly use this in your hand, keep your own hand size in mind. Mine is fairly small (size 6 glove) and this is too big and uncomfortable for hand-stapling. I keep it on my desk and insert and hit and it works well.

The Plusses:>Clean design for calendar; available with white frame>Size: Neither too big nor too small for use in many spaces in home office, kitchen, elsewhere in home.>Good size for one person's calendar notations>Nice that you can write on it with dry marker, use magnets, and have option (if you hang it) of pinning stuff on bottom bar of cork.Post-its seem to stick fairly well to surfaces.>>cleans easily with only a dry tissue or paper towel; no residual ink on surface. (Don't know if that's because of markers we used or the surface material or a combination of both.)The Negatives:>>Cheaply made, especially the frame>>Can only hang via use of sticky squares that come with it. Not good for some surfaces (messes the surface) and will not hold on other surfaces>>Unless you've got a very thin pointed dry marker, you can't write much on the squares>>Cork section is useless unless you are hanging this unit somewhere rather than leaning it against something.But the reason it only got three stars?The dry marker it came with, and the others we tried with it, produced mushy/blurred text  on the very shiny surface. Also, they came out very light and fading no matter who used the dry markers or how hard they pressed. Suggest trying different markers because the one that came with it is useless. (On the upside, there is no ghosting of ink when you remove what you've added.)

We basically use these as the household cleaner equivalent of antiseptic handwipes. Wipes are convenient and easy to use so we tend to use them more often to clean up various bits and pieces in the kitchen and bathroom as well as other elements that get a lot of individual hand prints each day (door knobs, metal or plastic handles on dressers,etc. the surfaces of various pieces of furniture not wood).They are a lot more convenient (albeit not less expensive) than toting around a spray bottle of cleaner and a roll of paper towels or microfiber cloths.We haven't done any scientific swabbing and testing to find out if these wipes actually disinfect surfaces, so who can say if/how effective they are. But Clorox is a trusted brand, so one starts by assuming they do work.The two downsides, and why they get three stars, are the scent (The citrus is tolerable; the fresh scent, not so much) and the way they get stuck in the top opening when you try to start them and during ongoing use. Very annoying to have to stick one's fingers in the tight plastic opening to pry stuff out and pull it through. That needs work. I've almost cut myself a few times.I don't know why companies think everything needs to be scented. I'm highly sensitive and loathe all this scented stuff. Are they trying to mask what they feel is an unpleasant smell?The size is good and we can use one or two to clean off the work surface of counters in our kitchen and/or to wipe down the sink in the bathroom. Convenience is key as I like being able to wipe down with one item versus paper towels and a spray bottle.I wish the package were a bit smaller as I'd like to be able to take these with me for train, air travel (although I think I saw them in small packets in a store recently.)They seemed to stay wet and not dry out in the package, which is good because we've tried other brands that seemed to dry out pretty quickly even in tightly closed packages.Our trio arrived intact, with no leakage.

Do you like really good chocolate? Do you like white chocolate? Are you a fan of "cookies and cream" just about anything? Then try these.I love the combination of the "hard" outer shell (flecked with bits of cookies) and the sweet creamy centers. I literally have to force myself from NOT eating the whole bag in a day. (They are rich and sweet, but oh, my, easy to go down.)These are neither low calorie nor low sugar so it's best to view these as an occasional treat.Taste is subjective. I've read some of the other reviews and I have to disagree. They don't taste gritty or coffee-ground like to me, but then taste is always personal. Yes, they are sweet and could be too sweet for some folks.Not sure if it's worth the money? Try an individual bag (with 12 pieces) for a minimal investment to see if these hit your taste buds in a good way.(To me, this is more like an upscale version of the Hershey cookies 'n cream bars that I love.)

I chose this book because, with little real depth of knowledge about gluten-free cooking, I wanted a reliable source of information. As a fan of America's Test Kitchen, I thought this would be a good jumping-off point to educate myself on the basics of gluten-free cooking.This book met those objectives. The up-front sections (background and how to select) info on grains, breads, gluten-free flours and pastas were an especially helpful summary/overview.I was, like others, somewhat surprised (shocked even) to see their reliance on white flour in recipes, something I want to avoid. The recipes also use a lot of milk and eggs. That said, you can still get a quick intro to the basics of gluten-free cooking and baking. Just don't treat this as the bible or the most comprehensive tome on the subject matter.Depending on your other health/dietary concerns, you'll find recipes that work within your dietary constraints. If you're into baking, there are a lot of recipes for bread, rolls as well as deserts, including cookies and cakes and pies. I don't bake a lot so I would have preferred more recipes for dinner appetizers and entrees.What I liked:>The book's format and layout; very clean and uncluttered. It's visually easy to read and see the important bits in each recipe and it's well-organized for easy quick reference to various topics. (If you're a novice cook, there are bits and bobs of "how-tos" on various relevant aspects for almost every recipe included in the book.  And I'm fond of the "Why it works" section, which helps educate you on the fine points of a recipe. (may be of no interest to some folks, however)>>The page on "Weight-to-Volume Equivalencies for GF Flours" which you'll find invaluable if you're trying to rework other recipes using various commercial flour brands.>The section on ingredient substitutions.There weren't a lot of recipes of interest to me given my interests. Again, I'm not a big bread, pasta or desert person.But I must say, some of the recipes did make me want to try them out.

I enjoyed this newest entry in the series because I like the main character, Ten,  (a Buddhist and  former LA cop and current PI) and I  enjoy how the authors weave in various Buddhist principals and teachings. I've always wondered how someone like Ten, who was raised/lived in a Buddhist monastery, would deal with the pressures and stresses of real life...and "real" life in LA!It's interesting to get inside Ten's head as he deals with various situations that challenge his beliefs and his practice. I like that he's written as a human (read: Flawed) hero and not as some unrealistic, idealized specimen. Ten doesn't always make the best choices for himself and he ends up hurting himself and others. It's his awareness and openness to change that makes the journey interesting---if you happen to be interested in and/or practice Buddhism.Let's be clear. This isn't a series with the depth of characters and plots as say Louise Perry or Donna Leon, but it's a light, quick read. The plot lines are thin, not all that intriguing or well-developed. This is a character-driven series and if you like Ten, you'll enjoy the latest entry. Reading is like catching up with a friend you haven't seen in a bit. You want to know how his/her life is going and what they've learned and been through.I'd strongly suggest that you read the first two books (in order) in the series before picking up this one.An excerpt from the fourth installment is included. I'm definitely intrigued especially as it raises some real questions about Ten's former partner.I'd like to see the writers go deeper with the plot lines to further explore Ten's integration into the modern world. And I hope we can steer clear of the over-emphasis on Ten's dating/relationship stuff, which I found so boring and uninteresting in this book.

We took the time to open every package and take out each bulb and test to be sure it worked. Thankfully, they all did.This makes it a good deal price-wise, which it would not be if some bulbs did not work or had been broken. It helped, I think, that the box of bulbs (four to a pack) was such that the twelve packs were tightly packed with no room for movement and then, the box they were in was wrapped in bubble wrap and placed in another box. That said, lightbulbs are fragile and we know that all shipping services pretty much treat packages roughly, even when, as this box was, it was labeled: Glass / Handle with care.The real test of course is how long these bulbs last. We've purchased bulbs in the past (all GE, bought at retail and online) that seemed to burn out in days of even mild use.Right now, I'm glad that we have the option of buying bulbs like these that have been discontinued. At the prices currently charged for the alternatives, we simply can't afford the number of bulbs we need for the lamps/lights in our apartment. Too bad the government doesn't take that into account. And the new bulbs? You spend a fortune experimenting until you find one that delivers the quality /color of light you need. Most are just awful.And as for the savings? We've heard from friends who have sprung for expensive bulbs that the new ones simply do not last for years and years (as advertised and promoted). So much for the "savings."We'll be buying these until we can't find them anymore.

It's hard to give an objective review when I've only been able to use this about five times before the tip wore down rendering it unusable as I need very thin, soft strokes which a stub cannot give.There was no sharpener in the package I received. I tried using other brow pencil sharpeners but none worked (they only wore down the tip). The lack of proper sharpener may have affected application but not the other elements (texture, color, look when applied, price/value ratio) that are a part of evaluating this pencil's effectiveness.I've used a wide variety of eyebrow pencils over the years at a variety of price points. The best are easy to apply in that they don't seem to cake or clump and go on evenly (with a well-sharpened tip) and don't smudge; you can shape the tip as needed to give thicker or thinner lines. The consistency (a bit waxy but not too much), which you can't try before you buy, is a key factor in both application and longevity, once applied.Other than the color itself, there's nothing that I liked about this product. Which is disappointing as this is a good brand and I've used other Longo products and been satisfied with their performance. It's especially disappointing given the price point.Application: Not as easy as other pencils, which is due, in part, I think, to the consistency (waxy, clumpy) and the size of the tip (too small and chubby and not thin enough to my liking).Texture: Not as smooth as other pencils I've used. Took longer to apply and had to keep smudging and fiddling with Q-tips to get a neat line. Didn't go on "evenly."Look when applied: Seemed heavier and line was not as strong and consistent. Getting a thin line was very difficult (again, an issue of consistency and size/shape of product tip)Color: This was a really good color for me, even though I have medium brown hair. I have found that many products labeled "blonde" are the right shade either alone or when used to lighten up a darker color.Price/Value: Simply not there for me. I've had better application, better looking brows with pencils that were cheaper. But since a person's brows (color, texture, etc.) differ greatly, this may work better for you than me. I have thin-ish brows and need thin, really feathery lines, which this could not deliver.

I've been using a variety of Suave body wash and haircare products for about a decade. This, like the others, has delivered in terms of my expectations for what I want from a shampoo: Moisturizing, non-drying, easy to lather and rinse out, economical and leaves hair easy to comb out wet even if you're not using a wash-out conditioner.Scent is highly personal, so it's not surprising that some reviewers have had a negative response. I'm very very fragrance sensitive and many haircare (and other) products never make it into the shopping cart because they have scents that are either too strong or unpleasant (to my nose). Fortunately, this was not the case here. I found the scent to be fairly mild in the shower and not the kind that lingers when your hair is wet or when it dries. What it does is turn shampooing in the shower into a bit of a spa experience. The scent, the color, the texture (very creamy) of the liquid all work together to make it feel as if I'm getting a shampoo in a salon. These are all plusses especially in a product at this price point.With my colored, dry, frizzy/wavy hair, the real test is how my hair feels wet after shampooing and how easy it is to comb out using my wide-toothed wooden comb. This product rinsed out easily (though it would be easy to put on too much given how creamy it is if you do not carefully monitor your application), left my hair tangle free and easy to comb.When my hair dried (naturally), it was clean, soft and did not have any lingering scent (what I love in a shower I do not necessarily want for my hair). All "good things" for any shampoo.

I'd been using another brand's case and was OK with it but felt it was too bulky and "ridged," plus the side buttons required intense pushing to work thru the case.This case is everything I wanted: Sleek, well-fitting, lightweight with easy to push side buttons and easy to access port covers for  headphones/speaker and power cord connections. I'm from the "less is more" school of design and this design is clean and functional. The materials and snug fit make it easy to store and easy to hold.Comes in easy to open (and store items) packaging, already a plus since you don't have to cut thru anything (or your fingers) to access the case and the screen protector (which comes with a little cloth to polish the screen).As others have noted, the one flaw is the screen protector. Mine did not seem to have any self-adhesive and did not stick to the surface (and it got smudges on it as I tried to get sticker off) so I just inserted it under the sides of the rubber cover, which pretty  much holds it in place--a workaround that may not be acceptable to you if you want something that actually adheres to the screen. It moves around (pulls down) a bit at times but no big deal.What I don't get is why the screen protector piece is NOT full size of the screen. Screen protector stops a bit before the bottom of the screen. Is this a flaw? Or by design?Installation was simple--once I realized that you have to separate the two pieces (the rubber wraparound and the plastic cut-out back). You place the phone inside the rubber piece, then secure the plastic cut-out back to that.There was a bit of pushing to get the edges of the rubber piece secure around the phone but once in place it was very secure.This is probably one of the best, if not THE best, protective cell phone cover sets I've used over the years.

Maybe my expectations were too high but I just could not get into this book.  The brothers' lives/stories just did not move me in the least.I've read other books (fiction, nonfiction) with cooking, restaurant and food prep themes. At heart,though, they were tales where the food/cooking/restaurant focus was a reflection of something deeper in the characters. The themes were, in other books, better integrated.I can tell by the first or second chapter whether I will read a book. Got thru two chapters and knew it wasn't for me.Which does NOT mean you might not like it. Just don't come with some idea that this is on the fictional level of a Kitchen Confidential.

Review upated 9/3/2015 with following comments (original review follows below)I had to come back and update my review here as I experienced problems with the remote that I had ordered and had been using when I wrote the review below.  I give great credit to the vendor as they have worked with me, or are working with me, to resolve the problems that I've had by accepting the now defective unit (the volume up area of the joystick on the remote ceased to function after a few weeks of being on my motorcycle's handlebar) as a return and get me a new one that will resolve this issue.  I appreciate the vendor's efforts and their customer service as they've been nothing but friendly about working with me.  I did get a little frustrated with the manufacturer who I turned to originally, expecting that they'd offer to RMA the device and swap it for me.While the manufacturer eventually headed towards doing an RMA, they also suggested that I would be best to turn back to the seller.  I'd much prefer to not have to go back to the vendor, especially with something that I'd call a manufacturing defect, but I have to admit it is up to the manufacturer to determine how they wish to proceed, and also up to the vendor as to how they want to handle problems.I am again looking forward to getting a replacement unit, but that will take a few weeks to get done.  Meanwhile I'll go back to using the headset directly (the 20S that I was pairing this with).  It may not be as convenient for adjusting the volume while listening to music, or switching the channels while listening to the FM radio, but it does work.Review updated 9/3/2015 - original review follows:I have a couple of observations and recommendations with this device as a few days of usage has lead me to a few issues and some pointers that may help others out.I originally oriented this device similarly to the picture that is shown on the product listing with the joystick on the "front" of the device and the power indicator light at the top.  When I did that, I found myself hitting the buttons too easily which lead to frustrations and actions that I didn't need/want at that point occurring (things like changing radio stations when I didn't intend to).I wound up turning the device "upside down".  Once I did that I found myself hitting the buttons much less frequently.  On a related note, I also found through trial and error that the buttons weren't doing what the instructions stated they would.  For example, bottom button is supposed to be the equivalent of the Ambient button for Sena 20S users (which I am) except that doesn't seem to be the case, at least not for me.  The bottom button (which is now the top button for me) instead serves to turn the FM radio on (if held in for 2 seconds, give or take) and also serves to advance the FM station to the next preset station when the button is pushed momentarily.I am easily able to use the joystick to flick up or down to lower or raise the volume (reminder, I'm using this device upside down to "up" lowers volume, "down" raises the volume).I have mild frustrations with how this device fits on my Harley Dyna, since it is a little wide and tends to line up in such a way that it blocks my thumb access to the left turn signal and other buttons on my left control cluster.  I find that I have to move my hand a bit to reach my thumb over past the joystick and this remote control to reach the turn signal, horn button, or headlight control.  Additionally, I would note that using this device also means lining up the open end of the remote control so that your clutch handle can be pulled back into the space where this remote control might otherwise block it at.  Think of this device as a bit horseshoe or U shape that has to have the opening of the horseshoe/U aligned with your clutch handle.  If you don't have that sort of alignment the thickness of this device may intrude into being able to completely use the clutch (which would be a very bad thing).For me this is a fairly solid 4 star device.  I might use more of a 3.5 star rating if that was possible, but it isn't, and I really do find this device very useful, so I'll stick with the 4 stars.  If you are a user of a Sena headset, then definitely consider this add-on if you can use it.

For the record, this would be a 4.5 star item for me, but I've rounded up here.  (Which is what I alluded to in the title for this review)Over the last year I've been through a Sena SMH5 (no FM), then later an SMH5-FM and then later a Cardo Scala Rider G9x before circling back around to get this product (20S-01).  I've liked all of the above, though each of the previous devices had something missing here or there that led me to swap one for the next (typically passing the older devices down to another rider who might be able to make some use of the device).I liked the SMH5.  It was fairly simplistic, but worked well enough for me to listen to music on or answer phone calls with while riding.  I would note that I didn't have a lot of success with voice commands for it, but using the Jog dial was easy enough to get the hang of.I upgraded later to the SMH5-FM because I wanted to be able to listen to "live music" over the radio, or get sports talk or news talk to catch up on current events.  That device worked well in the end, but I encountered some issues with it that originated from the TomTom Rider 2013 device that I paired it with (when I selected the sound "none" for alerts I didn't realize it was going to flip to silence for some period of time.  I assumed that none meant no alert sounds and no interruption of other audio that I might be listening to).  I didn't determine the source of that problem until after I had upgraded again, to the Cardo Scala Rider G9x.  With that device in use I was able to test things out more and link the alerts that the TomTom device was putting out back to the seemingly dropped audio.I liked the G9x but... it suffers from a lack of LOUDNESS in the audio.  It does boost the loudness with AGC (Automatic Gain Control) that is keyed to noise and speed, but when it does boost the audio it winds up garbling it a bit, or making it hard to determine what you are actually hearing.  Think of a speaker that was turned up too loud and just can't handle the volume level you are tasking it with.  Outside of that issue, I also found myself wanting the Sena Jog dial control again, versus the button arrangement that the G9x uses.  Oh, one other fault with that device is the lack of an available remote control (where one is available for this device).Now, this device isn't without issues for me.  The voice commands definitely worked with the G9x.  I was able to make enough noise to wake it up easily (typically by using the word "Radio" in a reasonably stern voice) and then could give it a command that it understood and completed.  I've not had similar success with the 20S, but do intend to practice more with it and fine tune it (if possible) to get it to respond better when I want it to.That leads me to another quibble with this device, and that is one that I've seen with all of the Sena products that included FM Radio (the products that I have tried).  The setting for using RDS to help "lock in" stations is apparently backwards, at least for my usage.  With that setting on the radio tends to "drift" and starts scanning around on the FM dial to find another station rather than actually sticking with the station that I was listening to and locking in that signal.  In fact, if I turn off the RDS functionality and just let the static and fuzz come through occasionally the signal locks much better and never drifts to another station.I would note a similar not quite as expected functionality with the use of the handlebar remote that I paired with this device, but that will show up in a review of that remote control when I get an opportunity to write it.The FM audio and other audio levels definitely reach a higher volume level without getting ruined (when compared to the G9x as an example).  The FM station range is reasonably close to the G9x as well, and as a big advantage, the Sena products don't come with concerns about gray market purchases that the Cardo Products seem to make an issue of for purchasers that didn't purchase directly from an authorized retailer (which the big A to Z retailer here is not).Oh, one other area where I would have to acknowledge that Cardo seems to have an edge compared to Sena is with their supporting smartphone application.  Probably just personal tastes, but I found I liked the Cardo app better compared to Sena's.  I somewhat assume that eventually the Sena app will offer the same things that I like in the Cardo app, and may even be an improvement over the Cardo app.  That's an area where the healthy competition should lead to improvement.So, this isn't quite perfect, but is awfully nice (from my perspective) and is a device that I absolutely love having.  Being able to listen to the radio, or take phone calls is really nice.  Made even better with the handlebar remote control (though that device isn't quite perfect for me).  4.5 stars if possible.  Rounded up to 5 if not. ;-)

I bought a refurbished one of these Acer Aspire Switch 11 computers (the SW5-171-39LB model) back in April, after searching around through potential local retailers to find any that might have one of these in stock to check out in person.  I was able to find the little brother version (the one with the 10" screen) at a certain brick and mortar store that just happens to have been primarily Windows oriented ;-)  Seeing that one in person left me feeling more comfortable about how big the keyboard was on this model and how much more I'd like it compared to an ASUS T100 10-Inch Laptop [2014] that I had purchased previously.  While that little Netbook/Tablet hybrid computer was OK, I had grown frustrated with the size of the keyboard (the keys are just a little too small on it) and also because of the size/resolution of the screen on that device.  Just a little too small (that 1.6 inches makes all the difference in the world).I loved the battery life on that T100, and really appreciated that it could be charged through a Micro-USB type connection, though I would also have to note that you needed to use the charger it came with or at least a charger that provides plenty of juice otherwise the poor thing would outpace the charger and leave you draining the battery faster than you could charge it.This Acer Aspire Switch 11 has its own charger that you likely won't find a good generic replacement for.  You can find some less expensive chargers for it, or some OEM chargers from the big A to Z online store here, but this is not a device that charges through a Micro-USB connection.Where this device shines is in an awfully pretty screen.  The 11.6" diagonal offers just enough additional screen real estate to let me see things without seriously straining my eyes because of the small type.  At least after adjusting and selecting the "larger" display mode that is offered on this device that is the case.  You can still select a display mode that makes things small (due to the higher resolution that this device offers) if you want, but for an aging set of eyes like mine you likely want bigger on the screen instead of smaller.The tablet portion of this device is definitely top heavy.  The keyboard portion of this 2-in-1 is very light.  It can easily tip backwards when used in laptop mode as the keyboard isn't heavy enough to counter balance the tablet portion.  Going with Tent mode helps in that area, or turning the screen backwards on the keyboard base if you'd prefer, but if you select either of those options you lose the use of the keyboard and are pretty much forced to use the device in tablet mode.The 128GB of "drive" space that the version of this device that I had purchased is nice.  While the T100 that I still have only had 64GB (which at the time I purchased it was a lot compared to the 32GB that was standard on most of the lower-end devices) of "drive" space, it was enough for most of my needs.  In fact, that device still had plenty of room available when it was time for me to upgrade to Windows 10 (and it did upgrade easily enough).  With the 128GB that this device featured I had absolutely zero concerns about having enough room for the Windows 10 upgrade process.4GB of RAM is definitely very nice with Windows 8 (or 8.1) or Windows 10.  While 2GB works fine (and worked well enough for me on a Dell Venue 8 Pro 5000 Series 32 GB Windows 8.1 Tablet), I go with the thought that with Windows operating systems that more RAM is always better.I really do like this device and use it quite frequently for taking notes (using OneNote), or streaming some music via iHeart Radio or Amazon Prime music streaming.  While I wouldn't turn down something more powerful if given the opportunity, I like this well enough to easily recommend it for most potential purchasers.  4 solid stars, leaning towards the 4.5 mark.

I requested this product for review because in just looking at it I could tell it was going to appeal to more than a couple of the youngsters in my extended family.  My nephew's son has been seriously into dinosaurs over the last year.  The unfortunate thing for me in having any thought that he'd really enjoy playing with this toy is that in his case if it doesn't appear to be hyper-realistic he just isn't interested.  For a still relatively young child, he is more than a little picky about his toys.  My wife and I gave him a couple of plastic dinosaurs that we did purchase through the big A (here) and those were some of his favorite toys last year at Christmas time.  While this toy is not as realistic as that one was, it does offer a big advantage - being able to assemble it in a similar fashion as one might do with Lego toys.For other, less selective, younger members of the family the ability to assemble these toys and then play with them after they are assembled would lead to many hours of fun.I would note that these aren't quite perfect.  The instructions are definitely similar to Lego instructions and unfortunately just like Legos the instructions seem to cut corners a little.  Just enough to possibly frustrate some individuals that might be working on assembling these toys.  More than likely the assembly would eventually happen, but not without some confused looks as to how things go together in a few of the potential steps.4 solid stars for this toy.  If you've got youngsters that would like to play with dinosaurs, there is plenty of value here.

If possible, this would be closer to 3.5 stars, or maybe a little below that level, but since ratings here can't use anything other than whole numbers I've rounded down.  Hang on for a bit and hopefully you'll find that I've justified that rating.Let me say that I like this device, and it does have a few features that I consider serious positives.  The ability to use your own speaker, or your own microphone if you preferred - either of which will easily plug in with a common plug type.  That is something that just isn't possible on the Sena Bluetooth headsets that this unit replaced for me.On the more immediate negative side though, and the reason that you won't find a "verified purchased" badge for this item for me is that the manufacturer has some notoriety for not wanting to provide support for their products if they weren't purchased from authorized retailers (which, unfortunately, the big "A" here is not :-( for this item)  While you might luck out and find an authorized dealer that lists the item here, that isn't likely as if they do list the item here they would likely do so at a discount and that is something that the item manufacturer doesn't want to see happen to this device.  Anyway, given the manufacturer's stance towards purchases from gray market retailers, you would potentially place your purchase at risk if you don't stick with buying from an authorized dealer.Realistically, buyers should not expect to have issues with this item, at least not the kinds of problems that would need warranty support.  It is well made, and well documented, and easy enough to "assemble" (install on your helmet).  The instructions are clear as well.  Those areas are also positives for this item.Back to the negatives though are a few more serious annoyances.  Volume levels top out at lower levels than I would like and lower than I suspect most buyers would be happy with.  While the AGC (Automatic Gain Control) works and boosts the volume as you get more noise and potential interference, it does so in a way that leaves the sound less clear.  My own feeling is that the device's sound quality lacks bass and tends to be more on the high (treble) side, so it tends to become a bit of a high pitch whine sound when the volume is boosted through the AGC.  If I could adjust the tone, I would certainly aim for more bass.  I'd also like to see this device "go to 11" to get at least one more, or perhaps two more notches of potential volume settings.  I don't wish to blow out my ear drums, but I find myself thinking this headset just isn't bringing the volume levels that it should.The FM radio functionality is nice.  The reception though, is a little disappointing, at least given the raving that other users did which helped lead me to purchase this headset.  I had an expectation that I'd be getting clearer reception than I had been getting from the Sena SMH5-FM headset that this headset replaced for me.  I've since passed that headset on to a co-worker who was thrilled to get it, but I suspect that if I put that headset back into usage I would find that the FM reception was actually better than this unit provides (meaning I could get reception of stations several miles further away with the SMH5-FM than I do with this Scala Rider G9x).  The reception, however, depends quite a bit on the routing of the speaker wires, and I might find myself getting better FM reception with this if I spend more time routing and/or re-routing the cable to the right speaker around in my helmet. Beyond the signal quality though the SMH5-FM had better - at least for my tastes - volume levels, which again leaves me thinking that perhaps I should have stuck with that device and not tried so hard to find nirvana in the motorcycle Bluetooth headset area.The control scheme (buttons) are not bad though it has been taking me a little while to get my fingers used to which buttons are which, especially when I have gloves on.  While these buttons are glove friendly, they're not exactly easy to distinguish even with obvious effort from the manufacturer (or their designers) to provide decent tactile response and controls.  You would likely find yourself feeling around a little to confirm whether you are hitting the A button, or the B button, or the center button, etc.  That problem area introduces another potential area of disappointment for me - the lack of a handlebar mounted remote control option (such as the type that is offered for some of the Sena models).I can use the smartphone app (which is another plus for this device), but that typically means either pulling over on the side of the road so I can tinker with the app, or doing something I'd consider a little stupid - mounting my smartphone on my motorcycle so I can attempt to use it while I'm riding.  Neither is really the right solution, at least not in my opinion.One more area of note for the FM radio options - the G9x offers only 6 presets for the radio station settings.  The SMH5-FM offered 10.  If you are lucky enough to live in an area with plenty of stations to choose from those extra presets can be handy and can again save you from having to pull out the phone and application so you can scan up or down the FM dial a bit.In the end, I like this device, but wish the manufacturer was more consumer friendly in their pricing and support for persons that purchase from, well, anywhere.  I wish it offered a handlebar remote control option, and I really wish it offered more volume and better tone preferences/options for users.  The positives for this device just don't make me want to move my rating higher.  (Though I suppose I could give this device another plus for the case that it comes with, which I would note I'm in agreement with some other comments that I've seen - the case is nice, but it will likely be put away quickly to collect dust once you get things configured and begin using the device regularly.)I may yet come back in the future and be posting a review of a SENA 20S device, though in my research on that device I'm still finding that it uses SENA's own speaker connection which means no chance at using my own preferred speakers with it.

I've been looking to improve the Wi-Fi strength within my home, especially from the Verizon FiOS router that is used primarily within the home.  Sadly that router has never done a great job of providing coverage from end-to-end in my home and because of that I've had to make use of a second router to reliably extend coverage into what would otherwise be under-served areas of the home.  In my efforts to improve the signal strength I've used replacement antennas from Hawking, as well as other manufacturers whose wares were peddled here.  Truthfully none of them seemed to have provided much benefit.  With that all said, I learned long ago that signals can be highly directional and where the antenna is pointed can make a great deal of difference.  That combined with where the antenna is situated vertically within the deployed space, as well as types of materials that exist within walls of the facility can all impact signal strength.Note, I would not expect to see any boost in network speed as a result of using these antennas, at least not in most situations.  The benefit that would be gained would be in signal strength.  If your equipment had been dropping speed in order to continue to maintain signal then you might see benefits in speed, but otherwise expecting a speed increase would be wishful thinking.I appreciate that these antennas were designed for both the 2.4 GHz and 5 GHz bands.  On one of my most recent purchases (an Alfa 9dBi WiFi Booster antenna) I could never find any specifications that discussed which bands that antenna was intended to cover.  With most current routers designed to provide Wi-Fi in either band, getting an improvement in both bands is appreciated.This two pack of antennas is a little spendy compared to other alternatives (the previously mentioned Alfa antennas as an example), but they are well made and simple to install.  4 solid stars.Edited to add: please do experiment with the antenna direction.  If possible, use a Wi-Fi signal strength application on your smart phone or tablet device and measure your performance as you change the antenna direction.  Doing this should help you nail down your best results.

This case reminds me a bit of my younger years when my father was into scuba diving and had high hopes of building his own water proof case for a 35 MM camera that he hoped to be able to use while diving.  I don't think my father ever did get his case to work as he had hoped, but I must admit to also sharing thoughts of being able to take pictures under water without having to be concerned that the camera would be ruined from exposure to the elements.  Those thoughts have caused me to put forth some disposable income on a digital camera that had promised to be usable under water.  That particular camera was not that great, as it was fairly low resolution and not as comfortable to use as I might have hoped.This case gives buyers a water proof case that offers a variety of lenses that can be used with your iPhone 6.  The lenses would be interchangeable with other Optrix Body Glove cases.  I really do like that feature, as it would allow me to, as an example, get a case for my daughter's hand-me-up iPhone 5S where I could use the same lenses.Negatives revolve primarily around the expense of this package.  It offers plenty of value for the cost, but it isn't an inexpensive item.  Consumers that can find iPhone cases at low cost from a variety of sellers may balk at the pricing level that is in effect for this item, but putting this case into use could save someone the cost of an action camera and also provides enough variety of lenses to achieve very favorable results.Personally, I'd love to see the same basic product available for my S5.  If it was, I'd be ordering as quickly as I could.

When a few friends posted about this item being a lightning special here I wanted to scream a little myself as I was mysteriously pushed into purchasing this little plush character even if I had no real justification for doing so.  Who needs justification? Are you trying to make me ANGRY OVER HERE?!< big wide evil grin >I really do like this little guy as I'm a big fan of the guy that provided the voice for this character in the Disney/Pixar movie that it comes from.  Lewis Black is someone that I've enjoyed hearing rants from going back several years now.  To me, he is very much in the same vein as another comic that left this spinning ball far too early, Sam Kinison.  Angry yes, but also really, really, really funny.  (Not necessarily politically correct, but definitely funny.)This plush is relatively tame, not really even rising to a PG type rating for the language that is used in the phrases that it is able to play back for you when you press it's left hand.My one complaint? (and the reason for the less than 5 star rating) IT ISN'T LOUD ENOUGH!!! I wish its screaming was louder, and wish that some of the other phrases weren't as quiet as well.  Other than that, it really is just what I would have expected and makes for a great addition to the toys around my cubicle.

I really hope I don't have to come back and update this review later, but for now the rating is at least 4 stars from my better half.Truth be told, I saw jewelry and thought back to the earlier subliminal programming that my wife has done ("I always love jewelry" "You can never go wrong with nice earrings" "Shiny is always nice" and other similar thoughts running through my head) and pretty much hit the button to request these right away.  That all said, I still have a few concerns.  10k Yellow Gold?  Hmm, isn't that a relatively low number?  Don't most people look for that number to be higher.  Shhh!!! Don't tell her, she may not notice.  Ah, heck, you know you can't do that.  Just tell her.  She'll still like 'em if they are shiny and pretty.  (And as it turns out, they are pretty much as shiny and pretty as you see in the image shown.  Not bad for such a low number.)No information available to refer to and research is another concern.  I would think that eventually Amazon will have more details about this item and maybe we'll all learn more about the specifications and quality, etc.  For now, the lack of such additional information is a little worrisome.  I did mention to my spouse that if she sees any strange side effects (shhh! don't jinx the potential use and re-use of these earrings!!!) from these to please let me know ASAP.  I don't expect any issues, but for some reason I have memories of some jewelry I remember my mom or grandmothers having that turned green with use.  Poor quality metals that never should have been used for jewelry got into the supply chain just a little too easily in decades past."Imported." noted on the product page.  Hmm, imported from where is also something that leaves me wondering.  For some reason my OCDness kicks in and leaves me wondering pretty strongly if these are imported from some country where the work was done by workers that haven't gotten enough breaks, haven't been paid enough for their time, or aren't as concerned with the potential health and safety of the end user (probably because they themselves weren't paid enough, were overworked, etc.)  I hope that none of these were ever a factor here, and in the end just want to be able to leave a nice 4 star rating that shows how well liked these were by my spouse.

I should note here, up front, that the 5 star rating for these isn't just my own, but rather it should be duplicated a few times as this item would earn 5 stars from me, my stepson, and his oldest son.  Each of us would be happy to give this toy set 5 solid stars as we all LOVE it.  Asking what we like about it (everything) is nearly impossible for us to remember individually, there are just too many aspects that make us love this set.  The range of the shots when fired, the fact that there are two guns to play with, the target to set up and aim at and the fun, fun, fun that can be had once you get things built.  And oh, yeah, the building of the items in the set.  I'm sure I'm forgetting a bunch of little things that also factor into the rating, but the important part hopefully shines through:  buy this toy set without regret.  It's worth the 5 stars and will provide hours and hours worth of fun for anyone that gets it into their hands.Oh, please, please, please Amazon - post some pictures of this item soon.  And big thanks to others that have been posting pictures for everyone to see.  Definitely nice to have them to see what this product actually is.

Updated comments (after dropping a few stars from this item as it wore with usage):Originally I had given this item 5 stars as I liked how it worked, but over time and with usage I found that this holster just doesn't hold up.  The front face got scuffed up sooner than I would have expected and the thickness of the leather (or pleather, whatever it is) wasn't enough to keep this holster from wearing through.  I'm certain it was from rubbing up against the seat belt clip in my vehicle, but either way the durability comes into question and results in me having to come back and drop the rating as I don't want to have someone seeing the 5 star rating I had originally given this item only to find out for themselves that the item isn't as durable as it should be.Functionality wise, it continued to do what I needed and wanted until I decided to retire it because of the worn spots on the front.  It easily held my Galaxy S5 and yet allowed for easy access sliding the phone in and out of the holster.  In that area, the 5 stars that I rated it originally would still apply.New rating (due to apparent lack of durability): 3 stars.Original review follows:I really wish this holster had been available when I first got my S5, or heck, even further back to when I had my Galaxy S3.  I had previously used a small hanging 'bag' as a holster for an older phone (back to my days of having and using an iPhone 3GS) and just liked having the phone available at my side by not obnoxiously so.I was "OK" with the holster that came with the Otterbox Defender case my phone is in, but inevitably the holster gets snagged on something -- typically the seatbelt/door area on the passenger side of a co-worker's vehicle -- and the OEM holster winds up destroyed (for all intents and purposes) and no longer usable for holding the phone at my waist where I want it.This belt holster works very well for my needs and seems to be plenty durable.  It holds the phone in either a portrait style stance or in a landscape stance if desired and it does it while the phone is still safely ensconced in the Otter Defender case so if the phone were to happen to slip out, it would still be protected.  Really though, there is no need to worry about the phone coming out of the holster as the holster closes nicely and holds well enough with the magnetic 'catch' that keeps the top of the holster held down.Easily a 5 star rating for me, and easily recommended for purchase for anyone that might want a nice holster to hold their Galaxy S5 phone in.  Note though that if you don't have a protective case on the phone about the size of the Otterbox Defender case then you will likely find an issue that I know someone was complaining about for one of these holsters for a Samsung Note 4 - the phone would be swimming around and bouncing around within the holster since these oversized (and clearly noted in the product listings and descriptions) holsters are intended to have the phone kept in a protective case within the holster.The manufacturer here does offer a variety of holsters though, and if you want to use the case for a phone that isn't enclosed in a protective case you can likely find a holster that will work well for your needs.

My relatively poor rating comes from several areas for improvement with this device - hopefully I don't forget them all, but here goes:* Put the display where it can easily be seen.* Put the exhaust area away from the console's air intake area* Personal preference: I'd prefer to have the thing leave the top of my console flat.  Just my own preference but I don't particularly care for the aesthetics of this relatively large add-on that covers only one side of the console.* With this device on top of the console stacking another device on the top of the console (I know, not really advised, but bear with me), even with some sort of spacers in between, would be difficult.If you are concerned that you need to help cool your console, this device would do the job but it may not make that much difference in the long term (unless you are somewhat abusing your console by using it in an small enclosed space with limited air flow).Thankfully Microsoft seems to have learned their lessons with heat exhaust and console devices compliments of the problems that had plaqued the first few years of the Xbox 360's lifetime.  I hope that the Xbox One continues to behave itself in this area and that I will continue to not really *need* this device.3 stars.  OK device, just not something that rates much higher for me.

If not for the smell, this might actually rise to the 5 star rating.  Seriously, the smell that this case has is one that will more than tickle your nose during the first several days of ownership.  That was a known for me at the point of ordering, but it remains something that I can't ignore in terms of making recommendations for others that might be interested in cases from this manufacturer.  I've purchased Fintie cases for other devices and have found them to be more than reasonably protective of the devices and easily functional for their designed purpose.  They cover the devices well and make the devices easier to stand and use without having to hold them.  But... during the first few days of ownership expect to notice the odor of the 'pleather' that is used for making these things.Looks (aesthetics) wise these cases look nice.  The one that I purchased was the "brown leather" (excuse me, it's actually Vintage Antique Bronze) hard cover book type that for some odd reason, at the time that I purchased and am writing this review, shows with a totally different pattern down in the row of sample color/pattern choices.  (Actually the pattern is a little confusing.  It is trying to show the pattern of the imprinted decoration on the case with a small corner in the upper left showing the Bronze color.  The pattern is drawn on paper or something similar and almost looks like an artist's doodle.)This case does make me smile a bit in that once it is installed the "spine" of the case appear to be about 3 or 4 times thicker than the incredibly thin iPad Air 2 that is installed in it.  While thin might be in when it comes to iPads, with this case thin isn't an option.  I don't have a problem with that, but if you really want the iPad to be thin while in the case, then you'll want to look for other options.Personally I like the protectiveness that this case offers and like that it has the 360 Degree Rotation feature.  It is nice to be able to rotate the case and iPad without having to take the iPad out of the case, using it in either a Portrait or Landscape style all while having it stand up nicely by using the grooves in the cover.  Also nice is the automatic wake feature that this case supports.  Open the cover and the iPad Air 2 wakes up automatically.  Other cases may include that feature as well, but not necessarily in combination with the 360 Degree Rotation.All told this is a nice case.  Not quite perfect, but pretty nice.  For me the room for improvement would be having the thing aired out thoroughly prior to packaging and shipping as well as making the cover a little thinner if possible.  I understand making the cover thinner might not work as well as I would hope as it might make the grooves that are in the cover too thin to be able to keep the iPad from slipping while it is standing.  That doesn't make me wish any less though ;-)

I love this game, but... Yeah, I know there's always gotta be a but there somewhere, or at least it seems that way.  There doesn't always have to be a but involved as there are times along the way when something is just so darned perfect that I can't or don't find any faults with it, but this isn't quite one of those times.I really like this game a lot.  It looks good.  Not perfect, but really good.  There is room for improvement graphically but it looks impressive and does a good job of showing off the kind of graphical output that the current generation of console gaming hardware (Playstation 4) can produce.  That said, I see the player images and think that while they are fairly recognizable they just aren't as realistic as I would hope to see.  A little rough around the edges is about the best way I can describe it.On the plus side, the gameplay options are thorough enough to give an older gamer geezer like me an enjoyable experience.  Realistically I just never got that good at playing the supposedly more realistic hit stick and pitching with the stick style games.  I can place the pitch and time the pitch (not that well, but enough to get by) in the beginners/basic interface and still get an enjoyable experience.  It'll take more practice to get the timing down again so I can control the pitches better and if I can find enough gaming time I will do just that.Given the chance, I would have given this a little less than the 5 stars it is getting from me here.  If I had any real alternatives, I might be looking at something more down in the 4 star range, but the alternatives are few and far between.  MLB's own RBI baseball just doesn't cut it for me as it looks too 'toony' and just not that impressive to me.  Wishing for alternatives doesn't make them happen though, and meanwhile looked at in its own right this game is pretty good.If pressed to justify the extra cost for the Anniversary Edition versus the regular edition I'd say spend the extra $$.  The additional cost is minimal compared to what is included for the gamer.  While you can earn extras through your own play, getting the Anniversary Edition gives you a head start and saves you time along the way.  It also offers up the bonus themes you can use immediately to give you PS4 some team flare.

This is yet another of those times when I get to welcome in a guest reviewer to help me with the review of this product.  My daughter (well, actually this isn't technically true, as it isn't just my daughter, rather all of the others in the household as I sit alone on Android island) is the iPhone user, at least when it comes to iPhone 6 (the others are still using iPhone 5 devices).  That being the case, and me still thoroughly enjoying the use of my Samsung Galaxy S5, left me looking towards my daughter to be the tester for this case.Given the damage that I've witnessed on the hand-me-down iPhone 3GS that I had passed along to my daughter (or should I say on the old case she had on that device) and the damage that I had seen on the cases she had for her iPhone 4S and the cables and headphones for same, I figure that anything that can survive her usage should be given a few extra stars no matter what I might otherwise think of it.I have to admit that when I saw the image of this case that I didn't think that I'd like the appearance that much.  It seemed a bit too busy for my tastes, and just didn't look that good to me.  My daughter wound up loving it and once I saw it in person and on the phone I didn't think it looked bad at all.  The busy pattern just isn't as busy when you see it in person.On the protective side, my daughter has had the phone cord get snagged with the phone taking a dive off of the table and on to the floor.  With this case on, there have been no negative impact from such occurrences (not that it happens that often, but it does occur often enough to see it happen with this case on the device).In the end, if the design doesn't bother you, then I would think this would settle in around the 4 solid stars that my daughter offered up as her rating.  I'm going along with that rating (hey, I'm not crazy enough to tell any of the women in this household they are wrong on anything ;-) )

While the 2 star rating might be harsh, it is hard to say that the level of harshness would approach that of the smell of the cleaning solution that the manufacturer supplied with this device.  While I do expect a "cleaning solution" like smell, this stuff goes further and is seriously off-putting.  If you are like me and have family members that experience breathing difficulties that are easily irritated and initiated by odors then you likely want to steer well away from this device or at least ignore the manufacturer's recommendation that you use their cleaning solution.  Of course if you do that, well then the manufacturer will caution that you likely won't get the best results -- as if they have some magic ingredient that works that much better than any other cleaning solution that previously existed or may be invented in the future (gee, imagine that, what are we supposed to do if the manufacturer changes their formula in the future??)Besides the smell, there's also the noise that this gadget makes.  On the plus-side, if you happen to be older and getting into the hard-of-hearing territory you might not hear it as well and it may not aggravate you in that area.  For those that do hear well this device seems to do a great job of generating an abundance of noise as it tries to do the job it was designed for.  Admittedly, that problem may be one that varies depending on the luck of the buyer/user but from what I can see in checking around about this device it seems to be a common issue.This device is relatively easy to assemble, is relatively lightweight, and seems like something that could handle a need for many people, but the end result here seems to be clear: this version of this device needs more in-house (back at the manufacturer, not your house) testing and improvement before it is turned loose on the marketplace.  As it stands now, 2.5 stars would be a bit of a stretch, hence the 2 star rating that I've used here.  Thanks for the opportunity to try it as this easily could have been something I purchased and then wanted to return after it was initially used.

Worked just as I had hoped.I've previously acquired a  NOCO Battery Life BLSOLAR2 2.5 Watt Solar Battery Charger and Maintainer that I have used with my Suzuki Savage LS650 just to keep the battery charged or charge the battery back up a bit if it is a bit low.  That panel works well for me if I have plenty of time to let the battery charge back up.  Unfortunately my lack of patience got the better of me when I tried to let the battery on my Harley-Davidson Dyna charge back up.  For that bike leaving the Solar panel charger on the bike all day didn't make much headway.  A little I guess, but not enough to get back to being able to turn over the starter when I was trying to do so (so I could take advantage of some milder weather).After checking through several different options for this device, I opted for the 3.5A model.  Once I got it, even though it was still a fairly damp day, knowing that better weather was ahead, I went for it and quickly put this device into service.  I plugged it in and instantly saw the 25% indicator blinking.  Given that the already attached NOCO battery indicator was saying the same thing I knew I'd have to wait for the charge to complete.  Within a short period I checked back and found that the battery level was then showing 50%, and later blinking at the 75% level.  Not long after, woohoo!! 100%.Today I uncovered the Dyna, disconnected the charger and hit the starter.  It roared to life and made me very happy as I was able to take a nice little ride to shake off some of the winter dirt and dust.I'll certainly keep using the Solar charger as it works well when there's time to let it do so, but meanwhile I'm very happy with my purchase of this charger.

I've had several versions of this software over the years and generally found it does a reasonable job if expectations are set appropriately. For a do-it-yourselfer that has a fairly straight forward set of requirements this software works well.  On the other hand, if you have a lot of variables and variations away from the types of templates that this software uses and provides then the usefulness goes down and the need may quickly arise to visit an attorney and have them handle your affairs.Note that if you have a previous edition of this software you can likely get by with that version, though upgrading does help to address changes in laws that happen throughout the country.For the price point, this is easy to recommend and solidly falls into the 4 star range for me.  Easily recommended for others, though usability (for completion of creation of wills, etc.) certainly varies depending on individual needs.  [ In terms of usability for simply navigating the software, it works well and really isn't difficult to use at all ]

What, you don't think you can believe the subject line I've used for this product review?  Do I need to take pictures of the before and after to show you?  I suppose I could take pictures to show, but if I did that the before pictures might wind up with too much shine (from my balding spots) and could potentially blind people and the after pictures might seriously look like someone glued or stapled a wig or  toupée to the top of my head.  I kid, I kid.I was so eager to get this bottle of shampoo, as I really needed to do something about the thinning hair I have up there.  Sadly, like many men, as I've aged I've gotten hair growing in places that I don't want, and am not growing hair in places where I'd prefer.  While it isn't a George Costanza situation at this time, I definitely see more bare spots up there than I'd like.  Given that situation, and the description of what this product is intended to do, I was hopeful that it would help breathe new life into what hair I've still got on top of my head.On the serious side, I've used Head and Shoulders for quite a while, with 2-in-1 for dry hair.  That product includes conditioner within the shampoo, which may bother some but never gave me much of a second thought.  That product worked OK for me, though I have a feeling that old tales of using the same shampoo too often leads to build-up and lack of response/performance for the product and I often wind up using a different product to come along and get in one last lather and rinse.  Either way, that was good enough and seemed to give reasonable results -- except for the continuing loss of hair in spots where there had been some previously.  No, the shampoo wasn't burning away the hair follicles, it was just father time smacking me around and reminding me that I should consider myself lucky that I have not wound up as hairless as my grandfather on the maternal side was at this stage of my life.Having just started using this product, I have to be serious and say that no, there isn't a new forest of hair up there, at least not yet.  Nor, would I expect one to start growing there.  This isn't a hair growth product, rather it is a product that is supposed to clean and nourish your hair and make the hair that is there fuller and thicker.  (Hmm, I seem to recall a spray-on product that did something like that, but looked hideous when it was used ;-) )  As a cleaner, I think this version of H&S works fine.  The smell was a bit different and slightly less pleasant to me compared to the H&S product I had been using, but the clean feeling seemed to kick in at about the same point as the product I was previously using (Lather, Rinse, Repeat once).This comes, at least for the package that I got, as a pretty hefty supply of shampoo.  It would last me many showers worth, so I really can't complain and wouldn't complain about the price point.  You get a fair amount of shampoo for your money.In the end, if Head and Shoulders is a brand you trust, I think you'd be happy with this product (or perhaps the males in your life would be happy with this product as it is aimed primarily at males).  4 solid stars from this reviewer.

While some may look back at the Harley-Davidson #1 days with less than fond memories, the Red, White & Blue #1 with the Stars and Stripes makes me think of the days of Evel Knievel doing stunt jumps on his motorcycles (and his attempt to cross the canyon in the rocket style motorcycle).  (Others may remember this particular style of logo as the days when AMF was ruining their favorite motorcycle manufacturing company.)Regardless of your own particular thoughts of this logo, as a key chain, this one does a good job.  It has a nice feel and gives an impression of being something that will be durable.  I have minor concerns that the chain may break over time and drop the logo along the way (I've had that happen in the past with a Coca-Cola logo key chain), but I think this key chain will hold up fairly well.If the logo appearance is important to the buyer, I think buyers will be happy with this key chain.  It looks exactly as you see in the item picture, has a nice shine and doesn't have a cheap or rushed appearance in the logo, the lettering or the color areas (there is no bleed-over from one color area to the next, as an example).Given the typical H-D 'tax' one might expect to pay for officially logo'd or licensed products, this item comes in at a reasonable pricing level.  I've seen relatively cheap looking plastic logo items sell for nearly as much and know from experience that they don't last long as the paint on those wears off quickly.

This Netgear N300 Wi-Fi router comes in at a very budget friendly price point, priced inexpensively enough to quickly inspire questions as to why it is so relatively inexpensive.  For the most part, those questions could be ignored, though not completely so as in the end the old adage about getting what you paid for probably applies here.  Performance wise this router is OK at best, but slows quickly when trying to use more than a few devices at the same time.  Similarly, the wireless coverage areas that this router provides is not that impressive and someone that hopes to provide wireless connectivity to a whole home would likely be somewhat disappointed as I found myself being.3 stars for an OK router, but asking for anything more than just OK would likely lead to disappointment and a return trip to find a router that performs better with more devices in use, or a router that provides a more sizable coverage range for the wireless network.

This is a very nice and durable toy block set and as a nice bonus it includes a wooden box/tray to put the pieces back into - the only problem being that the pieces don't have form fitted trays within the wood box/tray to actually snap or sit back in, which leaves the high probability that the pieces aren't going to be put back as neatly as they otherwise might.  One solution that might work there is that parents can take a picture of the set before they take the blocks out of the case the first time, then at least there would be a picture to reference for what goes where in the box if you want it back the way it started out.  Alternatively, you can place the individual blocks into bags for storage and just ignore the wooden tray (or use the wooden tray as a base to stand the blocks up in).The recommended age for this set starts at 3 years and up.  I think that number is a bit conservative as this set is easily durable enough to work well for younger ages, though of course playtime should be supervised and you shouldn't give pieces that might be a choking hazard to small children.The picture book that is included is a very nice addition as it sets up the possibility of sharing the play experience with a youngster that is going to be playing with the blocks, whether that shared experience is between older siblings and younger siblings, or between parents and children.Nicely priced, and durable enough to last through several children's playtimes.  Easily 4 solid stars.

I requested this item as something that I hoped one of my favorite guest product tester/reviewers (my daughter) would put through the wringer.  She, having recently upgraded phones to an iPhone 6, had been a longtime user of Otter products (for her iPhone 5).  The Otter case that she used with her iPhone 5 saved that phone multiple times and given the durability of the cases she used, she was happy to continue to rely on Otter products for her new precious.  That said, she was also very willing to give this Speck case a try as she was growing tired of the bulkiness that the Otterbox that she had been using added to her phone.She noted that she really liked the sleekness of this product.  It is thinner and less bulky compared to the Otterbox and yet she felt that this case still offered a high level of protection for the phone it encases.  She liked the looks, clearly aimed at younger people with the bright colors.  If she had to make a choice between this case and an Otterbox, her opinion was that she'd be glad to consider this option.  If the difference in price wasn't that significant she would likely stick with Otter as she has known their products longer and has found them highly reliable.My own experience with Speck products goes back to products that I had back when I had an older iPhone.  I liked the Speck case that I had though I wouldn't have categorized it as being as protective as the Otterbox product that I later went on to use and depend upon.This one rates at a solid 4 star level.  It looks nice and is good at doing the job it is intended for.

This turntable looks great and makes me wish that I still had more of the albums that I used to have, though the turntables I had back in the day did more than enough damage to those albums to make me glad that I've switched primarily to digital versions of the music that I favor.Don't get me wrong, I like music on vinyl, but there were plenty of reasons to switch to digital and those reasons weren't just because of the scratches that would inevitably befall the music I had on vinyl platters.  On the other hand, I would also note that digital lacks something compared to vinyl.  There's just something about putting on a record and setting the needle down gently to play the material that is embedded there-in.  Yes, even with the pops and hiss that might be there.I love the looks of this item.  It is aesthetically pleasing and fits very nicely into the area where I reserved space for it. It really does seem like a work of art (sculpture style).Setup of this device was simple, and using this device is also very user friendly.  Really there's not much to not like about this turntable.  Not quite perfect, but really, really nice.  4 solid stars for me, and a big salute to TEAC for helping to keep vinyl alive.

This review has been prepared by a special guest reviewer.  My daughter, who has significantly more hair to be concerned with taking care of.  ( As I'm getting older the amount of hair I've got up there keeps dwindling, seemingly replaced with hair in other places :-/ )  While I could use this product, I really couldn't give it the kind of test that my daughter could, hence the bottle was handed to her to allow her to do her best (or worst) with.  Her comments follow:I hopped on the dry shampoo band wagon a couple years ago and have since been on the hunt for that one dry shampoo that does it all. You could rattle off a list of brand names (high end or drug store) and ask me if I've tried them, and my answer would probably be yes to all. Even with high end brands I've had the constant issue of that white, powdery residue being left behind.I've been a long time fan of aussie products however, so I was hoping this one wouldn't be a let down. Much to my relief, it wasn't. I sprayed a bit at my roots and gently massaged into my scalp like I would with normal shampoo. No white residue, no stickiness or greasiness. It left my hair soft and more voluminous. Only thing that may bother someone is the fact that it has a fruity scent, and it does linger throughout the day. For me personally, I'll take the artificial fruity scent if it means having a great time saver like this around.Summary: 4 - 5 star range depending on how much you might like the scent.

I like this product though I'd have to say that I'm not sure I'd really like to have to carry one of these items in my already overloaded bag of electronics and gadgets that travel with me.  It isn't that big, nor that heavy, but by the time I bag up the various chargers and adapters, along with the cables and then the actual devices, I wind up walking around with enough weight that I think carrying around a 16-pound bowling ball would be the easier task.This little gadget works for the task that is intended, though like another reviewer here noted, be careful not to jam it in too far lest you find yourself having trouble getting it out from under the door.One other thought with this gadget - I'd really like to hope that I wouldn't need something like this for most of my travels.  If I think the area I'm staying in isn't that safe and secure then I'd more likely check-out and move to a safer area.  I actually think I'd wind up with more use for this at home, but maybe that's just me.

By now you've likely seen a ton of negative reviews and/or comments noting that the makers of TurboTax have apparently gotten a little, well, greedy.  Features that used to exist in the Deluxe level now require upgrading to the Premiere level.  Depending on how much you complain you can probably find an inexpensive upgrade to get back the features you need, but in reality it seems that plenty of people got upset at having to pay more for what they used to get or having to complain to get those features back no matter what had to be done to do so.  I'm trying to be fair here in noting that for an average user, the features that were taken away from the Deluxe version of this software probably aren't needed, but average is a highly unpredictable thing and many people might find that they actually do need those missing features and now they are expected to pay more to get it or switch to a competing product.Realistically both products won't see serious use from me for a few more weeks.  Once employers make the earnings statements available I'll get to spend serious time working on returns and determining the good or bad news about the tax situation for my family.  While I hope for good news in that area, I'm also hopeful that Intuit will yet again learn the lessons of not upsetting their customer base.  We'll see about that in future years though, assuming I continue to willing to give them a chance.I would note that at least one competing product (the HR Block application, for example) seems to be making a serious push to take advantage of the possible mis-steps here by Intuit.  I can't say that I blame them as it surely seems to be a golden opportunity (some people might remember how "New Coke" helped Pepsi make inroads against their competition) handed to them.I suppose I could have come here and chewed Intuit a new one like others have, plopping a one-star review here and just moving on but I'd prefer to be honest in my review and note the issues that I have with the product rather than just dog-piling on here.I've been a user of TurboTax for many years now.  Long enough to remember more than just this current year's issues with the application and stupid things that Intuit has done.  (I remember a big fuss over the equivalent of a root-kit that was installed compliments of one year's version of the product.  Apparently current management doesn't remember that mistake as they make a similarly upsetting move with this year's product differences compared to last years :-/ )  Given this year's mis-steps, and some problems I had with last year's product, I'm not sure I would remain a TurboTax user.  I seriously had intended to switch to a competing product this year (that earlier mentioned HR Block software, already purchased as part of an Amazon Gold Box deal not so long ago).  I felt forced into using that product last year (and I did buy it last year) as I had issues with a never fixed 'bug' in last year's TurboTax software.  While last year's taxes were a little more complex for my family than a typical year, they shouldn't have been that confusing and yet last year TurboTax caused me a lot of grief with my state tax filings and in the end caused a serious delay in getting the refund I was due.I hope this year's version is better in that area but won't know for sure until a few weeks from now when I have all of the required paperwork in hand.  Given that I have both the HR Block product for this year and the copy of this year's TurboTax product to double check things with, I am pretty sure I'll be able to e-file this season without issue as one product or another will work for me I'm sure.I have installed both products and have a couple of thoughts about both that I'll put here.  Both products irritated me a bit as they both wanted my personal information for product registration and/or activation (HR Block wants an activation code to be entered).  Neither product was smart enough to actually look for last year's tax return files to grab my personal information from to pre-fill that information out.  Given that a few steps later in the process the applications both read last year's returns and import personal information from same it seems both could make a little more effort to save customers time in that area.  I can note that the Block product didn't ask the questions about what product I used last year and/or where I purchased my products from.  It really doesn't take long to complete the information but it bugs me that I have to sit and type in information that is there for the taking if the apps used a smarter process for starting up.

When I requested this device I noted that it discussed both Apple iOS and Android (it's even part of the item title).  When I received the device I had to do a double check as the package that I received doesn't discuss Android at all.  There's plenty of mention of iOS and/or the Apple App store, but not a single logo on the package for Android, the Google Play store, or anything else android related.I can go to www.getqardio.com/devices to get a list of devices that I can use this item with and yes, it lists my Samsung Galaxy smart phone among the devices that I can use it with, but that list of devices is definitely shallow.
