I can understand not having had the time to get every possible Android device tested and I can even understand that some of the requirements may limit their list of supported devices due to newer Bluetooth features that might not exist in older Android devices, but I'm left with the thought that perhaps the company should be aiming at two different but very similar devices - one that is sold for iOS users and one that is sold for Android users; each with separate packaging and marketing.Beyond those issues, this is an interesting device.  I like the idea of being able to record information that can be used to check for patterns and patient history.  I can certainly see where that could be very useful for anyone that should be tracking their blood pressure on a regular basis (and even if you haven't been told to do so, it is still a great idea to check your blood pressure regularly).This device looks nice, ships in a nice little paper/cardboard can package, and comes with a manual and single sheet quick start/introduction to the device.  The quick start page uses color headlines that I suspect were supposed to be printed in the same color within the manual.  Apparently someone opted to print the manuals without color (except for the cover page) and that seems to have resulted in several spots within the manual being harder to read as the gray scale printing for the original color is light and harder to see than it otherwise would have been.Please realize that I'm seeing what might be a pre-release item and as such you may not find the same issues with a purchased product.This item falls into solid 3 star territory for me.  It is nice but has room for improvement that I expect will happen over time.

A small pet peeve for me is when manufacturers use the same manual for multiple devices but then don't have the manuals clearly point out all of the differences between the devices... so, you wind up wondering how something was supposed to be rather than being able to clearly find out from looking at the instructions.  Realistically, I'm a guy, and as a guy, well, I don't want to lose my guy card by having to read instructions but there are times when having a line or two of instructions or a picture or two worth can go a long way to putting things together correctly.In the case of this device, assembly was fairly simple and for the most part I didn't feel as if I had to check the instructions at all, except, well, to confirm that I didn't need to put in any screws or bolts to hold things together.  Since I hadn't found any of those items as I unboxed this beast, it was a pretty safe assumption that none should be needed, but then again when you are literally snapping things together you question a bit as to whether or not there should be something locking the connected pieces into place.  Even without screws, pins, bolts or other items to lock the pieces together, this Upright Vacuum feels sturdy enough for use just about anywhere in the manufacturer's intended target areas.With assembly issues discussed, it's time to move on and ask the question of how well this vacuum works to pull up dirt, fuzz, hair and other things from your floors or other target areas.  The manufacturer states that this device works better than a competitors products do.  I'm not sure they are wrong in making that boast, though I'd have to see some objective measurement that backs up that claim.  Truth be told, I expect either manufacturer could put together a test that shows their product bests the other, leaving the performance area pretty much a tie.One thought from my own personal preferences is that I wish that the cord and retractor were higher up in the upper portion of the device.  I prefer to have the cord well up and out of the way as I vacuum.  With this device the cord is mounted fairly lowly in the upright portion of the device and that tends to have the cord in an area that annoys me as it feels like I'm being tied up by the cord as I go through the home vacuuming up the floors.4 solid stars as this device seems to be not quite perfect, but yet very nice, for use around my home.

I was super excited about this product when it was initially going to be a project at one of the large crowd funding sites.  I loved the idea of how it would work and really liked the thought that it would just plain work and not require myself or others in the household to remember to change the magnetic sign that we hang on the door or pay attention to the light that shows that the dishes were washed (as soon as someone opens the door to the dishwasher that light goes out, so it isn't reliable if someone doesn't put the dishes away after opening the door).The problem that keeps me from giving this five stars is that this little gadget is a bit touchy about placement within the dishwasher and for some potential users it may keep this from being a usable solution at all.  Basically the gadget needs to be placed somewhere it will get covered with plenty of water.  Without enough water to float the indicator there's no way to get the gadget to register at all, so if you over-fill your dishwasher or if your dishwasher is super-efficient and doesn't use much water you may find that you aren't able to use this gadget at all.During the first few weeks of use in my household we had mixed results.  It was a little frustrating given the hope and faith I was wanting to place in this gadget.  I contacted the manufacturer/inventor and got some feedback that mentioned the placement of the gadget and how important it is to get a lot of water flow in and immediately around the device.  The suggestions pointed me in the right direction for making it work more reliably, though I would note that given my spousal units propensity to crowd things into the dishwasher and possibly block things a bit from larger objects placed in front of smaller ones, it hasn't been that easy to find a spot to place this gadget that works 100% of the time.

Small, but not really all that light (which affects portability) { side note: it seems a little odd to complain about weight and portability for a device that only weighs a few pounds, especially from someone (me) that remembers the older days of 'luggable' computers that weighed well more than a typical bowling ball would, but this is the world we now live in.  If it weighs more than a few ounces it gives us pause and we get distracted by how much something weighs and complain about it. }Sound quality is acceptable for my taste, but not so impressive to make me love this product.  For the price point that this product is sitting at, I think many people might expect better sound quality and may find themselves a bit disappointed.Build quality seems good, appearance is acceptable as an accessory that will be sitting out in your environment somewhere within range of whatever device you are using to stream content from.Pairing the device is very easy and should not cause problems for most typical users.  Realistically, if you can't figure out how to pair this device then you really must be technologically challenged.Power supply issues may confuse some users.  Don't assume that this device can be charged from any potential charger.  It is apparently power hungry and may not charge at all if you aren't using the charger that it comes with.  While other chargers may work in its place, you will likely find that using an alternate charger may not feed this thing enough juice to actually charge it up.  Given that this device can be used to charge other devices (such as a smart phone) from its own USB port, it kind of makes sense that it might take a bit more power to actually charge it up.  Mark the power supply if possible and keep it where you can find it if you intend to use this device frequently.Note this is a mono and not a stereo output device.  You can use more than one to get stereo sound, but that would obviously double the cost which could get awfully spendy given this device's own price point.

I'd just about give my right arm to be able to use half stars in the ratings here, as this isn't quite a 4 star item for me, but then again it is better than 3 stars.  What keeps it from being more solidly in the 4 star territory?  The idea that it just doesn't wow me that much more than a less expensive sister product in the Brother label maker line.Back over the spring/summer of this past year I picked up a similar product, also made by Brother, from one of the large office product retail chain (immediate need and sale pricing won out over purchasing from my favored retailer :-( though this favored retailer won out when I requested purchase of two of the same device for use in the office).  The version that I had picked up wasn't PC connectable so it didn't offer any of those features, but as a basic label maker it worked well and was considerably less expensive compared to this model.This model is nice, and if I considered the 'suggested retail price point' for this model and that one, there isn't that much difference between the two and realistically I'd probably say spend the extra just in case you do want the PC Connectable features later, but... well, the PC Connectible features may not add that much for most users and with that considered it probably makes the less spendy versions a better fit.In either case expect to wind up paying for the label tape as you'll find it doesn't last long at all.  About the time you get started labeling the things you want to you'll find the tape gone and the job only half done (if that).  In other words, buy additional tape at time of purchase.  You'll need it.

I noted in the subject for this review that these are value priced but not necessarily a better value than other choices.  I reached that conclusion by comparing these against a set of Sony headphones that I recently over-paid for (not really, they were priced similarly to these headphones) back when I was travelling on vacation with my daughter.  Having forgotten to grab a set of headphones or earphones before reaching the airport I wanted something that would be comfortable for use on the plane and having a preference for over the ear rather than in the ear the Sony headphones that I picked up were the only somewhat reasonably priced choice I had (outside of grabbing some cheap earbuds).In any case, I did use those Sony headphones for the duration of the trip and they worked well but weren't really what I would term high quality for sound and comfort.  They were fairly basic and probably should have been sold for about 1/3 less than what the airport vendor was charging for them, which is about 1/3 less than what this set of Pioneer Headphones seems to go for here at Amazon.Compared to those Sony headphones, this set of headphones is more comfortable for my taste, but still could be better and more comfortable.  Sound quality wise, these sound OK to me, but didn't wow me as much as I might have hoped for.  Not bad, but not so impressive either.  Factoring in the price point, I'd say they deliver what I might expect but not much more.In the end, I'd put these in the 3.5 star territory.  Good, solid, value priced, but not something I would necessarily consider my be-all, end-all headphone set.

This is going to be one of those times when some people will look at my Vine Review badge and probably figure that I was looking a gift horse in the mouth as this review isn't as favorable as some might expect (given that yes, I am review 'free' product that was provided by the vendor).While I don't want to be too negative (I try to be optimistic), there are a few things with this item that cause me to drop the rating and urge caution for any potential purchaser.  First up, I have to say that the directions that are included are somewhat sparse.  Yes, I would admit and acknowledge that if you visit the manufacturer's website, or especially if YOU search for that TUBE site where you can find so darned many videos that you'll probably find some very useful and helpful videos that are meant to teach a beginner how to use this item.  I appreciate the existence of the videos but found them to be a bit too simplistic as they skip over some things and just presume or assume that the viewer will put things together enough to get through the steps as easily as the person who was making the videos had.Normally I lean on my guy-card credentials and try to take the approach that instructions are for the weak, but this device and its controls are far from simplistic enough to just jump in and start flying (though I would admit that I did try taking that approach just to see what the results might be, and no, those results and the frustration from that approach aren't why I'm giving this middle-of-the-road rating to this device).I think a novice can learn how to work with this device, but in demonstrating it and working with it while around friends, we each came to the conclusion that it doesn't work nearly as easily as we might hope or expect.  Now, with that said, the fact that it 'takes off' and hovers in place puts it well ahead of some other RC copters and drone type devices that I have had in the past.  My frustrations with them often stemming from the fact that they don't work nearly as well as the demonstration units that one would see while walking through the mall areas ever do.Once the drone is flying, my own opinion, and that of the friends that were testing it with me, is that the controls for forward and back motion are slow to respond to.  While I appreciate caution in such things, the delay in the response means users like me wind up giving the drone the commands to fly forward more frequently than we should and the device winds up slamming into a wall or flying farther or backwards compared to where the pilot would expect it to go.  More responsiveness would be useful for sure.A few suggestions for the manufacturers: update your documentation to make the links to your website nice and bold.  Direct people to the website for clear step-by-step instructions on how to update the firmware, and how to start using the device.  Add the same website link to the box the device is shipped in as well just to make the point that a purchaser should start there.Additionally, it would be nice if the manufacturer included a spare blade or two in the package.  I appreciate that spare parts can be purchased from the manufacturer, and it is nice that they are easily replaced.  They do seem fairly durable, and yet not indestructible, hence the idea that a spare or two would be nice to have.  The body of the drone is durable as are the the legs and frame that the motors and blades are on.  The large wheels that are included with this rolling spider also seem fairly durable based on my own testing, though the blades can impact things and get bent up and damaged even if the wheels are on the drone.In the end I think this is a nice device, but it is not a toy and is not something that I would expect to be durable enough to be played with by younger persons who may not work with one as cautiously as would be required with this device.

At first thought, this was a 'woohoo! a Star Wars version of Army men', but upon closer inspection and further investigation, I'm not sure this set and others in the same series are really all that great.  Oh, for a Star Wars collector/fan, certainly there is value added, but as a toy with long term playability, in that area I'm really not so sure.It is cool to think that you have a remote control to 'use the force' to knock down the figures with, but the remote control works OK at best, and could be frustrating for kids to figure out.  Think of it in the same manner you might think of the old vibrating electronic football sets where you were happy to see movement of some sort but couldn't count on that movement playing out in the manner you wished for.  While that may lead some to use more imagination and perhaps to being an opportunity to be an optimist in how this set works, I think reality is more on the side of this being something that gets played with a little and then somewhat cast to the side just because it is almost too much work to use in the manner it was intended.Having multiple sets with different ships and figures available is very nice, and having any of those items relatively reasonably priced is also nice, but buying more than a few sets can start adding up the costs quickly and again just how much playability can be had from any of these sets?  That really depends on the imagination and patience levels of the kids you give the sets to.

I was so close to giving this the 4 star rating, but in reality the only reason I might knock a star off for this item is because of how heavy it is, which in reality is far more of a plus rather than a minus.  The weight is an issue for lugging it around and getting it ready to install in a vehicle, but once installed it should pretty much remain in place and from that point on the weight factors in just how sturdy and durable this item is.  It is made to last and the quality shines through.  While I can't promise I'd be back later to confirm that it really did last the touted 12 years, I suspect strongly that I could come back in 12 years and say positively that it really did last that long and would likely still have years of service left if someone really wanted to use it.  (Note: I would not recommend trying to use it beyond the rated life cycle as some materials do wear with time and the crash protection level could be compromised if used beyond the intended life span)This convertible booster seat delivers on its promises and is a very, very nice child safety seat.  It is, as one more potential, a little spendy but when it comes to safety for your children and/or loved ones (for those buying for grandchildren, or nieces or nephews, etc.) can you really put a price on safety?It is very comforting to know that when the youngsters in our family are being driven around that they are going to be comfortable and well protected while in this booster.  While my generation may have survived standing up on the back seat, leaning over the front bench seat screaming in our parents ears as we demanded to know 'are we there yet?', taking those sorts of chances with our children or our children's children is not recommended.Lots of other options exist within the market space for this item, and many of them are far less spendy, but they may not last nearly as long and/or my not be nearly as durable as this item is.  They all are made with the goal of protecting the occupant in case of a crash, but the materials and construction for many of the other options are just not nearly as nice as what Diono has delivered here.  That doesn't mean I wouldn't recommend one of the other options, it just means that given the choice, I would be happy to have this Diono seat or happy to see it used by anyone that I knew needed one.

This product is OK, but I just can't get myself much more excited about it.  It works as intended, in most cases, but it may come at the expense of blocking the air flow coming out of the vent that you attach it to.  It is nice that it allows the phone device that it is holding to be easily rotated, and it opens relatively wide so it will hold a good sized phone device (such as a Samsung Galaxy S5, my phone device of choice), but it doesn't wow me to the point of giving more than a 3 star rating.  It isn't bad, and some people might find it a great solution for their own application/usage.  If so, great for them.  3 solid stars from me.

Fun to build, though it can be a little frustrating trying to assemble in spots as things are more fragile at times then you might want to encounter.  Not terribly fragile, but enough that you might find yourself frustrated trying to get some pieces together without having other pieces knocked off.  If you are cautious and patient (not always a trait that I'm personally good with ;-) ) then it really isn't that bad, though noticeable enough that I felt it worthy of mention here.The finished product looks pretty cool and does remind me, as a player of the videogame that provided the inspiration, of the videogame.  It also provides a cool item for someone interested in the space program (who may not even care about the videogame) to build and display, though of course it is based entirely on a fictitious space weapons system, not on any real (at least not that we know of) satellite in the known U.S. space fleet.4 solid stars.

I can't help but think of say the baby that used to advertise for a certain stock market buying/selling/trading company, standing up, holding onto the side, and perhaps doing one of those old fashioned "Let me out of here!!!" chants while standing in this play yard.  About as soon as I think that though, I think wow, if that was truly the situation, I'd feel a bit sorry for the toddler and the relatively small space it was confined in.This is a nice play yard, but it is not terribly big.  The trade-off has already been made in making this particular play yard smaller, more portable, and lighter and easier to carry than one that would be bigger.  For a single baby, this would be OK, and mothers that want something smaller and lighter will certainly be happy, but if you have more than one child you might think of using this with, then please look elsewhere.

If not for the form factor this might be close to 5 stars from me.  It works well, doesn't look that bad in the white color, but the form factor that was chosen that makes it inconvenient to even consider using anywhere you can't find the room for it to stand up as it was designed for winds up costing this device a bit in my book.  While some might point at me and say the problem is mine, and that I should just reconsider where I would place the device, things aren't always so simple.  The location that I had been using a different router in is one that was on the shelf right below my TV.  If I were to place this device into the same space that was so nicely used before, I'd wind up with the antennas sitting up blocking part of the lower part of the TV screen.  Trying to place the device on a lower shelf isn't much better as the clearance height on the lower shelves is a bit lower and not to easy to place this device in.Beyond the form factor issue, this is a solid product.  The Wi-Fi signal that it delivers is good.  Not necessarily great, but solid in comparison to other routers that I've used in the home.  Wired Gigabit speed is a must have for me, and this router delivers solidly in that area.  The availability of a 'Guest' network is also really nice and can help alleviate concerns that someone that comes into your home could be gaining more access to your network than you would otherwise want to allow.The manual could use a bit more work and shows room for improvement, but the materials that are provided in the box and/or found at the manufacturer's web site are sufficient for most users to find what they need in.  If I had to note the expected user level for this item, I would go with novice or above, and not necessarily beginner.  While anyone should be able to use this router and get it working, a true beginner might find the setup process a bit more technically confusing with this product than other options that are available.

I've previously gotten plastic shelf liners that I'm still using several cabinets.  I liked those particular plastic liners because they featured ridges and troughs that let any moisture that might have remained on dishes that were being put away collect without worrying about possibly damaging the shelves.  The cost on those liners seemed comparable to these, and the ease of cutting those liners was similar since the ridges worked well for providing guides and cut lines.These liners definitely have an advantage in cutting them to fit since the pattern on them offers cutting guides in almost any direction you'd care to use.  They are also easily machine washable compared to the plastic liners where you must wipe them down or scrub them by hand (with a brush, sponge or similar cleaning tool).For me, these are nice, functional and reliable shelf liners.  Not really something that I'd normally get overly excited about, but definitely something that I appreciate having around.(I would note my excitement level for these might be a bit higher were it not for the idea that the installation of these liners may lead to a long list of honey-do items being brought along for the ride ;-)  That whole 'while we're doing this, how about we go ahead and get this done too' type thing :-/ )

It's somewhat ironic that this showed up for me as an Amazon Vine offering *after* I had already ordered and received a 'Premium Value pack' version of this same product, along with a host of additional items including the Guardians of the Galaxy play set and a few extra figurines and power discs.  I was, obviously, all-in on Infinity 2.0, though I hadn't let myself get pulled into the Infinity world back in the 1.0 version other than to collect a couple of the figurines.Disney Infinity, even in that earlier rendition, was somewhat ingenious (one of my friends and I were using the word devious) in how it appeals on so many levels.  Disney collectors can collect the figures just to display while others may be collecting the figures both for use in the game and for display and collecting.  Throw in the power discs and the play sets that offer new areas to play in and the appeal broadens further, and beyond that there's the Toy box mode for even more appeal and potential gaming satisfaction.This starter pack offers gamers what they would need to get started in Disney Infinity 2.0's Marvel environment.  3 of the now infamous Marvel heroes are included: Thor, Ironman, and Black Widow.  Each nicely done though missing one key aspect that some collectors might look for as they are not movable (non-articulated) in their poses.  They are not exactly like their movie representations, but are close enough to both the movies and the comics to be instantly recognizable.For those that aren't familiar with the Disney Infinity environment, the figures double as your playing piece for use in the video game environment.  Players pick one of the figures to use to select that character within the gaming environment and then place that figure on the Infinity base which is connected to the gaming console.  The Infinity base reads electronics that are in the base of the figure (or in the power discs) to determine which character should be used as which player in the game, or which additional options should be available to that player within the game.  The Infinity base has two separate player slots on it, and a third spot for where the play set activator goes.  The play set activator determines where the players will be playing, or which story the players will be working within.With the 2.0 series, the Marvel Super Heroes move into the spotlight, along with the Guardians of the Galaxy.  More play sets will be available along the way as each play set offers yet more playability to gamers and also offers Disney the opportunity to sell more of the collectible figures.  With the 1.0 series Infinity seemed to be oriented much more towards younger children while the 2.0 series opens up lots of possibility for (Marvel) comics fanboys (and girls) of all ages.Fans of the comic book characters get to explore the environment and smash, bash, blast and shoot bad guys as they work to save the universe from the evil that would otherwise rule.  The only real problem in that area, and one that helps lead to the less than 5 star rating here, is that the play set environments and stories are fairly short.  Serious gamers will fly through (no pun intended there) the play set within a 4 - 5 hour period in many cases and then be left feeling that they got ripped off a little on the game playability.  Having other play sets available helps to eliminate that problem, but those play sets typically come at a cost of approximately 1/2 of the price of the original starter pack.  (Of course the play sets also include additional figures which would normally sell separately for about 1/2 the cost of a play set)Fans of the Disney Infinity 1.0 series, or people that had collected the figures and play sets will find that they can use the figures within the toy box mode when playing in the Infinity 2.0 environment.  The play sets from 1.0 are not compatible with 2.0, and the figures and play sets from 2.0 are not backwards compatible with the 1.0 environment.  In some instances the 2.0 figures may not be completely cross compatible with all of the play sets (as an example, the Hulk character can't be used in all of the 2.0 play sets, and the Rocket character from Guardians doesn't work in all environments either).For those that aren't aware, there is a Collector's edition (PlayStation 3 or 4 only) that adds a display base.  That display base is NOT used within the game, rather it just offers a nice base to display your figures on.  That set also includes the otherwise as yet unavailable (outside of auctions and third party sales) Hulk figure.  That figure will be available for separate sale late October 2014.One other consideration that comes into mind is that in order to use this item you'll need to have room for setting the Infinity base up and will also need a USB port available on your PS4 (also compatible with the PS3, though then you'd need the software for same) to plug your base into.  If you are space constrained in the area where your console is set up, you may find it frustrating having to plug the Infinity base in.  You can plug the base into a USB hub if you want/need to, but that would add the need to purchase same (separately).Besides the somewhat disappointing play set average game times, the cost of buying the power discs and figures and/or the pre-arranged packages of figures that don't always include the combination of characters you might otherwise have preferred factors into the not quite perfect 5.0 rating here.  I do like being able to mix and match by getting separate figures and play sets, but those costs do keep adding up.  In the end, this sits squarely in the 4 star range.

I have to snicker a bit as I read the note that Amazon is showing me about this item not fitting my Harley Dyna Super Glide.  Uh, really?  I have it mounted there already and had no problems at all mounting it there (well, except that I stripped the bolt and then wound up breaking the one that came with this pedal pad and instead had to use the one from the old pedal pad that was being replaced).Of course the reason it fits so nicely may be that the prior owner had gotten several upgrades done on the bike when he owned it, including several Kuryakyn components (including the smaller version of this brake pedal pad).  My only real complaint about these pedal pads is that part of the reason that I was replacing this pedal pad is because one of the rubber pads on the original pedal pad was lost just a few days back.  I'm not sure what happened to that rubber pad other than the glue and sticky material that was holding it just wearing out, but the missing piece sent me here to find a replacement pedal pad.  Since I was doing the replacement, I opted to add this Longhorn version which adds more surface area to the brake pedal for my big feet to more easily hit.I like the looks of this Brake Pedal pad, and prior to having lost one of the rubber pads from the old ISO Brake Pedal Pad, had really liked the one that was on the bike previously.  It was not terribly spendy and it does make a pretty nice customization for any bike.  Not quite perfect, but relatively nice.  4 stars.

If not for the fact that I lost one of the rubber pads from this shifter peg within a short period of time from having installed it on my Harley, I would likely give this shift peg a higher rating.  I like the looks, though not having been the original owner of my Harley, I have to admit that the Kuryakyn mods were chosen by the prior owner so I was just replacing the same basic item with a newer one (which I had to replace after laying the bike down back in the spring).Replacing this shift peg is a simple enough task, and I like the Longhorn peg for the extra length which leaves it easier to maneuver my big feet on.  I also like that I could find replacement pads for this shift peg after I did lose one as that saved me from having to buy yet another shift peg.  Finally, I like the fairly reasonable cost for this replacement shift peg.  If the pads were stuck on the peg with some adhesive before the item was packaged, I think it would be a higher rated product for me.  As is, I would recommend getting some Gorilla Glue super glue or something similar to use to make sure the pads adhere to the peg; otherwise expect to need to purchase some replacement pads sooner rather than later.

I'm a bit irritated at having to buy these replacement rubber pads, though I'm glad that they were available so I didn't have to (instead) buy a new shifter peg since I had only recently purchased the one that I wound up buying these pads for.  Replacing the missing pad was easy enough, though I chose to combine one of these replacement pads with some Gorilla Glue (super glue) that I hope will keep the newly replaced pad in place for a long time.  I did take the precaution of wiping down the shifter peg good before hitting it with the Gorilla Glue, then placed the new pad in place.The new pad isn't as worn as the pads that have been in place over the last several weeks, so it isn't as weather faded.  It doesn't look bad, but the better recommendation would likely be to replace all of the pads at the same time if you are concerned about keeping the pads well matched.I can say that the pads that have stayed on the shifter (and had stayed on the brake pedal) have held up well, though I also wound up ordering a new brake pedal after losing one of the pads on it at about the same time I lost the pad on the shifter peg.

This is a cute toy, with bright colors that instantly draw your eyes to it, and it also offers up the promise that it can be played with on both wet or dry surfaces, but the reality is running it in water will leave users a bit frustrated because it tends not to be driven/powered in any sort of controllable fashion.  While the marketing materials and blurbs on the box say it will work in water, work is just not the term that I would use here.  More like it will run while in water, but not be steerable or powered well enough to control well once it is sitting in water.  Riding it through a puddle where the wheels can still touch the bottom and get traction is fine (though it will catch water in the toy that would eventually need to be dumped out).  Riding it through sand and dirt would likely result in the dirt being pulled into the toy and eventually fouling up the toy for future use.Controls are not quite as intuitive as one would hope.  It is hard to describe other than to say that even with practice, controlling this toy will be a bit of a challenge.  Kids will have to be patient (and how often is that happening?!? ;-) ) as they try to make the toy go the way they want.  Young children may not care, older children may be frustrated by the lack of control, and older children (approaching teenage) would likely look at this toy and think it is more for younger children.If used primarily indoors, I think this might last a good while.  Taken indoors and outdoors, I'd expect it to break down faster than purchasers might like.  3 middle of the road stars for this toy.

My step-daughter recently had to give up her nasal spray habit and lay off all of the allergy meds she'd be taking as she and her mother (wife 2.0) went off to get updated testing for allergies done.  The allergist required a week of no use of allergy meds (or at least no meds that included antihistamines) and that was leaving my step-daughter a bit frustrated as her breathing was impacted, along with the extra itchiness and irritants to her skin and eyes that was floating in the air.Now, I must admit to being a little less sympathetic towards her allergies considering she seems to pour an abundance of perfumes and chemical smells on herself, or light up enough candles to light up a minor ballpark just because she likes the scents; meanwhile her mother gets a whiff of any of the above and nearly has an asthma attack due to those irritants.  Of course mom's health doesn't really matter as the personal satisfaction of smelling like you have something to hide is more important don't you know?In any case, about the time that the allergy testing and week of no meds was hitting this little device arrived from Amazon and was instantly deployed into step-daughter's room.  The size of the room is about perfect for the stated capacity and ability of this device.  Step-daughter loves the fact that it has a timer function so she can set it up for use for a few hours as she goes to bed.  Her mother and I like the fact that it does take a lot of contaminants out of the air.  It can't quite combat the burning candles (or at least we still get plenty of exposure to same when they are burning and the step-daughter's bedroom door is open), but that likely has more to do with the sheer numbers of candles she might light up at a given moment.This device is a bit spendy, but it does seem to work well.  It might wind up helping to break the step-child of the nasal spray habit and if so that would be a great thing.  Of course getting rid of the perfumes and other irritants would be the real answer, but that will continue to go unrecognized no matter how much us old folks try to convince the younger generation that we do actually know best.

Remember that old saying about if you can't say anything nice?  Uh, yeah, I might be able to stop this review right about here :/I like the idea of this toy and thought it would be cool for fanboys of the Titanfall game to be able to build their own Titan for display, but if you want something to display, you'll need to look around for something other than this frustratingly fragile model.While it is possible to build the model, it is also possible you'll be spending just as much time putting things back together as you did putting them together to begin with, all while trying to assemble the next part of the model.  Just as you put one piece in place, another one you had already put together will come apart and you'll end up cursing this thing more than appreciating it.Nice try, but just not something that most kids would get satisfaction from.  2 generous stars, but really that is a reach.

When my internet friends and acquaintances were raving on and on about their support of some Kickstarter project for the PowerCube I was otherwise engaged, uh, distracted, uh, cash strapped and feeling a little let down by having supported some other projects that were delayed and seemingly never coming to fruition.  If I had the funds available, I'm still not sure I would have been a supporter of the project as I just couldn't see that much need for yet another extension cord/power strip in the house.  I have plenty of devices that need to be plugged in, and I have definitely gone out of my way to pick up strips that had plenty of room between the various outlet ports so I could plug in the necessary wall-warts without blocking ports I would eventually wind up needing.One of the more recent power strips that I had gotten was similar to this: Belkin 12 Outlet Home/Office Surge Protector with Telephone and Coaxial Protection (except the one that I had picked up at the local home improvement store also included USB power ports).  That strip was used for the area where my daughter's desktop PC was setup at.  She made use of the USB ports to charge her fruity phone device or her music playing pod device.  It was nice that in doing that she was able to keep some of the otherwise likely used power ports so she could plug in other devices and a/c adapters for charging up some other things as well.That power strip was/is nice, but it eats up a fair amount of floor or desk space as compared to this compact PowerCube device.  Yes it offers up several additional outlets compared to this PowerCube, but given the well-designed modular nature of the PowerCubes, that can be resolved fairly easily (though at additional costs as you add those other PowerCube modules/devices).While I can't discount the use of the larger power strips, I do really like the PowerCube.  I think it works well and do think that the designers delivered on their vision and promises.  If you need a power strip, give the PowerCube serious consideration.  It deserves the 5 stars that I'm giving it here.

On my metric bike (an older Suzuki LS model), I had the luxury of having an official manufacturer's toolbag/kit available.  While the toolkit wasn't with that bike at the point I got the bike (used), it was easy enough to find a new replacement set via internet ordering.  With that set and that bike the toolkit has its own area of reserved space on the bike where the toolbag is supposed to be kept.My Harley Dyna doesn't offer up the reserved space, and didn't come with a toolbag/toolkit at all.  With that bike I wanted a set similar to the useful but not too big/heavy toolkit that I had for the Suzuki.  That's where this set comes in nicely.  Since I have saddlebags behind me with plenty of room in the bottom of same, putting a set of these tools (in their nice storage bag) in a semi-permanent home in the saddlebags is an easy enough task.This isn't a set of every tool you'd ever possibly need, but it does include the most frequently used/needed tools and sizes for the wrenches so *most* issues that might require having a set of tools handy can be dealt with even if you were stuck out on the road to nowhere.  Definitely not a substitute for a good roadside assistance program (check with your insurance agent/providers as many may offer such coverage), but for those that know how to turn a wrench or use a screwdriver, it might help get you back on the road a little quicker.

These have got to be some of the most comfortable boxers I have owned. Very nice. Soft. They are a skin-tight fit, which might not suit some people. The fabric is so nice and soft, that I enjoy the tight fit, whereas with some boxes/underpants I just find it constrictive.I primarily bought these because they are organic cotton. I figure it's best to keep my family jewels in toxin free fabrics, since they hang out in there all day.

Very nice. These pants have a lovely soft finish to the fabric. Like brushed cotton, I suppose. Doesn't look fluffy, but feels fluffy soft. Super comfy.They have a great cut, making them easy to move around in, and very comfortable for lounging and for activities. The elastic at the hems (bottom of the legs) are handy. Not tight (which I wouldn't like) but enough to stop them falling over my shoes and potentially dragging on the ground.The draw string has a nice feature I've not come across before. It actually crosses over at the front (inside the waistband) so when tying it into a bow you just make a bow without first tying a cross-over. Not sure how to explain that, but normally tying a bow requires two steps. One to cross the chords over, and the next to actually form the bow. Because they are already crossed over inside the waistband, you just do step two. Quick and easy. A simple touch, yet it shows the designers of these are actually thinking about how to make their product better.

Excellent price. Seem like good quality. As good as any other organic chia seeds I have tried (many, over the years).The company has a good vibe to it, and I see they donate 1% of their profits to charity. Not much, but a note-worthy gesture on their part. I bought 2x 1lb bags, and I am part-way through the second bag. All good. Will buy again.I have no hesitation recommending this chia seed product to others. I am not yet familiar with the many other products TruVibe offer, but intend to try more of them out.

I've written many Amazon reviews, and it's quit rare for me to not recommend what I am writing about. Mostly because I do a lot of research before buying things, and I typically end up with exactly what I require. Not so with this HomeSpot Bluetooth Audio receiver.I've had no end of trouble with it on Apple devices. I've tried it with:* iPhone 5* iPhone 6* MacBook Pro 17" (mid 2010)* MacBook Air 11" (latest)In my experience, it's been a pain in the proverbial arse on all of these Apple devices. It refuses to connect with the MBP. It is fickle with connecting (and staying connected) with the iPhones. Each time I try to connect the iPhones, I typically I have delete the connection/pairing every time, and then repair them. That in itself can be tricky, but at least it tends to stay connected until I terminate the connection. But to then reconnect, again I'll have to remove the pairing completely from the iPhone, and start from scratch. The MacBook Air has better luck, but not 100% success.I also have a Nexus 4 and a Samsung Galaxy Tab Pro 8. I have better success with these devices. It should be noted that both are running Cyanogenmod (non-stock android). They connect and play fairly decently. So, based on my experience, I'd say this device has decent compatibility with Android devices, and very questionable compatibility with Apple devices.If it was just on my Apple MacBookPro I experience these issues, I might be inclined to think it's the computer that's at fault. That's actually the only Apple device I own, and I was tending toward blaming the MacBookPro. But>> AlternativesI also have experience with the Brightech - BrightPlay Home HDTM Bluetooth 4.0 Music Receiver / Adapter with apt-X Technology for CD Quality Sound. I set a family member up with one. It has worked well with my MBP, and their iPad and iPhone 6. I would have bought the same one for myself, but since the HomeSpot was a little cheaper and had great reviews I figured I'd try it out. Also, I liked the idea of the device not having to be located right at a power point. The BrightPlay sits in the powerpoint (I suppose one could use an extension lead to reposition it), whilst the HomeSpot powers-up via a USB cable. This gives more flexibility as to where it is positioned.>> Conclusion...I would not buy it again, and would return it if I could (too late for that though). I am now looking for a better device, and also considering WiFi audio streaming instead (such as the Sabrent WiFi Audio Receiver). I see plenty of other people who are very happy with this device (which is why I ordered it), so there's a good chance your experience with it will be better than mine. If you buy it, I'd suggest giving it a thorough work-out in the first couple of weeks, on as many different devices and usage scenarios (such as distance from device) as you can. That way, if you're happy with it, great. But if not, you can make use of Amazon's excellent 30 return policy and send it back. Otherwise, I'd recommend the Brightech - BrightPlay Home HDTM Bluetooth 4.0 Music Receiver over this HomeSpot device.

I own three pairs of Ecco shoes, all from the BIOM range.I've been an advocate of barefoot walking for many years, and have been mostly barefoot all my life. So I tend toward only wearing shoes with no arch support, and little or no raised heal padding. For instance, the other shoes I wear are Merrel Barefoot shoes.The Ecco Zero Cross-training shoes are very well made (as per most, if not all, Ecco shoes). They are lightweight, have have zero heel lift. The leather is Yak leather, and is well stitched.People who are accustomed to "normal" shoes will very likely NOT find these shoes to be comfortable for walking or standing for anything more than short lengths of time. This are as close to a minimalist shoe Ecco do, and that means almost no padding, arch support, heel lift, etc. I only recommend buying these shoes if you are into barefoot walking, and are looking for a little something to help protect your feet, with a shoe that also looks great.I hear from other reviews around the Internet that the one notable downside of Ecco shoes is the soles wear out much quicker than the rest of the shoe. I've not had mine long enough to comment on this, but it is a concern. I expect the uppers on these will easily last 5+ years of regular and near daily use, but I suspect the soles will wear out long before then if they are used outdoors (which one would expect to do).I know my size in the Ecco range (which I determined by visiting an Ecco shop), and it's been consistent across the three pairs I own.

What follows is my review I posted on the 1lb jars of Nutrex Spirulina a few years ago, with a few extra comments regarding this bulk 5 lb option (which is the way I buy it).My so-called "reviews" are typically long. This is no exception. If that's not what you're after, I provide the IN BRIEF section at the top. If you have the time and inclination to browse over a lot more information about spirulina, please read the FULL REVIEW. If you find this review helpful, please click the button that says so. Thanks.<< IN BRIEF - THE CONDENSED REVIEW >>With this brand of Spirulina you are on to a good thing! Especially as far as taste and quality are concerned.Simply put, after 20+ years of Spirulina usage, this is the best Spirulina I know of, at one of the the best prices (and shipping options) I have seen anywhere online and off-line. If the best tasting Spirulina, made to high standards, is what you are looking for, this is the one to buy. In my opinion, it's best to pass on the slightly cheaper non-Hawaiian varieties (from India, China, etc.). There are a few other US made brands that are also good, but for reasons explored below, I stick with the Hawaiian variety.If you've never had spirulina, try this one first, as that taste is the easiest to handle. If you've had (non-Hawaiian) spirulina and didn't like the taste, try this one as it will likely taste better.Worried about Fukushima fall-out? Nutrex spirulina comes up clean. Only into RAW foods? Nutrex spirulina is dried at below 116F using a patented "OceanChilled" drying process. It's about as raw as you'll get unless you grow your own fresh spirulina. Looking for organic spirulina only? Nutrex was certified organic up until around 2008. Then the rules changed around the use of what's called Chilean Nitrate. So they dropped the certification, as Cyanotech believe other nitrogen sources are no "cleaner" or better than Chilean Nitrate. So, in my opinion, Nutrex is as good as certified organic, but if the certification matters to you, check out NOW Foods organic spirulina.That's my IN BRIEF review in a nutshell.I like to share detailed information where appropriate, so people like yourself can inform yourself if you so desire. For my more in-depth info, please read on:<< FULL REVIEW - THE FULL MONTY >>Let me first put this review into a helpful context.I have been eating Spirulina on an almost daily basis for approximately the past 20 years. Since my mid-teens I've been making big green looking smoothies every morning. My father and I affectionately refer to them as my "Swamp Water" or "Swamp juice" drinks.This particular Spirulina is from a fantastic high-tech Spirulina production facility on the coast of the Big Island of Hawaii. They use ultra pure deep ocean water for both growing and drying the Spirulina. It is dried at a low temperature to keep the nutrients in tact (at or below 116F / 46C).<< THE 5LB BULK OPTION >>It is worth noting that quite often the 1 lb jars actually work out cheaper, per pound, than the 5 lb bags (here on Amazon). The 1 lb jars often drop to around $23 to $25 each, which is around $115 to $125 for 5 lbs. The 5 lb bags are often selling on Amazon for around $140. Right now (Nov 4, 2014) I see 5 lb is only $118, which is the best I've seen in the last few years. So currently it's the best deal, but be sure to check as it might change by the time you read this.If you are having your order shipped internationally (via freight forwarding, or a friend, or simply in your luggage, since Amazon don't ship this item internationally) the 5 lb bag weighs a LOT less than 5x 1 lb jars, as the glass is heavy. So even if the 5 lb bag costs a little more than 5x 1lb jars, it may be worth it to cut back on weight.<< STORAGE - IMPORTANT >>If you buy the 5 lb bag, one concern for some people is whether they will use it quickly enough before it deteriorates. Here is what I suggest: Take a few weeks to a months worth out of the bag and store in an air-tight glass jar (use an old Nutrex spirulina jar, if you have one), and store the 5 lb bag in the fridge or freezer. Keep it well sealed. It will last a LONG time (many years) stored in the freezer. I recommend to NOT use the main bag (especially if you keep it in the fridge or freezer) on a daily basis. Aside from the fact the bag is hard to seal well, and the snap-lock seal will likely peel away from the bag if used often, it will also keep the spirulina dryer. Because refrigerated spirulina is much colder than the atmosphere in your house, each time you open the bag a little moisture will condensate onto the powder (this is especially true in humid [60% +] environments).<< THE TASTE FACTOR >>I'd been eating Spirulina for perhaps 5 years before I tried this Hawaiian variety (manufactured by Nutrex). Now, let me say I had always loved the taste of Spirulina. I'd put a couple of heaped tablespoons of it into my morning drink. Friends and family, however, found the taste too strong and "green" if I put in that much though.One day I met the guy who was importing Nutrex Hawaiian Spirulina into New Zealand (where I lived at the time). He asked if I'd like to try some (at a health Expo). I said, "No thanks, I am very familiar with Spirulina". He said, "Not Hawaiian Spirulina. It tastes much nicer than the other kinds". I let him know that I actually already enjoy the taste of Spirulina. At the time I was getting New Zealand branded Spirulina (imported from India or China). The guy said that compared to the Hawaiian variety, other Spirulina tastes like earth. I'd never noticed that. Curious, I tried his little cup of green stuff, and WOW it was extra delicious. I realised, for the first time, that indeed the other varieties tasted a bit like soil. Whereas the Hawaiian variety tastes creamy and... well, it's hard to describe. Let's just say it is delicious for those people into concentrated green foods, and whilst perhaps calling it "delicious" is going too far for some, it is certainly the most palatable for those folk who are not yet used to eating concentrated green foods.So, that was over 15 years ago, and I've eaten primarily Hawaiian Spirulina ever since. Partly because it tastes great, which means I can put as much as I want into my drink without it getting over-powering, but also because my research indicated that the Hawaiian variety is superior in quality and nutritional content. This particular one being sold here on Amazon is at one of the best prices I have seen, which is why I often buy it from here when I am in the USA.<< SPIRULINA BENEFITS >>Rather than me listing here all the many benefits of spirulina, I suggest doing some research online. There's no point in me repeating already widely available info. What I will say is that I am not without reason for using spirulina pretty much every day for over 20 years. For me, I consider it a staple food. I have excellent health, and I attribute some of that to regular use of spirulina. If I couldn't buy it any more (for whatever reason), I'd get into growing it fresh myself (in fact I am investigating that option anyway).If you are new to Spirulina and super-foods in general, I suggest adding this product to a smoothie, and drinking that each day. Use clean spring water if you can. Certainly avoid chlorinated and fluoridated tap water if at all possible. In a blender add to the water 1 ripe organic banana as a base. It will greatly improve the taste.Then add the following:- Start out with 1 teaspoon of Spirulina. Increase to 2 or so tablespoons if you wish, and as you get accustomed to the taste.- A handful of Raw Organic Goji Berries (soak them in water overnight if you want them to blend more smoothly),- 1/2 to 1 tablespoon of Organic Raw Maca Powder- 1/2 to 1 tablespoon of Lucuma Powder- 1 tablesppon of Y.S. Organic Bee Farms - Fresh Bee Pollen Whole Granules (or any other decent pollen on Amazon, as there are quite a few now)- 1/2 to 1 teaspoon of organic Ginger Root Powder (that'll help with your digestion of the other goodies).- You could also add 1/2 to 2 teaspoons of Chlorella powder. The one from NOW foods is a good deal.This approximate recipe is for about a quart (1 litre) of drink so use 1 quart (1 L) of water.Blend them up in a blender, and enjoy.I have given workshops on what I call "Intelligent Nutritional" throughout Europe and Canada, and this is a basic version of a recipe I share with people. I've had many people after just 3 to 7 days tell me they feel like a new person (they look like it too!!) after drinking this each morning. Friends comment on how them seem to be "glowing" and ask what they are up to!! Try it out.<< TABLETS OR POWDER ? >>I recommend using spirulina as a powder, if possible. I think it's best to taste and "chew" (keep in the mouth for a little time) what we are eating.  Swallowing tablets by-passes that step. If you really can't stomach the taste of Spirulina at all (and I know some people can't), you'll have to go with the tablets. Power is also more instantly digestible, although that's unlikely to make any real difference. If you decide to buy tablets from another company, make sure they are 100% low pressure/low-heat pressed tablets. Some brands have fillers and binders in their tablets which indicate a poor quality product and high-pressure tableting machines (which will damage the spirulina). Nutrex tablets are good quality.If you know little or nothing about Spirulina, please read up on it on the Internet - it's worth leaning about. I'll mention here that it is a highly concentrated source of a very broad range of nutrients. I'd say a couple of tablespoons of this rich green powder contains more nutrition that the people eating the Standard American Diet (SAD) might get in a week worth of meals. This is powerful stuff that will change the way you feel, big time! Enjoy! I know many people who have had a wide range of very positive benefits from adding spirulina to their diet. Less food cravings, diminished desire for junk food, more energy, improved sex-life, less need for coffee in the morning, weight loss, improved memory, and many other benefits are just some of what people have reported to me and in literature.<< ORGANIC STATUS >>If you want ORGANIC spirulina, the Nutrex brand is NOT certified (or un-certified) organic. HOWEVER my research into spirulina indicates it is not possible to grow certified organic spirulina with reputable certification authorities (such as the major ones in the "Western World". Since October 2005, most of ` Organic Spirulina ' was from USA. Two major USA companies (Cyanotech, the makers of Nutrex brand, being one of them) have both ceased production of `Organic Spirulina', due to the USDA terminating the use of a fertiliser which was originally permitted as an organic feed for the growth of Spirulina. When those rules changed, the organic status was dropped. It is my understanding the only so-called "organic spirulina" is from China and India, and that one reason for this is that the so-called "organic" standards there are questionable (i.e. not worth paying extra money on). The best organic spirulina, according to my research, is made by Parry Nutraceuticals, and marketed by third parties under many different brands.For the past 18 years I have been eating almost more-or-less only organically produced foods. Yet in the case of the Nutrex spirulina it does not bother me that it lost its organic certification status due to changes in the organic standards. Having researched the matter, I have no problems with that technicality in this particular case.I have asked NOW Foods about their ORGANIC SPIRULINA POWDER and their non-organic spirulina (that was previously from Hawaii). The organic product is certified organic (by a number of reputable certifying groups) and grown/produced in India. They tell me it is very high quality and from a state-of-the-art facility there in India. I am aware it is manufactured by Parry Nutraceuticals. You can look them up online. I have a tub of it sitting in my kitchen draw. It's been there since mid-2012, hardly touched. The reason is that it tastes awful. It literally smells and tastes like cow or horse manure. I've bought a wide range of spirulina brands around the world, and the Organic NOW Foods Spirulina takes the award for the worst tasting, by a long shot. It's the first time I've found Spirulina to be unpalatable. I understand from Parry literature (online) their product is high quality, and has a long list of organic certifications. But in this instance taste wins out over my wish to eat organic foods. I have communicated with NOW Foods numerous times in the last year about this issue. They say they are aware of it and are that the manufacturer is working on it. You can read my full review of the NOW Foods Spirulina for more details of those emails.<< OTHER BRANDS (of Hawaiian Spirulina) >>It should be noted that ALL of the above info I have been posting applies not only to the product this review is on. It applies to all Hawaiian spirulina, under any brand, as it is all manufactured by Cyanotech, the owners of the Nutrex brand. Other brands that are stated to be Hawaiian are: MicrOrganics (UK), TruNature (from Costco), Nature's Life Hawaiian Spirulina, Lifetime Hawaiian Spirulina, Thompson Nutritional Products. Obviously the prices go up and down, but in general this Nutrex product I am reviewing is the best price.[[ UPDATE on the above statement: Since late 2011 Cyanotech ceased selling their Hawaiian Spirulina in bulk to US based companies, who then resell it under their own brands. This means that there are no US brands with Hawaiian spirulina except Nutrex. If they still claim to be selling Hawaiian spirulina, it is highly questionable. Only non-US companies continue to bulk buy from Cyanotech and package this spirulina under their own brands (mostly in the UK). There are brands selling spirulina grown in California, and perhaps some other US sources I am not aware of (see below).<< OTHER USA GROWN OPTIONS ? >>Apart from the various brands listed above which are Hawaiian, the other USA grown spirulina (from California, not Hawaii) is the Earthrise Spirulina Natural brand. I have bought it a few times over the years (although not in the last 5 years or so) and I don't recall having any personal issues with it. I see most people report it tastes acceptable or nice. I know some people have switched form Nutrex to Earthrise because of concerns about radioactivity from Fukushima. I think it's pretty hard to say what the exact impact of that ongoing (yes, it's still critical, as of Feb 2013) disaster. Most, if not all, of the US West coast received fallout from Fukushima, so the Earthrise facilities in California might have been just as likely to be affected as Hawaii. Anyway, that's another option if you want a US made product (as opposed to spirulina from China, India, or Thailand - the other main producers), that is also is quality packaging (brown glass jar). Right now on Amazon, Earthrise Spirulina Natural is $30.99 plus $5 shipping (shipped by Swanson Health Products).<< BETTER PRICE OPTIONS ? >>As mentioned in my UPDATE above, there is no companies in the United States selling Hawaiian spirulina except Cyanotech who have the Nutrex brand. There if Hawaiian spirulina is what you want, this is it. The best option, and the best price.PACKAGING NOTE: Spirulina is sensitive to oxidation from light and air. The dark brown glass jar of the Nutrex brand (and Earthrise brand) is superior to the thin white HDPE plastic used by many companies bottling spirulina.<< NOW FOODS SPIRULINA (the non-organic one) >>For a nearly two years I was recommending in this review that people buy the bulk 4 lb tub of (non-organic) Hawaiian Spirulina from NOW FOODS. That's because it came from the same grower in Hawaii (Cyanotech) as the Nutrex brand. At that time the 4 lb tub was by far the best price for Hawaiian Spirulina. As of late 2011 I dropped that recommendation, because NOW FOODS changed their non-organic supplier to Parry Nutraceuticals (the same company they get their Organic product from). I have not tried it, but from what I am reading online it tastes as awful as the organic one from Parry (many people have also mentioned the manure smell and taste). If it tastes anything like their Organic Spirulina from India, it will not be at all pleasant. So since late 2011 I've been again recommending the Nutrex brand as the best spirulina at the best price. There are a few other companies selling the Hawaiian variety, but their prices are higher and their packaging cheaper (plastic as opposed to dark brown air-tight glass bottles).<< COMMUNICATIONS WITH CYANOTECH ON ORGANIC STATUS>>(12/Mar/2012) I have received numerous communications from Cyanotech in response to my questions to them. I'll pass on the following information for your consideration:I communicated with Cyanotech some time ago now... and they assure me their spirulina is "herbicide, pesticide, and GMO free". They did not mention fertilisers, so I will enquire further on that.They have stated:(Quote) >> "Plant-based organic (biological) agriculture is fundamentally a system of maintaining soil health and therefore plant vitality. Organic farming relies heavily on the use of nitrogen fixing cover crops, composted manures, crop rotation, and of course organic farming eschews the use of synthetic pesticides (including herbicides). Properly managed organic growing systems build a healthy topsoil with a minimum of soil loss, and also minimized losses of nutrients to ground water, streams, and lakes.The line between organic and standard cultivation of Spirulina is much less distinct, as pesticides and herbicides are not used in the culture of Spirulina. Furthermore, since Spirulina is grown without soil, there is no crop rotation or direct additions of manure to the growing system. Instead, Spirulina growers create the exact conditions of nature (high baking soda and ample amounts of soluble phosphorous and nitrogen) . Manures do not work in this system as they would be harvested with the algae and would contaminate it. This is because Spirulina is a filamentous algae and must be screened out of the water using a very fine mesh.In many ways, however, Spirulina culture belongs with more traditional biological growing systems. Spirulina does not create any ground water pollution or soil erosion (it is grown in lined ponds). Water and energy use are much enhanced over those of terrestrial agriculture (including organic systems). And as I mentioned, there are no pesticides or herbicides used. Spirulina culture is also extremely energy efficient. And although traditional organic farming can use cover crops for nitrogen, there are also phosphorous inputs that are from outside sources (this is absolutely necessary also with Spirulina). Simply put, both organic terrestrial and Spirulina culture systems are reduced input farming techniques that are much lower impact in terms of pollution and soil loss than typical commercial farming.">> (End quote)Their literature also states the following about their Spirulina:>> "Pesticide free, Herbicide free, Environmentally friendly, Full nutritional value, Purified nutrients, Highest growth rate, Low heavy metal level, Low bacterial count"There is still no mention of where they source the nutrients for spirulina production. I'll asked about this in March 2012, with no reply. (Feb 2013, I have asked again, and will post their answer when I get it).Nutrex also share the following explanation about why they dropped the organic certification:>> "In October 2002 the National Organic Standards Board (NOSB) voted to continue to allow the use of mined Chilean nitrate in Spirulina production until October 2005.  (Chilean nitrate is a water soluble form of nitrogen used in the production of Organic Spirulina.)  Unfortunately, the USDA organic production regulations are directed at terrestrial farming and do not address the unique position occupied by aquatic farming of crops such as Spirulina.  Production of Spirulina requires water soluble forms of phosphorus and nitrogen.  This is not desired in terrestrial farming as soluble forms of phosphorous and nitrogen can harm the soil and contaminate ground water; on the other hand, in Spirulina production this is not a problem because all culture ponds are lined and there is no runoff or contamination of ground water.  Cyanotech feels that the NOSB will vote to disallow the use of Chilean nitrate in October 2005 as it is mined and thus not considered a sustainable source of nitrogen.With Chilean nitrate prohibited in all organic production systems, an alternative source of organic soluble nitrogen must be found.  The only sources of soluble nitrogen allowed under organic regulations are compost teas and various manures.  Cyanotech has examined these potential sources of soluble nitrogen and found them unsatisfactory because they would:1) Contaminate our Spirulina with lead and other heavy metals2) Increase the bacterial count in Spirulina3) Produce inferior Spirulina products at a much higher costFor these reasons, Cyanotech will stop production of organic Spirulina if Chilean nitrate is disallowed in October, 2005.  Instead we will concentrate our efforts to continually improve the quality of our All Natural Spirulina products.In many ways standard Spirulina culture methods (not organic) are compatible with traditional organic growing systems. Spirulina does not create any ground water pollution or soil erosion since it is grown in lined ponds.  Water and energy are used much more efficiently than in terrestrial agriculture use (including organic systems).  Cyanotech's All Natural Spirulina products are GMO free, are produced without the use of pesticides or herbicides, are produced using pure deep seawater pumped from a depth of 2000 ft as a source of trace minerals and use a patented OceanChill(tm) drying process to preserve oxygen sensitive nutrients.  Hawaiian Spirulina from Cyanotech has the highest purity, and by far the highest nutritional value of any Spirulina available.>> (End quote)I will post back here when I find out more about their fertilisation methods. For now it seems they use what is called "Chilean nitrate," which was until 2005 an excepted fertiliser under US organic standards.<< FUKUSHIMA RADIOACTIVITY CONCERNS >>(Added 13/03/2012) Fukushima radioactivity impact report: Nutrex/Cyanotech assure me (and the public) they have not experienced any fallout or related effects from the Fukushima nuclear power plant incident in Japan. They have made this public statement:>>" Cyanotech implemented monitoring of our Hawaiian Spirulina Pacifica and BioAstin Natural Astaxanthin products immediately after the disaster in Japan through independent third party laboratory analysis. The analyses found no detectable radiation (less than 1.0 Bq/kg for iodine-131; less than 0.5 Bq/kg for cesium-134; and less than 0.6 Bq/kg for cesium-137), in products produced on 3/22/2011, which was the time in which it was theorized that the tail of the radiation plume from Japan could reach Hawaii. Cyanotech continues to test its products for radiation contamination through independent third party laboratory analysis to ensure that they are the highest quality, most healthful products available in the supplement industry. Recent radiation testing of Hawaiian Spirulina Pacifica and BioAstin products find no detectable radiation." << (End Quote)For those people concerned about radioactivity in general, please note that Spirulina has been proven to significantly reduce the ill effects of radiation exposure. If you want to maximise that effect look into using Astaxanthin, which is extracted from Spirulina. It is the primary antioxidant in Spirulina, and is considered to be the most potent anti-oxidant we know of. There are many options for this on Amazon so I recommend doing a search to see them all.<< MY CONCLUSIONS >>Nutrex Hawaiian Spirulina is a great product and I am sure you'll be as or more happy with it that the other spirulina options. Ideally go for the powder, but if you can't stomach it, switch to tablets. If you want certified organic you'll have to go with a potentially fowl tasting variety from India. If you simply want US made, use either Hawaiian (Nutrex or one of the other brands I listed) or Earthrise (from CA). This bulk 5 lb option is often the most cost effective way to buy Hawaiian spirulina, but the price can vary a lot, so I suggest comparing the per pound price to the 1lb jars before you purchase.I wish you all the best of health,Jonathan EvattInternational lecturer, Traditional Naturopath, and award-winning author of Peace, Power, and Presence: Wisdom for a Lift of Freedom.>> If you find this review helpful, please click the Helpful button. If you don't find it helpful, please feel free to let me know why. Thanks.P.S. I have posted links to the products above, specifically selecting only brands I personally have tried and highly recommend. Different merchants, however, sell these products on Amazon and elsewhere online. So search here and elsewhere for the best price. The ones I have posted links to do not necessarily represent the best price and shipping deals, etc. Although some of them are the best prices I have come across (which helps, because stocking up on super-foods can seem expensive for some of us)

Young Living Essential Oils make decent oils. No complaints there.The are, however, all basically over-priced... in my opinion. That's pretty much always the case with Multi-level marketing companies (which YL is).In this particular case, however, there are some additional complications that may be confusion for people in terms of the price. I know it had me confused for a bit, until I spent a good half hour researching it. Therefore I wish to point a few things out, and share what I discovered:Whoever is selling this 5ml of Valor blend on Amazon is charging a relatively high price (as many other "reviewers" have pointed out). But not necessarily higher than it would otherwise be (say if you bought this directly from a YL distributor).The primary VALOR product available in the USA is actually a 15 ml blend WITH a carrier oil. The recommended retail price from a YLEO for a 15 ml bottle of Valor is CA$33 (in Canada) and around US$28.62 in the USA. But these all have a relatively inexpensive carrier oil. So we can't compare this 5ml product with the 15ml products.HOWEVER: I notice there are different product images showing for this 5ml product on Amazon. The one on the product page indicates it is 100% Pure Therapeutic Grade Essential Oil, which will mean it is without the (relatively inexpensive) base oil. This is the reason for the higher price, when comparing the 5ml with the 15ml Valor. I have not been able to find any YL Internet literature showing this 5ml Valor as a 100% pure oil, except when sold as part of a kit (with a selection of other oils). Otherwise, all one can buy is the 15ml version, which, as mentioned, contains a base oil. The image that shows up as I write this review (on the review writing page) shows a different label, and it does not state 100% Therapeutic Grade Essential Oil on the visible part of the label... to that adds further ambiguity. Despite this, I am going to assume this is the 100% essential oil being sold here.<< WHAT TO MAKE OF ALL THIS >>From my perspective, if someone wants Young Living oils they are best to buy them from an official distributor.Hopefully you can find a distributor that is not going to push you into joining and getting a distributor kit, etc., if all you want is the oils. Good luck.BUT in all honesty, my professional opinion is that YL oils are (like EVERY other MLM product I've seen in the past 30+ years) significantly over priced. You can make up the Valor blend yourself... save money, and likely learn a few things and have some fun along the way.The Valor blend is made up of the following oils:- Spruce (Picea mariana)- Rosewood (Aniba rosaeodora)- Blue Tansy (Tanacetum annuum)- Frankincense (Boswellia carteri)- In a base of almond oil (also listed as "in a base of coconut oil")So, as mentioned, this does not classify as a pure essential oil. It is a blend in a base (or "carrier") oil. There's no telling just how much base oil is in there, but it makes a huge difference to the value of the product. I think it is safe to say this is mostly base oil. Hence the price difference between the 5ml Pure oil and the 15 ml "massage" blend.<< MAKING YOUR OWN >>If you have an interest in getting more hands-on with your essential oils, I suggest making your own blends. You'll save money, and no doubt learn a few things and enjoy the experience. if that doesn't sound like your cup of tea, by all means buy this oil blend directly from a YL distributor.There are numerous options on Amazon for what looks like good quality alternatives for each of these ingredients, except the Blue tansy:To make it easy I have created a list using Amazon Listmania: http://www.amazon.com/lm/R2J7OIKKRPTPOB/The Blue tansy, as far as I can tell, is currently (Oct 15, 2014) best bought directly from Plant Therapy or Eden's Garden.I suggest keeping it simple, and using equal amounts of each oil. That way if you buy 10 ml bottles of each, you'll end up with 40 ml of 100% pure therapeutic grade Valor blend.I'd suggest adding around 10 to 20 drops of that to 30 ml of carrier oil, or less if you prefer.<< RATING >>I have giving this what I consider to be a "neutral" rating. Three stars. Not bad per se, but not something I recommend, for the above-mentioned reasons.

I was not familiar with the Gramicci brand until buying this item, along with a number of others. I was looking for clothing made from hemp and/or organic cotton.This Gramicci Men's Organic McKay Performance Crew is made from 53% Hemp/44% Certified Organic Cotton. The remaining 3% is spandex, which gives it a nice stretch quality to it.This garment is excellently constructed. The seems are very well stitched, and they are flattened to reduce any rubbing for those who are highly active. The seam layout includes a panel up each side, which is nice. It distinguishes the shirt from cheaper T's.Looking at the picture here on Amazon I was not convinced I would like the Oasis Green color. Now that I have the garment, I see it’s a slightly deeper green than the picture indicates, which is great. It looks also a tad neon in the photo, which had me concerned.Gramicci does not indicate what kind of dyes they use. That might be my only complaint. I am sure many of the people going for hemp and organic cotton garments would quite likely appreciate knowing if non-toxic / natural dyes have been used. They don't say, so I can only assume the dyes are nothing out of the ordinary.I highly recommend this garment to anyone who appreciates well made clothing and highly quality ecologically sound fabrics.
