It does clearly point out that quantum theory can not say "how" or "why" these new discoveries are possible... yet it can say that it's discovered some things that defy what we have come to think of as so "real".WTB uses a lot of great computer generated graphics to illustrate concepts and metaphysical realities that would otherwise be very hard to depict. I think this too is a real benefit for people that tend to view life in a fairly "solid" way (most people do). Those that have not experienced the less "solid" and more fluid aspects of reality (through meditation, spiritual revelation, mystical experiences, or the use of entheogenic plants) can have a hard time imagining reality in any other form. WTB does a great job of making these non-ordinary realities more tangible and imaginable.I highly recommend this movie... to all people except perhaps those that are really strongly attached to status-quo perceptions of how the world and reality is. Although even if you are one of those people, if you feel at all open to new ways of seeing things then you too might find that this movie leaves you joyfully pondering on "Just what the bleep did I know..."For those that are interested in this film from a technical point of view... Strictly as a movie (for entertainment) I can't say it is particularly well constructed. The script in the movie portion is pretty simplistic and lacking the substance I would personally look for in a film. As a documentary I think it would be fair to say that it lacks the level objectivity and comprehensive depth I would expect from a well produced documentary. Yet, WTB is a combination of Doco and an entertaining movie--a different genre entirely--and in this regard it the result is something that is both entertaining and informative.With my regards,Jonathan Evatt

For those that consider them self a healer; aspire to be a healer; training to be a healer; or are not sure what a healer is... I believe this audio book will be of great value to you.Caroline explores many of the myths, issues, challenges, and important understandings that I am sure all healers will face, experience or deal with a some stage in their career. Her no-nonsense approach is clear and concise.This work is very much a "guide". It is not a manual. It is not an instructive work. It does not teach you how to heal or be a healer. Rather it is a general guide to those that work in or wish to work in this field. It is a guide that will assit a healer to be better at what they do. What will also become apparent to those who listen to this work is just how broad the field of the healer really is. From human health through to the health of a corporation... healers have a role in a wide cut of society. Caroline's elaboration on this may be helpful to those who have struggled to identify their mode of healing.I know many healers, some who are very experienced and established in their field, teaching other's to be healers. As I listed to this excellent guide I was constantly aware of just how much this information would benefit these healers that I know personally. Caroline directly addresses many of the issues that I see these healers struggling with for various reasons.Disc 1 explores the "Archetype of the healer": Addresses topics such as "Healers as spiritual midwives", "The myth of the wounded healer", "How do you know if you called to be a healer", and "Knowing your own motivations".Disc 2 explores "The Shadow side of the healer": Topics such as "It's a shadow perspective to see disease as an enemy", "Offering your best without attachment to the outcome", "Symptoms of psychic burn-out" (important for most healers), "The suffering healer"... etcDisc 3 explores "Healthy Self-Esteem and the Art of Healing". This disc often had me thinking of healers I know that are struggling in one way or another... what Caroline covers on this disc is a very important contribution to the art of healing.Disc 4 explores "Advice for the developing healer": Topics like "What type of healer are you?", "Spirituality, money, gender, and right livelihood", "Psychic boundaries", "The role of the healer in the larger world"... and more.This disc, like all of them, also contains a great deal of information that I am sure will be of value to most healers... both established healers and those that are in the early stages of exploring this vocation.UPDATE: APRIL 2010: I still refer inwardly to much of what I listened to in this Essential Guide, and it is quite some years since I listened to it. To me that is a good testament in itself about the value of this audio book by Myss.I wish you all the best of health,Jonathan EvattAuthor of multi-award winning book Peace, Power, and Presence: A guide to Self Empowerment, Inner Peace, and Spiritual Enlightenment, the first title in the Wisdom for a Life of Freedom series - available on Amazon.com

I have read (and reread) many of Joel Goldsmiths books.The Art Of Spiritual Healing was the first one I read, after finding it on my father's bookshelf when I was about 18. It left a very lasting impression and in fact Goldsmith, through this book, set the yard stick against which all my other explorations into health and healing have been measured.I've always felt that no matter what approach to health and healing I am looking at, it is always (in my opinion) dealing with symptoms and this includes all the natural and alternative approaches. Spiritual Healing (as beautifully described and successfully practised by Goldsmith) is the one exception. It goes to the root cause.Of course, many are not ready to go to that place and for some such folk I am sure this book would be a displeaser. If, however, you have a sincere interest in what true healing is really about then please read this book. It is clear, simple, concise. It effectively covers the essential information of what spiritual healing is, how it is practised, it's effectiveness (through Goldsmith's many years of successfully treating thousands of clients), and it's attainment. Spiritual Healing, after all, is a capacity that will all have yet we must wake up to it and attain the fruits of that awakening.Much of Goldsmiths other books will most certainly assist you in that path to awakening to the Truth of who and what you are, and your capacity to function as a Spiritual Healer, and hence I highly recommend his other books too. If you've read nothing of Goldsmiths work then this book is a great place to start.I wish you all the best of health,Jonathan Evatt

Farious and Wikholm investigate what science reveals about Buddhist mindfulness and meditation - and what they found is troubling.Many people have experienced alarming reactions when practicing Buddhist meditation.  Aaron Alexis attended a Buddhist temple, and was enthusiastic enough to tell everyone he wanted to become a monk.  Yet one day he drove to Washington's Navy Yard and murdered 12 people.  A yoga instructor, after 20 years of meditation, suddenly felt her identity fracturing.There are actually a number of interesting research studies that have been published showing troubling problems with meditation.  Shapiro found that 63% "had at least one negative effect and 7% suffered profoundly adverse effects" (p 145).  Furthermore, it seems the greater the years a person had spent meditating, the more adverse were the effects.  Lazarus and Ellis also reported that many practicing Buddhists has "serious disturbances after meditating" (p 145).Buddhism has a reputation in the west as being about compassion and peacefulness.  However, as the authors point out, there are any number of books proving that, historically, Buddhists have been violent.  Three books on the subject they suggest are" "Zen at War", "Buddhism and Warfare" and "Buddhism and Violence".  The Zen soldiers in Japan believed Buddhist teaching that this world is illusory, and the other people we meet are also illusions, was justification for killing."The Buddhist idea, that, by becoming selfless, life and death become undifferentiated; there is nothing to lose by dying...once you realize the emptiness of the self...Takuan, a famous Zen master from the 1600s wrote:  'The uplifted sword...is all emptiness....The man who is to be struck down  is also of emptiness, and so is the one who wields the sword" (p 171).Nor is Buddhism free of historic forced conversions.  Quite the contrary.  The authors discovered  that, "Just like Christianity and Islam churches and mosques from pagan temples...Shamanic practices where prohibited in Mongolia from the 1500s, spirit figurines were burned and replaced with Buddhist images...Those who continued to practice Shamanic rites were subjected to brutal punishments or executed...forced conversions...' (pp167-8).

"Universities, like cathedrals and parliaments, are a product of the Middle Ages" writes  Haskins.Universities began in the 12th and 13th centuries, in what many historians are now referring to as the renaissance of the 12th century.  The Vikings were no longer burning and looting monasteries, and, once again, towns began to be full of people as trade resumed.Certain cities became noted centers for particular studies, such as medicine or theology.  Irnerius, of Bologna,  was a noted scholar of law, and later, Gratian a monk in Bologna wrote the 'Decretum', a standard law text.  Their influence made Bologna famous  for its law school.  Paris became famous for its school of theology - and the unending wrangles between various theological positions.  And here is one fact that surprised me: "There were relatively few students of theology" (p 34).Amazingly "By the end of the Middle Ages at least 80 universities had been founded" (p 20), many of them still surviving, such as Oxford. Students came to the universities to attain a certificate, the licentia docendi, which would allow them to later teach the subject.  Sometimes a master would bring students to a lecture at his house.  If a large hall was required, Paris  had an entire street of them "on the Left Bank, the Vicus Stramineus or Rue du Fouarre celebrated by Dante, apparently so-called from the straw-covered floor on which the students sat as they took notes 45).By the beginning of the 1300s the library of the Sorbonne had 1722 volumes, a staggering number considering that every word had to be laboriously hand written.

If you want the orthodox take on the era from the collapse of the Roman empire to the Reformation, then you need this book.  Dawson's knowledge of the era is immense, and his writing is crisp and clear.  And he always find that one, telling point that reveals an era to you.Even as the Romans enjoyed their brief moment of triumph and empire, a tiny, persecuted group would grow into the religion that conquered the empire.  Almost overnight a "great network of Greek-speaking Churches strung out along the shores of the Mediterranean...to Rome itself" (p 89), a movement so compelling  that in a letter to the emperor Pliny complains of the pagan temples being deserted, in about 100 AD .  That's less than a century after the death of Christ."The conversion of the Roman Empire to Christianity...marked a revolution...in the history of the world" (p 118).  Enormous changes came to to the Empire in the 3rd and 4th centuries, when the barbarian incursions increased, and men from Balkans and even from Spain took over the reigns of the empire.The ancient world despised manual labor; Christianity exulted in it.  Christian alms giving "became so great as to cause a real economic change in the distribution of property" (p 127).  Some of the great senatorial families gave all their lands and moneys to the poor.  "Melania is said to have freed eight thousand slaves in the year 406 alone" (p 127).The Empire, split, hobbled on until Islam swept in bloody spasms across the entire of Africa, Egypt, and the Middle East.  Rome and the west declined into what  some called the Dark Ages.As cities vanished, literacy vanished, and barbarians increased, it was the monasteries which created islands of Christianity and western civilization.  In Italy, St Benedict founded Monte Cassino, writing his famous rule so noted for its moderation and charity.  It was to be the template for a thousand monasteries to come.  Until the 10th century, monasteries alone provided education.Dawson argues "It is impossible to exaggerate the destructiveness of the Viking attacks"  (p 190).  "The chronicler of Vendast wrote in 884 '"Everywhere there is nothing but dead bodies....There is no road or place where the ground is not covered with corpses'" (pp 190-1). In "the Carolingian territories...the great abbeys were practically all destroyed...the towns were destroyed, too (p 193).  Vikings didn't merely raid and kill and loot.  They also stole  people, especially children,  to sell as slaves to the Muslims.  One man wrote "the land is reduced to a solitude" (p 194).Yet these dreadful centuries would be followed by a great revival, a renaissance which is not called by the word.  Towns formed, and soon, guilds flourished and fairs and markets.  The monasteries were rebuilt, vast  Romanesque  churches rose from the ground,  statues were once again made, and manuscripts were lavishly illustrated.

Mangalwadi gives a brilliant overview of the most famous and recent guru movements in India.  He asks of the Divine Life Society "If God (or unity consciousness) alone is real and ....beyond good and evil...how can....karma, which distinguishes good from bad, also be true" (p50).  So, he deduces, "If no deed is actually good or evil, then the belief in transmigration, namely, that on e has to be be reborn repeatedly to take consequences of good and bad"  (p 51) is patently false.Besides, if the world is all illusion, what is even the point of trying to convert people who are illusions?Time and again, Mangalwadi finds that each variety of Hinduism argues against "the basis for science" (p 52) by positing an alternate reality.  This is a long standing charge against Hinduism and Buddhism, , made by such men as Whitehead and Oppenheimer.  The pantheistic belief that the world is an illusion, merely a part of the god/pantheistic entity that exists,  explains why China and India did not develop real science.Instead, what was seen worthy was becoming unattached to yourself, to extinguish your personality and your intellect and your reasoning mind.  Accomplishment in this world was regarded as unworthy.The Sathya Sai movement emphasizes individual otherworldliness, just as nearly all the other gurus do, which also explains why India has been crippled by lack of social action movements.  A recent Australian study found the country with the highest number of slaves in the world was India.  But, unlike in western countries where Christianity fueled social action against slavery, there is no movement in India to aid these people.The Swami Muktananda tells his followers to seek to be delivered from the "'impossible webs of intellect'" (p 128).

The Maybrick case iss fascinating because it is still open ended.  Colquhoun's title said it all: "Did She Kill Him?"  And the truth is....we just don't know.Florence, an American, married a wealthy Liverpool cotton merchant.  He was much older; she was young and pretty.  Apparently - you have to put this together as you read - he was upset because Florence didn't bring much money into the marriage as he expected,  and he was also annoyed at the way she threw away money on fripperies like clothes.  Still, they got on well at first and the marriage was blessed with two children.Then the husband, James, took a mistress.  And his wife found out.  Soon after, she spent a few nights in a hotel with a gentleman who was not her husband.James was a hypochondriac who constantly dosed himself with the Victorian tonics promising to cure everything - indigestion, baldness, cancer, melancholy, and foot trouble.  And, incredibly, arsenic was an ingredient in  far, far too many of these nostrums.  More than seems believable today, yet it was all too common to use arsenic in medicines.  Arsenic was also a common beauty aid for women.  It gave you the popular pale complexion so beloved of Victorian women.So there was plenty of arsenic in the house, so much that it seems plausible that James could have ingested enough poison to kill himself by accident.What I found annoying was the author interjected her opinions into the book constantly.  She keeps talking about the early feminist movement, and how this must be the reason the murder was such a focus of the press at the time.  Which is to ignore the fact that the it's a fascinating case even today.  Besides, this was a wealthy, attractive couple.  When is the press not interested in wealthy, attractive people involved in  twisty murder case?

Putnam finds a huge disparity growing between the well off - who typically  stay in school, marry and stay married - and the dismal downhill trend of the lower half of America.  Once a flourishing middle class, these  are people who seem to be sliding into real poverty.The trickle of unmarried women who once gave birth to the most disadvantaged children in America has now become a flood.  More than 50 percent of the women in America  who are thirty and younger now give birth without being married.  And the statistics on the children raised without both parents  is simply dismal.  All too often, single parenthood leads to failure in school for the child.  Failure later in life.  Drugs.  Emotional problems.  An aimless, unhappy life.It's urgent that the problem be turned around, but how?  He claims 60% of all births to single women - statistically, most of whom are in their 20s and living with the baby daddy - are unplanned.  Really?  Twenty five year old women are having sex without contraceptives and they are shocked, shocked to discover they are pregnant?  Hmm.He notes the vast gap between the behavior of the well off from the behavior of the single mother.  The well off, married mother reads to her children, takes them to zoos, the library, parks, and so on.  The poor single mother, whose baby daddy has just left her stranded with two toddlers, will, unamazingly, not have time to do any of the activities the married mommy accomplishes.  And how is that problem to be solved?Putnam eagerly suggests all the various bromides that have failed.  Lots more money for schools, for example.  Well, sorry, that's been tried, and failed spectacularly.  Vast sums spent on Head Start and similar programs have shown, decade after decade after decade, no real result.  Having Harvard graduates teach in poor schools?  Been tried.  Very little real results.  Look up the research; I'm right.Putnam claims there is "no clear path to reviving marriage rates among poor Americans" (p 245).  That may be true, but, alas, it is the only thing that will save the majority of the children involved.  Period.  The reason the children are leading chaotic lives is because the mother is not married to the baby daddy.  The reason there is not enough money and not enough time and not enough serene evenings is all the same.  No lasting marriage.  Even very poor people who marry and stay married, the research shows, manage to raise children well.I hope Putnam is wrong about being unable to revive marriage, because without it, I can see no solution.

This short book, with its many charming and fascinating illustrations from ancient China, will interest many. Needham gives the history of gunpowder and firearms and comparative macrobiotics.What really interested me, however, is the concluding essay, in which Needham speculates why science never developed in China. And it is a mystery, one that many scholars have pondered. China's civilization had thousands of years of stable government. And it has a tradition that venerated scholars. China also had a history of many interesting inventions and engineers. Certainly, all the factors seemed lined up to aid in the blossoming of science.Yet science, not just mere technology, real science, with its organized effort to explain and understand nature, with its interest in abstract subjects and its testing of theories, only developed in the west. Why?Needham suggests it was the way the Chinese viewed time. Across the entire of the western ancient world, as well as India and China, time was viewed as a great wheel, with one golden age with great technologies succeeded by a fallen era, when idea would be lost. Then the golden age would reappear, with all the same technologies.What the west had was Christianity, which posited a time which was not a wheel, but which progressed. Christ, after all, came in historical time.Alfred North Whitehead placed the reason the west developed science on Christian theology. This is what he stated: "There seems but one source...It must come from the medieval insistence on the rationality of God...Every detail was supervised and ordered; the search in to nature could only result in the vindication of the faith in rationality".From the very start, as shown in such Christian theologians as Tertullian and Augustine, Christians argued that there was a truth. Truth was God. And the truth could be discovered by rationality.

The book was originally published over a century ago, and it shows. And I am not just talking about the ghastly, stilted language.It's the scholarship that's so awful.This book was part of what came to be known as the "History of Religions" school in biblical scholarship. It was a theory that Christianity borrowed doctrines from ancient pagan religions. This theory flourished for half a century before it was put to death by thousands of scholars doing research. Not to mention archaeological discoveries that proved much of the claims to be bogus. The author, Massey, was born in 1828, to give you an idea of just how long ago all this was.The theory is now so dead that not a single biblical scholar, atheist or not, will touch it. Anyone interested in the "History of Religions" theory should read "The Jesus Legend" by Paul Eddy and Gregory Boyd. This is a book you could order today from Amazon, and it gives a good overview of the "History of Religions" theory and explains what refuted it. On a popular level, try "The Gospel and the Greeks" by Nash, a fine summation of what modern scholarship has revealed. For deepest scholarship, try Martin Hengel's "The Son of God".Here are what some scholars have said on the subject: From Jonathan Z Smith's famous essay "Dying and Rising Gods" which you can buy on Amazon today: "The category of dying and rising gods, once a major topic of scholarly investigation, must now be understood to be largely a misnomer based on imaginative reconstructions."Also, from Nash's "The Gospel and the Greeks" which you can buy on Amazon today: " The tide of scholarly opinion has turned dramatically against attempts to make early Christianity dependent on the so-called dying and rising gods of Hellenistic paganism" (p 162).From Gunter Wagner"That Paul modeled his Christ 'myth' on the myths about other 'dying and rising gods' is now no more seriously held than is the derivation of the observance of Sunday and of the resurrection on the third day from the mystery cults" from "Pauline Baptism" p 266.Massey believed that Christianity had been more or less invented by the Egyptians, mostly because it hadn't struck him that ONE THOUSAND years had passed since the time of the pyramids to the time of early Christianity, and that in that one thousand years the Egypt had first been conquered many times, first by  Alexander and then by the Romans.  There wasn't any flourishing Egyptian religion to pass on by time the Gospels were written.  And no, the Romans weren't heavily into mystical cults by the time of the Gospels either.  It is a laughable theory.Scholar W. Ward Gasque points out that actual Egyptian scholars have refuted Massey's points, one by one.There are hundreds of books on this subject. Other scholars who have written on the topic: Edwin Yamauchi, C H Dodd, Gunter Wagner, and many others.

If you have no interest whatsoever in facts, this might be the book for you! Published in 1875 this book is a curiosity but little more. Even in the Victorian era when this was written, this book was considered silly by scholars.That it has been reprinted says some truly appalling about our educational system.There was a period in biblical scholarship when many scholars investigated whether or not Christianity had borrowed doctrines from paganism, especially the mystery religions. If you are curious, look up the 'History of Religions' theory, in any book about biblical scholarship. It lasted from the middle of the Victorian era to about 1920.But all this was long, long ago. There is now not a single credible biblical  scholar anywhere in the world that will argue in favor of this theory. Not one. Massive numbers of books were published on the theory, and whole libraries still groan from their weight.The result of all this investigation? That Christianity not only did not borrow doctrines from pagan sources, but paganism borrowed from Christianity. The earliest Gnostic writing was a hundred years after the death of Christ, for example, yet the Gnostics stole names of apostles to give their works added credibility.As for the subject of so-called 'dying and rising gods' here is a quote from Dr Jonathan Z Smith: "the category of dying and rising gods, once a major topic of scholarly investigation, must now be understood to be largely a misnomer based on imaginative reconstructions and exceedingly late or highly imaginative texts".Also, from Nash's "The Gospel and the Greeks" which you can buy on Amazon today: " The tide of scholarly opinion has turned dramatically against attempts to make early Christianity dependent on the so-called dying and rising gods of Hellenistic paganism" (p 162).From Gunter Wagner"That Paul modeled his Christ 'myth' on the myths about other 'dying and rising gods' is now no more seriously held than is the derivation of the observance of Sunday and of the resurrection on the third day from the mystery cults" from "Pauline Baptism" p 266.Want to investigate further? To read a summary of the entire "History of Religions" theory, as it was called, please buy "The Jesus Legend" by Paul Eddy and Gregory Boyd. You can order this from Amazon today. Or for a book written on the popular level, try "The Gospel and the Greeks" by Nash. For a top flight scholar on the subject: Martin Hengel and "The Son of God". Other scholars who have written books on this subject: Edwin Yamauchi, Gunter lWagner, and C H Dodd.Look, there are hundreds upon hundreds of atheists who publish books of scholarship attacking Christianity.  None of them are still slogging along with the antique 'dead and rising gods' nonsense.

Vitoria, a Dominican friar, was Professor of Sacred Theology at Salamanca University, was one of the pivotal figures in arguments about human rights.  In 1532 he published a number of works on the relations of Spain to America.Here is how it came about:  Augustine had argued that the mentally incompetent could not own  property.  This idea was pounced upon by the brigands and thugs who  arrived in the new Americas, and saw all that land.  And all those Indians.The argument of the dreadful ruffians was "the Indians lacked ownership because of want of reason or unsoundness of mind" (p 111) which, yes, they stole from Augustine.  So they felt free to appropriate all the land and enslave the Indians.Vitoria responded that the Indians had rights,  "The Indian aborigines have...the use of reason...They have politics...marriage and magistrates, overlords, laws, and workshops, and a system of exchange, all of which call for the use of reason" (p113).  In short, "that the aborigines...were true owners before the Spaniards came" (p 115).Making Indians slaves had already been condemned by the church, first in 1435, with the bull  Sicut Dudum, which said any Catholic who had slaves would incur excommunication.  Again,  in 1537, Sublimus Deus was published by yet another pope. This bull was intended as the major pedagogical work on the Catholic church on the subject of slavery. It stated clearly that that all the natives of America are men, that they are capable of faith and salvation, so they must never be made slaves, and any Catholic who kept slaves, sold slaves, or participated in slavery, was excommunicated.The arguments of Vitoria was based on the idea of a natural law.  "International law is natural law, that is to say, the law of nature was part of international law, and indeed was the general source from which its special rules would be derived (p 164).  He proposed that "the rule of law should be based on reason" (p 165) and it also had to be "consistent with the dignity...and his well-being and ultimate happiness in society...should be the aim and purpose of law" (p 172)..

There are a surprising number of pictures in this small book, and a massive amount of knowledge crammed in as well.Monasteries began in the Egyptian  desert soon after Christianity became a licit religion in the Roman empire.  Rather like John the Baptist,  hermits chose to live out their lives of prayer and fasting in the arid emptiness of the Egyptian desert.  Soon two or three hermits began living together, and thus monasteries began.The Egyptian Christian monasteries were "small towns of a thousand or two thousand inhabitants;  they were divided into houses of thirty or forty ...tailors, bakers, gardeners...and surplus products were sold down the Nile to Alexandria  (p 14).Monasteries spread across the Christian world.  In Ireland, "Celtic monasticism in its golden age was austere in the extreme; physical penances...such as fasting and immersion in cold water, were severe.  yet...a vivid Latin culture sprang up and a still more remarkable artistic achievement that has put Celtic monastic illuminations and metalwork among the masterpieces of art-history" (p 32).Benedict of Nursia wrote the rule that was to be the basis for monastic living across the western Christian world.  The rule emphasized spirituality, while it was physically moderate enough to be undertaken by almost anyone. Because of monastic life, there was a renaissance of learning in the 800s that would save many of the classical writings for posterity,  By 1050, the famous monastery at Cluny  "reached a degree of liturgical splendor unequaled before or since" (o 52).  Monasteries flourished, so  that in England, there were some 1,000 houses by the year 1200.  Pope Benedict XII imposed the rule that one monk in 20 must attend a university.Then came the Reformation.  The northern half of Germany lost most of its monasteries.  "In England the monasteries went down violently between 1535 and 1540" (p 143)  overturning the 800 religious houses.

A biased and confusing book which leaves out the most important historical points.Maxwell - who never includes the other side - ignores all the evidence that many in the first centuries of the church found slavery immoral.  That there were instances of Christians raising money to buy slaves their freedom.  He ignores that and ignores that  the laws of Justinian called slavery against the law of nature.Maxwell actually ignores the entire history of the Dark and Middle Ages, as the church  banished slavery from the majority of the western world, and instead refashioned  both the slavery of the barbarians and the ancient cultures into serfdom.  According to research by the famous historian Marc Bloch, in most areas, especially in England and France, the duties of a serf were to work for his lord for a maximum of two days a week.  Serfs, according to Bloch. were far more like renters than slaves.  (From the book Slavery and Serfdom in the Middle Ages by Bloch).The Viking raiders that pillaged city and monastery were hunting for people as often as they were searching for gold.  They took slaves by the thousands to sell in the Islamic slave markets.  Slavery existed then in Europe in very few places, mostly only on the periphery of the western nations - in the countries of Eastern Europe, which were constantly raided by the Muslims.  Muslims  captured  so many slaves that the very word slave derives from Slav. Whole orders of nuns and priests were formed to do nothing but try to buy back the Christians taken as  slaves in Muslim countries.  Maxwell mentions none of this.Then some Canary Islanders were forced into slavery.  The pope was furious and he promptly issued the bull Sicut Dudum, which was published  in 1435.  The pope  demanded that all who had been enslaved were to be restored to their liberty immediately or those who had caused the enslavement, or who owned slaves, or who bought and sold slaves, would incur excommunication. The pope calls the enslavement of natives both illegal and sinful.  And excommunicated anyone holding or selling slaves.This would be the first volley in a long and sad war, with greedy, immoral  Catholics refusing to listen to the pope.  In South America, wealthy owners of vast plantations preferred not to hear the pope on the issue of slavery, preferred to believe the natives weren't fully human.  And, in just the same way, multitudes of people who call themselves Catholics today pretend to be deaf to the pope and their bishops telling them that abortion is a mortal sin.  Not that  you will read this background in Maxwell's book.About a century later, in 1537, Sublimus Deus was published by yet another pope.  This bull was intended as the major  pedagogical work on the Catholic church on the subject of  slavery. It stated clearly that  that all the natives of America  are men, that they are capable of faith and salvation, so they must never be made slaves.Again, in 1591, Pope Gregory issued yet another bull on the subject, Ci, Sicuti, which reiterated that all who bought, sold, captured, or owned slaves to be excommunicated from the Catholic church.The main tenets of Sublimus Deus would never be altered in any way, and are in effect today.However, some leniency was allowed, not for slavery, but for a later form of punishment. Indentured servants who had essentially sold themselves into a kind of slavery for a limited time, perhaps in order to gain a ship's crossing to America, was allowed, as was the taking of prisoners in war. For limited time, the captured men could be put to work, under very strict circumstances that never lessened their dignity.Anyone interested in the subject of the Catholic church and slavery would be well advised to ignore this book.  Get a copy of "The Popes and Slavery" instead.,

A very strange thing happened after Rome fell.  Slavery vanished, and serfdom took its place.  Was being a serf essentially like being a slave in the ancient world?Bloch argues forcibly that the serf "was not at all a slave.  ..he could possess land by rental or even as...property to give, sell...inherit...his obligations were...strictly limited by custom" (p 22).  Bloch's research suggests serfs were closer in their obligations and rights to renters, rather than as people who were owned body and soul by their  lord.  The Middle Ages had a closely reasoned network of obligations between people, and the obligations were frequently equal to the duties required.What was required of a serf?  Was he tied to the land and not allowed to change to a different lord?  Actually, the requirements seemed to vary from century to century, from country to country, and from lord to lord.  Perhaps the most universal of all the requirements for a serf was the work he owed his lord.  "The  heaviest duties required only a few days of work work per week:" (p 23) in France and England.  Many serfs did even  less work than that for their lord.This was not the situation in  Germany, however, where the Tageschalken were obliged to work for their lord daily.  .  Drawing any conclusions from the Tageschalken is difficult, Bloch concluded, because from the references it is unclear whether a family was required to send one person  from their entire clan every day, or if every man had to work some hours a day for his lord.Marriage, however, could be tricky for serfs.  It was difficult to marry someone who had a different overlord, or who was free, unless a fee changed hands.  The key here was the obligation the serf had to serve his lord for a day or two in the fields, or to pay the annual rent, which made it difficult to marry outside the domain of the seigneur.In the beginning, serfs paid a yearly tax to their seigneur, which typically was a very small amount.  Sometimes the tax was called rent, or chevage.  Perhaps it was so tiny an amount it wasn't missed, because in some areas "as early as...the twelfth century the serfs...had ceased to pay it"  (p 37).  Oddly, with apparently no complaint from the seigneurs.  "The serf was a tenant like any other, subject only to...the obligations attached to his land" (p 55).Could a serf  move to a different place, away from his lord?  "As soon as a man abandoned his fields, dependance ceased...In spite of the obstacles that seigneurial powers here and there erected to limit this procedure, departure generally remained legitimate" (p 77).  This actually surprised me;  I had assumed serfs were tied to their land by legal measures.  They  may have preferred their own land and fields, but when they wanted to change to another lord it appears they could.It was also possible to slide from being a serf to becoming free, just as sometimes those born free could become serfs.  Wars could suddenly change the status of a  family, for example, or a group of small farm holdings could gradually come under the influence of a newly built castle and the free farm holders become serfs.Starting in the 11th and 12th centuries, there was an additional class added between free men and serfs, that of the colliberti.  These are noted in the Doomsday Book, which mentions 858 instances.And this is the most surprising fact I learned:  many people became serfs because they chose to.  "In the tenth and eleventh centuries...documents ...reveal the existence of a very large number of self-donations into serfdom" (p 143)For all these reasons, serfs were not comparable to slaves..  (For a good book on the subject of the slavery of the ancient world, pick up a copy of "the Economy of Prostitution in Rome").

Panzer covers the topic of the papal bulls and pronouncements on slavery from the 1400s.The bull Sicut Dudum in 1435 was the papal reaction to Canary islanders have been enslaved.  The pope was outraged.  He demanded that all who had been enslaved had to be restored to their liberty immediately  or those who had caused the enslavement, or who owned slaves, or who bought and sold slaves,  would incur excommunication.  The pope  calls the enslavement of natives "illicit and evil" (p 9).This would be the first volley in a long and sad war, with greedy Catholics refusing to listen to the pope, just as many do today regarding abortion and other issues.About a century later, in 1537,  Sublimus Deus was published, which was intended as "the central pedagogical work against slavery" (p 17).  It insisted that all the natives of America "are men and therefore capable of faith and salvation, they are not to be given into servitude" (p 22).  Against the cries of many who believed the natives to  merely brutes, the pope contended that they were fully human, and  that they must never be enslaved.In 1591, Pope Gregory issued yet another bull on the subject, Ci, Sicuti, which reiterated that all who bought, sold, captured, or owned slaves to be excommunicated from the Catholic church.The main tenets of Sublimus Deus would never be altered in any way, and are in effect today.  However, some leniency was allowed, not for slavery, but for a later form of punishment.  Indentured servants who had essentially sold themselves into a kind of slavery for a limited time, perhaps in order to gain a ship's crossing to America, was allowed, as was  the taking of prisoners in war.  For  limited time, the captured men could be put to work, under very strict circumstances that never lessened their dignity.This is a fascinating book, well written and comprehensive.

NOTE:  Those looking for a history that covers  the  Catholic church and slavery will need to look elsewhere.  I would suggest "The Popes and Slavery" by Panzer.  That's a good book, but I should warn you that Panzer begins with the year 1435,  when the Pope issued a Bull saying that a "sentence of excommunication be incurred by one and all who attempt to capture or sell or subject to slavery" any of the residents of the Canary Islands.  He covers nothing in the Middle Ages or earlier.But about this book:  What Brett investigates  are the arguments made about international rights as discussed with regard to jus and lex.  Although many books on international law are silent on anything that happened before the Enlightenment, here is proof that Catholic scholars were arguing such ideas long before, especially in the works of Vitoria and Soto.Slavery had first been declared immoral  in the laws of the west in the 6th century, when the "Institutes of Justinian stated that slavery violated the natural law" (p 45).  Although acknowledging the practice, the laws of Justinian called slavery against the law of nature.Yet slavery persisted, especially outside of the western world, in the Islamic countries, and later, in the Americas.It was the position of Vitoria that human law, derived from social consensus, could confer rights and responsibilities.  This is similar to the later arguments of John Locke, and a break with Aquinas' arguments about jus gentium."All just human laws are derived from 'the first rule of reason'"(p 13), which St Thomas of Aquinas stated, means the natural law.  Furthermore, Aquinas argues, "any just relationship entails a relation of equality" (p 19), and must be for the good of both people involved.Vitoria wrote that men can fall into slavery if they are captured during a war yet he insists that "Christians captured in war are captives rather than slaves" (p 108).  Men could be sentenced to slavery over a crime.  A more vexing problem were the Indians in the Americas, many of whom had been forced into slavery.  The Council of the Indies was written to protect Indians from this sort of abuse.Aristotle had argued that some men were by nature slaves.  Vitoria's "answer is to deny that any are inherently slaves" (p 126).  In the section of De Indis he concludes with an affirmation of human rights.

Politics!  Theater!  Over the top everything!  All of it combined in Roman spectacle.Beacham unveils a Rome for his readers that was rich with the booty of conquered nations, and Roman politicians spent the wealth lavishly, even on temporary entertainments.  "Scaurus constructed ...for a few days' temporary use...theater ...had three stories, supported by three hundred and sixty columns...marble...the next glass...the top was fashioned from gilded boards" (p 33).  Glass?You could be born into the elite, in this status conscious era, or you could claw and buy your way to the top, especially in electoral campaigns,  where voters were bought by incredible entertainments as much as promises.  Status was earned by flaunting money, and "the mere display of the emblems of status and authority was enough to awed the unruly and restore peace" (p 35).Augustus, that most wily of emperors, used a wild variety of propaganda tools, including statues, triumphs, reliefs, and games to convince the populace that he was Rome, and he was victorious Rome at that.  He used pageantry and theater.  "The friezes of Augustus's altar place secular events into the eternal world of myth and interpret them to show that ...Rome legendary history...reach their fulfillment with...Augustus" (p 133).Beacham stresses how vital the theater was to Rome.  Mime (go figure) was adored in Rome.  Caligula kept his favorite mime as a friend and even consular.  Caligula kissed one mime in public, and the emperor sat transfixed, in his ordained front row seats, at the nighttime performances "for which the whole city was transformed into a festively illuminated stage set" (p 173).Sex was included in the lavish, gaudy entertainments  Nero had a raft built for his pleasure towed by "barges fashioned from gold and ivory and rowed by a crew of obliging young 'joy boys' (exoleti) chosen for their 'lascivious talents'" (p 22).  Women of "both high and low birth...were all freely available" (p 222)  as well for the orgy that followed.

Bauckham offers splendid insights, insights that you will ponder for a long time,  in this collection of essays on John's Gospel.My favorite essay was the last, "The Johannine Jesus and the Synoptic Jesus".  The four Gospels had a  "diversity...was already a problem to which Papias of Hierapolis, at the beginning of the second century, was responding, and certainly it was a perceived problem by the end of the second century" (p  185).  Marcion tried reducing the gospels to one; the church fathers furiously brought up apostolic witness, attested to by individual apostolic churches and bishops in an unbroken line.By the 19th century, the differences between John and the Synoptics was brought up  by "Liberal scholars (who found)  the Fourth Gospel's portrayal  of Jesus the least palatable" (p 186), which is putting it mildly.  Some insisted it was so different that clearly it had been written around 200.  What usually happened with these scholars was that the gospels were stripped off all that was distinctive, and the Jesus they found was markedly  reduced, a Jesus who was much less than the Jesus of the gospels.John is selective, according to Bauckham, deliberately omitting  many of the incidents relayed in the Synoptics, and he makes a point of noting that many more miracles were performed by Jesus than John chose to tell.  Bauckham argues "only by reducing the 'literal' story to key moments and indispensable sequences  - albeit told in relatively lavish detail - has John allowed himself space to expound the 'symbolic' meaning of it all" (p 201) especially taken with the interrelatedness of the other gospels.In "Dualisms" Bauckham reinters Bultmann, and Bultmann's "reconstruction of the Gnostic myth of the Revealer and the claim that this Gospel owes its distinctive character to its dependence on this myths" (p 114).  All pretty much sniggered at today.  Similarly,  Bultmann's Heideggerian analysis has ceased to have impact.  (Okay, picture vast rolling of eyes here) .  In sum, Bultmann ideas have not fared well with time.For that matter, the stunning finds at Qumran have overturned the claims of Liberal scholars that John must have been influenced by Gnostics, (Liberal scholars failed to note that Gnostics were mysteriously unmentioned by the early Christians  for another 40-50 years).Bauckham argues "that the resemblances can be explained as independent developments...The theological significance of the (light/dark) imagery...can be better explained from other sources" (p 117) rather than a direct influence by Qumran.  Bauckham concludes "that soteriology is the central concern in the Gospel's prominent use of dualisms" (pp 128-9).  And this is a simply wonderful line by Bauckham: "Light dispels darkness, requiring decision, while the world that rejects Jesus is conquered and saved by him through its rejection of him" (p 129).John is notable for the emphasis he places on individualism.  In the essay "Individualism"  Bauckham points to 'aphoristic sayings about the individual's relationship with Jesus" (p 4) in an ancient society that emphasized the collective nature of society, rather than the person.  Various scholars have attempted "to find parallels to this Johannine language in Philo...or even Ignatius" (p 12), but in fact the language is unique to John.Yet John also underlines 'oneness',  The Father and Son are one (hen) Jesus says in John 10:30, a statement which "could not fail to recall the Shema for any Jewish hearer" (p 32).  Christian is urged to become part of the love between the Father and the Son.

Morton paints the young Duke as  a petulant narcissist, irked by  the chores required of a future king.  As a young adult, although he set female hearts fluttering, his family was deeply unhappy about his heavy drinking, his mistresses, and the racy set he partied with, a group increasingly pro German in the 1930s.Then he met the future Duchess. a woman who was very much married.  In one year alone, the king lavished the modern equivalent of 11 million dollars in gifts of jewelry to the always acquisitive Duchess.  This was a woman who was not only cheating on her husband, but she may have had an affair with von Ribbentrop.  Gossip suggested he sent her 17 carnations every day as a sign of the 17 times they had  gone to bed together.  And there may even have been another young man she was showering gifts upon.The king  ended up giving up the throne for this woman.  After the abdication, and a few years before the start of the war, the now  Duke and Duchess made a triumphant tour through Germany, ending with a meeting with Hitler himself.  This in itself was not too awful - the nations were not at war, and the former king apparently longed to live in the spotlight again, with all those cheering crowds.But later, were the Duke and Duchess traitors?That's the crux of the book.  Before the US entered the war, before Pearl Harbor, when Germany was bombing the heck out of London, there was a period when people fled  the war in France.  The Duke and Duchess ended up first in Spain, and then in Portugal.  It was during this time that the former king of Great Britain flirted with ideas from German agents that he could ascend the throne again, following a peace agreement between the two countries.

Anyone familiar with biblical scholars will have heard of Emanuel Tov, perhaps the most respected scholar  writing about the Old Testament today."Textual Criticism" is a large book - almost 500 pages - but it is chock full of charts, and something really fascinating to anyone interested in the history of the bible: actual photographs of the ancient texts.  Really, this is an invaluable guide for anyone interested in the subject.  It is less a book that you would read straight through than a collection of essays giving information on the state of our knowledge on the Old Testament.The state of our knowledge about the Old Testament is much more fragmentary and more controversial than that of the New Testament.  Much has been revolutionized, however, since the finding of the Dead Sea scrolls.  One interesting argument:  Tov notes that it takes time for a all the old ideas to be swept away in light of the new finds.  It may well be decades, or longer, before a new consensus is reached.Tov points out that "Interest in the text of Scripture began in the first centuries CE when learned church fathers compared the text of Jewish Scripture to the Greek version" (p 19) but the truly critical scrutiny began in the 17th century.

Christianity revolutionized the treatment of children in the ancient world.  Perhaps the most spectacular alteration was in the use of children as sexual playthings.  Both ancient Greece and ancient Rome regarded using little boys, especially slaves, or the children of the poor, as objects of desire.A slave had no rights over his body, and it was regarded as legal and not immoral in the least to use the slave sexually.  Both little boys and little girls were used sexually, although it appears little boys were preferred.  The boys were considered of interest sexually until they sprouted body hair, which gives some idea of the age of the children abused.  After the master had used the slave, the slave could also obtain money for his master by being sent to one of the many boy brothels in Rome.  (Pick up a copy of "The Economy of Prostitution in Rome" for a fuller treatment).Christianity, of course, viewed this as utterly immoral.  Many Christians wrote scathing denunciations of such practices, such as Tatian, who pointed out that,  at least in this matter, the barbarians, whose cultures despised  such things,  were more moral.  Tatian bitterly criticized "the Romans...for gathering herds of boys for this purpose" (p 230).In the  area of protecting children "from sexual advances...may be the one area of morality in which early Christianity was truly counter-cultural" (p 231).The ancient world, including the Second Temple Jews, regarded a girl as ready for marriage between the ages of 12 to 14.  Boys, on the other hand, appear to have been older at the age of marriage, perhaps in the late teens or early twenties.  This seems to have held true across all the cultures in the Roman empire.Where Jewish and later Christians differed from the other cultures was the importance they placed on the child.  "In significant strands of Judaism, the family is based upon the child" (p 72).  Because every child had an immortal soul, Christians  taught their children early the truths of Christianity and brought them to Christian gatherings to participate.  "The process of socializing children into the Christian Church was closely related to the quality and extent of the religious education and formation the children received" (p 271).They also strove to keep their children from the immoral influences all around them.  John Chrysostrom insisted young men should be kept away from the theater, for example, since ''the sight of naked women uttering shameful words'" (p 157) should be avoided.  Chrysostrom urged boys to fast on Wednesdays and Fridays, pray, and to be taught to fear hell.Children had toys and games similar to many today.  One I had never heard of was tying a rattle around the neck of a baby.  Every time the baby moved, the rattle would jingle and amuse the child.  Tops, hoops, balls, and dolls were all available, although many of the dolls appear to be based on pagan gods, and therefore were likely unused by Christian children.I would also strongly recommend the book "When Children Became People", which also deals with the changes Christianity brought to the ancient world for children.

Christians will be deeply hurt by this book.  Chopra has written a number of books mocking or denigrating Christianity, and I am sorry to say this is yet another one.Here's  the enlightened Chopra sneering at  Christians:  "The church needed a scare tactic to keep the sheep in line"  (p 253) and "The decline of faith in our time indicates that obedience is out of fashion" (p 262).And here is the loving, kindly, enlightened Chopra on what we should do with the Christian God: "Kill God.  Yes, maybe that's a good idea" (p 141 )  and "Now we have something to believe in together.  Let's kill God.  I'm ready." (p 141).Chopra  apparently hates Jesus Christ with a shivering, feverish loathing.  "'I hated the God that kids are brainwashed into loving and worshiping.  That God is a fraud, a cheat.  He doesn't exist'" (p 143).  Not that he offers any proof.  But in order to join his mystery school and be  someone Chopra approves of, you have to "push the church out of the way" (p 127).Chopra's book insultingly calls St John "an idiot and a fanatic....But his side won...The crazies came up with a bizarre myth" (pp 253-4).  This is deeply wounding to Christians, and so cruel.Another indirect slam against Christ is his frequently repeated, "Everything is a miracle or nothing is", which simply makes no sense.  Sure, a baby and a rose can be called miracles, but when Christ rose from the dead after three days that was a miracle in a very true, very gritty sense than Chopra certainly can't duplicate.  He can't even duplicate the smaller but real miracles that still occur, like the ones at Lourdes where an organ that has been removed miraculously reappears, or the miracle of the sun dancing at Fatima, seen by 70,000 people.Christians will also be hurt by his distortions about their faith.  "No word is more important in the New Testament than 'light'" (p 265), he insists.  Which is simply not true.  What about the word God, Chopra?  Oh, wait.  Chopra wants to see God destroyed, but he approves of a vague inner 'light' that the chosen among us possess.This light isn't the Christian God, and certainly isn't absolute truth, so the followers Chopra expects in his mystery schools won't have to bother about any of  that pesky stuff about right and wrong.  Forget having to do anything, especially anything unpleasant, and instead concentrate on  finding out how to "see your true self" (p 271) because everything is all about me, me, me.  I cringed at Chopra's advice, which seemed aimed at growing  vanity.  The mystery school followers of Chopra need to  "see ourselves as pure light" (p 272), he soothingly assures his preening audience.  If Chopra is pure light, how can he call Christians "crazies"?"True belief rests on personal experience" (p 273) he pontificates.  If you wonder if you are special enough to join the mystery school, you will find proof if "The forces of nature support you".  Yes, he really wrote that.  What, palm trees bow down to you?  Flower petals scatter themselves under your feet?  Also,"You experience the timeless...You feel in control....You feel free... Your choices expand...You feel a sense of acceptance that makes blame and guilt pointless" (pp273-4).  I am shocked, shocked to learn  Chopra has done away with guilt.Besides, Chopra grousingly points out, "Jesus'... teachings are impossible, from loving your neighbor as yourself to turning the other cheek" (p 272).  Funny thing then about  Mother Teresa of Calcutta and Father Damian of Molokai, not to mention the kindly couple down the street who take in foster children out of the kindness of their hearts.Chopra tells his followers "You are an unbounded field of infinite possibilities.  You are infinite consciousness manifesting in space-time" (p 267) but even though you are infinite consciousness and staggeringly wonderful it's just too, too hard to try to turn the other cheek and love your neighbor as yourself.Practically foaming at the mouth at the mere mention of Christianity and God - the man really needs to learn not to be such a hating hater -  Chopra invents for his book a  13th disciple who knew the  real truth about  Jesus.  Which, Chopra insists,  had nothing to do with Jesus Christ, or Christianity, or  anything else that  Chopra hates.So what's left, after shoving Christianity to the trash bin?  Chopra, that's what!  Chopra, who has grown extremely wealthy by being  guru to such light filled members of society as Kim Kardashian and Michael Jackson.  Chopra called Michael 'the most spiritual person with whom he has ever worked' .  I am not making any of this up.The spirituality Chopra's pushing is New Age, blended with a dash  of old time Gnosticism and Hinduism.  Chopra shucks off  Gnostic condemnation of flesh, women, and life on earth, just as he ignores the the predetermination and the fatalistic cycles of Hinduism or any suggestion that you might reincarnate as a worm.  Instead, he's writing to narcissists who know, deep within their wonderful inner selves, that they themselves are God.  Well, god, maybe.Really.  I am not making this up.

This is a two volume work, first published in 1878 by a Catholic priest, Father Thebaud, who gathered together every single scrap of evidence about  church history, the lives of the apostles, and the trajectory of Christianity throughout the Roman empire.  Each volume is about 500 pages in the set I have.  That's the good news.  Now, here's the bad news:  there is no index.Thebaud wrote in the leisurely, personal style of late Victorian era rather than like a modern biblical scholar.  He dismisses  Baur's arguments  with a sniff: "These arguments suppose that the apostles were only ambitious knaves, we may as well pass them over, as beneath the notice of a Christian" (p 342 Vol 2).  Not an argument I've ever seen before, although I loved it.  Or, regarding the authorship of Daniel: "Catholic exegetists have...vindicated successfully the authorship"  (p 129 Vol 1) - but, alas,  not  today.So, yes, it was fun to read this.  I found  Vol. 1 less useful than Vol. 2.Thebaud must have visited Pompeii because here is what he has to say about it:  "It must be said without fear of contradiction that any one who...looks...at these proofs of beastliness on the part of Pompeians, cannot conceive how a 'refined' people could possibly place this mass of moral slop under the eyes not only of their friends and visitors, but particularly of their wives and daughter...and proves that the apostles of Christ had an immense task before them when they undertook the reformation of the world" (p 235 Vol 1).  Imagine what Father Thebaud would have to say about internet porn.He strongly rejects the arguments then current by the Tubingen school on a split between Paul and Peter.  "The Church of Jerusalem seems to have been composed of all elements...We see here no well-marked sign of a strict Hebrew community" (p 245 Vol 1).  Thebaud argues both were right, and there is no proof of such a split.Anyone familiar with the argument, usually made by atheists, that the Stoics were perfectly moral, long before Christ, will relish this line by Thebaud: "The Stoic philosophy did not prevent Trajan from being a monster of lust, Marcus Aurelius from being a fierce persecutor of virtuous Christians, and...Seneca from hankering all his life after wealth" (p 355 Vol 1).He had some interesting information on how Christians altered ancient society with monasteries.  The monastery of Pachomius required "two large boats...for sending manufactured goods to market" (p 389 Vol 1).  He points out the evidence, not only of industry, but of the absence of any information about pagan worship.  "The former deities appear to have been already unknown" (p 391) Vol 1) by the era of the monasteries.Father Thebaud argues that Christianity spread quickly, and was fiercely persecuted.  He points to the 'immense multitude' slaughtered by Nero and that Pliny complained that the pagan shrines were now deserted, in about 110 AD.  Ignatius of Antioch mentioned "bishops, established in the whole universe" and soon after Tertullian wrote "We are but of yesterday, and we have filled every place among you—cities, islands, fortresses, towns, market-places, the very camp, tribes, companies, palace, senate, forum,—we have left nothing to you but the temples of your gods."Origen pointed out that "'The Christian churches, compared with the popular assemblies in the same cities...shine like stars...the first is peaceful and well ordered....the second is full of turbulence'" (pp 286-7 Vol 2).  Another proof Thebaud  found of the spread of Christianity is the reaction of the ancient world to Constantine.  "None of the decrees of this emperor in favor of the new religion....met with any opposition" (p 280 Vol 2).  Paganism disappeared surprisingly quickly, whereas everywhere there is evidence of the growth of Christianity.Another proof of the growth of Christianity is the number of bishops by the second century, and the councils that began to meet.  Long before Constantine, there  were 'three successive meetings of bishops held at Antioch"  (p 290 Vol2), one of which had 70 bishops present to condemn the heresies of Paul of Samosata.  In 256, a council was called at Iconium.Christian schools were formed during the second century.  Origen taught at one, and the schools at Caesarea became almost as famous as the ones in Alexandria.
