Yancey pulls together research  that  proves how much hostility there is against Christians.  This hostility, bordering on hatred,  is especially found in the chattering classes and the cultural progressives.  Although this is a short book, Yancey presents research study finding after another research study, all showing that Christians have become the Other for a large segment of the American public.For example, when asked if they would rather have a politically vocal Republican as a neighbor, or an apolitical Christian, a staggering 49.3 showed greater antipathy for  Christians.  Hostility was highest among the well educated and wealthy.  And I am shocked, shocked to reveal that "The traditional values promoted by Christians can be seen as interfering with the rights of others to practice...progressive sexual freedoms" (p 55).  Gosh, could there be a connection between that and their hatred?To go by the studies, many cultural progressives have dehumanized Christians, finding in them the Other.  "Those with anti-Christian perspectives perceive themselves as enjoying an enlightenment that has eluded conservative Christians" (p 64).  Cultural progressives denounce, above all things, judging other people, and they judge Christians to be  - and these are the very words found in research -  superstitious, ignorant, irrational bigots desiring of forcing a theocracy upon them, and above all they see them as intolerant.Because none of them has ever heard of logic.  Or irony.Yancey points out that "Previous research has documented the existence of intolerance and bias among progressives" (p 86), and his new research, mostly from Pew, only underlines the problem.This is a very troubling book.

This is a thriller that breaks all the boundaries.  It's not just a simple police procedural.  Nor is it just a horror novel.  Nor is it only a penetrating gaze into the darkness within each of us.  It's all of these things, and, amazingly, Klavan makes it work brilliantly.It starts off at a breakneck speed, with two  famous police detectives  inspecting a slaughter house -  the bloody bodies of five people strewn across a room.  A drug deal gone bad?  One small child was left alive, hidden behind a secret panel that concealed a vast stash of money.  The terrified little boy didn't see what took place, but he recalls the killers saying a mysterious two words.Zach, a police detective,  sets out to discover the meaning of the words, and it's like pulling at a thread until it unravels the sweater.  He's soon off to Germany, and hot on the trail of Stumpf's Baselard, a dagger from the 15th century that's been missing since that era.This is a fun page turner.  Highly recommended.

Alas, a lot.First, there is the attack on reality: "the universe is the merest illusion" (p 14). Yet if everything we see and know is an illusion, please explain why a train smashing into a person causes damage or death, every single time.He claims "Waking is long and a dream short; other than this there is no difference" (p 39). No difference between being alert and awake and sleeping? Yet all I am is consciousness. Was I given a mind that reasons only to deny its capacity for judgment and instead try to empty my mind of everything, which is what Marharshi advises?Maharshi's pantheism insists I don't exist. My mind and body are illusions. And the very best, the highest thing that can happen to the illusion-that-is-me is that I should once and forever truly die, and whatever history and thought and feeling that was once me be utterly extinguished within the universal entity.It is difficult to see how this is different from the cold fact of death itself. A classic nontheist definition of death would be that I cease to exist utterly, my consciousness is gone, and what is left even of my body will be gradually subsumed into earth and worms.Contrast this with Christianity, which insists each one of us has infinite value. And that we will all continue to exist forever, long after the earth itself has vanished. And what's more, that we will exist not as an amorphous speck in a sea of amorphous specks, but will exist with all that makes us unique, including all our consciousness and memories. Christianity insists we are, each one of us, valuable.Christianity led to the belief in human rights. If all people have immortal souls, and were created by a loving God, in whose eyes we are all equal, we must treat everyone with respect.According to the Global Slavery Index published in 2014, the nation with the greatest number of slaves today is India. India tops the ranking by far with a total of 14 million slaves. May I repeat that? Fourteen million slaves.Here's Christianity: in 1434 Pope Eugene IV declared all Catholics who owned a slave excommunicated.Whereas Maharshi says "Karma...is its cause" and "Karma alone is responsible" (p 59), and again and again blames Karma for what happened. A belief in predestination and fate has crippled India for thousands of years. Millions have suffered from the heartless caste system, especially those in the lowest castes, such as the Dalits.Mother Teresa helped the poorest of the poor because India didn't. In the past few decades, Brahmins have rioted to protest any improvement in the lives of the Dalits. The Brahmins explained that the Dalits had earned their fate by a past life, so let them suffer. This sounds like a monstrous cruelty to me.Pantheism could be used to argue against human rights, as in the case of the Brahmins who rioted. It could be used to extend human rights to cows and chimps.In 2008, Hindu mobs in Orissa attacked and killed between 75 to 123 Christians, close to 5,000 houses were destroyed and at least 264 churches and prayer halls were desecrated and demolished. Today, according to testimony by Alliance Defending Freedom given before the US House of Representatives, Christians are being persecuted, sexually assaulted and attacked by mobs in India. These crimes are going unpunished.What has pantheism given to the world? One out of every three charities in this world is run by Christians. And even in India, it's the Christians who care for the lepers.Maharshi urges me to "overcome infatuation for the body and for wife and children" (p 169) and he scorns "gross objects of pleasure such as garlands, sandal paste, women" (p 169).Speaking as a woman and a mother, I find this insulting. I also find it insulting that in Hinduism merely being born a woman is considered a punishment. Hasn't one cost of pantheism been the harm it has brought to the lives of Indian women? How many women were burned to death in suttee? How many female infants have been exposed or fed dry hulls to kill them?Maharshi refers frequently to Hindu gods. But for the most part, the Hindu gods, just like the pagan Greek and Roman gods, were amoral, petty, vain, and occasionally murderous. Dwelling on their stories would never lead anyone to a moral life. Kali with her chain of human heads can be argued to be the background to the savage Thuggee cult that killed so many people.In fact, what bothers most people who study Hinduism is the absence of morality.If my Karma has fated me to kill or steal, how am I to blame? And since the pantheistic entity fates both good and evil, exactly why is stealing and murder wrong? There are no ten commandments in Hinduism, no belief in absolute evil or good.The pantheistic entity fated the Nazis to push 6 million Jews into the ovens to die. The pantheistic entity fated the Communists to slaughter 100 million human beings in the 20th century.Another tragic consequence of pantheism is indifference. If the world is an illusion why should anyone care about consequences? Pol Pot ordering that everyone over fifteen be shot to death is of no more moral weight than eating an apple.Maharshi scorns what he calls "worldly knowledge"(p 137). This is the standard Hindu dismissal of knowledge, science, and pretty much everything that's made this century better than the year 100 BC.It is the reverse of Christianity. Christianity gave birth to the university system and real science grew out of the Christian Middle Ages. Pick up a copy of The Genesis of Science: How the Christian Middle Ages Launched the Scientific Revolution by James Hannamick for an explanation.Comment Comment | Permalink

It was once axiomatic among western intellectuals that China would never embrace Christianity.  Centuries of missionaries had failed.  The only converts were 'rice Christians', those "cynical souls who had frequented the missions for the benefits they provided" (p 1).  And then came communism, and the suppression of any religion.  The few Chinese who clung to Christianity were martyred, set to prison, or persecuted. With such a background, it seemed impossible to imagine an explosion of belief.  But that is exactly what has happened.Estimates of the number of Christians in China today vary widely, from  16 million to 200 million. Some westerners have argued  China has been struck by a kind of religious fervor, and all sorts of beliefs  growing among the uneducated rural poor.  This idea was solidly debunked by statistics found by Stark and Wang, whose research clearly showed no difference at all between urban and rural belief patterns.  In fact, Christianity was growing most in the educated elite, and it was spread through family contact as well as friends.  Still, how many Chinese Christians are there?  Stark and Wang set out to discover reliable statistics on Christianity in China, and would they found is astonishing.First off, it is important to note that many Chinese people practice a folk religion, which is based on ancestral worship with some Confucianism and Buddhism thrown in, and yet will nevertheless say that they don't practice a religion.  For the Chinese, religion means an organized religion.  Even a large number of Chinese  who "believe in Jesus Christ... (deny) that they are Christians"  (p 5), since they  aren't currently  members of any particular  congregation.  Getting exact statistics under such conditions has proven very difficult.Christianity began in China with Catholic missionaries who arrived in the 1500s.  By 1724 "the emperor outlawed Christianity"...and in 1814 another emperor  proclaimed "those spreading the gospel 'shall be sentenced to death'" (p 13).  Protestant missionaries began entering China in the 1800s.  It was the Catholic church, however, that sustained the brunt of persecution, even later under the communists, "because the Catholic church acknowledges the pope's authority" (p 14), and perhaps also because "in China overall, Catholics outnumbered Protestants by three to one" (p 26).Chinese resentment of European activities led to the Boxer rebellion, and the murder of 30,000 Chinese Christians, as well as priests, nuns, and Protestant missionaries, as well as 53 children of the Protestant missionaries.  Furthermore, vast  cultural changes in the west had occurred.  "Protestant...elite seminaries were dominated by theologians who...rejected most traditional Christian doctrines as outmoded from the standpoint of of modern science and knowledge" (p 32) and were uncomfortable with missionary activity.Then came Mao and the communists.  In 1966 Mao began the decade of the brutal cultural revolution, which attacked anything foreign.  "Ironically, the persecution of Protestants may have been the single most beneficial event for the success of Christianity" (p 43-44), turning the movement into one that had become entirely Chinese.  "The continuing growth of Christianity in China during the years of the Cultural Revolution was truly an underground activity" (p p 50) which spread from person to person and through family contacts.Meanwhile, Catholics were severely persecuted.  About 4,000 schools were Catholic, and all were closed, as well as hospitals and orphanages and printing presses.  Many priests and bishops were killed.  "By 1954 three hundred Chinese priests were in prison...and then...there was a mass arrest of more than two hundred clergy" (p 53) and Catholics.One interesting fact noted is that persecution has had an immense impact on the growth of Christianity in China, but only among the most traditional forms of Christianity.  Protestants "are almost uniformly members of extremely conservative and intense congregations.  Why?  ...Lukewarm liberalism simply could not generate the level of commitment needed to hold onto one"s faith in the fact of considerable personal risk" (p 72).Another surprise is that among the Chinese, it is the more educated who are interested in Christianity.  It is on Chinese college campuses that one hears the argument that "'we have realized that the heart of your culture is your religion: Christianity.  That is why the West is so powerful.  the Christian moral foundation...was what made possible the emergence of capitalism and then...democratic politics'" (p 82).Stark and Wang conclude that by 2007 there were some 60 million Christians in China, which was equal to the number of people who were members of the communist party.  If this rate of growth continues for the next fifteen years "there will be 294.6 million Chinese Christians" (p 114) by only 2030.

This book by  Jeremias  is famous and has proved  influential for decades.  Really, this is  the place to start when investigating early Christianity and the Eucharist.The book was first published in English in 1955, and it is utterly exhaustive.  Jeremias argues persuasively  that the words spoken by Jesus were reliably conveyed to the early church and reported faithfully by Paul and the gospel writers.There had been types of Eucharist in Judaism, but the Eucharist begun by Christ was not merely a Passover meal, and would be memorialized constantly by the early Christians, not only at Passover, and not only in a small  family group, but by a new kind of family - those who accepted Christ.Although earlier scholars had argued against the Eucharist being a memorial, Jeremias digs into the Old Testament to locate numerous earlier memorials.  For example, the cereal offering of Lev. 2.2 is a memorial.  Also the shewbread is a clear memorial and obvious type of the Eucharist.  He finds that the 'fruit of the vine' does refer back to the first cup of Passover."Already in the first century AD we can trace the eschatological interpretation of the unleavened bread; on it God had miraculously fed Israel during their journey through the desert...It is no accident that in the New Testament the unleavened loaves are also eschatologically interpreted: (p 59). For Second Temple Jews  "wine was drunk at festive occasions...when entertaining guests...family celebrations...circumcisions...marriage" (p 50).Jeremias tackled the greatest objection many scholars have to the reliability of the transmission of the Eucharist to early Christians, that of John's gospel.  He points out that "The fact that John depicts here the same meal as that described in Mark...is shown by the betrayal scene...as well as by the ensuing walk to Gethsemane.  Some of the remarks made by John presuppose that this was a passover meal...the Last Supper was held at an unusual hour....Jesus celebrated this meal with the closest circle of his disciples....a ceremonial meal...reclining at table"  (p 81).The information about the Eucharist has been conveyed reliably can also be seen in "I Cor 11:23-25 Paul...quotes the words: 'For I received of the Lord what I also delivered to you...'to receive'...'to deliver' ..represent the rabbinical technical terms kibbel min and masar le....the chain of tradition goes back unbroken to Jesus himself: (p 101).Proof of the fact that the early Christians believed the Eucharist to be sacred can be found in Hippolytus of Rome when he wrote about the Eucharist "'He shall not tell this to any but the faithful'" (p 136).  More proof:  "an enigmatic manner of speaking about the Lord's Supper to the Acts of the Apostles (pseudonyms for the Eucharist), to Hebrews (reservation of Eucharistic teaching to the 'mature'), to the Didache (silence about Eucharistic procedure), then to the shorter text of Luke (limitation to the first words of the formula), and to the symbolic representation of the Eucharist in the Abercius inscription, and finally top the secrecy imposed upon the whole baptismal and Eucharistic procedure by Hippolytus" (p 136).One book you must have in your library.

Merdinger's book is crisply written, and always interesting.  Although her viewpoint is Protestant, I found her quite evenhanded.With the arrival of Constantine, it appeared  the  persecutions had finally stopped.  But that certainly didn't mean Christianity could expect five minutes of peace.  Oh no.  Instead, heresies, schisms and problem clergy spouted up like weeds.  Theological questions vexed bishops, who in turn vexed Rome with solving them.  In  North Africa  the most pressing question at first was what should be done with the  traditors (those who had handed over sacred scripture under the threat of persecution).Augustine spent 40 years fighting  unceasingly against an unending flood of heresies - Manicheans, Novatians, Donatists, Arians, and Pelagians.  Above all, like Cyprian, Augustine strove for unity in the church, but never by accepting or pasting over differences.  He attended synod after synod,  ruled on ecclesiastical conundrums,  visited Rome time and again to discuss problem clergy and theological matters, and, let us not forget, led a monastery.  Oh, and did I forget to mention his writing?Augustine lived in one of of the most vital parts of the empire, with  Hippo a flourishing seaport.  "Africa was the breadbasket of the West; if the flow of grain and oil were impeded because of civil tumult, famine would stalk the streets of Rome" (p 18).  After 410, when Rome was sacked, refugees streamed into the area, hoping for sanctuary from the chaos that was Rome.I especially enjoyed Merdinger's  description of the problems Augustine had with clergy.  In an area that was once firmly in the Donatist clutches, it was difficult to find well versed, solidly trained  Catholic priests to oversee areas.  That is the explanation for Apiarius, who turned out to be a disaster  as clergy, a man who defrauded his flock shamelessly.

Here's the problem:  "Study after study...indicates conclusively that no other family structure produces such consistently positive outcomes as the married couple" (p 117).What will be the consequences now that  a majority of women under 30 are not married to their father of their children? Yes, a majority.Yet we've spent the last 50 years tossing marriage out the window.  The social repercussions are terrifying. It's causing a growing class divide, with the children raised by their married genetic parents going to and graduating from college, and forming an elite, prosperous class. The bottom half of the divide are the marriage losers: women who never married or who are divorced. Their children, especially the boys, research shows, are losers in life.They grow up in chaotic households. They do poorly in school, and drop out too frequently. They have emotional problems, which, tragically, continue throughout their lives. They suffer in greatly disproportional numbers from drug abuse, alcohol abuse, promiscuity, lack of motivation, and failure in school and later in the job market. They commit suicide in far greater numbers than the happy upper class children of married parents. Over 80% of our prison population comes from this class. And, in catastrophic numbers compared to the era before 1950. they suffer more from being sexually and physically and emotionally abused.The lower class has swallowed the enticing bait of what Crouse calls "the individualistic conception of marriage...marriage has gone from a  sacred covenant with a legally binding contract...to a 'contract' that is more easily terminated...than most other contracts" (p 7).Irregardless of the cause, what can be done to help single mothers and to aid their children? We have fifty years of research suggesting very little helps. As Crouse points out "We have spent more than $10,000 per child in the nation's public school programs (more than some top-quality privater schools and we continue to spend 7.4 percent of the Gross Domestic Product to education the nation's children (p 146). Huge, massively funded government programs like Head Start have produced little, if any, positive results.If we can't figure out a way to halt the trajectory that the majority of these children are on, what will this mean for our future?  And what does it mean for these children?Nor is marriage evaporating before our eyes in only  America.  Fewer and fewer people are marrying in Europe, while divorce and single parenthood have soared.Europe and Asia have a new class of people those who embrace voluntary childlessness.  Europe’s most rapidly growing family type is the one-person household.  In Denmark the number of single person households exceeds 45%.  That's practically half the population.  Living alone.Childlessness is on the rise in Asian nations as well, especially in Japan,  South Korea and  Singapore, and even China.We have veered onto an unknown path, without a map to guide us.  No way to tell what the future will be.

Honestly, I think this is better than WEN, mostly because it's cheaper, not as strong of a smell, and it's still got a lightweight texture that isn't overly conditioning. So I buy low fat chicken and add it to this, sometimes with some fat free yogurt, fat free cottage cheese, or pumpkin.  This has been a great life saver for us because I can know what's in it but also change it up a little bit so it's not the same thing all the time.  He likes to eat it too.

The title of this listing says CLEAR.  It is actually TRANSLUCENT and by that I mean that this is frosted plastic.The sticker actually on the plastic item even says "Transparent".  Transparent means clear, which this item is NOT.  Translucent means a little light passes through, like frosted glass, which is how this item should be labeled on the listing AND the object itself.  Obviously this company doesn't know the difference and this listing reflects that.I'm returning this item because i can't use it.

Adorable!  I like clings that are cute, but not too cartoon-ish.  These fit the bill.  I mixed these with some pure white glitter clings I found and it looked cute for the winter.  I use these clings, along with UV liquid to prevent birds from hitting my windows.  I used to get one bird hit the window per week (only one died) and clings alone didn't work, but when I "paint" these with UV liquid, the bird hits stopped.

Seems to work.  We generally had one bird hit the window each week, only one of which died.  We made little X's on the window and I can't see the residue on my front window, but I can see it a little on the back.  I think it depends on how the light hits it.  My plan is to rub this liquid onto window clings (like seasonal snowflakes or leaves) so that way the birds can see the UV, but I can see the decorations.  Seems like a good compromise for the window where I can see the film the product leaves behind.
