8:53 Mins This is a review for the OTG Hub-White, it'd be nice if the seller didn't sell several different products under the same listing but it is what it is. As for the hub, it works very well but it's extremely cheap-feeling. You can use this with both Micro-USB and USB, the USB connector flips down to expose a Micro-USB connector, something I haven't seen before. I go much more in-depth in the video and I show you what I'm talking about.Note: I received this product free of charge in exchange for my 100% honest feedback.

6:43 Mins This is a good emergency light, however the flashing-red mode is pretty dim. It would also be nice to see some specifications included with this product, as I'm unsure about how long it would retain its charge while it's not being used. Being able to have a spec for the LED type and brightness would be nice too. In the video I go much more in-depth and I show you the different modes.Note: I received this product free of charge in exchange for my honest feedback

How well this camera works (wirelessly) largely depends on your internet speed. If you have fast, reliable internet, this camera works very well. The video is in stunning quality, not something I was expecting from a camera at this price. If your internet is slow, however, there will be a large delay for both the video and the in-app controls.Anyway, included in the box are -CameraAntennaPower cableEthernet cableWall MountScrewsAnchorsManualInstallation CDPackaging -Upon opening the box, you notice that everything is very well packed in foam made custom for this product. Even if your package is abused a little in the shipping process, your camera should be just fine. The camera is in a little foam bag inside of the main foam in the box, the manual comes in a bag, the disc comes in a plastic sleeve, the Ethernet cables comes twist-tied, the screws/anchors are in a bag, the power cable comes twist tied, and the mount and antenna are loose in the foam. Pretty sure that wasn't particularly important, but I thought I'd include it.Setup -The included instruction manual is VERY easy to follow. It provides step by step information on how to set the device up, with pictures/screenshots of the software. It shows you how to set up the camera with a wired connection, and then shows you how to set it up wirelessly. By "wired" it just means that it is wired directly to your router, rather than being in a completely separate room. If you are able to, I would use this device with a wired connection to reduce the video delay. However even on a wireless connection there isn't more than a couple second delay. The manual also shows you how to set up the camera with HooToo's smartphone app. On the bottom of the camera itself is a QR code, which you may scan within the app. Scanning this automatically fills out all of the devices info (except the password) which is a really nice and easy way of doing so. Within the app you may control the camera, monitor audio, and even use your phone's mic to speak through the camera's speaker.Design -The camera can swivel just about 360 degrees, and it can tilt up or down quite a bit. This will allow you to look around a room or something using the application on your phone or your computer. The movements are relatively smooth and fluid, the camera isn't constantly jerking up or down while you are adjusting it. The included wall mount is also adjustable, so you can really point this camera just about anywhere in a room, if you plan on using it in a fixed postilion. I was very impressed by the IR night vision. I was expecting it to work, but not as well as it does. You can almost see as much as if it light, the only difference is the color. This makes this a great security camera, as it will record very well in both the light and the dark. The only downside to using this as a security camera is if your wifi goes out, you are unprotected. This camera doesn't support recording directly to an SD card; you have to stream it from another device and save it to that device. The speaker on this camera is really tiny, quiet, and not very high quality. If you wanted to tell someone something through this camera, they'd better be very close to it or they're not going to hear you. The mic however isn't bad. There was a little static, but it could pick up noises and conversations pretty well.Overall, if you have good, reliable internet this is a great camera. There are many settings that you can use to customize this to your liking. Everything you need to set the camera up is included, and the wall mount is very nice as I imagine a lot of people would like this on their wall. The night vision is really good, and the rotation possibilities of the camera make it so you can place the camera almost anywhere in a room and still be able to see where you would like to.

While this is definitely one of the least-expensive selfie sticks I have seen, after using the selfie pole for a bit I can kind of see why it's so inexpensive.One of the main problems with this selfie pole is that when you press the little built-in shutter button, it only registers on the phone about half the time. This might just be a problem with my unit specifically, but I found that I was having to repeatedly press the shutter button in order to actually take a picture.As for the overall feel of the selfie stick, you can definitely feel that it is made with pretty low end materials. It's fairly flimsy, and the grip on the handle just feels cheap. I wouldn't trust that this selfie pole would last very long, but then again, it's only $7.Overall you get what you pay for with this selfie stick. If it's just my unit that has the shutter button issue, this is a pretty good deal. If not, the selfie stick still functions, just not very well. You can determine if it's a worthwhile purchase, I personally would recommend spending a bit more for a selfie stick that works better and will last longer.Note: I received this product free of charge in exchange for my honest feedback.

This device has many features, and every feature I have tested works extremely well. This devices is marketed as a 'travel' router, which means that it should be easy to travel with. It definitely is, weighing in at just over 5 oz. The device is about as thick as 1 1/2 decks of cards, about the same length as a deck of cards, and slightly less wide than a deck of cards. The build quality is great, it seems like it could be loosely placed in a bag with no problems. There are protective covers for the WAN and USB output port, but unfortunately the SD card slot is left open all the time. My only concern would be the possibility of a thin object damaging the internals of the slot.As a media sharing hub -This device will allow you to read files from USB flash drives, external hard drives, and SD cards on virtually any iOS device, Android, or PC. I think being able to read the files from an iOS device is particularly useful, because with a PC you could just plug the flash drive in, and most Android devices have Micro-SD card slots that could be used to read files. I believe you could have multiple people connect to this device, however, and so putting a ton of movies on a Flash Drive for a car ride would allow everyone (except the driver) to watch their own movies without having to have them on the device they are using. One of the most useful features of this device is being able to take photos from your iOS device and put them onto a flash drive. Say you're on vacation and you are taking a ton of photos on your iPhone. You start running out of storage, but to alleviate this, you simply connect to a flash drive through the FileHub and transfer all of your pictures over. This is much easier than plugging your phone into a computer, and many people don't even have a computer while traveling. This of course also applies to Android devices, but with the exception of Androids without Micro-SD card slots, I don't see this being as useful as with iOS devices.As a power bank -This devices houses 6000mAh, and despite having many more features than a standard power bank, it's almost exactly the same size as several 6000mAh power banks that I own. I even have a 5400mAh power bank that is bigger than this 6000mAh one. However there is one very big con with this FileHub, and it's that the charging output is only 1A. This means extremely slow charging times for anything other than really old cell phones or very tiny devices. Most smartphones nowadays charge at 2.1A, and most tablets at 2.4A. Charging a device at 1A won't harm the device, but your device will charge significantly slower than if it were being charged at 2.1A. The FileHub also doesn't turn off once it has charged a device to 100%. Almost every power bank I own turns off automatically, but this one does not. I'm not sure if that means that extra battery is being used, but it still seems like it should turn off once it has charged a device to its full capacity.As a router -I tested this device by unplugging my router, and plugging this device in directly to my modem. Connecting was as easy as connecting to the FileHub through my phone's Wi-Fi settings, and then I was connected to the internet. Setting the FileHub up as a bridge is much more complicated, but I did not test this feature so I am unable to comment on it. While this device was connected to my modem I got about 30 feet of range out of it. Not a ton, but plenty for use in a hotel room or something similar. This device is made for travel, after all, and so 30ft is plenty. The connection remained steady, even when I put my phone to sleep. Sometimes I have a problem with my phone taking a while to connect to a Wi-Fi network after waking up from sleep mode, but I didn't have that problem with this FileHub. I see many people complain about the security of this device, but I don't see it as a huge problem. I wouldn't personally recommend doing anything with banking and such, although in reality it should be encrypted on the bank's side of things so you should still be fine.Overall, this device packs many features into one little device so it really is great for traveling. Some people may bring along a bunch of other devices in order to transfer photos from their camera to their phone or external hard drive, but with this device, you can transfer between all three of these things without having to bring a bunch of equipment. The only real con I can see to this product is the 1A charging output, but even that isn't a huge deal if you're patient.Note: I received this product free of charge in exchange for my honest feedback

While I wouldn't say these silicone wine (glasses?) are the most attractive containers to drink from, they are definitely very functional.They had a very chemical-smell to them when I first took them out of the packaging, but this was fixed after a quick run through the dishwasher.On a lot of cheaper silicone items you might see seams and extra pieces of silicone hanging off the product. This isn't the case with these wine glasses, they are very well molded and they feel like they're built to last. Even if they don't, it looks like Freshlove has a 100% money-back guarantee. I wouldn't expect anyone to have to utilize that, but it's extremely nice to know that Freshlove stands behind the quality of their products.Maybe it was just because of the initial chemical-smell, but I was totally expecting these glasses to alter the taste of whatever I was drinking from them. I'm happy to report that I didn't notice any difference in taste between drinking from these and an actual wine glass. However drinking from the silicone did feel pretty weird, and you have to be much more careful that you don't squeeze your glass while you're using it.I see camping as one of the main uses for these glasses. They are much more portable than plastic, they are nicer to drink from (unless you don't like the feel of silicone) and you really can't break them unless you're trying to. Even plastic can be broken, and so I would say these are the ultimate camping wine glasses. Any other occasion I would probably recommend plastic (if you really can't use glass) just because of how it looks, but as far as silicone wine glasses go, these ones from Freshlove are great.Note: I received this product free of charge in exchange for my honest feedback.

While these trays won't make FLAWLESS ice spheres, they can get pretty close depending on how much care you put into filling them. Using the right amount of water and making sure the water is only in the spheres and not around them should give you some pretty nice ice spheres. Unfortunately I wasn't all that careful when I filled up my tray, so the sphere had some extra ice attached to it. There were also a ton of cracks in the ice, but that's going to happen when you place the spheres in a drink anyway.Supposedly ice spheres keep drinks cold for longer than ice cubes, so there's a benefit apart from the fact that the spheres look really cool. You get two trays, so you can make 8 spheres at a time. The spheres are decent sized, you can fit about 3 in a pint glass. Three of these spheres would keep your drink cold for a very long time, and you'd still have spheres left over afterwards.These trays feel like they're built to last. I can't imagine them falling apart any time soon, but even if they do, they're backed by a lifetime guarantee. $16 for two sphere ice trays that are guaranteed to last a lifetime, pretty good if you ask me.Overall these trays are an excellent way to make ice spheres. The spheres are easy to make, they look nice, and they keep drinks cold longer than traditional ice cubes. Especially if you put a lot of effort into filling the trays up, you can make some really fancy looking beverages that will stay cold for a long time.Note: I received this product free of charge in exchange for my honest feedback.

I only used these trays for ice, unfortunately I didn't even think about using them for candy or something like that. The molds work extremely well for ice, and so I I'm sure they would work for other things just as well.When I first got these they had a pretty bad rubber smell, and I definitely wouldn't have felt comfortable making something consumable with them. However I put them in the dishwasher, and they came out clean and intact.Making ice was as simple as filling the molds with water and putting them in the freezer. Making something like candy would definitely be more difficult, but the result would also last quite a bit longer. I then took the trays out about 6 hours later, and I had a bunch of fun ice figures waiting for me. They were extremely easy to take out of the mold, I didn't have to use any hot water or anything like that. This is because of the flexible design of the trays, and while it may make transporting the not-yet-solid figures more difficult, you'll appreciate the design when it comes time to remove the solid figures.Overall, these molds are made of very high quality silicone and I'm not worried about them falling apart any time soon. I was surprised by the quality when I initially picked up the trays, and I was even more satisfied with how the ice figures turned out. These molds are a great inexpensive way to make some interesting ice, and they'd make even cooler candies or crayons.Note: I received this product free of charge in exchange for my honest feedback.

Selfie poles are made by soooooooo many companies nowadays that it's hard to really select which one is best for you. This one from Pomarks is excellent in my opinion, but there is one thing that may deter people from it, and that's the lack of a standard tripod threading. I'll get into this more in the "portability" section (I'm breaking this review up into multiple parts). I've also included a ton of photos, I hope you find them to be helpful.1) FunctionalityThis is a wireless selfie pole, which I prefer over wired ones. I find that wired ones take longer to actually take pictures, and if you press the button 5 times they may only take 2 pictures. With wired selfie poles, such as this one, not only do you not have to worry about plugging anything in, the shutter button also seems to work better. The only downside I can think of is the fact that you'll have to charge the pole every once in a while, but that's as simple as plugging in a micro-USB cable for a couple hours. To pair this selfie pole you simply hold down the shutter button until the light starts blinking. Then you go into your phone's Bluetooth settings, and the selfie pole should show up as "POMARKS". Tapping on the name should pair it, and you're good to go. When you press the shutter button, it simulates pressing the "volume up" button on iPhone. This takes a picture in the iPhone's camera app, and in Snapchat. It may not work in other photography apps, but you can test this by seeing if you can take a photo by pressing the volume button. On Android I believe it's different, but I did not use this selfie pole on an Android device.2) BuildThis selfie pole is very well built, you can tell that it's a high-quality product. The only thing is that when the selfie pole is fully extended with an iPhone 6s on the end, it bows slightly. Not enough to worry me, but it bows a little more than other selfie poles I have used. Again, I'm not super worried about it. The shutter button feels pretty good, and the handle is one of my favorite parts of this selfie pole. It's made of nice quality rubber, and there are little ridges and bumps on it for grip. There is also a wrist strap which attaches to the bottom of the pole, so even if your hand did somehow slip you should be okay.3) PortabilityMost selfie poles are made to be portable, but more recently companies have been coming out with a design that allows the "phone holder" to fold down onto the pole. This is the case with this selfie pole.This makes the selfie pole MUCH more portable, with the downside being that the phone holder is permanently attached. On some selfie poles you can simply unscrew the "phone holder", and attach something like a point-and-shoot camera or a GoPro. This isn't the case with this selfie pole, which has its pros and cons. We also get a carrying pouch for the selfie stick, which is of course great for portability and traveling. The phone holder's angle can also be adjusted, so you can choose whether or not to show the selfie pole in the shot, decrease glare, etc.Overall this is a great selfie stick, definitely up there for one of the best I have used. The only reason I wouldn't recommend it is if you wanted to be able to mount a GoPro as well as a phone, but for just mounting phones, this selfie stick is great.Note: I received this product free of charge in exchange for my honest feedback.

When buying a pair of sport headphones, there are 6 main things I consider -- Comfort- Whether or not they stay in your ears- How well they connect to your phone- Physical appearance/Build quality- Battery life- Ease of use/SoundThis headset excels in every category, with the one exception maybe being comfort.Comfort -This headset, out of the box, fits very well in my ears. There are a TON of different sizes of ear tips and such, so if out of the box these don't fit very well, I'm sure you can change some things so that they do. The fit in my ears isn't why I thought these were slightly uncomfortable, it's the loose cable that connects the ear pieces. The cable kinda flops around while you exercise, which can be pretty irritating. I would much prefer if it was a wire or a formed cable, one that doesn't move around at all and fits with your head.I've used several "sport" headsets that aren't really good for much because they don't stay in your ears. If you're buying a sport headset you're most likely going to be moving around a lot, and so whether or not the headphones stay in your ears is very important. This headset was great, the ear pieces never fell out of my ear. Rather than simply a rubber ear tip there's also a piece that rests inside your ear, kind of like a fan shaped rubber piece. Headsets that have these generally stay in your ear better, so that's something to watch out for when buying a sport headset. This headset of course has those, and it also includes several different sizes of them. I think this plays a big part in why these headphones stay in your ears so well, along with the overall design of the headset and the angle at which the rubber ear tips are positioned.Connectivity -It's not too common, but sometimes I'll use a sport headset that has about 6 inches of range. Meaning you'll have your phone in your pocket, the headset in your ears, and you'll lose connection. There are also headsets that have a super choppy connection while running, but this headset suffers from none of those problems. Connecting is easy, and the headset stays connected as long as you are within reasonable range. By reasonable I mean up to around 30 feet, much better than the 6 inches on some headsets.Physical Appearance/Build Quality -Vastar manages to pack in good sound, media controls, and good connectivity to a headset that keeps a fairly small form factor. Some wireless headsets have an in-line media remote, and I can't stand using those. Generally the cable on wireless headsets is really short, which makes the in-line remote up somewhere behind/right beside your neck. It's great that Vastar avoided these in-line controls, and instead they put the controls on the headset. This improves the overall look in my opinion, while boosting ease of use and functionality as well. As for the build quality, this is an extremely well built headset. Everything about it feels sturdy, and I feel like this headset is definitely built to last.Battery Life -Vastar advertises 6.5 hours of battery life, and while that may not seem like a bit, it can actually go a long way depending on how active you are. This headset's standby battery life is excellent, meaning it won't lose much battery at all while it is off. Say you work out for about an hour each day, you'll only have to charge this headset once a week. Of course it all depends on how much you're actually using this headset, but the 6.5 hours is pretty much of actual use and you can go many days with this headset off and not really see any decrease in its battery life.Ease of use/Sound -Connecting to this headset is incredibly simple, but that's not exactly what I'm focusing on when I look at ease of use. I'm looking at how easy it is to pull out these headphones and get them working, and then how easy it is to control media from the headset. Once these headphones are paired with your phone you simply turn them on (assuming your phone has Bluetooth enabled) and you're good to go. You can select a song, put your phone in your pocket, and you're ready. From the headset you can skip tracks, pause/play music, and adjust the volume. On some headsets the pause/play/answer calls button is on top of the headset. which is in your ear when you're actually using it. This doesn't do much good at all, so it's nice that Vastar included the main button on the side of the headset. This makes using the button very easy, so you don't have to awkwardly fiddle in your ear if you want to pause the music to talk to someone or answer a phone call. As for sound quality, this headset is pretty good. Obviously it's not GREAT, as it's a $30 headset that's sole purpose is to be used while exercising. Sound is still kept in mind on sport headsets, but you can never really expect great sound quality even compared to a wired pair of headphones for the same price. While using this headset I did notice that a lot of sound is blocked out, which is both a good and bad thing. Good is that your music arguably sounds better, you can't hear all the people around you, and you can concentrate better. Bad is that you can't really hear cars or people, so using these on outdoor runs, especially at night, might not be a good idea. The noise-isolation also causes you to kind of hear everything you do much louder, kind of like when you plug your ears. Talking sounds weird, swallowing is made louder, and your breathing has the potential to drive you insane. This takes some getting used to, and I know there are some people out there that would never really be able to get used to it. However if you are playing music it isn't that bad, just when you have the music paused or you are in-between songs.Overall I enjoy using this headset, and while there are a few flaws that I have mentioned, it's a very nice headset overall.Note: I received this product for free in exchange for my honest feedback and evaluation.Thanks for reading, I hope you found this review to be helpful.

I tested this cable with the following devices -iPad 4iPad AiriPhone 5iPhone 5CiPhone 5SiPhone 6iPhone 6SFor every single one, I get the same error message. "Accessory not supported". This cable is supposedly MFI certified, so I'm not sure why I would be getting this error message. It seems that I may have gotten a bad cable, because all of the other reviews on here are saying that the cable works great and that they would recommend it. I, however, cannot, because this cable is useless to me. Neither charging nor syncing work, and while the cable feels like it's a very nice cable, if it can't do its only job, it's not a good product.Note: I received this product free of charge in exchange for my honest feedback

Not only does this speaker look really good, it is very functional as well.Structurally, this speaker is excellent. It is incredibly well built, and it simply feels like a very high-quality product right out of the box. We have rubber covering all of the buttons, and plenty of metal and screws to add to the rugged look. This does more than just make the speaker look good; IPX5 Waterproof coating protects the speaker against splashes, mud, and dust, proving that the speaker is functionally as rugged as it looks.When you buy a speaker like this, that is, a very rugged speaker priced at under $30, I think you will care more about if you can throw it in the mud than how it sounds. It's going to be very hard to find a budget speaker that is rugged without compromising sound quality. That being said, this speaker doesn't sound terrible. I would say that it's comparable to about a $15, non-rugged speaker. The sound out of the box is pretty tinny.  Highs are somewhat sharp, but mids sound pretty good. It really depends on the song, but I've noticed that some songs sound incredible while other songs are exactly the opposite. I'm not taking a star off for sound quality, because like I said, you're most likely buying this speaker for its ability to withstand the elements, and with that comes a small sacrifice in audio quality.If for some reason you are not wanting to use this speaker via Bluetooth, you have the option of using the included aux cable. One thing to note is that while you are using this speaker in a wired connection it loses its IPX5 waterproofness. This is because you have to have a rubber flap open, and the micro-USB charging port is exposed. So while you can technically use this speaker via an aux cord, you will be sacrificing one of the best features of the speaker.Two somewhat overlooked features of this speaker are the carrying strap and the tripod socket. I'm not entirely sure when I would use the tripod socket, but I guess if you have a use for it it's a nice addition. The carrying strap, however, is extremely useful. It's made of rubber, so it will dry very quickly and continue being comfortable to hold. You can also unscrew the screw on the strap, and attach the speaker to a backpack or something similar. The strap will be very secure, so you don't have to worry about the speaker falling off. This makes it very convenient to listen to music while backpacking or something, and you don't even have to hold the speaker.Overall, this is an excellent rugged speaker for a very good price. There are definitely some sacrifices made in sound quality, but you're buying this speaker to be rugged. You won't really find an excellent sounding waterproof speaker, especially for this price.Note: I received this product free of charge in exchange for my honest feedback.

This is a great selfie stick, however I think there may be better alternatives. The only reason is because of the fact that this selfie stick's remote requires batteries. Most selfie sticks are rechargeable nowadays, and so having to replace the batteries is extremely inconvenient. However, batteries are included and they will probably last for quite a while. It's just when the remote battery dies that you will be wishing you could simply recharge it. The benefit of having batteries is that you are able to remove the remote from the Selfie Pole. This means that you could set your phone down somewhere and use the remote to take a picture. This is instead of having the remote built into the selfie pole, but I personally think a rechargeable built-in is better than a battery powered remote. It can definitely vary from person to person, you may see a huge benefit in having a detachable remote.The overall feel of this selfie pole is excellent. This one from SelfieGo has the best grip out of any selfie pole I've used, there are actual places for your fingers on the back of the handle. The entire design feels very sturdy, and you can tell that a lot of time went into the design.This selfie pole is also extremely portable. The pole itself telescopes down like every other selfie pole, but then the phone holder actually folds down onto the pole; which isn't as common. This allows the selfie pole to get quite compact, although it will be thicker than most selfie poles if you have the remote attached to the handle. No carrying case or anything is included, which is unfortunate.This selfie pole works as expected, which is of course a very good thing. You simply pair the remote to your phone via Bluetooth, and then whenever you press the button on the remote it simulates pressing the "volume up" button on your iPhone. This will take a picture in most camera apps, it definitely works in the iPhone's camera app and Snapchat. When you aren't in an app and you press the remote, your phone's volume will simply go up a notch.One of the main things I look for in selfie pole's is security. If I am trusting this device to secure my $750 phone, I want to make sure it's going to do just that. The grip on this selfie pole's handle is excellent, and there is a wrist strap. Dropping the selfie pole shouldn't be a problem, which is good. The other thing is how securely the phone is actually being held. I didn't see any problems here either, I was able to gently shake the selfie pole without my phone slipping at all.Overall this is a great selfie pole if you're looking for one with a detachable remote. It's still a great selfie pole either way, but the fact that you can't recharge this selfie pole is enough for me to recommend a different one that has a built in remote. It all depends on your use and how much you value having a detachable remote, and it's your decision in the end.Thanks for reading this review, I hope you found it helpful.Note: I received this product free of charge in exchange for my honest feedback.

This is one of the least expensive GoPro accessory kits I have seen, and it comes with almost every mount/accessory you would need for a GoPro. All of the parts seem to be of very high quality, except for the little tripod which is super cheaply made. The tripod is very hard to adjust, and minute adjustments are impossible. It's okay if you are using it as a standard tripod, but if you're trying to wrap the legs around a pole or something you may have a difficult time. The other accessories are all great, however, and you're getting a ton for the $17 price point.Note: I received this kit free of charge in exchange for my honest feedback

I’m always hesitant to try 3rd party lightning cables due to the fact that so many of them cause my iPhone 6 to display the message “accessory not supported”. This was not the case with this cable, and I was very relieved. The cable is only 1m, which may be a bit short for some people. The part around the lightning cable is also a bit large, so it may not fit with some more rugged cases. Other than these two things, this cable is arguably better than the one that Apple sells. Apple’s lightning cables tend to break after 6 months or so, but this cable from YellowKnife is braided so it should be a lot sturdier. The braiding also prevents tangling, but that’s not really a problem I’ve had with any lightning cables. As for charging/data transfer, this cable seemed to charge about the same as my Apple lightning cable. I didn’t get out a stopwatch or anything like that, but the difference wasn’t enough to make me notice and switch back to Apple’s cable. Data transfer also seemed to be about the same. Overall this is a great cable, it’s cheaper than Apple’s and I’m convinced that it’s going to last longer.

I have used a ton of third party lightning cables, and quite few of them either charge really slowly or they say “accessory not supported” with my iPhone 6. This particular cable suffers from neither of these problems, and except for the length, it looks similar to the lightning cables from Apple until you feel it. It feels like it was made with a slightly lower grade rubber and plastic, but considering it’s a fraction of the price compared to Apple’s, it makes sense. The cable is slightly less flexible than Apple's, which will probably make it last longer. There aren’t any logos or anything on the cable (like Apple’s), so it looks really nice. Functionality wise this cable is better than Apple’s, because of the extra length. Technically you’re not supposed to use your phone while it’s charging, but I’m pretty sure everyone ignores that. The extra length of this cable doesn’t seem to affect charging times and it makes the cable much less noticeable because of the extra freedom you have to move the phone around.  Overall it’s hard to go wrong with this cable, it’s similar to Apple’s (except for the additional length) and for a fraction of the price.This is a review of the Yellowknife Extra Long 10ft / 3m USB to Lightning Cable, I wish the cables were listed under separate listings so that the reviews weren't all weird.Note: I received this product free of charge in exchange for my honest feedback

Micro-USB cables are extremely common nowadays, so many devices use them for charging and data transfer. Unfortunately, a lot of Micro-USB cables that come with lower-end products end up being very cheap feeling, too short, or not working exactly as they should. This set from Eoso suffers from none of these problems, and I would consider these to be the "perfect" micro-USB cables for the majority of tasks. They are extremely well made, which is shown in how they feel. You can tell that Eoso used higher-grade materials in these cables, it's nothing like those Micro-USB cables that come with super generic selfie poles or Bluetooth speakers. Each cable is three feet long, which I think is great for most things. You may want a longer cable if your outlet is far from your nightstand and you may want a shorter one for use with portable chargers, but I think 3 feet is pretty average and so these cables suffice. As for charging/data transfer, everything is extremely fast. With buying cables on eBay or something you never know how much of a charge the cables will allow to pass through. This could result in your phone charging much slower than it should, but these cables don't have that problem. My Galaxy S6 charged as fast as it would using Samsung's cable, and I noticed no differences in data transfer rates. Overall, these are great cables, and they are very fairly priced as well. I recommend them to anyone that wants a fast, reliable Micro-USB cable that feels like it's built to last.

I'm pretty sure I own at least 25 "selfie sticks", and this one has most of the best features from every one put into one Selfie Pole. There is only one con that I have noticed - you can't actually remove the phone holder from the monopod. Theoretically you could still put a small point and shoot or a GoPro into the phone holder, but almost every other selfie pole I have seen has a feature where you can remove the phone mount and it reveals a 1/4" threading for mounting the majority of cameras. Other than this small thing, everything about this Selfie Pole is excellent.Feel -One of my favorite things about this selfie stick is how it feels. You can tell that it is made with very high quality materials, and it isn't going to break any time soon. The rubber on the handle makes gripping very easy, and simply adds to the overall feel of the selfie pole. The shutter button is perfectly located too, you don't have to strain your thumb or anything to press the shutter button. Adjusting the angle at which your phone sits is also a very pleasant process. On some other selfie poles, you try to adjust the mount and you cringe because it sounds like the screws and such inside are going to break. This isn't the case at all with this one from The Memory Journalists, everything feels extremely solid.Portability -One plus of not having a "traditional" tripod mount with a phone holder attached is that the selfie pole compacts much more easily. This is due to how the way the "phone holder" part at the top of the monopod folds down onto the handle when not in use. This creates a very compact package, making this Selfie pole ideal for traveling. When you are ready to use the pole you simply flip the holder up and you're good to go.Functionality -As for the functionality of the selfie pole itself, it's everything that you would be looking for. This selfie pole connects wirelessly to your phone, so you don't have to deal with any wires or anything like that. One possible downside is that you will have to charge the selfie pole, but it's as simple as plugging in a Micro-USB cable for a couple of hours. To pair your phone with the Selfie Pole you simply hold down on the shutter button until the LED starts blinking. It will show up in your phone's bluetooth settings, and it will be paired whenever you turn the Selfie Pole on. For iPhones at least, this selfie pole simulates pressing the "up" volume button. This is the same with every other selfie pole that I have used, and it works in both the iPhone's camera app and Snapchat. The part of this selfie pole that holds your phone is also very functional. The angle is adjustable as I have mentioned, but one of the main things to look at is how secure your phone will be while you're using this selfie stick. I've noticed that the mount grips your phone extremely well, I was able to kind of gently shake the selfie pole back and forth without my phone falling out of the mount.While I'm not really one to use a selfie pole in public, if I were to do so, I would most likely choose this one. It's probably the best-built one I own, and it has most of the features I look for in a selfie pole. If I need to mount a GoPro or something I'll have to use a different Selfie Pole, but that's the only real reason I can think of.Note: I have noticed is that this Selfie Pole is almost EXACTLY the same as ones from Mpow and The Memory Journalists, and this one is slightly less expensive.

Not only does this cable look more interesting than your standard Apple lightning cable, it's more functional too. With Apple lightning cables I find that after 6 months or so they no longer work. Different pieces of them break, Apple's lightning cables seem to be oddly cheap. This cable should solve that problem, the braided design should make the cable much more durable. The USB and lightning ends are also of much higher quality, this cable just feels like it's going to last longer. The extra length of this cable is extremely nice as well. I hadn't realized how limited I was by Apple's stock cable until I got this cable from Eoso. Technically you're not supposed to use your phone while it's charging, but I'm pretty sure everybody ignores that. The extra length of this cable will provide you with more freedom, you won't feel nearly as tethered down. The only potential problem I can see with this cable is that the area around the lightning cable is a bit large. I haven't personally had a problem with it, but people with rugged, restrictive cases may find that this cable doesn't fit into the phone while it's in a case. I have used a ton third party lightning cables, and a quite few of them either charge really slowly or they say “accessory not supported” with my iPhone 6. This particular cable suffers from neither of these problems, and both charging and transferring data was flawless.Note: I received this product free of charge in exchange for my honest feedback

When buying a pair of sport headphones, there are 6 main things I consider -- Comfort- Whether or not they stay in your ears- How well they connect to your phone- Physical appearance/Build quality- Battery life- Ease of use/SoundThis headset excels in every category, with the one exception maybe being comfort.Comfort -This headset, out of the box, fits very well in my ears. There are several different sizes of ear tips and such, so if out of the box these don't fit very well, I'm sure you can find a ear tip that does. The fit in my ears isn't why I thought these were slightly uncomfortable, it's the loose cable that connects the ear pieces. The cable kinda flops around while you exercise, which can be pretty irritating. I would much prefer if it was a wire or a formed cable, one that doesn't move around at all and fits with your head.I've used several "sport" headsets that aren't really good for much because they don't stay in your ears. If you're buying a sport headset you're most likely going to be moving around a lot, and so whether or not the headphones stay in your ears is very important. This headset was great, the ear pieces never fell out of my ear. Rather than simply a rubber ear tip there's also a piece that rests inside your ear, kind of like a fan shaped rubber piece. Headsets that have these generally stay in your ear better, so that's something to watch out for when buying a sport headset. This headset of course has those, and it also includes several different sizes of them. I think this plays a big part in why these headphones stay in your ears so well, along with the overall design of the headset and the angle at which the rubber ear tips are positioned.Connectivity -It's not too common, but sometimes I'll use a sport headset that has about 6 inches of range. Meaning you'll have your phone in your pocket, the headset in your ears, and you'll lose connection. There are also headsets that have a super choppy connection while running, but this headset suffers from none of those problems. Connecting is easy, and the headset stays connected as long as you are within reasonable range. By reasonable I mean up to around 30 feet, much better than the 6 inches on some headsets.Physical Appearance/Build Quality -Mpow manages to pack in good sound, media controls, and good connectivity to a headset that keeps a fairly small form factor. Some wireless headsets have an in-line media remote, and I can't stand using those. Generally the cable on wireless headsets is really short, which makes the in-line remote up somewhere behind/right beside your neck. It's great that Mpow avoided these in-line controls, and instead they put the controls on the headset. This improves the overall look in my opinion, while boosting ease of use and functionality as well. As for the build quality, this is an extremely well built headset. Everything about it feels sturdy, and from using Mpow's products in the past I know that this headset is definitely built to last.Battery Life -Mpow advertises 5 hours of battery life, and while that may not seem like a bit, it can actually go a long way depending on how active you are. This headset's standby battery life is excellent, meaning it won't lose much battery at all while it is off. Say you work out for an hour each day, you'll only have to charge this headset every 5 days. Of course it all depends on how much you're actually using this headset, but the 5 hours is pretty much of actual use and you can go many days with this headset off and not really see any decrease in its battery life.Ease of use/Sound -Connecting to this headset is incredibly simple, but that's not exactly what I'm focusing on when I look at ease of use. I'm looking at how easy it is to pull out these headphones and get them working, and then how easy it is to control media from the headset. Once these headphones are paired with your phone you simply turn them on (assuming your phone has Bluetooth enabled) and you're good to go. You can select a song, put your phone in your pocket, and you're good to go. From the headset you can skip tracks, pause/play music, and adjust the volume. On some headsets the pause/play/answer calls button is on top of the headset. which is in your ear when you're actually using it. This doesn't do much good at all, so it's nice that Mpow included the main button on the side of the headset. This makes using the button very easy, so you don't have to awkwardly fiddle in your ear if you want to pause the music to talk to someone or answer a phone call. As for sound quality, this headset is pretty good. Obviously it's not GREAT, as it's a $30 headset that's sole purpose is to be used while exercising. Sound is still kept in mind on sport headsets, but you can never really expect great sound quality even compared to a wired pair of headphones for the same price. While using this headset I did notice that a lot of sound is blocked out, which is both a good and bad thing. Good is that your music arguably sounds better, you can't hear all the people around you, and you can concentrate better. Bad is that you can't really hear cars or people, so using these on outdoor runs, especially at night, might not be a good idea. The noise-isolation also causes you to kind of hear everything you do much louder, kind of like when you plug your ears. Talking sounds weird, swallowing is made louder, and your breathing has the potential to drive you insane. This takes some getting used to, and I know there are some people out there that would never really be able to get used to it. However if you are playing music it isn't that bad, just when you have the music paused or you are in-between songs.Overall I enjoy using this headset, and while there are a few flaws that I have mentioned, it's a very nice headset overall.Note: I received this product for free in exchange for my honest feedback and evaluation.Thanks for reading, I hope you found this review to be helpful.

I'm pretty sure I own at least 25 "selfie sticks", and this one has most of the best features from every one put into one Selfie Pole. There is only one con that I have noticed - you can't actually remove the phone holder from the monopod. Theoretically you could still put a small point and shoot or a GoPro into the phone holder, but almost every other selfie pole I have seen has a feature where you can remove the phone mount and it reveals a 1/4" threading for mounting the majority of cameras. Other than this small thing, everything about this Selfie Pole is excellent.Feel -One of my favorite things about this selfie stick is how it feels. You can tell that it is made with very high quality materials, and it isn't going to break any time soon. The rubber on the handle makes gripping very easy, and simply adds to the overall feel of the selfie pole. The shutter button is perfectly located too, you don't have to strain your thumb or anything to press the shutter button. Adjusting the angle at which your phone sits is also a very pleasant process. On some other selfie poles, you try to adjust the mount and you cringe because it sounds like the screws and such inside are going to break. This isn't the case at all with this one from Mpow, everything feels extremely solid.Portability -One plus of not having a "traditional" tripod mount with a phone holder attached is that the selfie pole compacts much more easily. This is due to how the way the "phone holder" part at the top of the monopod folds down onto the handle when not in use. This creates a very compact package, making this Selfie pole ideal for traveling. When you are ready to use the pole you simply flip the holder up and you're good to go.Functionality -As for the functionality of the selfie pole itself, it's everything that you would be looking for. This selfie pole connects wirelessly to your phone, so you don't have to deal with any wires or anything like that. One possible downside is that you will have to charge the selfie pole, but it's as simple as plugging in a Micro-USB cable for a couple of hours. To pair your phone with the Selfie Pole you simply hold down on the shutter button until the LED starts blinking. It will show up in your phone's bluetooth settings, and it will be paired whenever you turn the Selfie Pole on. For iPhones at least, this selfie pole simulates pressing the "up" volume button. This is the same with every other selfie pole that I have used, and it works in both the iPhone's camera app and Snapchat. The part of this selfie pole that holds your phone is also very functional. The angle is adjustable as I have mentioned, but one of the main things to look at is how secure your phone will be while you're using this selfie stick. I've noticed that the mount grips your phone extremely well, I was able to kind of gently shake the selfie pole back and forth without my phone falling out of the mount.While I'm not really one to use a selfie pole in public, if I were to do so, I would most likely choose this one. It's probably the best-built one I own, and it has most of the features I look for in a selfie pole. If I need to mount a GoPro or something I'll have to use a different Selfie Pole, but that's the only real reason I can think of.Note: I have noticed that this Selfie Pole is almost EXACTLY the same as one from The Memory Journalists, and The Memory Journalists one is slightly cheaper.
